HEADLINE: U.S. Contests Europe's Ban On Some Food 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13 

 BODY:
The Bush administration filed suit today at the World Trade Organization to force Europe to lift its ban on genetically modified food, a move that was postponed earlier this year by the debate on Iraq.
 The suit will further heighten trans-Atlantic trade tensions after several recent rulings against the United States in cases brought by Europe at the W.T.O. over United States steel tariffs and tax shelters for overseas corporations. 
 The administration was backed by the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, and other senior Republican and Democratic lawmakers who have been promoting the lawsuit for months. American farmers have led the complaints, saying they have invested in the technology needed to raise genetically modified crops only to see one of the biggest markets -- Europe -- closed to their products. 
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said the administration had run out of patience waiting for the European Union to lift what he called a five-year-old moratorium that blocked several hundred million dollars of American exports into Europe. Worse, he said, European attitudes were spreading unfounded fears in the developing world, where the need is greatest for the increased yield of genetically modified crops.
"In developing countries, these crops can spell the difference between life and death," he said. "The human cost of rejecting this new technology is enormous."
Mr. Hastert estimated that American farmers lost $300 million in corn exports each year because of the European policy toward genetically modified food and animal feed.
"There's no question in my mind that the European Union's protectionist, discriminatory trade policies are costing American agriculture and our nation's economy hundreds of millions of dollars each and every year," Mr. Hastert said.
But European officials said today that they were dumbfounded by the suit. They said there was no moratorium on genetically modified food. 
"The U.S. claims that there is a so-called moratorium, but the fact is that the E.U. has authorized G.M. varieties in the past and is currently processing applications," said Pascal Lamy, the top European trade official. "So what is the real U.S. motive in bringing a case?"
In practice, the Europeans did have an informal moratorium on new varieties of genetically modified food from 1998 until last year, when the E.U. instituted a new regulatory system that has approved two applications, with others pending.
At the center of the debate over genetically modified crops, if not the suit filed today, is a growing disagreement between the United States and Europe over what steps are necessary to protect public health and the environment. 
European consumers are far more wary of genetically modified food than are Americans, and many object to what they consider aggressive American promotion of those foods, influenced by agribusiness. 
The European Union is demanding that genetically modified food be labeled as such. They also want to be able to trace the origins of the food's ingredients and are near completion of new legislation to require both.
The United States opposes such labels and tracing mechanisms, saying they are too costly and impractical.
Margot Wallstrom, the European environmental commissioner, said the European legislature would complete its measure to require labeling and methods for tracing food and animal feed that is genetically modified.
"This U.S. move is unhelpful," she said. "It can only make an already difficult debate in Europe more difficult." 
The United States agriculture secretary, Ann M. Veneman, said today that the case was aimed at protecting American farmers and ranchers. 
"With this case," she said, "we are fighting for the interests of American agriculture. This case is about playing by the rules negotiated in good faith. The European Union has failed to comply with its W.T.O. obligations." 
The United States was joined by Argentina, Canada and Egypt. Australia, Chile, Colombia, El Salvador, Honduras, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru and Uruguay expressed support as third parties without direct commercial interest.
Many of these countries are in negotiations with the United States for a free trade agreement.
Chile is waiting for the administration to sign off on its accord after a delay driven in part by disappointment that it refused to side with the United States on the war with Iraq at the United Nations.
Mr. Zoellick promised European officials last week that trade would bring the allies together after the arguments over Iraq, not further separate them. 
But trade is becoming a divisive issue, especially since the end of the war.
European officials lashed back at the administration today, refusing to be blamed for blocking genetically modified food aid and reminding the United States that it had refused to join 100 other countries and sign the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety. That agreement sets out rules for exporters and importers of genetically modified crops to provide the proper information about the food and feed.
Nonprofit groups opposed to the W.T.O.'s influence said the case showed how globalization undermined local and national governments.
"The people eating the food or living in the environment that could be affected must decide domestic policy, not some secretive W.T.O. tribunal of three trade experts," said Lori Wallach, director of Public Citizen's Global Trade Watch.
But several African farmers and scientists at a news conference here joined Mr. Zoellick and Ms. Veneman in praising the American action. 
"We believe it is better to give a person food to eat today than wait 10 years to be sure it is safe," said Darin Makinde, dean of the school of agriculture at the University of Venda in South Africa.
"Two elephants are fighting -- the United States and Europe -- and it is Africa that is suffering," he said.

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: THE DEFENSE SECRETARY; 
Cheney Tells of Meeting Rumsfeld 35 Years Ago

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13 

 BODY:
It is part of Washington lore that Donald Rumsfeld gave young Dick Cheney his start in government, hiring him as an assistant in the Nixon administration.
 But Mr. Cheney revealed today that 35 years ago, when Mr. Rumsfeld was still a congressman, he flunked his first interview with the man who would eventually become his mentor, boss and hawkish ally. 
 "It was clear that we hadn't hit it off," the vice president said of his ill-fated 15-minute meeting in Mr. Rumsfeld's Capitol Hill office in 1968. "He thought I was some kind of airhead academic, and I thought he was rather an arrogant young member of Congress."
"Probably we were both right," Mr. Cheney said deadpan, dropping a punch line that brought down the house at an awards lunch here today.
The "airhead academic" and the "arrogant young congressman," now the secretary of defense, met today on neutral turf, with Mr. Cheney presenting his old friend with a public service award from the Hudson Institute, a research and policy organization with conservative leanings.
But the gathering at a downtown Washington hotel also offered a rare public glimpse into the three-decade friendship of two of the superpowers of the Bush administration. Mr. Rumsfeld, who is 70, and Mr. Cheney, who is 62, talk frequently and socialize regularly, but most of their face-to-face dealings are at cabinet meetings behind closed doors.
Today, however, they put on a public version of what one Hudson Institute official called the "Cheney-Rumsfeld routine," a mix of mutual admiration and good-natured needling.
The two men can finish each other's sentences, if necessary, aides say. Over the years, they have found themselves in superior-subordinate roles three times. They have shared some of the same titles: congressman, White House chief of staff (Mr. Cheney took Mr. Rumsfeld's place under President Gerald R. Ford) and, of course, secretary of defense.
But it is rare to get either one of them talking about their history together, at least in public.
 Mr. Cheney said today that he came to Washington in the late 1960's as a Congressional fellow and doctoral candidate working on his dissertation with an eye on returning to a teaching job at the University of Wisconsin.
 But one day, a young Republican lawmaker from Illinois named Rumsfeld spoke to the fellows, and Mr. Cheney said he was impressed. He made an appointment to interview for a job with Mr. Rumsfeld, but the meeting was a disaster.
 "As I recall, what he was looking for was somebody with some practical experience who could help out in a Congressional office," Mr. Cheney said. "He had a requirement for a speechwriter. Now if you know Don Rumsfeld, throughout his career, he's always had a requirement for a speechwriter because he has great difficulty keeping speechwriters."
Undaunted by the setback, Mr. Cheney, then 28, went to work for another Republican, Representative William Steiger of Wisconsin. A few months later, President Nixon nominated Mr. Rumsfeld to head the Office of Economic Opportunity, and Mr. Cheney said he hatched a plan.
 "I sat down one night, unsolicited, and wrote a 12-page memo suggesting to him how he should handle himself in his confirmation hearings, giving him some sterling advice on what he ought to do with the department once he got confirmed," said Mr. Cheney, clearly relishing his retelling.
Mr. Cheney said he never received a reply but was nonetheless invited to serve on Mr. Rumsfeld's transition team after the Senate approved his nomination.
Mr. Cheney said: "Don came in, spoke to the group, left, and shortly after he'd left, his secretary came in and said, 'Is there somebody here named Mr. Cheney?' I held up my hand, and she said, 'Come with me.' Took me back into his office there at O.E.O. behind the conference room, and he was in there all by himself -- second day on the job. And he said, 'You, you're Congressional relations. Now get out of here.' "
"That's how I was hired," Mr. Cheney said to peals of laughter. "That was, of course, just before he developed his suave, smooth, warm, fuzzy personality that we've all grown to love over the years."
Taking his turn on the podium, Mr. Rumsfeld expressed mock indignation at Mr. Cheney's account ("It wasn't like that!"), before waxing eloquent: "A superb executive, a wise counselor, the vice president is a combination of both thinker and doer. I am sure glad I discovered him!"

GRAPHIC:  Photo: Vice President Dick Cheney lowered his head as he stepped back from the podium yesterday after remarks at the James H. Doolittle Award Luncheon honoring Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld in Washington. (Doug Mills/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Faces the Public, and the Music, With Some Assurance 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
He did not emote, in a Bill Clinton-I-feel-your-pain way. Nor did he spar with questioners, in a Rudolph W. Giuliani-confrontational way.
 Instead, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went to a community breakfast in Flatbush, Brooklyn, yesterday and did the compassion thing, the connection thing, the outreach thing and the vision thing that pundits and some ordinary New Yorkers have been urging him to do. 
 It was short on theatrics. He arrived late, and took only four questions. But it was a calm, matter-of-fact, businesslike rendition of the world according to Mike Bloomberg, and it went over fairly well. 
"There are no easy answers to complex problems, whether they are fiscal problems or problems in society, or problems in your own personal family lives," Mr. Bloomberg, who has been second-guessed a lot of late, told the crowd. "We all know how to raise other people's children, but we all know that our children are complex."
The mayor, who has been tetchy of late as he has come under fire from different constituencies, kept his cool yesterday when one woman in the audience, Cynthia Dennis, heckled him with a question about the city's plan to reduce garbage collections in July, just in time for the summer's heat to add to the city's stench.
"No. 1, we're going to pick up the trash," the mayor began.
"How often?" pressed Ms. Dennis, 65, who lives in Canarsie.
"Let me finish," the mayor persevered. "Can I finish my sentence? And let me give you an answer that will get me off the hook. As often as is needed and we can afford. The fact of the matter is we've got to decide -- do we want fewer cops on the street, or more frequent pickups? It's those kinds of choices that I was elected to make."
It was a theme he returned to repeatedly at the Brooklyn breakfast, which offered a relatively rare opportunity for Mr. Bloomberg, who has generally shunned the frequent town hall-style meetings of his predecessors, to explain his unpopular proposed budget cuts and tax increases to average New Yorkers and to take a few of their questions.
The breakfast at Vanderveer Park United Methodist Church on Glenwood Road, where roughly three-quarters of the congregants are from the Caribbean, was the mayor's first community meeting since his recent moves drove his approval ratings down in the polls. It was exactly the kind of event his advisers and others have been urging him to do.
About 150 people heard him speak about the dilemmas he has had to face in deciding which services to cut, and which taxes to raise. 
"We have to make the tough choices of, do we tax ourselves or let the streets fall apart?" he said. "I know what the right answer is to that."
The mayor, who tried last year to close several centers for the elderly, pledged to keep the centers open. He spoke of trying to preserve health care, but candidly told a health care advocate, "I'm not sure you should relax."
When Mr. Giuliani was mayor, he held monthly town hall meetings with his commissioners to face city residents. Mayor Bloomberg did a couple of these sessions, then stopped. Instead he holds community breakfasts with selected members of the City Council. But in his 16 months in office, an aide to Mr. Bloomberg said, the mayor has had two town meetings and five breakfasts.
The breakfast's host, Councilman Kendall Stewart, praised Mr. Bloomberg, but his introduction was not the usual buttering-up heard in political speeches. Mr. Stewart said the budget cuts were affecting almost everyone in the district, and he told about a Haitian immigrant with four children whose son is losing his after-school program. He stated bluntly, "Mr. Mayor, our community has never gotten its fair share of the city's economic pie." When it was over, though, Mr. Stewart said he thought the mayor did well.
Hyacinth Mooyoung, 50, a real estate agent who lives in East Flatbush, said she wished the mayor had taken more questions, and had spoken about foreclosures, but she praised him for showing up. "It's a privilege for him to come to a community and take time out from his busy schedule to come and talk to us," she said.
After breakfast the mayor slowly helped Lillie Mae Ferebee, who just turned 100, down the steps of the church, chatting with her about his own mother. Then he headed back to City Hall, where he had a visit planned with Margaret Thatcher, Britain's former prime minister.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with Lillie Mae Ferebee, who was celebrating her 100th birthday yesterday in Brooklyn. (Michael Nagle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush's Support Strong Despite Tax Cut Doubts 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Americans have persistent reservations about the tax cuts that are the centerpiece of President Bush's postwar agenda, but those concerns have not hurt Mr. Bush, who continues to ride a huge wave of support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
 The number of Americans who said they had confidence in Mr. Bush's ability to manage the economy dropped seven points, to 47 percent, in the month the president has been pushing his tax cut plan in speeches in Washington and across the nation. The poll also found that many Americans say that instead of cutting taxes, the nation should use the moneyto cut the deficit or finance a national health care system. 
 There is no evidence, however, that those doubts have damaged Mr. Bush's overall standing. The poll found that 67 percent approved of his job performance, while 70 percent said he had strong qualities of leadership, the trait that the White House has long contended would trump any concerns Americans might have about Mr. Bush's policies. 
Beyond that, Americans now hold a notably more favorable view of the Republican Party than of the Democratic Party, and 53 percent said Republicans had a clear vision of where to lead the country, compared with just 40 percent who said that of Democrats. That finding is reminiscent of what the Times/CBS News poll found last fall, just before Republicans took control of Congress.
By any measure, the Times/CBS News poll, which is the second since the fall of Baghdad and was taken at a time when activity on the presidential campaign trail has been increasing, offered a glimpse of the daunting task the Democrats face at least today, 18 months before Election Day, in trying to win back the White House and Congress.
For all the emphasis that Democrats have placed on questioning Mr. Bush's economic record, Americans were evenly divided over which party was more likely to ensure a strong economy. And in a finding that suggests that Democratic attacks against Mr. Bush have yet to take hold, 67 percent of Americans said they thought that Mr. Bush cared a lot or some "about the needs and problems of people like yourself," though 54 percent said that Mr. Bush's policies favored the rich.
Still, there were a few encouraging signs in the poll for the nine Democratic presidential candidates.
Americans overwhelmingly said the nation's health care system needed fundamental change or a complete overhaul, and they said the Democratic Party was better equipped to do that. 
That finding seems not to have been lost on the Democratic presidential candidates. Yesterday, Howard Dean became the latest to offer a plan for expanding health care coverage, using a speech to counter an ambitious proposal to provide universal health care put forward by Representative Richard A. Gephardt three weeks ago. A third candidate, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, will offer his health care plan in Iowa tomorrow.
Respondents also said that the Democrats would do a better job of creating jobs and improving education. In addition, the number of Americans who named the economy as the chief problem facing the country continued to climb, to 29 percent in this poll, up from 23 percent last month, suggesting the potential potency of the issue that both the White House and Democrats believe could prove pivotal in next year's presidential election. 
The poll was conducted by telephone from Friday through Monday. It involved 910 adults and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Whatever enthusiasm Americans have for their president has, so far at least, not extended to what Mr. Bush has identified as his chief domestic goal now that the war is nearly over: slashing taxes. Almost uniformly, the Democratic presidential candidates have called for rejecting either all or most of Mr. Bush's tax cut, describing it as economically damaging and tilted unfairly to the rich, and the findings suggested that this argument could eventually have some resonance.
A plurality of those polled, 41 percent, said they believed that Mr. Bush's tax cut could help the economy. But 48 percent rejected one of Mr. Bush's central arguments for tax cuts, saying the cuts were not very or not at all likely to create jobs. In addition, 58 percent said they did not expect to find any more money in their paychecks as a result of Mr. Bush's tax cuts. And 63 percent of respondents said the tax cuts in 2001 had not helped the economy.
On matters of economic policy, Americans appear to have a different set of priorities from their president's. For example, 81 percent of respondents said that the country should make sure Americans had access to health care, rather than cut taxes. And 58 percent said the priority should be reducing the deficit.
"We need to lower the deficit," said Ed Petrone, 73, an independent voter from Boca Raton, Fla., in a follow-up interview. "Reducing taxes is only a short-term bump in the economy. Lowering the deficit will help us down the road. Reduce the deficit and we can put more money in the economy."
Carroll Smith, 76, an independent voter from Gallipolis, Ohio, said, "If they would balance the budget, the country would be in better shape."
Beyond the economy, with nine months to go before the caucuses in Iowa, most people do not know who is running to unseat Mr. Bush. Nearly two-thirds of voters, regardless of which party they were from, were unable to name a single one of the nine Democrats seeking the party's nomination.
Still, the poll suggested that some of the early contours of the coming election were becoming clear.
Continuing a historical trend that has played to the advantage of the Republican Party, the Times/CBS News poll found that Americans overwhelmingly saw Republicans as better able to make the right decisions on terrorism and to keep the military strong. 
Although some Democratic presidential candidates, notably Senators John Edwards of North Carolina and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, have sought to challenge Mr. Bush's foreign policy credentials by saying that Mr. Bush had not done enough to protect Americans from another terrorist attack, those warnings did not seem to have been embraced by voters.
An overwhelming majority of respondents said Mr. Bush had made progress in developing a plan to protect the United States from terrorist attacks. The number of Americans who named terrorism as the most important problem facing the nation has declined steadily since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The poll, however, was completed before the latest terrorist attacks, in Saudi Arabia. 
Fifty-eight percent of respondents said Republicans would do a better job of protecting the United States against terrorist attacks; just 18 percent said the same thing of Democrats. And 66 percent said Republicans were more likely to make sure the nation's military forces were strong, compared with 19 percent who expressed such confidence in Democrats.
In one sign of the challenge Democrats face if they criticize Mr. Bush's foreign policy credentials, 6 in 10 respondents rejected complaints by Democrats who charged that it was inappropriate for Mr. Bush to have announced the end of fighting in Iraq by landing a plane on an aircraft carrier in the Pacific.
Notwithstanding Mr. Bush's strong standing in the aftermath of the war in Iraq, the poll found continued evidence that the nation remains politically polarized after the disputed election of 2000. A majority of Democrats and half of all independents said they did not consider that Mr. Bush had legitimately won the White House.
"Bush is a court-appointed president," said Jo Carney, 59, an independent voter from East Hampton, N.Y. "He was not elected. Everything was completely mishandled in Florida, and the way the court intervened was really pulling strings."
The poll suggested that Republicans have continued to do a better job in laying out an agenda that is clear to Americans. Democrats have long thought that that would change as attention moved away from Capitol Hill, where Democrats are in the minority and thus do not have a platform, and to the presidential campaign, thus improving the party's standing with the public. 
The speech by Dr. Dean in New York, setting off a debate with Mr. Gephardt on who has the more realistic and efficient plan for providing health care coverage, would seem to be an example of that. For now, though, the poll found that 53 percent of respondents had a favorable view of the Republican Party, compared with 46 percent with a favorable view of Democrats.
"The Republicans have a clear view of what they want and are effective in promoting it," said Wendy Satterford, 50, a Democrat from San Diego. "The Democrats don't have a clear vision. They seem afraid of the electorate and the apparent rising tide of conservatism. They don't seem to be able to speak out even for the middle-of-the-road things."

Conducting the Poll
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Friday through Monday with 910 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country. Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers alike. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variation in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would be obtained from all American adults. For smaller subgroups the margin of error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variation in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.
Complete results are atnytimes.com/washington.

HEADLINE: Pataki Banks Heavily on Gambling in New Plan to Rescue New York City 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 13 

 BODY:
A day before his promised veto of the State Legislature's budget plan, Gov. George E. Pataki today tried to change the subject, unveiling a new plan for bailing out New York City that avoids raising taxes but counts on money from gambling, leasing a water pipeline and selling off city assets.
 The governor would add as many as 4,500 video lottery terminals to three large Off-Track Betting outlets. He would help the city refinance its lingering 1970's debt, but not transfer the burden to the state. He would have the Metropolitan Transportation Authority buy property it uses, like lots, bus maintenance facilities and property close to access points. 
 But he would not raise, even temporarily, sales taxes or the income tax on the rich. 
The governor's proposal was widely viewed as an attempt to answer critics who have complained that he has not done enough to help save the city from its fiscal crisis. It came as a new poll revealed that his approval rating had slipped to its lowest level in eight years, and that his personal crusade against raising taxes was hurting him with voters, particularly those who describe themselves as Democrats or who live in New York City.
Many elected officials from the city and in the Legislature scoffed at the proposal.
"After listening to the governor's plan for New York City, is there any doubt now that the governor is out of touch with the people he was elected to serve?" said Sheldon Silver, the Democratic speaker of the State Assembly. He said the governor was choosing slot machines over preschool for 4-year-olds, and called the plan a gimmick. "Really, this plan is an insult to working parents throughout New York City," Mr. Silver said.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued a statement that was tantamount to a "thanks, but no thanks," diplomatically rejecting the governor's plan in favor of the Legislature's.
"The $2.7 billion agreement with the State Legislature covers both new revenues and restorations, both of which are necessary for the city to close its budget gap," Mr. Bloomberg's statement said.
"We know the governor is trying to find additional help for the city and we are open to all ideas," he said, "some that we may find work and some that for reasons beyond anyone's control, or due to other constraints, may not be available at this time."
The governor called a news conference, as he has done frequently in recent weeks, to announce the assistance package. He also used the opportunity to continue his battle against the tax increases proposed by the Legislature to help the city and state bridge deficits this year -- $3.8 billion in the city and $11.5 billion in the state.
The governor estimated that his plan would give the city $1.7 billion in aid, a figure that legislative leaders and some city officials disputed.
Mr. Pataki said the Legislature's plan for helping the city would drive businesses and jobs to other states and that proposed tax increases would further burden city residents already reeling from rising rent costs and property taxes.
"I truly think there is a better path," Mr. Pataki said. He added: "This is a better way. And it's so clearly a better way that rejects these massive tax increases."
Democrats in the Senate and the Assembly and officials in the Republican administration of Mayor Bloomberg said many parts of the proposal stood little chance of becoming law because of political resistance.
Many lawmakers and city officials said they were also troubled because the governor was silent about whether he would veto a portion of the Legislature's budget proposal that restores $1 billion worth of cuts in education and health care that lawmakers say the city needs.
Some grumbled that the governor was protecting the economically well off in New York from tax increases while putting the temptation of gambling within reach of many poor and desperate people.
"Gambling is the tax on the addicted," said Senator David A. Paterson, of Harlem, who is the leader of the Senate Democrats. "And believe me, that is job-killing and family-killing."
But the governor said that New York City was already dealing with the social fallout from gambling because city residents go to casinos in Atlantic City and Connecticut. He also pointed out that thousands of video lottery terminals were going to be installed at the Aqueduct and Yonkers racetracks.
"But the city doesn't get any direct benefit from any of the revenues that are generated from those facilities," said the governor, who pushed through the legislation that would place the lottery terminals at racetracks. Under his plan, he said, the city would collect $210 million in proceeds in the first fiscal year and $395 million the next fiscal year.
In his plan, the governor would fulfill a request by the city to lease a 20-mile-long aqueduct that runs from the city limit at Yonkers through the Bronx and Queens to Brooklyn to a private investor who could then claim depreciation rights for what would be changed to personal property from real property for tax-law purposes. The city would get a one-time benefit of $100 million, the governor said.
Many, including Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, said the governor's plan amounted to too little, too late. But the governor asserted that there was plenty of time to consider his ideas, negotiate them and pass them before the city's fiscal year begins on July 1.
The governor was not without support. Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the Partnership for New York City, said any proposal that avoided tax increases was worth considering.
Mr. Bloomberg also found things to praise in the governor's proposal. While the mayor has characterized gambling as an unsavory and unreliable way of raising revenues, he said he desperately wants some of the reforms the governor supports, such as changing the state's tort laws to limit damages and lessen the city's liability to lawsuits, and repealing the Wicks Law, which requires most public construction projects to use different contractors for different types of work. But those changes are subject to legislative approval and would likely face serious opposition.
Other city officials said the plan was a political ploy that would never fly. What made many of them most angry, however, was the proposal to refinance the last $2.5 billion worth of debt left from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, without transferring the payments to the state, as the Legislature had proposed.
In the governor's plan, the city would pay back the debt on a shorter schedule and at a lower interest rate than the Legislature had agreed to, aides to Mr. Pataki said. The governor said the city would save $1.1 billion over the next two years under his refinancing plan.
The governor released his plan for the city as his aides were poring over the Legislature's budget bills, choosing what he will veto on Wednesday.
Aides said Mr. Pataki would hold a press conference in the afternoon to explain his actions. Then, during commercial breaks in the 6 p.m. television news, he will air a two-minute taped address to explain to New Yorkers why he has vetoed large parts of the spending plan, his spokeswoman, Lisa Dewald Stoll, said. The governor's campaign committee will pay for the air time in all the state's major markets, she said.
So far, according to a new poll, voters are siding with the Legislature. In a one-day statewide survey of 512 registered voters, the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion found that only 37 percent of those who responded thought Mr. Pataki was doing a good or excellent job as governor, his lowest rating in the survey in eight years.
The poll also said that 57 percent disapproved of Mr. Pataki's handling of the budget, 55 percent agreed with the Legislature's approach of raising taxes to maintain services and 56 percent would rather see him sign the budget than veto it.
The telephone poll was conducted Monday evening and has a margin or sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Polls taken on just one night are subject to additional error because of the limited time to reach people.

HEADLINE: Justice Dept. Plans to Step Up Gun-Crime Prosecutions 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LICHTBLAU 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13 

 BODY:
Justice Department officials said today that they planned to step up prosecutions of gun crimes as part of a new initiative, even as a private study said prosecutors had "ignored" a vast majority of gun crimes.
 The study, to be released here on Wednesday by Americans for Gun Safety, found that 2 percent of federal gun crimes resulted in prosecutions and that gun traffickers were rarely prosecuted. 
 Justice Department officials disputed some findings in the report. They said the department had made "dramatic increases" in prosecuting gun crimes since Attorney General John Ashcroft made that a top priority when he took office in 2001, with overall prosecutions increasing more than 32 percent as of the latest tally. 
The report was issued as supporters of gun rights push for legislation to protect firearms manufacturers and sellers from lawsuits and Congress is considering whether to extend the nine-year-old ban on assault weapons. The White House favors keeping the prohibition against the possesion and sale of such weapons, a stance that has put him at odds with the National Rifle Association and its allies in Congress. 
Today, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader, said he saw little chance that the House would vote this year to extend the ban. "The votes in the House are not there to reauthorize it," Mr. DeLay said. 
Law enforcement officials and gun control groups are divided on a strategy to combat gun violence, which kills more than 10,000 people a year. 
The Bush administration has focused on two problems, felons who possess guns illegally and people who use firearms in committing crimes. 
The new study, which analyzed information from the Justice Department from 2000 to 2002, found that illegal possession and use during a crime accounted for 85 percent of the more than 25,000 federal firearms cases in that period. 
Gun control groups say by focusing so extensively on street crimes, the department under Mr. Ashcroft and his predecessor, Janet Reno, has largely ignored black market dealers, corrupt shop owners, "straw purchase" distributors and others who are central to the problem of illegal guns. The report cited 20 "rarely enforced" federal gun crimes. 
"There's a huge enforcement gap in areas where the federal government has a unique responsibility to prosecute cases," said Jim Kessler, the policy and research director for Americans for Gun Safety who is a co-author of the study.
It found that although people younger than 18 committed an estimated 93,000 violent crimes, federal prosecutors brought 24 cases for selling firearms to minors. 
Although an estimated 420,000 firearms were reported stolen in that period, prosecutors filed 524 cases related to the possession, transfer or sale of stolen firearms, the report said. An estimated 450,000 would-be buyers were found to have lied about their histories and had their applications rejected, but fewer than 1,600 were prosecuted for lying in their background checks, the report added. 
Justice Department officials said they had concentrated prosecutions on felons and people who used guns in crimes because they represented the most dangerous owners. The officials said Mr. Ashcroft had also sought to step up prosecutions of would-be owners who lied on background checks, and the number of prosecutions for false statements rose 8 percent last year, officials said. 
"We're seeing increases across the board in prosecutions, and we are not neglecting any cases," said Reagan Dunn, who coordinates the antigun crime initiative that Mr. Ashcroft began in 2001.
At a hearing today before the Senate Judiciary Committee, federal and local law enforcement officials said they were pleased with the gun initiative and were planning to expand on the progress of the last two years. 
The department plans to commit $900 million to the initiative over three years and has added more than 600 prosecutors and agents to aid in the effort, officials said.
The United States attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, Paul J. McNulty, told the panel that although it was too early to judge the program, it had already produced "unprecedented coordination" among officials.
But two professors who specialize in gun crime and also appeared before the committee questioned the effectiveness of the program. 
Jens Ludwig, an associate professor of public policy at Georgetown University, said although advocates pointed to a pilot program in Virginia as a model, that program "has not been as successful as is widely believed." Although his comment drew a rebuke from Mr. McNulty, the professor said his own research did not support the idea that a push to remove illegal guns from the street had contributed greatly to a significant drop in firearms murders in the late 1990's in the Richmond, Va., metropolitan region.
Another witness, Alfred Blumstein, an expert on violent crime at Carnegie Mellon University, said he believed that the Justice Department had failed to develop a coordinated approach to gun crime.
"We are still woefully ignorant of the mix of factors contributing to gun violence and how that mix varies across locality," Professor Blumstein said.
Although he was not involved in the study, he said he agreed that prosecutors had not paid enough attention to cutting off the black market. "We're getting the low-hanging fruit," the professor said. "The other piece of the puzzle we're not really touching on is the whole gun distribution network."

HEADLINE: The Agents of Change in Cuba 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "How to Hurt Castro," by Representative Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona (Op-Ed, May 12):
 On the basis of a recent, legal trip to Cuba, I agree with Mr. Flake. 
Contact with Americans and with people from other free countries is a valuable agent for change. 
 Cubans are highly curious about other countries, and few appear to share Fidel Castro's bitter anti-Americanism. Discontent increases as Cubans contrast their own poverty and restricted personal and economic freedoms with what they hear about the outside world.
As a result of the growth of a dollar economy, introduced by tourism, many Cubans have become engaged in entrepreneurial capitalism.
I concluded that the best way to undermine Mr. Castro's power and to bring about a more open society in Cuba is to continue to undermine its isolation and poverty. Policies that have isolated and penalized Cuba have aided Mr. Castro, enabling him better to control information and to blame outside forces for economic deprivation and human rights violations.

LYNN NICHOLAS
New York, May 12, 2003

HEADLINE: Korea Distiller Is Ordered Into Bankruptcy 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

 BODY:
A South Korean court ordered Jinro, the country's largest distiller, into bankruptcy yesterday and removed its management.
 The ruling was a groundbreaking victory for a group of foreign creditors led by Goldman Sachs. They hold $449 million of the company's debt and have been fighting with Jiro for five years over repayment. Goldman itself holds bonds with a face value of $270 million. 
 The case has taken on immense symbolism in South Korea, where the courts are believed to have never issued such a ruling before on behalf of foreign creditors. There is strong nationalist sentiment against foreign ownership or control of Korean businesses, and Jinro is seen as especially Korean because it is the leading producer of soju, the national drink, a liquor distilled from rice, sweet potatoes and tapioca.
Jinro said it would appeal the ruling immediately.
The company has been in financial distress since the Asian currency crisis of 1997, when, despite a 38 percent share of the domestic soju market, the company nearly collapsed under $1.5 billion in debts run up on diversification moves into department stores and other ventures. It was delisted by the Korea Stock Exchange in January.
The company began selling off peripheral assets in 1998, and in the years since has built its core business to an even more dominant 54 percent market share. But it has tried the patience of creditors, principally the group led by Goldman Sachs.
A five-year moratorium on repayment of debts expired in April, and the company immediately defaulted, failing to make a $58 million payment due to Goldman Sachs and its partners. Goldman responded by suing in Seoul district court to force the company into receivership. 
Domestic creditors, who hold 64 percent of Jinro's total debts, have tended to back management, including the company's leading Korean lender, Hana Bank, which has expressed concern that putting the company in receivership will make it harder to line up future financing from foreign sources. Many of the company's 3,000 workers, fearful for their jobs under any new management, demonstrated angrily in Seoul yesterday, according to news agencies. 
South Korean corporate receiverships are similar in some ways to Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in the United States. Debt collection by creditors is blocked while the company tries, sometimes for several years, to right itself and win court approval for a new financial plan. The most important difference lies in who runs the company during the process: under South Korean law, the court appoints new management at the outset.
In the Jinro case, the court was at pains to allay fears that its ruling amounted to a takeover of the company by Goldman Sachs. The purpose of the decision, the court said, was to rebuild Jinro "through strict and transparent procedures to maximize the company's corporate value." It did not mean, the court said, that "the fate of Jinro rests in the hands of foreign creditors or that it will disappear."

HEADLINE: Africans Suffer, As We Look Away 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Ethiopia's Dying Children" (column, May 13), Nicholas D. Kristof quoted an alliance of aid groups as claiming that "for the international community to allow this to happen in the 21st century is unforgivable." 
 Unforgivable it may be, but it is certainly not unpredictable. As Mr. Kristof stated, Africa has been the forgotten continent in recent years.
But he must remember that Africa has been the forgotten continent since Alexandria was considered a major city -- or a city at all. If the world can recoil at the thought of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party, how can it ignore the deaths of thousands of Africans at the hands of poverty-stricken, corrupt governments? 
Tragic as it may be, famine and poverty in Africa have become a cliche in the eyes of the West. This, combined with Africa's low economic productivity, results in the West's finding it too easy to ignore Africa. While we are laboring over how to reconstruct the United Nations, why not seek to construct a plan by which the international community might be forgiven?

CHELSEA PAIGE
Andover, Mass., May 13, 2003

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
The benefits to the economy of a weaker dollar and global coordination.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and the journal Indicators, and he also teaches at Cooper Union and New School University. His new book is "Why Economies Grow," from Basic Books. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
THE falling dollar has raised alarms in certain circles. But it is just what the doctor ordered for a weak American economy. And if it falls some more, all the better. 
 In fact, there is now an opportunity for the Bush administration to stimulate the economy without relying almost solely on tax cuts that are likely to sap the nation's long-term strength. It should try to coordinate fiscal and monetary policies with Europe and Asia to push the dollar down further while simultaneously stimulating demand in other nations. 
 John W. Snow, the Treasury secretary, hinted on television on Sunday that the administration, despite subsequent official denials, might not be opposed to a lower dollar. But there is little sign the administration will take the important step of coordinating policies, especially given the continuing friction over its foreign policy in major capitals. Good relations with Poland and Portugal, part of "New Europe," are not going to get anyone far. Mr. Snow travels to Europe on Saturday to meet with finance ministers there. Perhaps he will surprise us. 
A lower dollar can stimulate the economy by making America's exports cheaper. Though it takes a while, this is particularly helpful to struggling manufacturers. It also makes imports more expensive, enabling domestic producers to capture more market share. "A lower dollar is like a tax cut to producers," said Robert Blecker, an economics professor at American University, "but it doesn't show up in the deficit." 
The dollar has been falling since early last year and is now down about 8 percent against a large basket of currencies and much more against the euro. But to generate adequate stimulus, it will have to fall further. The customary fear that it will reignite inflation is hardly a danger now. 
The main problem is that what is good for American manufacturers is bad for European, Canadian and Asian ones. As the euro and other currencies go up, Americans will buy fewer of these countries' products. And if their economies weaken -- Germany and other European nations are teetering on the brink of recession -- they will not be able to buy American exports, no matter how cheap. Ideally, Europe should be cutting interest rates to support demand at home. So far, it is resisting for fear it will ignite inflation. 
There are several ways to get a reasonable sense of how low a dollar the United States now needs. What crystalizes theissue best is a model developed by the British economist Wynne Godley, formerly of the Jerome Levy Institute for Economics and now returned to the University of Cambridge.
Mr. Godley's model, cited by some academic and business economists, conjectures that the nation's current account deficit, which includes its trade deficit as well as interest payments, will continue to rise from its current 5 percent. 
But this net spending on foreign goods and services means that some of America's demand is lost to overseas economies. This must be counteracted by either private or government borrowing at home to keep spending up and avoid a fall in output. 
Mr. Godley and others argue that the high levels of debt taken on by consumers and business will probably impede this. So the federal government is the last resort. 
If the balance of payments continues to deteriorate, and the private sector does not increase investment, Mr. Godley reckons that the federal deficit might have to reach an astonishing 9 to 10 percent of gross domestic product to avoid serious recession. 
There are several ways out of the morass, some not desirable. A steep recession will reduce demand for foreign goods and lower the trade deficit. 
More hopefully, business could start investing vigorously again. But given the size of the 1990's investment bubble, will it? 
Overseas economies could start growing so rapidly that they would import many of America's goods. But many are getting weaker by the hour, it seems. 
Finally, the dollar could fall enough to reduce the balance-of-payments deficit. Several economists at the Levy Institute -- Dimitri Papadimitriou, Anwar Shaikh, Gennaro Zezza and Claudio Dos Santos -- have updated the Godley analysis and argue that at least a 25 percent fall in the dollar is desirable. 
A more conventional analysis by J. Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics arrives at a similar conclusion. He figures that every 1 percent fall in a trade-weighted dollar index results in roughly a $10 billion reduction in the balance of payments. He thinks the current deficit is not sustainable and must be cut in half as a percentage of G.D.P.
The great advantage of coordination is that it requires no single policy to do all the lifting. With coordination, the dollar might not have to fall as far or the deficit rise as steeply as demand overseas picks up -- and all may benefit. 
In one scenario, America would have to admit it wants a lower dollar. It would have to persuade the European Central Bank to reduce its relatively high interest rates and the European Union to allow member governments to run bigger deficits to stoke domestic demand. 
Most difficult, as Mr. Blecker and others point out, the administration would encourage the typically stubborn Asian nations, like Japan and China, to stop holding their currencies down as well. 
The markets might force policy makers' hands anyway. But this runs the danger of unbalanced policy responses and financial instability. 
Can coordination work? It is fashionable to dismiss it. But on balance, a version of it did work in 1985, when the Reagan administration sought to reduce the dollar's level during the famous Plaza Accord, and again in 1987 at the Louvre meetings, when it sought to stop its fall. 
Given its unilateral tendencies, will the Bush administration make such a concerted effort? A coordinated policy would be a mark of leadership in a complex and interconnected world. It is the best chance the world has for renewed stable growth.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Falling Dollar"The value of the dollar has been slipping against the currencies of major United States trading partners. Graph shows the TRADE WEIGHTED DOLLAR INDEX since February 2002 (Adjusted for inflation). (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: Niagara Hopes Casino Visitors Won't Mutter, 'What Falls?' 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 9 

 BODY:
They had a traffic jam here one day last winter. The city was delighted.
 After all, people have been getting scarcer in this town for half a century, ever since the big steel and chemical plants that fed on the energy of the Niagara River began shutting down. If the opening of the Seneca Niagara casino on New Year's Day could back the cars up at Third Street at Rainbow Boulevard, it could only be an improvement. 
 Now, with this bedraggled city on the cusp of its all-important summer tourism season, the first with a casino to match the one on the Canadian side, people here are waiting to see if the opening-day rush to the Indian casino will be the harbinger of things to come or just the latest disappointment. 
Without much good news in recent years, people here are hoping for the best.
"The local guys are starting to feel the momentum," said Michael Wilton, president of USA Niagara Development Corporation, a state economic development agency. "If anything, this casino is a sign to local people that things can happen here, that things are moving."
Mr. Wilton is a booster, but he is not alone. These days, the notion that gambling can lift failing economies is an article of faith across the New York region and beyond. Eastern states from Maryland to Massachusetts are looking at casinos as painless alternatives to tax increases, and Gov. George E. Pataki, who is counting on new casinos to balance the state budget, recently announced a plan for lottery terminals in OTB betting parlors to help New York City cover its deficit.
But it is tourism, not just taxes, that Niagara Falls is hoping for in this first summer of gambling.
"For one thing, the casino brought 2,000 new jobs, so obviously it has already helped," said Mayor Irene J. Elia. "But will people come just for the casino? We're in trouble if we think so."
Will most visitors be the usual mom and dad with kids in tow -- few gamblers there -- or will they be the couples rich in years and in retirement savings who are drawn like moths to the light of the slots?
"I see a certain mutual exclusivity between the casino customers and our customers," said Christopher M. Glynn, president of the Maid of the Mist Corporation, whose boats take tourists into the spray of the falls.
"All of the gamblers won't be tourists, and all of the tourists won't be gamblers," Mr. Glynn said. "But if some of the gamblers decide to spend some time as tourists, that would be great."
Most of all, what people hope is that the millions of Americans who pour into Niagara Falls each summer will not take one look at the dingy, empty buildings and scattered attractions here, then head directly across the Rainbow Bridge to the bright lights, tidy streets and booming casino and other attractions on the Canadian side. 
Plenty of business people evidently believe that the wealth of the casino, which is taking in close to $1 million a day from gamblers, will spill over into the city, home to 52,000 people. Howard Milstein, the developer, bought the vacant Nabisco plant on the edge of the casino development area for $3.2 million. 
"You couldn't have got a dollar for it before the casino," said Howard Smith, a real estate broker. 
And a one-block walk up Third Street from the casino shows that a dozen or so small businesses are following in the casino's wake. The scaffolding is still up in front of the new bar that Dan Vecchies is building, but another spot, Club 427, opened with a big party a few doors down from him last week. Up the street is a new boutique, LaRussa Fashion Casino Wear, and across the street from LaRussa's stands a new restaurant, Donatello's, which is next to Cafe Etc., the old place that Steve Fournier has restored into an hot spot for the city's young crowd.
Mr. Vecchies, who also owns a mortgage business, says he is going to name his bar Shadows.
"I think this market is ready for an upscale martini bar that serves high-end food and liquor," he said. "And besides, there are 200 high-income managers in the casino who will be looking for a place like this after work."
But not everyone is counting on the casino to put money in their pockets. Gary Deutschlander runs a coffee and pastry shop on the pedestrian mall outside the entrance to the American side of the falls. "The casino people, they're not going to come in here," he said. "They've got everything they want to eat and drink right where they are."
The bars and restaurants do worry that the casino will do what casinos everywhere try to do keep their customers inside and gambling with plentiful, cheap food and free drinks. So Mr. Vecchies and other bar owners are pushing the city and county to let them extend their hours to 4 a.m. from 2. As an Indian business, the casino is exempt from local laws, but it voluntarily stops serving alcohol at 4.
Still, Mr. Fournier, in Cafe Etc., said he was not necessarily counting on casino patronage. 
"Everyone's saying we're banking on the casino," he said. "I'm not banking on anything except opening a business in my hometown, like my father and my grandfather did. With all the people crossing the ditch every day, I figure some of them will come in here."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Worries on Retailers and Chip Industry Lead Shares Down

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks declined yesterday as a disappointing forecast from Applied Materials, the world's biggest supplier of equipment for making semiconductors, hurt shares of chip-related companies.
 Retailers like J. C. Penney and Home Depot slid after the government reported an unexpected decline in retail sales in April. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 3.02 points, or 0.3 percent, to 939.28. The index has gained 17 percent over the last two months. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 31.43 points, or 0.4 percent, to 8,647.82, while the Nasdaq composite index slid 4.78 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,534.90. 
"The big rally we saw in stocks was predicated on the belief that the world was getting better and the economy was getting better," said Joseph Basset, who helps manage $149 billion at Banc One Investment Advisors. Reports like the outlook from Applied Materials suggest otherwise, he said.
Rising and declining stocks were about equal in number on the New York Stock Exchange. More than 1.37 billion shares traded, in line with the three-month average daily volume.
The S.& P. 500 reached a nine-month high this week on optimism that corporate earnings and the economy would accelerate this year. Still, some investors say, the rally since March 11 already reflects the prospect for faster growth.
"It's been a good, solid run, but we'll probably slow to a walk from here, at least until we see confirmation that the economy is genuinely gaining traction," said Paul McManus, director of fundamental research at Independence Investments, based in Boston, which manages $15 billion.
In a sign that the economy may not pick up as expected through 2003, a government report showed that retail sales declined in April. Sales decreased 0.1 percent, to $309.5 billion, as consumers spent less on furniture, clothing and gasoline. Economists had forecast a gain of 0.4 percent. A group of consumer companies, including J. C. Penney, accounted for almost one-third of the decline in the S.& P. 500 index.
Computer-related shares also accounted for one-third of the S.& P. 500's decline. Applied Materials fell 59 cents, to $14.97. The company reported a loss of $62.1 million in the quarter ended April 27, in contrast to a profit of $52 million a year earlier. Revenue declined 4.3 percent, to $1.11 billion, and the company said new orders would be little changed in the quarter ending in July.
Among other chip-related shares, KLA-Tencor, the world's biggest maker of semiconductor inspection equipment, fell $1.21, to $41.54.
Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, slid 16 cents, to $19.66. Texas Instruments, the largest maker of chips that power cellular telephones, declined 28 cents, to $19.42.
Network Appliance, whose machines store and distribute computer data files on corporate networks, fell $1.24, to $15.49. The company reported first-quarter profit of 7 cents a share, excluding some costs, matching expectations.
Federated Department Stores declined 75 cents, to $31.70. Federated, the parent of Macy's and Lazarus, said earnings last quarter decreased 48 percent and sales declined 4.6 percent.
Home Depot, the world's largest home improvement chain, slid 35 cents, to $29.60. J. C. Penney dropped $1.63, to $17.22.
Abercrombie & Fitch, the clothing retailer, declined $1.87, to $27.98. The company forecast second-quarter profit of 30 cents to 34 cents a share, less than the average estimate of 35 cents.
Millennium Pharmaceuticals rose $1.90, or 15 percent, to $14.39. It received Food and Drug Administration approval for a drug, Velcade, intended to treat multiple myeloma, an incurable form of blood cancer.

HEADLINE: A Job Half-Done in Afghanistan 

 BODY:
Iraqis worried about the future of their country cannot be encouraged by what they see in Afghanistan, America's first effort at nation-building in the Islamic world. Nearly 18 months after American-backed forces ousted the Taliban from power, Afghanistan languishes in a strange limbo between war and peace. Though Washington's efforts have brought a measure of freedom and democracy, many of America's promises about rebuilding Afghanistan have yet to be realized. 
 Two big mistakes proved costly. The Bush administration did not adequately concern itself with issues of internal security. And it seriously underestimated the amount of aid it would take to pay for both relief and reconstruction needs. The combined effect of these errors has seriously weakened the power of President Hamid Karzai and slowed Afghanistan's economic regeneration. 
 Understandably, the Pentagon's main concern in Afghanistan has been fighting what remains of the Taliban, a declared enemy of the United States, not bringing to heel local warlords, many of whom fought alongside American troops. That has left most of the country under the control of feuding warlords. Armed men are everywhere, including about 100,000 in various private armies. Their battles, banditry and financial exactions have impeded economic recovery and national cohesion. This problem might have been better contained if international peacekeepers had been stationed throughout the country, not just in Kabul. 
The longer-term answer to the warlords' power is the new national army Washington is training. While plans call for a force of 70,000, so far only about 4,500 members have been trained. Yet there is talk of withdrawing the remaining 8,500 American troops in Afghanistan next year, long before the new national army will be strong enough to take over.
Roughly $1 billion a year in American aid, along with contributions from other donors, has not been enough to overcome the devastation inflicted by more than two decades of conflict on what was already one of the world's poorest and least developed economies. Continuing security problems have discouraged private investment and slowed the country's economic regeneration. That has kept tax revenues too low to pay the police and other government workers. And with much of the population unemployed, much of the aid has had to go into emergency relief programs. That has left far too little for projects needed to restart the economy, like repairing roads and dams, restoring electricity and telephones and repairing irrigation systems.
Washington needs to augment its efforts to bring security and development to Afghanistan. And it must avoid making similar mistakes in Iraq.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
10-Year Treasury Note Yield Falls to 45-Year Low

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note fell to 3.52 percent yesterday, a 45-year low, after a report of weak retail sales in April capped a string of disappointing economic reports.
 But there are signs elsewhere in the fixed-income markets of growing investor confidence about the economic outlook for the second half of the year. In addition, the decline in yields, which has already pushed home mortgage rates back down near four-decade lows, should inject more life into the economy, economic analysts say. 
 A positive sign in the fixed-income market is the spread, or difference, between the yields on Treasury securities and both investment-grade and high-yield corporate bonds. While not near historic lows, the spread for high-yield bonds is down more than three percentage points from near-record highs last November. The spread on investment-grade corporate bonds just above junk status is down about a percentage point, also from near-record highs. 
The narrowing spread indicates that investors are willing to take on more risk and suggests that their economic outlook is improving.
The yield on junk bonds has dropped to just below 9 percent, according to the KDP Investment Advisors index, from 12.26 percent last September, translating into lower borrowing costs for many companies trying to turn the corner.
"The equivocal economic data is enough to tell a story that the economy is weakening again," said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of ITG/Hoenig. "But I don't believe it. The high-yield market is saying the economy is getting better."
David M. Blitzer, the chief economist at Standard & Poor's, agreed.
"I think in this case the spreads have probably got it right," he said. "The spreads are responding to the economy, and they are saying that the economy is not great but it has not deteriorated lately."
Some economists also contend that the decline in the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note is more of a response to the statement on inflation by Federal Reserve officials on May 6 than slowing economic growth.
That statement led many to believe that the central bank was not worried about inflation at all in the near term and intended to keep interest rates low for a long time to ensure that the economy got back to a path of sustainable growth. Since that statement, the yield on the 10-year note has fallen more than a third of a percentage point, to 3.52 percent.
Some economists also believe that Federal Reserve policy makers have signaled a willingness to cut their benchmark for short-term interest rates further if the economy continues to struggle or if there is a significant decline in inflation. Fed policy makers meet again in June.
"This is definitely help for the economy and it is a major help for borrowers," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan.
One impact of the Fed keeping its short-term benchmark, now at 1.25 percent, low is that longer-term rates will come down. This is called a flattening of the yield curve and is positive for the economy because businesses and homeowners pay these longer-term rates when they borrow.
The flattening can be seen in the recent performance of Treasury yields. Until yesterday, the recent low for yields on both the 10-year note and the 2-year note had come on March 10. Since then, the yield on the 10-year note has fallen to a new low, while the yield on the 2-year note, at 1.38 percent, remains above its March 10 low of 1.33 percent.
Mr. Glassman said there were indications that some companies were actually borrowing for new projects at these lower rates. Home mortgage rates have already slipped again. The national average on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 5.62 percent last week, according to Freddie Mac, just above the 5.61 percent for the week ended March 15, the lowest rates since the 1960's. Because mortgage rates are sensitive to the moves of the yield on 10-year Treasury notes, the rate could fall to a new low this week. The new data is scheduled to be released today.
The dip in rates means that homeowners can still refinance their mortgages, freeing up cash for other spending. Over the last year and a half, refinancing to lower interest rates and to withdraw equity out of one's home has supported consumer spending, which has helped pull the economy out of the recession that is now thought to have concluded at the end of 2001.
The possibility that rates can stay low longer also means less of a threat that rising rates will slow the buying and selling of houses and put downward pressure on home prices. If prices hold steady or rise, consumer confidence could strengthen. 
"You couldn't ask for a more positive financial environment to get the economy going," Mr. Glassman said.
In late trading in the Treasury market yesterday, the price of the 10-year note rose 23/32, to 100 28/32, as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 3.52 percent, from 3.61 percent on Tuesday. Based on monthly data from the Federal Reserve, that is the lowest yield on a security with a 10-year maturity since July 1958.

HEADLINE: Consumer Pullback: Retail Sales Fell 0.1% in April 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Consumers spent a shade less in retail stores and food service outlets in April than in March, according to figures released yesterday by the Commerce Department. Experts attributed the sluggishness to job-related uncertainty and the psychological hangover from the war in Iraq.
 Overall spending fell by 0.1 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis, though sales were still up 2.2 percent since February. 
 "What people are waiting for is to see better economic data -- to see a pick-up primarily in the labor market and to see it reflected in their incomes," said Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the National Retail Federation. "It's a difficult environment, and people are being very cautious." 
Taking out a 2.5 percent rise in sales of autos and parts, retail spending fell 0.9 percent in April -- the biggest drop since September 2001. Lower gasoline prices accounted for more than half that decline, dragging down spending at filling stations by 5.9 percent. But consumers also spent less at clothing shops, where sales fell 3.2 percent, and at department stores, which posted a 1.4 percent drop.
Several analysts said they were expecting a modest rise in sales. In an average month, retail sales besides autos and parts would increase about 0.4 percent.
"We were a bit surprised that they were as weak as they were, and we're sort of on the weaker side of things in general," said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs.
Consumer anxiety may be at the heart of the weakness. Though they have supported the economy through its worst moments in the last two years of recession and uncertain recovery, shoppers may be showing the effects of concerns about their personal well-being.
"They don't feel terribly secure about the future right now because of what's been happening in the recent past," Ms. Wells said. "The war and terrorism was one big factor, and probably won't be entirely gone for a long, long time. The other factor, probably even more important, is their own personal financial situation and their thoughts about how secure their jobs are and how their income will be growing. That's what really drives spending."
The stock market's travails and slow growth in wages, adjusted for changes in prices, could also be holding back spending, said Richard T. Curtin, director of consumer surveys at the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan. Concerns about nest eggs for retirement and earnings in the next few years will cause people to save more, he predicted.
"I'd expect the saving rate to move toward 5 percent by the end of this year, and perhaps 6 percent by the end of next year," Mr. Curtin said. The Commerce Department's most recent measure of the saving rate was 3.6 percent for March.
In a truly tentative economic atmosphere, Ms. Wells said, stores have resorted to marking down prices and kicking off special promotions to entice consumers to come in and spend -- just as the biggest carmakers have since Sept. 11, 2001.
Yet those kinds of sales tactics might not make much of an impression on consumers these days, said Barbara E. Kahn, a professor of marketing at the University of Pennsylvania.
"People adapted to the state of discounting" during the economic slump, she said, "so it was no longer a reason to buy."
Moreover, Mr. McKelvey explained, the shallowness of the recession in 2001 resulted in little pent-up demand for big-ticket items like cars, furniture and appliances. "The problem is, those sectors never really took the hit," he said, "so you can't really look at them as drivers."
Professor Kahn added that some new technologies that might have spurred consumers' demand -- like hard-drive recorders for television and third-generation mobile phones -- have not yet done so to the extent forecast.
Congress looks increasingly likely to pass hundreds of billions of dollars in tax cuts, intended in part as a spark for the economy. But even if the cuts become law, the experts said, the spark may never materialize.
"Obviously, when you reduce people's taxes and free up a little bit of income for them to spend, it can help," Mr. McKelvey said. "But we've never seen the proposals that they're considering to be strongly stimulative in a near-term sense."
Ms. Wells agreed: "I don't expect any immediate positive reaction to that tax cut. I don't see it as a big stimulus in the near term."
More recent indicators than those released by the Commerce Department have included faint hints of better times, however.
"The weekly retail indexes do seem to be getting a little bit better in the transition from late April into early May," Mr. McKelvey said, "but that's a thin read." According to reports from retailers, Ms. Wells added, "there seems to be a bit of a bounceback."

HEADLINE: Gun Makers Not Liable for Violence, Jury Says 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH 

 BODY:
A federal jury in Brooklyn found yesterday that the marketing practices of 45 gun manufacturers and distributors were not responsible for fostering gun violence in minority communities in New York City, a finding that was seen as a victory for the gun industry. 
 The jury reached its verdict in its fourth day of deliberations in a case that drew national attention because the plaintiff, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, gained access to previously sealed government data tracing the sales of guns that may have been used in crimes. 
 The jury's verdict will play only an advisory role in the outcome of the case, in accordance with a ruling by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Both sides will submit written arguments interpreting the jury's verdict within 30 days, and Judge Weinstein will make the final ruling. 
The jury was unable to reach a verdict on about 23 other defendants in the case.
Even if the judge rules against the manufacturers and distributors, the case might be rendered moot by pending federal legislation that would retroactively shield the gun industry from most lawsuits. The bill passed the House of Representatives last month and is now before the Senate.
Elisa Barnes, the N.A.A.C.P.'s chief lawyer in the case, expressed disappointment with the outcome and said the absence of identifiable victims and the complex statistical evidence may have influenced the verdict.
"It's a conceptually very difficult case, and it's very hard to understand what it is we were saying they had done wrong," she said.
Lawrence G. Keane, the vice president and general counsel for the National Shooting Sports Foundation, the firearms industry's trade association, said: "We welcome the advisory jury's common-sense finding that manufacturers and distributors of firearms are not responsible for the criminal misuse of their products."
But before the verdict was released, Mr. Keane had expressed concern that no matter what the jury found, Judge Weinstein, who has a reputation as a liberal, might rule against all 68 defendants.
The verdict followed nearly six weeks of testimony in the case, which was filed in 1999 and followed similar lawsuits by two dozen cities and counties claiming that the practices of the gun industry amount to a public nuisance because they permit guns to fall into the hands of criminals.
Unlike many earlier suits, the N.A.A.C.P.'s suit, brought against 68 defendants, including such industry giants as Smith & Wesson and Glock Inc., does not seek damages for the cost of gun violence. Instead, it seeks an injunction that would create new restrictions on the distribution and marketing of handguns.
During the trial, the association's lawyers argued that the gun industry knows of many ways in which dealers could be monitored to prevent guns from reaching criminals, but has failed to take action.
The gun makers' lawyers countered that the suit was baseless, and that they should not be held responsible for what happens to a gun after it is legally sold.
The association's case relied heavily on a statistical analysis of a registry of guns recovered by law enforcement that is maintained by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and was suppressed for years.
The association's experts testified that certain dealers and manufacturers were far more likely to have their handguns become "crime guns" than others, that some practices by dealers were associated with crime guns, and that if they wanted to, gun makers and distributors could pressure dealers not to engage in those practices.
For example, an economist, Lucy Allen, testified that 1 percent of gun dealers hold multiple dealer licenses at the same address, but that those dealers sold 13 percent of the guns that were later traced to crimes by the A.T.F.
The association also called a former firearms industry lobbyist, Robert A. Ricker, in the first important testimony against the industry by a former insider. 
Lawyers for the gun makers countered the association's experts with their own, who called the association's analytical methods shoddy. 
The association's data-heavy approach may have been dictated in part by the outcome of a 1999 case in which Ms. Barnes, appearing before Judge Weinstein, won a landmark verdict against gun makers on behalf of a group of shooting victims. That verdict was later overturned by an appeals court that found the association had not adequately linked industry marketing practices to gun violence. 
In closing statements, the association's lawyers struggled to humanize their case, naming an N.A.A.C.P. member who was afraid to leave her house at night because of the danger of being shot.
But the link between the gun makers' practices and harm to association's members was not clear enough, said one juror, Harold Renault, 56. 
"There wasn't enough concrete evidence," he said after the verdict was released, adding that the association's case would have been stronger if the relatives of crime victims had testified.
