HEADLINE: American Air Again Warns Of Bankruptcy 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
American Airlines said yesterday in a securities filing that it might have to file for bankruptcy protection from creditors despite having extracted nearly $4 billion in annual cost cuts.
 The glum warning came on the same day that American, the world's largest airline, said that it had obtained more than $175 million in annual concessions from more than 100 suppliers, vendors and aircraft lessors. The airline said it would give those companies three million shares of common stock in AMR, its parent. 
 Those savings mean American is near to achieving the $4 billion in annual concessions it said it needed to return to profitability. The largest chunk comes from $1.8 billion in annual labor savings, most from unionized workers. American won the union agreements last month after a contentious voting process during which Donald J. Carty, the former chief executive, resigned over issues of compensation. 
As part of its labor cost cuts, American told its flight attendants' union on Wednesday that it would lay off more than 3,100 flight attendants on July 1, leaving 19,600 on the payroll.
Tara Baten, a spokeswoman for American, said Gerard J. Arpey, the new chief executive, and other managers were working to obtain still more savings from vendors and suppliers. American is $25 million short of its $4 billion goal.
But the company clearly has doubts that even the $4 billion in annual savings will help it avert bankruptcy. In the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American said that "the company may nonetheless need to initiate a filing under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code because its financial condition will remain weak and its prospects uncertain."
"Among other things," the securities filing said, "the following factors have had and/or may have a negative impact on the company's business and financial results: the continued weakness of the U.S. economy; the residual effects of the war in Iraq; the fear of another terrorist attack; the SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) outbreak; the inability of the company to satisfy the liquidity requirements or other covenants in certain of its credit arrangements"; and "the inability of the company to access the capital markets for additional financing."
Though domestic passenger traffic has shown slight year-to-year growth in recent weeks, international traffic remains weak, according to statistics from the Air Transport Association.
Jim Corridore, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, said American's self-assessment was accurate, given the bleak travel climate.
"My position for some time is, even after they got the employee concessions, they're still not out of the woods," Mr. Corridore said.
"Their past losses have been such over the past few years that I fear they won't be able to survive until the industry turns up again," he added. "I don't know if they can survive until 2005."
In April, AMR reported a first-quarter loss of $1.04 billion. It lost a total of nearly $5.2 billion in 2001 and 2002.
John Ward, the president of the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, said in a message on the union's Web site that the round of layoffs in July meant American would have cut more than 6,000 flight attendants from its payroll since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
"The morale is, as expected, pretty awful," Mr. Ward wrote.
If morale among workers continues to deteriorate, then that could present serious problems for American, industry experts said. Disaffected workers could affect service, causing travelers to switch to other airlines.
In the summer of 2000, for example, the pilots at United Airlines, a unit of UAL, refused to work overtime -- what the company called a work slowdown -- because the pilots felt threatened by United's bid to merge with US Airways.
Citing a recent improvement in bookings, United said yesterday that it would restore 162 daily flights next month.
The airline is also recalling 1,527 laid-off flight attendants for June, the flight attendants' union said on its Web site. United confirmed the recall of flight attendants.

HEADLINE: U.S. Moves to Allow Trading Of Radio Spectrum Licenses 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
The government took the first steps today to permit companies to lease and trade radio spectrum licenses, a move that could result in improved service for the nation's millions of users of cellphones and other wireless devices. 
 By a vote of 4 to 1, the Federal Communications Commission removed the impediments for leasing such licenses, making it more economically efficient for big and small wireless companies to gain access to spectrum licenses held by others. That should help them patch the holes in their networks that create cellphone dead spots, without having to make big capital investments. 
 The move followed heavy lobbying by the largest wireless carriers, including AT&T, Verizon and Cingular, as well as players on Wall Street like Cantor Fitzgerald that are hoping to serve as brokers or clearinghouses in the creation of a secondary market for swapping licenses. 
Officials and industry analysts say the hope is that by allowing license holders to lease slivers of the spectrum that are currently underused, consumers will benefit from reduced instances of cellphone calls being dropped. More efficient use of the spectrum would make it easier to connect to the Internet with hand-held computers in crowded areas where the spectrum available is inadequate to move data and it should help extend wireless services in rural areas that are underserved.
The decision to allow companies to transfer portions of the spectrum they do not use promises to reshape the economics of the market. It will also change the longstanding federal framework that regulates the holders of spectrum licenses. 
The commission extinguished a 40-year-old rule that had the effect of requiring the holder of a spectrum license to also control the physical infrastructure needed to use that piece of the spectrum -- the antenna, the transmitter and the employees who run the operation. The rule was intended to ensure that the license holder be responsible for fixing signal interference and other problems. 
Under the new rules, the holder of a license who is not making use of the spectrum will be able to lease it to another company that would provide the equipment and personnel.
"Today's action is one of the most important spectrum reform decisions by this commission in the last decade," said Michael K. Powell, chairman of the commission, in a joint statement with another commissioner, Kevin J. Martin. "For years, the commission has rhetorically praised the concept and possibilities created by secondary markets in spectrum. Today that rhetoric turns into reality."
"Our decision signals a new day of increased spectrum access and improved services for consumers," they added.
Telecommunications industry executives were similarly pleased.
"Permitting secondary markets for spectrum will deliver to carriers improved access to the airwaves, increasing their flexibility and bringing down their costs, which should ultimately result in lower prices for consumers," said Tom Wheeler, president of the industry's main trade group, the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association. "Football teams aren't done after draft day. They continue to meet their changing needs through trades and late-season acquisitions. Wireless carriers deserve, and will now receive, similar flexibility." 
Officials have provided a variety of examples of how a commodities market in the spectrum would work, including the following:
*Nationwide cellphone companies would be able to lease pieces of the spectrum in different regions of the country depending on the available supply and on customer demand. 
*News organizations covering political conventions or the Olympics, for example, would be able to buy contracts to use a piece of the spectrum during the event to give them greater capacity to beam pictures, sound and data.
*An airport with congested airwaves from air-traffic transmissions and cellphone use would be able to lease a piece of the spectrum from other spectrum holders that are not using their space during peak hours.
With the proliferation of wireless communications, including growth in wireless browsing of the Internet, an expanding group of companies has been clamoring for scarce space on portions of the spectrum.
But federal regulations have long impeded the ability of holders to sell or lease licenses. A 1963 F.C.C. decision called Intermountain Microwave linked the license to the requirement that each holder also control the transmission equipment. 
Three years ago, William E. Kennard, then chairman of the commission, proposed altering the rules and allowing the formation of a secondary market for spectrum licenses in response to increasing complaints from phone companies and others that they did not have enough space on the spectrum. 
In reconsidering the Intermountain case, the agency found a host of problems that prevented the owner of a license from lending it. In particular, it was not clear which company in such a transaction ought to be held responsible for problems like signal interference.
The commission said today that it had resolved that issue. A company can become what officials call a lease manager and provide short-term access to the spectrum. In those circumstances, the license holder would remain responsible for complying with rules and would be liable for any interference problems.
For long-term transfers, a company could turn over control of the license along with the responsibilities of complying with the regulations. That would require the approval of the commission, although officials emphasized today that they would streamline the process.
One commissioner, Michael J. Copps, dissented. He said the agency did not have the authority under the Communications Act of 1934 to alter the rules in such a way.

HEADLINE: Restless Koreans, Stifled at Home, Head Overseas 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
Jeong SeungKeun's apartment sits on a high floor of a recently built skyscraper, affording a fantastic view of the city. Modern art hangs on the walls. Fancy exercise equipment sits tucked away in a corner.
 Indeed, just about everything in Mr. Jeong's home speaks of a successful life, from the elegant clothes worn by his wife, who attentively oversees their two children's homework, down to the Calloway golf bag propped up by the door, ready for an early morning outing. 
 For all of his comfort, however, Mr. Jeong, a 43-year-old civil engineer, wants out. Like hundreds of other high-achieving South Koreans each year, he has decided to emigrate to the United States, where he figures his family's life, if not necessarily richer, will be far more enriching in personal terms. 
"I've walked an elite path all of my life in Korea, and it would be easy to spend the rest of our lives here," said Mr. Jeong, who is a managing director at one of South Korea's major international construction firms. "But the United States is the center of the world these days, the country with the most to offer. We have a saying, if you want to meet the tiger, you have to enter its cave, and I want our children to grow up according to American standards."
The profile of those who emigrate from South Korea has changed significantly in less than a generation, a shift that reflects the country's dizzying economic rise.
In the 1970's and 80's most South Koreans who left their country were from the lower middle class and went abroad because they thought that was the only way they could improve their economic status. Once in the United States, they often founded mom-and-pop grocery stores in depressed urban neighborhoods, working endless hours, sacrificing themselves for the education of their children.
Now, South Korea's economic takeoff and democratization, which began in the 1980's, have created widespread opportunity and hope. Fewer people are seeking their fortunes abroad -- and those who do increasingly tend to be among the most successful, those who find that even the newly affluent and open South Korea cannot match their ambitions.
In 1980, 29,572 South Koreans were issued immigration visas to the United States; the number last year was just 6,696. 
"Up until the early 1990's, the push factor out of Korea was much more important than the pull factor from the United States," said Bernard Alter, the consul general at the American Embassy in Seoul, adding that immigration to the United States has sharply declined. "Levels are probably one-fifth of what they were in the 1980's, but proportionally, the investor category has become much more important."
High achievers of the upper middle class who leave today often do so with $250,000 or more in savings. Their reasons include a yearning for the wide-open spaces not found in South Korea, one of the most densely populated countries, and an itch for more professional stimulation.
Better education for children remains another huge part of the equation, although in these cases the switch is often from the best that South Korea has to offer to elite American schooling. South Koreans like the Jeong family say they expect that in the United States their children will learn things like individuality and problem-solving that they feel are missing back home.
"My daughter, who is 11, has to work until 11 p.m. every night just to finish her homework," said Mr. Jeong's 39-year-old wife, Kyung Woon, who said she eagerly looked forward to their move to the Seattle area later this year.
"Things are so competitive in Korea there isno time for children to play," she said. "In America, she will be able to get a good education and relax sometimes, which makes you well-rounded.
"Besides, I think there is more fresh air there." 
Generally, American consular officials say, the United States is happy to receive well-heeled immigrants like the Jeongs, who will be entering on investor visas, which, among other qualifications, generally require an investment of more than $100,000 in a business in the United States. The Jeongs' plans include investing immediately in several small retail store franchises, to develop a stream of income until Mr. Jeong can find work in his own profession again.
The Jeongs are arranging their relocation, including their American visas, through an emigration service run by Kang Young Ho, the chief executive officer and founder of the Nammi Emigration Corporation, a pioneer 13 years ago in a field that has now grown crowded with international relocation services for this country's upper middle class.
"I myself emigrated to Canada in 1971, with my wife and son, and $200 in my pocket," said Mr. Kang, a voluble man with a loud laugh. "Everybody was like that back then."
Asked what motive for moving is most frequently cited by his clients, without hesitating Mr. Kang, whose company relocates about 50 families to the United States and 200 to Canada each year, said English-language education.
"Before, people were going to make money and survive, but now it is to raise their children in English," Mr. Kang said. "We are one of the worst countries in the world for English education. Even our English teachers can't speak English."
The consolidation of the English language's place as an indispensable tool in business and many other fields, in the 1990's, coincided with the most profound period in South Korea's economic transformation.
"The people who hire my services think of $100,000 as peanuts," Mr. Kang said. "They are doctors, professionals, civil servants, and most of them made a killing with the explosion of real estate values."
As upscale emigration has become more and more popular in South Korea, recently, many professionals have begun to eschew the services of companies like Mr. Kang's, which cost $15,000 or more, pooling information, both tactical and practical. Sometimes they do business together in their new country of adoption.
Kim Jong Kap, a 37-year-old manager with the Industrial Bank of Korea, banded together in an online group with about 30 other South Korean accountants who have passed the accreditation test of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and are seeking to emigrate and set up businesses in the United States.
Mr. Kim, whose wife, a cancer researcher at Columbia, lives with their two small children, plans to join them in August. He invited three other men he had never met in person, all C.P.A.'s who have been talking up American business ventures online for weeks, to meet a foreign journalist at a downtown hotel.
"There's nothing bad about Korea, but the company I work for doesn't really have a lot to teach me anymore," Mr. Kim said. "We view America as the frontier, and I want to experience it."
Kim Song Ho, his online acquaintance, plans to move to the United States this summer too, even though this month he will marry a women with a big job -- and salary -- at the Korea Stock Exchange. Mr. Kim is not sure yet whether he wants to set himself up in Los Angeles, Chicago or Atlanta. Whichever he chooses, at least for now his soon-to-be wife, will stay behind.
"I know that in America I'll be rewarded for the amount of work I do, and not just designated to a position and stuck there," Mr. Kim said. "My fiancee is behind me all the way. Even if I have to struggle, she says, she wants me to have the reward of being a self-made man."

HEADLINE: Slicing and Dicing: Tired Senators Achieve Goal, to Pass a Tax Bill, Any Tax Bill 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
When the Senate began to talk last month about cutting taxes, the goals set out by Republicans were clear and high-minded: End the double taxation on dividends Republicans said they were seeking. Create jobs through business investment. Reduce the tax burden on two-income families.
 But by tonight, as weary senators finally approved their oddly shaped tax cut, the goal had shrunk to something very different: Pass a tax bill, any tax bill, and get it to a conference with the House where the real work would begin. 
 Theoretically, the point of a tax reduction is to revive a stagnant economy. But even the most conservative senators said they barely recognized that original objective in the bill they passed tonight, after it had been sliced, diced and rearranged to fit the needs of the many swing senators whose votes were necessary for passage.
"I think there's a great question of exactly what we're passing today," said Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican who strongly supports the president's drive for widespread tax reduction. "But here in the Senate, with the way things are, we just had to pass something out of here and get it to conference. Hopefully there we can get back to the idea of stimulating the economy."
The Senate bill would not end the double taxation of dividends that Mr. Bush has crusaded for across the country. It would halve the dividend tax this year, then stop it for three years, at which point it would come back again. This maneuver, known as a sunset, was necessary to satisfy senators who said the tax cut could not cost more than $350 billion, less than half of President Bush's original request. Supporters say they hope that after the cut expires in 2007, they can reinstate it.
The bill raises the taxes of Americans working abroad, to stay within the $350 billion shoebox, and reduces only slightly the so-called marriage penalty on two-income couples. To placate centrist senators concerned about the huge budget gaps in the states, the bill would provide $20 billion in aid to state and local governments.
All of these techniques have had the unusual effect of uniting House conservatives and Senate Democrats in ridiculing the final product, which seemed to generate no parental pride tonight. Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a Democrat who supported the Bush tax cut in 2001, said today's bill "set a new standard for gimmicks," and predicted that it would not improve in conference.
"To get the votes, they had to resort to gimmickry to sunset things that they always argued should never be sunsetted," Mr. Breaux said. "I mean, we're cutting the dividend tax for three years and then trying to extend it every year? No one thinks that's a good idea."
Another lawmaker who says he considers the bill a bad idea is House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, who today described the plan as an "all of a sudden you see it, and now you don't" idea.
"If the dividend tax is 50 percent and then nothing, and all of a sudden it is back to 100 percent or whatever it is, my feeling is that it does not solve the problem," Mr. Hastert said, also expressing hope that things would be worked out in conference. By contrast, he said, the House had passed "a very good bill," but he did not mention that his chamber's bill also sunsets a half-dozen major provisions.
The off-again-on-again dividend tax cut was included at the insistence of the White House, Republican officials said. The president has invested time and prestige in the idea that the dividend tax must be eliminated completely because its underlying premise -- taxing corporate profits twice -- is wrong at a fundamental, almost moral level. By having it in the bill even in a truncated form, administration officials argued, there was a greater chance that something similar would appear in the conference agreement.
But the very act of eliminating the tax and then restoring it in 2007 has stunned and angered the economic conservatives who would normally be the president's natural allies on the bill. Several said it would not change business behavior and investment, because no manager could know for certain whether Congress would bring it back after it expired.
"I can understand the political reasons why they put it in that way, but it's such an incredibly bad idea," said Norbert Michel, a tax policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group in Washington. "Phasing it in and then sunsetting it so quickly will eliminate all the economic benefit. And then when it doesn't work, your enemies will just say it produced no growth, so why should we pass it again."
Kevin A. Hassett, resident scholar at the pro-business American Enterprise Institute, called the idea bizarre and "one of the most patently absurd tax policies ever proposed."
With the Senate so closely divided, however, political concerns tend to trump fiscal ones. Ben Nelson of Nebraska, one of two Democratic senators who supported the final plan, spoke for many in the chamber today when he said an idea was not a gimmick "if it lets you do the best you can with what you've got." 
Mr. Brownback said many senators were relieved that a tax bill passed at all.
"Getting anything through is a success," he said. "Of course, I realize that in the Senate our standards of success are a bit lower than in other places."

HEADLINE: BUDGETS IN CRISIS: OVERVIEW; 
STATE LEGISLATURE OVERRIDES PATAKI ON BUDGET VETOES

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 15 

 BODY:
For the first time in two decades, New York's Legislature overrode a governor's vetoes of its spending plan today. The lawmakers revived a budget that increases state taxes to restore billions of dollars in spending on schools, hospitals, nursing homes and localities.
 Moving deliberately and in a coordinated fashion rarely seen in Albany, both Republicans and Democrats rolled over George E. Pataki, the three-term Republican governor, who seemed resigned to losing the biggest governing battle of his career. 
 Both chambers of the Legislature moved with far greater speed than even they had expected, engaging in very little debate. The only support for the governor came from the hard-line conservative Republicans in the Assembly, who said the budget was financially unsound. 
The process began shortly after 11 a.m. The Democratic Assembly finished overriding all 119 vetoes by 3:26 p.m. The Republican Senate, which had started the process later, finished soon afterward, passing all 119 overrides unanimously. 
Less than 20 hours after Governor Pataki had signed the scores of vetoes with much fanfare, they were cast aside.
But the governor continued to act in defiance: Later in the day, he announced that he would veto a $1.8 billion assistance package that the Legislature had passed for New York City. That set the stage for another override fight in the Legislature, which has until the end of its session in June to act.
By enacting tax increases that a governor had vetoed, the Legislature revealed a boldness that many in Albany said they could not remember seeing before. The two houses had not turned back a veto of a spending plan since 1982, when Hugh L. Carey was governor.
The lawmakers' swift action demonstrated that a legislative body known for its plodding ways and entrenched partisan politics could exert a different kind of influence on state government.
The process departed from the usual custom in Albany of governing by three men in a room: Mr. Pataki; Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader; and Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly speaker, who normally decide issues and get their conferences to rubber-stamp them.
Mr. Pataki acknowledged early in the day that he did not have the votes to prevail. "This is a sad day for New Yorkers," said the governor, speaking after ceremonies this morning honoring the state police. "The Legislature is passing, over my vetoes, the largest tax increase in the state's history." Legislators vigorously dispute that assertion.
The governor, as he has all week, seemed to be looking beyond the moment, perhaps setting up his argument for next year. He said the Legislature's $92.8 billion budget was unbalanced, would worsen the state's financial crisis, the worst since the Great Depression, and create deficits in future years. "I knew that it was going to be a very difficult fight to prevent the override, but the vetoes were purely a matter of principle," Mr. Pataki said.
The governor said he would carry out the parts of the budget that his lawyers believe are constitutional. He said he would ensure that school districts receive their state aid, even though he believed that part of the budget was unconstitutional.
He said he had not decided yet whether to put in place other large appropriations he says were improperly drafted by the Legislature and which he considers unconstitutional. He also would not say whether he would take the Legislature to court, as he did in 1998 and 2001, to ask a judge to nullify much of the budget.
By leaving the possibility of lawsuits open, he left an air of uncertainty over a budget that appeared to be all but resolved, more than 40 days late but still earlier than in many other years. The state has missed the April 1 budget deadline every year for 19 years in a row.
Mr. Silver characterized the day's mood as solemn. Sitting in his office after the overrides, he munched on pretzels and watched the governor's news conference on television.
Mr. Silver said that he wished the governor had been more involved in the final budget deal, but that the overrides showed that "there is a safety mechanism when there is a failure of agreement between the three parties." He added, "The framers of the Constitution actually had this circumstance in mind, and we went right through it the way they had it in mind."
On the Republican side, in the Senate, the overrides were seen by many as a breakdown of the governor's influence over his own party.
Still, Mr. Bruno said the legislative victory was not a political breach with Mr. Pataki. Rather, he said, it represented the senators' determination to carry out the will of their constituents, who across the state had expressed fears that the governor's proposed cuts would push local property taxes up, close hospitals and cause teacher layoffs.
"The two-thirds majority felt that they were right, and they overrode all of the vetoes, and that is now the budget for the people here in New York State," Mr. Bruno said. He said it was time to move on and heal whatever hurt remained.
"Two-thirds of the Legislature voting, again, unanimously in the Senate on every issue ought to make some statement," he said. "And I would think the governor would take that into consideration as he contemplates how he moves forward."
The state's $11.5 billion deficit and its dire fiscal situation set off the battle that led to the veto-override showdown, with the two sides disagreeing on how to bridge the shortfall. The governor wanted to borrow and cut local assistance. The Legislature wanted to raise sales and personal income taxes, borrow and restore local aid.
The lawmakers received one bit of positive news today: The United States Senate was set to pass a tax-cut bill that included a provision that would provide $20 billion over two years to states and localities. Half the money would be set aside to bail out states and localities facing the worst financial problems in decades; the rest would help them cover mounting Medicaid costs.
New York State stands to receive about $2.2 billion, with as much as $460 million going to New York City, according to Senator Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat who was one of the authors of the aid package for states. The package still needs approval by the House.
Some Republicans in the State Senate said they resented what they saw as Governor Pataki's withdrawal from the process. Senator Dale M. Volker, a Republican from Depew, in western New York, said Mr. Pataki did not propose Medicaid reform in his budget, but then complained that the Legislature had failed to enact such reforms.
"I think that the governor, in my opinion, made it an institutional thing," Mr. Volker said. "And when the members saw that they felt it was an institutional thing, some of them got mad."
He said history showed that governors who challenge the entire Legislature rarely win. "If you challenge the institution, you're going to be in trouble," he said.
Over recent days, fiscal purists said that both the Legislature's and the governor's budget plans were flawed, mainly because each relied on $4.2 billion in borrowing to pay for day-to-day operating costs, which would lead to deficits in later years.
Some lawmakers said that point was not lost on them. One, Assemblyman William L. Parment, Democrat of Jamestown, said that the decision to override was a difficult one, but that he decided to vote for the overrides in part because he thought that the Legislature's budget was fairer to the poor and put less burden on property taxes.
"The governor is calling this a fiscal train wreck," Mr. Parment said, repeating an idea he had told a television reporter. "I would point out, though, that the governor was the chief engineer. He put the train on the track, opened the throttle wide open, then jumped from the cab and now is standing on the side of the tracks calling, 'Train wreck!' Well, of course it's a train wreck. There's no engineer in the cab."
Others said it was a simple decision of not wanting to accept the governor's cuts to education and Medicaid, which they said would drive up property taxes in localities.
Paul A. Tokasz, a Democratic assemblyman from Cheektowaga, in western New York, said the Cleveland Hill school district has indicated that its property tax levy would increase by 19 percent under the governor's proposal, compared with 4 percent under the legislative proposal.
"By not doing state aid to suburban school districts, the governor is saying, 'Property taxpayers, you pay the bill,' " Mr. Tokasz said. "Property taxes are the most regressive way we can pay for services."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
With Quick Approval, Moreno Buys Angels From Disney

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
For $182.5 million, Arturo Moreno bought a baseball team yesterday. Why did he want to do that in these perilous times both for the economy and baseball?
 "I guess I look at baseball as something that historically has been here for a long time," Moreno said after other owners unanimously approved him as the new owner of the Anaheim Angels, the defending World Series champions. "I think it's going to be here for a long time. It's a fun thing. It's a kids' game. I think long-term the balance of entertainment will always lean toward baseball. I think it's just part of our culture." 
 Moreno, 56, was rewarded for his faith in baseball by gaining rapid approval by his new partners.
"This sale went through the ownership committee, executive council and ownership as fast as anything I've ever seen in all my years in baseball," Commissioner Bud Selig said at an unusually brief news conference at baseball's Manhattan headquarters. 
Most often the approval process takes many months. In this instance, Moreno was the sole buyer, and he was paying cash. "He's what you hope you're going to get when you get an owner," Selig said.
Both Selig and Moreno played down the fact that Moreno is the first Hispanic, or even member of a minority group, to buy controlling interest in a Major League Baseball team. There's even some question whether Moreno can be considered a minority-group member. He is of Mexican descent, but as he said: "I'm fourth-generation American. First thing is I'm an American" He was born and raised in Tucson and has homes in Phoenix and Southern California.
"I'm proud of being a Mexican-American, but as far as being a first minority," he added, he didn't place any significance on that. "I think we're all Americans. Most of us are immigrants from someplace, and I think we always try to do our best being an American." 
Moreno bought the Angels from the Walt Disney Company, which paid Gene Autry, the original owner, $130 million for the team in a two-stage transaction. Disney bought 25 percent and assumed control in 1996, then added the rest after Autry died in 1998. Disney spent $100 million for a stadium renovation and has said it has lost $100 million on the team during its ownership. 
The Angels succeeded in doing under Disney what Autry yearned for in vain -- win the World Series. They never even reached the World Series in Autry's 38-year ownership. They reached it and won it as the American League wild-card team last year.
"I think they have good people," Moreno said when asked if he planned changes. "Obviously they won a world championship. For me, it's a learning process. I'm going to try to sit back and listen. I've been very successful surrounding myself with good people and keeping those people in place and over a period of time try to step up to the plate."
But, Moreno added, he would be involved with the operation of the team on a day-to-day basis. 
Moreno sold his outdoor advertising company in 1999 for more than $8 billion. He sold his 5 percent ownership of the Arizona Diamondbacks in November.
The completion of the sale of the Angels leaves the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Atlanta Braves, the Minnesota Twins and the Montreal Expos as teams available for purchase. Among those teams, the Dodgers are most actively in play.
Malcolm Glazer, owner of the National Football League's Super Bowl champion Tampa Bay Buccaneers, is the leading contender to buy the Dodgers, whose owner, the Fox Group, wants to get at least $350 million for the team it paid $311 million for in 1998. Glazer and his family are considered the most likely buyers because other prospective purchasers, including the Dave Checketts group, have dropped out.
The N.F.L. has a cross-ownership policy that could ordinarily block Glazer's ownership of the Dodgers, but Commissioner Paul Tagliabue has said a deal could be approved if the Glazers use independent resources and financing and have a management that is separate from that of the Buccaneers.

HEADLINE: If You Want to Lead the Fed In New York, Raise Your Hand 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Does anyone want to be president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York? Only a month before the planned departure of the current president, William J. McDonough, several top candidates for the job have apparently pulled out of the running.
 Yesterday, Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said he did not want to assume the post after Mr. McDonough leaves for Washington to become chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. 
 "I am not interested in the job," Mr. Ferguson said in a statement relayed by a spokeswoman. "I am extremely happy in the job I'm doing here in Washington." 
Attention shifted to Mr. Ferguson and a few other well-known names in economics and finance after two former leading candidates for Mr. McDonough's position appeared to drop out.
"I would have thought that Roger would be a good choice as someone who has been on the outside and on the inside, and has the respect that's needed," said Stephen G. Cecchetti, a professor of economics at Ohio State University and former director of research at the New York Fed. Mr. Cecchetti had not been informed of Mr. Ferguson's decision at the time he was interviewed.
In the last few days, The Washington Post and news wires reported that Peter R. Fisher and Stanley Fischer were no longer in contention.
Mr. Fisher, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, was widely regarded as a shoo-in for the New York Fed's presidency, thanks in part to his role in coordinating the bailout of Long-Term Capital Management, a troubled hedge fund linked to several big banks, in 1998.
A few weeks ago, however, a buzz began to build around Stanley Fischer, a vice chairman of Citigroup who had been the chief economist of the World Bank and second in command at the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Fischer declined to comment on the search process when reached by phone on Wednesday evening.
Mr. Fisher could not be reached for comment, though a person close to him said he had removed himself from consideration.
The president of the New York Fed acts as vice chairman of the Federal Open Market Committee, which makes decisions about monetary policy.
"The job is much more powerful than the public understands," said Anthony M. Solomon, a former president of the New York Fed and current chairman of the executive committee at the Institute for International Economics.
In addition to making the securities trades that carry out monetary policy, Mr. Solomon said, "probably two-thirds of the U.S. government's bond sales are in the New York federal district, and a great number of the financial transactions in the country are in the New York federal district."
Other names that have circulated on Wall Street and in Washington include William Poole, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis; Stephen Friedman, the White House's top economic adviser; and Martin S. Feldstein, a professor of economics at Harvard University who is also president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, a nonpartisan group.
Mr. Poole was not available for comment yesterday.
Professor Feldstein had been held out as a successor to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, before President Bush declared his intent to reappoint Mr. Greenspan. Professor Feldstein was out of the country yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
A senior Wall Street economist said he considered Professor Feldstein a candidate, "although I really think he wants Greenspan's job." The economist, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that David H. Komansky, a former chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch, might also be a good choice. "Having somebody who's involved in the marketplace has its advantages," he said.
If no one is appointed to succeed Mr. McDonough before he leaves in mid-June, the first vice president, Jamie B. Stewart Jr., will assume the president's responsibilities, said Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the New York Fed. Mr. Bakstansky said Mr. Stewart was not granting interviews.

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Weekender Bridgewater, Conn.

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH MAKER 

 BODY:
"IT's delicious," said Cathleen P. Black, president of Hearst Magazines, who bought a 1790 farmhouse in Bridgewater for $1.3 million in 1997 and has spent every possible weekend there with her family since. "I look out at the horses and the baby cows in the fields across the road, and just say 'ahhh.' You come to Bridgewater and just completely chill out and calm down."
 Back in the 1980's, weekenders were virtually unheard of in Bridgewater. Now, drawn by the country serenity, they make up about a third of the residents, according to the town clerk. 
 Bridgewater is determined to retain its character. The vigilance of both residents and public officials, most notably William Stuart, who has been the first selectman for 22 years, have kept it a quiet country town of stately Victorian and Colonial houses -- many of them now worth millions of dollars -- and sprawling farmsteads. 
"Developers lose completely here," said Rebecca Devine, a third-generation Bridgewater native. "I think most of them know enough to not even bother trying."
Mr. Stuart is especially protective of the town. "We're blowing up the bridge over Lake Lillinonah," he said with a wink, speaking of the main entrance to town, "and we're posting 'Keep Out' signs everywhere else."

The Scene
"We have a lot of celebrities here, but nobody bothers them," said Sandra Neary, director of the town's public library. "They just sort of blend right in with everyone else."
At the Bridgewater Village Store, built in 1899 and now stocked with specialty coffees, chocolates, deli meals and fresh flowers, longtime farming families line up for coffee and scones with celebrities like Mia Farrow, or the writers William and Susan Kinsolving, or Mike Nichols and Diane Sawyer, who have sold their home here but still own a large Arabian horse farm in town.
Susie Gharib, a co-anchor of the "Nightly Business Report" on public television, and her husband, the venture capitalist Fred Nazem, may have pioneered the weekender movement in Bridgewater. They bought a dilapidated 1775 house 22 years ago and have transformed the property into a luxurious estate worth millions. They are happy that Bridgewater has no "high-pressure social scene," as Ms. Gharib puts it. "Here, you can go around in a baseball cap and jeans and feel just right," she said.
Many wealthy New Yorkers board their horses at Shallow Brook Farm, owned by Mr. Stuart, and are members of the Fairfield County Hounds, a cross-country riding club associated with the farm.
Despite the name, it is not a hunt club. "We don't kill foxes," said one member, John Hennigan, who escapes to Bridgewater from Rye every weekend. "It's all about riding."
Community events flourish. In October, contestants rig contraptions to launch pumpkins in the pumpkin catapult party, open to everyone from Bridgewater and neighboring Roxbury. In the ridiculously entertaining Tractor Parade, held on Labor Day weekend, fancifully decorated tractors parade down Main Street and Mr. Stuart holds a barbecue at his house, open to all residents. In August, many of the town's residents volunteer in some way, from baking pies to selling tickets to spinning the cake wheel, at the Bridgewater Fair, a large and deliberately old-fashioned country fair and the main source of revenue for the fire department.

Pros
Bridgewater has been unusually successful in preserving open space, mainly through zoning regulations that require four-acre lots for new houses in most of the town. Wealthy residents have also bought up farm land and deeded it to land trusts, and many have preserved their own property through conservation easements.
Stuart Saft, a commercial real estate lawyer in Manhattan, and his wife, Stephanie, live on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and own a weekend home on Lake Lillinonah in Bridgewater. "This lake is 16 miles long and there are maybe 40 houses on it," Mr. Saft said. "It's totally pristine because so much of it is preserved in land trusts."
There are two points of public access on the lake -- a state-owned boat launch on Route 133 and a town park tucked away down a quiet lane.
With residents well able to pay their town taxes, Bridgewater has good services, including highly efficient road maintenance. "You might recall we had a bit of snow this year?" Mr. Saft asked. "Well, not once did we have a problem getting down our road. It was plowed constantly."
A 42-acre recreation area in the center of town has ball fields, playgrounds, tennis and basketball courts, bike paths and a riding ring. Another 26-acres across the street is for hiking and other recreation. 
Bridgewater also has a long history of generous gifts from citizens, including large sums of money for public land, the library, town hall renovations and the Bridgewater Scholarship Fund, which helps local students with college costs.
"There's a great sense of community here, and everyone treats each other with enormous kindness and respect," Mrs. Saft said.

Cons
Bridgewater has the distinction of being one of only two dry towns in Connecticut, so there are no liquor stores, restaurants or nightclubs. The only two retail businesses in town are the Village Store and a gas station with a convenience shop. The nearest grocery store is about seven miles away.
There is a bank, but no doctors or hospitals. There are no water or sewer lines. Residents must have their own wells and septic tanks.
The price of admission to Bridgewater is high. The town's exclusivity is reinforced not only by stringent zoning, but by high real estate prices.

Real Estate Market
Housing prices have steadily soared over the last two decades. Carolyn Klemm, an agent at Klemm Real Estate in nearby Washington, Conn. (860-868-7313), said she helped an owner sell a three-bedroom home on 10 acres with a pond and guesthouse for $325,000 in 1985 and then represented a new owner who sold the same house this year for $1.2 million. Another property that she handled, an 1820 farmhouse on 17 acres with a pool, went for $300,000 in the late 1980's and is now on the market for $875,000.
"I do think you'll see prices leveling off for a while, because of the war and the economy," Ms. Klemm said.
This week, Joy Luongo, regional manager of William Raveis Real Estate in Washington (860-868-0511), was listing a contemporary home on five acres with a pond and a brook, Spanish marble floors and a Japanese spa made of stone that was blasted from the property, for $2.25 million. 
Altogether the Multiple Listing Service had 23 properties available in Bridgewater this week, ranging from a simple 1,125-square-foot cottage for $254,000 to a 3,330-square-foot lakefront home with a pool and guesthouse on 34 acres for $2.6 million.

LAY OF THE LAND
A Pricey Ticket, But a Stellar Show

POPULATION -- 1,824.
SIZE -- 16.3 square miles.
NUMBER OF HOMES -- 773.
MEDIAN HOUSE PRICE -- Realtors estimate $400,000, but for the 23 properties on the market this week, the median asking price is $850,000.
RECENT SALES -- Within the last three months, a 2,212-square-foot, three-bedroom, three-and-a-half bathroom ranch on four acres with designer kitchen, tumbled marble baths, wide board cherry floors and a fireplace sold for $490,000 after two months on the market; a three-bedroom Colonial on 10 acres with a pond and guesthouse sold for $1.2 million after three months on the market; and a 4,000- square-foot, four-bedroom Victorian house with two-and-a-half baths and two fireplaces sold for $1.8 million after eight months on the market.
DISTANCE FROM NEW YORK -- 70 miles.
TRAVEL TIME -- In light traffic, about one hour and 15 minutes.
GETTING THERE -- From Manhattan, go north on the Henry Hudson Parkway, which becomes the Saw Mill River Parkway. Continue to Interstate 684 North. Take Exit 9E to Interstate 84, east toward Danbury. Get off at Exit 7 (Brookfield/New Milford) and continue for 4.5 miles to the end of the expressway. Turn right onto Route 202, which is also Federal Road, and right again at the stoplight onto Route 25 toward Brookfield Center. At the next light, turn left onto Route 133 toward Bridgewater.
WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING -- There is no lodging in Bridgewater. In neighboring New Milford, the Homestead Inn (5 Elm Street, 860-354-4080) has 15 rooms with doubles rates from $102 to $135 and the Heritage Inn (34 Bridge Street, 860-354-8883) has 20 rooms with doubles for $95 to $125. Both include breakfast.

HEADLINE: As Ethics Panel Raises Its Profile, Chairman Warns of Budget Cuts 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Unlike, say, that of the Department of Sanitation, the work of the Conflicts of Interest Board goes largely unnoticed by most New Yorkers. The board members spend much of their time advising city employees on things like what to do when they marry someone with a stock portfolio full of companies doing business with the city, or whether it is acceptable to take a gift from a contractor (as a rule, no).
 But a billionaire mayor, an anemic economy and an administration determined to avoid even the appearance of impropriety have combined to greatly raise the profile and expand the mission of the board, which examines and rules on myriad financial and conduct issues. 
 Yet even as its work increases, budget cuts are threatening some of the basic missions of the board, said its chairman, Steven B. Rosenfeld, who was appointed by the mayor last year. 
"The mayor has said there are no sacred cows," Mr. Rosenfeld said in a recent interview in his Midtown office at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, where he is a partner in the law firm's litigation department. "And I'm not asking to be an exception. But I would think there would be some recognition that a small agency can't function with these kinds of cuts in staffing."
When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg first took office, he became the most scrutinized mayor since the agency's inception in 1988. The board spent several months poring over the personal finances of Mr. Bloomberg, who at that time had extensive stock holdings and complicated relationships with major companies doing business with the city through his firm, Bloomberg LP. 
At the same time, Mr. Bloomberg's administration has been soliciting contributions from the private sector to help shore up city services that are threatened by extensive budget cuts. Last week, the board essentially reversed its earlier ruling on fund-raising by city officials, saying that some degree was acceptable.
Mr. Bloomberg has required many city officials to be trained in conflict-of-interest issues. 
"The mayor wants our administration to have the highest ethical standards," said his press secretary, Edward Skyler. "So having an open and ongoing dialogue with the C.O.I.B. helps avoid even the appearance of impropriety."
Since 2001, telephone requests for advice from the board have risen 46 percent, and complaints to the agency have risen 85 percent. At the end of 2001, 40 requests for advice had not been resolved and were rolled over to the next year; at the end of 2002, 184 such requests were pending.
"The number of complaints and requests are up because people are much more knowledgeable and sensitive about the law," Mr. Rosenfeld said. But, he added, "advice that has to be delayed that long ends up being not useful advice at all."
Mr. Rosenfeld said his agency recently laid off the four people who made up its education and training unit, which the Bloomberg administration has been relying on to spread the word about conflict-of-interest issues. Today, he will ask the City Council to restore $143,000 to reinstate that unit. And he will seek to remove the mayor's authority over the agency's budget, as is the case with the Campaign Finance Board.
The Conflicts of Interest Board was established in 1988 as part of the city's charter reform and as the successor to the Board of Ethics, which was formed in 1959. The board is a nonmayoral city agency charged with interpreting and enforcing the city's conflict-of-interest rules, but the mayor appoints the board's five members to staggered six-year terms. The agency had been operating with 23 people -- it is down to 17 after budget cuts -- divided among six units: legal advice, training and education, financial disclosure, enforcement, management information systems, and administration.
One of the first acts the board undertook after Mr. Bloomberg took office was an eight-month study of the mayor's holdings and relationships with a wide variety of companies.
The resulting 13-page opinion advised the mayor to sell all of his stocks, along with his interests in a hedge fund, and to refrain from participating in the selection of the city's bond underwriters, so as not to appear to favor Merrill Lynch, which owns 20 percent of his firm. 
The board also said Mr. Bloomberg should recuse himself from city decisions about cable television franchises, so as not to appear to favor Bloomberg Television.
"No mayor has ever confronted these issues," Mr. Rosenfeld said. "And he has attracted other people from the private sector who require similar kind of scrutiny."
In what Mr. Rosenfeld characterized as one of the board's most important rulings in years, the panel concluded last week that city officials could directly solicit contributions for the city from the private sector unless those being solicited had matters before the city. Before that, such solicitation had been prohibited. 
The board will also ask the mayor's charter revision committee to remove the agency from mayoral oversight of its budget. "There is something inconsistent with having a watchdog agency watching over city officials when the city holds the purse strings," Mr. Rosenfeld said. It will also seek to increase the maximum fines for violations to $25,000 from its current $10,000 level, to streamline the financial disclosure process and to raise the income threshold of those subject to financial disclosure law.

HEADLINE: Keepers of Bush Image Lift Stagecraft to New Heights 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
George W. Bush's "Top Gun" landing on the deck of the carrier Abraham Lincoln will be remembered as one of the most audacious moments of presidential theater in American history. But it was only the latest example of how the Bush administration, going far beyond the foundations in stagecraft set by the Reagan White House, is using the powers of television and technology to promote a presidency like never before.
 Officials of past Democratic and Republican administrations marvel at how the White House does not seem to miss an opportunity to showcase Mr. Bush in dramatic and perfectly lighted settings. It is all by design: the White House has stocked its communications operation with people from network television who have expertise in lighting, camera angles and the importance of backdrops. 
 On Tuesday, at a speech promoting his economic plan in Indianapolis, White House aides went so far as to ask people in the crowd behind Mr. Bush to take off their ties, WISH-TV in Indianapolis reported, so they would look more like the ordinary folk the president said would benefit from his tax cut. 
"They understand the visual as well as anybody ever has," said Michael K. Deaver, Ronald Reagan's chief image maker. "They watched what we did, they watched the mistakes of Bush I, they watched how Clinton kind of stumbled into it, and they've taken it to an art form."
The White House efforts have been ambitious -- and costly. For the prime-time television address that Mr. Bush delivered to the nation on the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, the White House rented three barges of giant Musco lights, the kind used to illuminate sports stadiums and rock concerts, sent them across New York Harbor, tethered them in the water around the base of the Statue of Liberty and then blasted them upward to illuminate all 305 feet of America's symbol of freedom. It was the ultimate patriotic backdrop for Mr. Bush, who spoke from Ellis Island.
For a speech that Mr. Bush delivered last summer at Mount Rushmore, the White House positioned the best platform for television crews off to one side, not head on as other White Houses have done, so that the cameras caught Mr. Bush in profile, his face perfectly aligned with the four presidents carved in stone.
And on Monday, for remarks the president made promoting his tax cut plan near Albuquerque, the White House unfurled a backdrop that proclaimed its message of the day, "Helping Small Business," over and over. The type was too small to be read by most in the audience, but just the right size for television viewers at home.
"I don't know who does it," Mr. Deaver said, "but somebody's got a good eye over there."
That somebody, White House officials and television executives say, is in fact three or four people. First among equals is Scott Sforza, a former ABC producer who was hired by the Bush campaign in Austin, Tex., and who now works for Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director. Mr. Sforza created the White House "message of the day" backdrops and helped design the $250,000 set at the United States Central Command forward headquarters in Doha, Qatar, during the Iraq war.
Mr. Sforza works closely with Bob DeServi, a former NBC cameraman whom the Bush White House hired after seeing his work in the 2000 campaign. Mr. DeServi, whose title is associate director of communications for production, is considered a master at lighting. "You want it, I'll heat it up and make a picture," he said early this week. Mr. DeServi helped produce one of Mr. Bush's largest events, a speech to a crowd in Revolution Square in Bucharest last November.
To stage the event, Mr. DeServi went so far as to rent Musco lights in Britain, which were then shipped across the English Channel and driven across Europe to Romania, where they lighted Mr. Bush and the giant stage across from the country's former Communist headquarters.
A third crucial player is Greg Jenkins, a former Fox News television producer in Washington who is now the director of presidential advance. Mr. Jenkins manages the small army of staff members and volunteers who move days ahead of Mr. Bush and his entourage to set up the staging of all White House events.
"We pay particular attention to not only what the president says but what the American people see," Mr. Bartlett said. "Americans are leading busy lives, and sometimes they don't have the opportunity to read a story or listen to an entire broadcast. But if they can have an instant understanding of what the president is talking about by seeing 60 seconds of television, you accomplish your goals as communicators. So we take it seriously."
The president's image makers, Mr. Bartlett said, work within a budget for White House travel and events allotted by Congress, which for fiscal 2003 was $3.7 million. He said he did not know the specific cost of staging Mr. Bush's Sept. 11 anniversary speech, or what the White House was charged for the lights. A spokeswoman at the headquarters of Musco Lighting in Oskaloosa, Iowa, said the company did not disclose the prices it charged clients. 
White House communications operatives in previous administrations said many costs of presidential trips were paid for by whoever was deemed the official host of a trip -- typically a federal agency, a city or a company. Trips deemed political are paid for by the parties.
"The total cost of a trip is ultimately shared across a wide spectrum of agencies and hosts," said Joshua King, who was director of production of presidential events in the Clinton administration. "To get to who really pays for presidential events would keep a team of accountants very busy."
The most elaborate -- and criticized -- White House event so far was Mr. Bush's speech aboard the Abraham Lincoln announcing the end of major combat in Iraq. White House officials say that a variety of people, including the president, came up with the idea, and that Mr. Sforza embedded himself on the carrier to make preparations days before Mr. Bush's landing in a flight suit and his early evening speech.
Media strategists noted afterward that Mr. Sforza and his aides had choreographed every aspect of the event, even down to the members of the Lincoln crew arrayed in coordinated shirt colors over Mr. Bush's right shoulder and the "Mission Accomplished" banner placed to perfectly capture the president and the celebratory two words in a single shot. The speech was specifically timed for what image makers call "magic hour light," which cast a golden glow on Mr. Bush.
"If you looked at the TV picture, you saw there was flattering light on his left cheek and slight shadowing on his right," Mr. King said. "It looked great."
The trip was attacked by Democrats as an expensive political stunt, but White House officials said that Democrats needed a better issue for taking on the president. A New York Times/CBS News nationwide poll conducted May 9-12 found that the White House may have been right: 59 percent of those polled said it was appropriate, and not an effort to make political gain, for Mr. Bush to dress in a flight suit and announce the end of combat operations on the aircraft carrier.
But even this White House makes mistakes. One of the more notable ones occurred in January, when Mr. Bush delivered a speech about his economic plan at a St. Louis trucking company. Volunteers for the White House covered "Made in China" stamps with white stickers on boxes arrayed on either side of the president. Behind Mr. Bush was a printed backdrop of faux boxes that read "Made in U.S.A.," the message the administration wanted to convey to the television audience.
The White House takes great pride in the backdrops, which are created by Mr. Sforza, and has gone so far as to help design them for universities where Mr. Bush travels to make commencement addresses. Last year, the White House helped design a large banner for Ohio State as part of the background for Mr. Bush; last week, the White House collaborated with the University of South Carolina to make Sforzian backdrops for a presidential commencement speech in the school's new Carolina Center.
"They really are good," said Russ McKinney, the school's director of public affairs, as he listened to the president.
Television camera crews, meanwhile, say they have rarely had such consistently attractive pictures to send back to editing rooms.
"They seem to approach an event site like it's a TV set," said Chris Carlson, an ABC cameraman who covers the White House. "They dress it up really nicely. It looks like a million bucks."
Even for standard-issue White House events, Mr. Bush's image makers watch every angle. Last week, when the president had a joint news conference with Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain, it was staged in the Grand Foyer of the White House, under grand marble columns, with the Blue Room and a huge cream-colored bouquet of flowers illuminated in the background. (Mr. Sforza and Mr. DeServi could be seen there conferring before the cameras began rolling.) The scene was lush and rich, filled with the beauty of the White House in real time.
"They understand they have to build a set, whether it's an aircraft carrier or the Rose Garden or the South Lawn," Mr. Deaver said. "They understand that putting depth into the picture makes the candidate or president look better."
Or as Mr. Deaver said he learned long ago with Mr. Reagan: "They understand that what's around the head is just as important as the head."

HEADLINE: Senate Adopts A Tax Cut Plan Of $350 Billion 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday May 16 

 BODY:
The Senate Thursday night approved a sweeping tax cut bill that would reduce then suspend taxes on stock dividends before restoring them in 2007, adopting at least for now the central element of President Bush's tax plan.
 Vice President Dick Cheney cast a vote breaking a 50-50 tie on the dividend measure. Several hours later, the bill was approved 51 to 49 when a Democrat who had voted against the dividend aspect, Evan Bayh of Indiana, voted for the overall bill. 
 The bill will now go to a conference with the House, which passed a substantially different tax cut package last week.
Mr. Bush wanted to eliminate the tax on dividends for the full 10-year period covered by the legislation, but the the president praised the bill approved Thursday. 
"Jobs are on the line, and I look forward to working with the full Congress to pass a robust economic growth plan," Mr. Bush said in a statement issued this morning. 
The measure would exclude half of a taxpayer's income from stock dividends from taxation this year and eliminate taxes on dividends altogether for three years, from 2004 through 2006. But to keep the 10-year cost of the bill within the $350 billion limit set by the budget the Senate adopted last month, dividend taxes would be fully reinstated in 2007.
The bill's sponsors expressed confidence that once the taxes were off the books they would never be allowed to reappear.
Democrats ridiculed the temporary suspension, called a sunset, as an irresponsible gimmick. Republicans said it would let Congress revisit the issue after a few years to see if eliminating the tax bite on dividends proves to be as effective in bolstering the stock market as its sponsors hope. 
"It would make the growth package a lot more robust," said the main sponsor, Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma. "It would encourage investment. It would encourage jobs. It would encourage growth."
The dividend vote mostly followed party lines. Only two Democrats, Zell Miller of Georgia and Ben Nelson of Nebraska, voted for the measure. Three Republicans, John McCain of Arizona, Lincoln D. Chafee of Rhode Island and Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, were opposed. 
In contrast to the action taken last week by the Senate Finance Committee, the dividend measure moved the Senate closer to Mr. Bush's position. The committee would have excluded from taxation the first $500 of dividends and a small part of the remaining dividends.
The provision suspending the tax on stock dividends means that some dividend cut is almost sure to be in the final package, a major victory for the president. Mr. Bush has said it is unfair to tax corporate profits twice, once when the companies pay their taxes and again when individuals receive their share in dividends.
Democrats offered a substitute that would have paid a tax rebate this year of $300 a person, but it lost on a procedural vote, 54 to 46. The Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said his proposal would have led to more new jobs and been much less costly than the Republican bill.
The bill would repeal the law that let American workers overseas exempt $80,000 of their income from taxation. An effort to delete this provision was rejected, 51 to 49, but senators said there was an understanding it would be knocked out of the bill in the conference committee.
A large share of the tax benefits from the Senate bill would go to the wealthiest taxpayers. Sponsors said this would give new impetus to the economy, since rich people make the investments that lead to new jobs. 
The 10-year cost of the Senate bill is substantially lower than the $726 billion plan Mr. Bush proposed and the $550 billion package adopted by the House last week. But it would still be the third-largest tax cut in history, behind only the reductions in 1981 in the Reagan administration and 2001 in Mr. Bush's first year in office.
The key provision on dividends is completely different from what the House passed, a reduction of the tax rate on dividends and capital gains. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, objected to the Senate measure Thursday, saying, "It doesn't solve the problem."
The conference committee will begin next week to resolve the differences in size and policy.
In the last few weeks, Republicans in Congress have tried not so much to draft a tax bill that might become law as to assemble packages that could win majorities in the House and Senate so the final details could be worked out in the conference.
The Senate bill would reinstate the full tax on dividends after four years and would eliminate after two years a tax break the bill would provide this year for married couples. These sunsets keep the cost of the measure artificially low, since the sponsors expect Congress to re-enact the tax benefits before they expire.
Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, called the sunset "a huge yo-yo tax provision, now you see it, now you don't."
"This is absurd," he added. "This is irresponsible tax legislation."
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research group that opposes the tax cuts, calculated that if the exclusion of dividends from taxation and the marriage bonus are in effect for the full 10 years, the cost in lost revenue would be $660 billion.
The House bill also holds down the price tag with sunsets of its own. Without them, its cost would be more than $1 trillion over 10 years.
Sunsets have been employed in tax bills before but never so extensively as this year. The willingness of lawmakers to use them may mean that the biggest battles in the conference will be over policy, not size.
The swing votes that passed the dividend proposal came from Mr. Nelson and Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio. Both are former governors who said a decisive factor was the Senate's agreement earlier today to provide $10 billion a year for two years to help state and local governments. Half the money is for Medicaid, the federal-state health program for the poor. The House bill does not have a comparable provision.
"I feel good about this package," said Mr. Voinovich, who declared his position only this morning. "It will give this economy a good jolt."
Another important provision would raise the tax credit for each child to $1,000 from the current $600. Families could expect a $400 check for each child this summer, representing the larger credit.
Thursday, the Senate added a measure raising the Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals in rural areas. To offset the expense, Medicare payments would be cut for equipment like wheelchairs and chemotherapy drugs. Patients would also be charged deductibles and co-payments for laboratory services, both completely covered now.
The Medicare provisions are not in the House bill and could lead to some difficulty in conference.
Like the House bill, the Senate would let small businesses deduct up to $100,000 each year for the next five years to offset expenses on plants and equipment. The current maximum is $25,000.

SENATE -- Would reduce tax rates on stock dividends as follows: 50 percent of dividends would be tax free in 2003, all dividends would be tax free in 2004 through 2006, then in 2007, dividends would again be taxable at the same rate as the taxpayer's other income. CAPITAL GAINS HOUSE -- Would lower the maximum tax rate for capital gains to 15 percent. The maximum capital gains rate is now 18 percent on stocks held at least five years, and 20 percent on those held for a shorter period. Taxpayers in the two lowest brackets would owe only 5 percent on capital gains. SENATE -- No provision on capital gains taxes. All changes would be effective through 2005. SENATE -- Would keep these changes in effect through 2013. Also would extend through 2004 the current law allowing businesses to use current losses to recoup taxes paid in the profitable years of the 1990's. SENATE -- No provisions. SENATE -- Includes the same provision. PROVISIONS IN SENATE BILL THAT ARE NOT IN HOUSE BILL AID TO STATES -- Would provide $10 billion a year for two years to state and local governments, half for Medicaid and the rest for other services. TAX SHELTERS -- Would curtail several tax shelters and other tax breaks, generating about $30 billion in additional revenue for the government over 10 years. FOREIGN INCOME -- Would repeal the law that lets Americans working abroad exempt $80,000 of their income from taxes. MEDICARE -- Would allow higher payments to hospitals and other providers in rural areas. To offset the cost, payments would be reduced for some equipment like wheelchairs and drugs used in chemotherapy, and patients would have to pay more for laboratory services. (pg. A22)

HEADLINE: Target Posts Slow Growth as Spending Lags 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Target Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 1.2 percent, the smallest increase in a year and a half. The company predicted disappointing results for this quarter. 
 Net income rose to $349 million, or 38 cents a share, in the quarter ended May 3, from $345 million, or 38 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales increased 7.6 percent, to $10.3 billion from $9.59 billion. 
 Sales at stores open at least a year fell less than 1 percent, including results at its Marshall Field's and Mervyn's department stores.
Analysts' expectations of 42 cents a share for this quarter are "slightly above" the company's profit forecast, Target officials told investors in a conference call.
Slower consumer spending has hurt Target more than its larger rival Wal-Mart because of a greater reliance on discretionary items, like Swell sheets by Cynthia Rowley and other designer housewares, investors said. Target plans to cut prices on some food items and increase advertising of basic products like napkins to compete with Wal-Mart's larger grocery sections.
"They spent too much time emphasizing the designer items and not enough time in a tough economic environment emphasizing good value," said Martin Bukoll, an analyst at the Northern Trust Corporation. "You need to advertise specific goods at low prices now."
Target said it still expected to meet Wall Street estimates of $2.03 a share in profit for the year.
Shares of Target, which is based in Minneapolis, fell $1.47, or 4.1 percent, to $34.46.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid By Consumers Decline 0.3% 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
Lower prices for energy, cars and clothes drove consumer costs down in April by the largest amount in 18 months, underscoring Federal Reserve anxiety about the possibility of a destabilizing decline.
 The Consumer Price Index, the government's most closely watched inflation gauge, declined by 0.3 percent last month, after rising by 0.3 percent in March, the Labor Department reported today. 
 For the 12 months ended April 30, consumer prices were up a modest 2.2 percent. The performance of core prices, which exclude volatile energy and food costs, was even lower, a gain of just 1.5 percent during the period, the smallest increase since 1966. 
Faced with lackluster customer demand, businesses are keeping a lid on price increases and in some cases are cutting prices to lure shoppers.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and his colleagues are on guard for any signs of deflation -- a prolonged and widespread decline in prices -- in the economy. Though they say the chances of deflation are remote, Fed policy makers signaled last week that they were prepared to lower short-term interest rates to ward off even the threat of that happening.
Private economists said the Fed's worries over deflation raised the odds of a cut in the federal funds rate, now at a 41-year low of 1.25 percent, at the central bank's next meeting on June 24 and 25.
The drop in the Consumer Price Index came one day after the government reported that wholesale prices fell by a record 1.9 percent in April.
While deflation is dangerous, more normal and contained cases of falling prices can benefit consumers.
High energy prices have put a damper on consumer spending, the main force keeping the economy going.
Economists are hopeful that retreating energy prices will make consumers feel more inclined to buy. That is important because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity in the United States.
In April, as the Iraq war wound down, energy prices fell 4.6 percent, which reversed an increase of the samesize in March. Gasoline prices fell 8.3 percent, fuel oil prices were down 14.9 percent and natural gas prices decreased 3.8 percent. Even with April's decline, energy prices are still up 13 percent over the last 12 months.
A preliminary report showed that the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index rose to 93.2 in May from a reading of 86 in April.
One bright spot of the economy, the residential construction market, hit a rough spot in April, another report showed.
The number of new housing projects that builders began work on in April dropped 6.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.63 million, the Commerce Department said. The decline, which some economists said reflected rainy and cool weather in some parts of the country, came after housing starts rose by a solid 6.6 percent in March.
David Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders, said that with 30-year mortgage rates at record lows and builders now feeling more upbeat about sales prospects, he expected a rebound in residential construction in May.
