HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW; 
Race as a Fiction Invented By the Ruling Classes

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

 BODY:
To make the point that people are all alike under the skin, PBS interviewed not one or two but eight eminent scholars who all agree: under the skin, people are all alike.
 Instead of diversity of opinion, PBS's three-part series "Race: The Power of an Illusion" offers viewers a racially diverse selection of like-minded experts, ranging from Stephen Jay Gould, the white Harvard paleontologist who died last year, to Evelynn Hammonds, a black female professor of History of Science and Afro-American Studies at Harvard. 
 The series has some important things to say about race in America, particularly in explaining how society concocted expedient notions about race that have no backing in genetics or biology -- what Mark Twain described as a "a fiction of law and custom." But its larger message is overpowered by the intellectual timidity of the messenger. 
The series could more aptly be titled "PBS: The Power of Self-Delusion," a study of how a publicly owned television network with a mandate to challenge the mind can instead put even the most caffeinated brains to sleep.
In three hourlong installments the filmmakers painstakingly examine the evolution of race discrimination, from Thomas Jefferson's "Notes on the State of Virginia" to restrictions in the postwar suburban development of Levittown on Long Island.
"Race is a human invention," Ms. Hammonds says. "Race is a concept we invented to categorize the perceived biological, social and cultural differences between human groups."
She and others describe how stereotypes and assumptions still stigmatize nonwhites in American society, yet the filmmakers avoid addressing race relations as they are lived right now.
There is no discussion, let alone lively debate, about the issues confounding our society, from college affirmative-action admissions policies to racial profiling. Instead, it is a history lesson about economic and social injustice that PBS has told well, many times, and with much of the same source material. Like the character played by Bill Murray in "Groundhog Day," PBS keeps reliving the horrors of slavery, segregation and discrimation without advancing to the more politically and culturally sensitive issues of race relations today.
The project isn't helped by its shopworn format: images of scholars, interviewed against the same blue backdrop, are interspersed with clips, old photographs and archival materials. A cello plays mournful music, and the narration by the actress C C H Pounder ("The Shield") is enunciated so slowly and sonorously that it seems addressed to viewers who speak English as a second language.
The notion that race is not biological but merely an artificial construct imposed by the country's ruling classes to justify first slavery and then segregation is not new. It has been articulated by some of the most respected scholars in the country, from K. Anthony Appiah, a professor of philosophy at Princeton, to Alan Goodman, a professor of biological anthropology at Hampshire College, who is one of several dozen experts interviewed on camera. 
The implications of modern genetics are not as easily grasped, and it is understandable that the filmmakers felt they had to set a slow, careful pace when dealing with science. Scientific research showing no significant genetic or biological differences between the races can be counterintuitive: in the film, a black high school student who assumed he would have fewer differences in his DNA with another black student than with a white student, was surprised to learn he was wrong. 
The film also takes up the common assumption that African-American prowess in sports like track or basketball is somehow a result of genetics or biology. (In the film, a young black high school track star says, "I assume a white girl can't beat me in the 200.") 
The documentary suggests where she is in error, but that still complicated issue was explained more thoroughly and persuasively by the science writer Malcolm Gladwell in a 1997 article in The New Yorker, "The Sports Taboo: Why Blacks Are Like Boys and Whites Are Like Girls," a mischievous title that would never find its way past the political correctness of PBS. 
The documentary goes out of its way to avoid conflict. There are some scholars who contest the notion that race is neither genetic nor biological, but they are not interviewed. Instead, the documentary shows a short clip of John Entine, author of "Taboo: Why Black Athletes Dominate Sports and Why We're Afraid to Talk About It," heatedly expressing his views on CNN's "Talk Back Live," a television format that reduces all guests to the level of hollering crackpots. 
The famous quote of Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court is the film's conclusion: "In order to get beyond racism we must first take account of race." Oddly, however, reliably decent PBS does not trust its own viewers' decency enough to take account of an opposing view.

RACE: THE POWER OF AN ILLUSION
WLIW, tomorrow through Tuesday nights at 10, Eastern time, in New York area. Elsewhere, check PBS listings.

HEADLINE: A Ruling Makes E-Mail Evidence More Accessible 

BYLINE:  By LANDON THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
UBS Warburg was ordered this week to pay for the search and recovery of e-mail messages requested by a plaintiff, giving aggrieved investors a new legal tool to support their cases against investment banks.
 Shira A. Scheindlin, a judge in the southern district of New York, said that UBS had to dig into its archives and pay for the restoration of a limited batch of e-mail messages sought by a former employee who is suing the firm for sexual discrimination and retaliatory dismissal. 
 Judge Scheindlin's opinion, delivered on Tuesday, is already being referred to by lawyers representing investors and investment banks as a definitive piece of jurisprudence. It suggests that investment banks will have to take responsibility and pay for the recovery of e-mail messages as long as plaintiffs can demonstrate that the evidence sought is relevant to their cases. 
Arbitration lawyers say that Judge Scheindlin's decision will change the economics of arbitration cases involving investors seeking damages from investment banks over fraudulent research.
"The decision is very significant and will help customers get crucial evidence for their cases," said Jacob H. Zamansky, a leading arbitration lawyer. "As long as you can make a showing that the evidence you are asking for is relevant, the banks must bear the cost for searching through the e-mails."
Investment banks have cited the technical challenge and cost involved in retrieving old e-mail traffic as a reason to dismiss arbitration claims, many of which are frivolous, bank and arbitration lawyers agree. (Under industry rules, most customer and employee complaints must be resolved by arbitration, rather than in court.) In the UBS case, lawyers for the bank stated that if the plaintiff, Laura Zubulake, wanted the additional files, which were stored on tape and not readily accessible, she should pay the $175,000 it would cost to retrieve them.
Ms. Zubulake, who has not worked since her dismissal in October 2001, could not afford to pay such a sum, her lawyers say. In her decision, Judge Scheindlin ordered UBS to turn over 5 of the 94 files that were stored on backup tapes and additional e-mail messages on optical disks, which will cost much less than the original request.
"We are pleased that we won this motion, which significantly limited the scope of discovery and prevented an unjustified fishing expedition," a spokesman for UBS Warburg said yesterday.
Much of the opinion's legal punch comes from its author: Judge Scheindlin will be the presiding judge over a seminal class-action suit contending that 55 investment banks and executives at technology companies defrauded investors by artificially inflating the prices of hot initial public offerings.
The outcome of that suit, which could cost investment banks billions of dollars, will depend largely on what kind of e-mail evidence plaintiffs can secure from the banks.
"It's very important for our case," said Melvyn I. Weiss, whose law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, is leading the suit. "Judge Scheindlin has set the standard. She has made it clear that she will force the defendants to make available all material that otherwise would be difficult to obtain."
In her opinion, which spanned 38 pages and quoted Henry David Thoreau in its introduction, Judge Scheindlin argued that federal standards governing the discovery process are outdated and were written before the flowering of e-mail as the primary means of corporate communication.
She set new standards, which effectively give plaintiffs the right to ask that investment banks provide expanded levels of e-mail traffic that may take a significant effort to retrieve, if the plaintiff proves that the messages are relevant to the case. The investment bank would then be responsible for bearing the cost.
"This will be the law of the land when it comes to arbitrations," said James A. Batson, of Liddle & Robinson, who is representing Ms. Zubulake. "Defendants can no longer hide behind the cost factor." 
More than 7,000 arbitration cases were filed against investment banks last year, most of them involving investors contending that fraudulent research from Wall Street wiped out their investments. Many were dismissed by arbitrators because of the lack of e-mail evidence.
If plaintiffs wanted such evidence, banks argued, they should pay the costs themselves. Given that e-mail recovery operations can be expensive, plaintiffs have often dropped their cases.
The Scheindlin opinion, lawyers say, will be a powerful new weapon in their continuing attempts to extract fresh e-mail evidence from the investment banks.
Analysts estimate that investment banks could have hundreds of millions of dollars of potential exposure to arbitration claims. Banks have become more aggressive in contesting such claims and agreeing to settle fewer of them. One of their most effective defenses has been to hold the line on broad requests for e-mail traffic.
Ms. Zubulake, a former institutional equities saleswoman at UBS Warburg, hopes to use the e-mail messages to support her contention that she was fired in retaliation for filing a claim with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. In that claim, she asserted that she had been passed over for promotion because of her gender.
She then filed suit against UBS for gender discrimination and illegal retaliation.
Ms. Zubulake's lawyers at Liddle & Robinson originally made a broad request: they wanted all e-mail traffic concerning Ms. Zubulake and any UBS official, which would have required UBS to delve deep into its e-mail archives for the recovery and restoration of 94 e-mail files.
Such a request is typical in cases between private parties and corporations and is generally seen to be an attempt to pressure the defendant into settling, say lawyers for investment banks that have opposed Liddle & Robinson in other cases. Liddle & Robinson is a leading law firm known for aggressive suits by bankers and brokers against their former employers.
UBS lawyers responded that the bulk of these e-mail messages had been stored on tapes, that they were not relevant to the case and that to restore them would be unduly expensive and time-consuming. Ms. Zubulake's lawyers asked for a more limited trove of e-mail messages and got them.
In ordering UBS to produce only 5 of the 94 files for Ms. Zubulake, Judge Scheindlin also asked that the bank include an affidavit of the cost.
While this decision has thrilled arbitration lawyers, executives at investment banks point out that Judge Scheindlin decreed that UBS provide only a small fraction of the plaintiff's request. And on June 17, Judge Scheindlin will hear arguments to decide whether UBS or Ms. Zubulake would have to pay for the recovery of any more files.

HEADLINE: Big Gamble For Pataki 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 16 

 BODY:
Many legislators were declaring an unmitigated victory today, a day after they moved with striking swiftness to override each of Gov. George E. Pataki's 119 vetoes of the state budget. There was talk of a lame-duck governor, a robust Legislature and a new balance of power in the State Capitol.
 But it may be too soon to write the three-term Republican governor off as a loser. 
 Mr. Pataki and his advisers do not define victory the way lawmakers do. In political terms, he has succeeded in burnishing his credentials as a fiscal conservative within the national party and in laying the groundwork to avoid blame for a budget that may well fall apart and turn into a fiscal debacle.
Indeed, as if to bolster his case, Standard & Poor's today lowered its outlook on New York state bonds, to negative from stable, saying revenues and expenditures do not match up, and giving the governor more ammunition as he rails about the irresponsibility of the State Legislature's $92.8 billion budget.
In the view of most legislators and lobbyists, however, Mr. Pataki's only success was in empowering the Legislature, reversing what has traditionally been a balance of power in favor of the governor and enabling the often-fractious Legislature to prove that, when united, it can accomplish a lot.
"That's what the governor allowed to happen," said Sheldon Silver, speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly. "If he planned it, he released something that really hasn't happened previously. I don't think he wanted to do that. I think he believed he would, ultimately, have the control."
"All his friends think he suffered a terrible loss, to my knowledge," Mr. Silver said.
But Mr. Pataki's aides said it is too soon to declare winners and losers. "This is one battle in what will be a sustained war," said one senior aide, who asked not to be identified.
Mr. Pataki's closest aides concede that the outcome was not what the governor had wanted or planned. He never expected his disagreement with the Legislature to lead to the override of his vetoes, labor leaders and others familiar with the budget battle said. He believed that Joseph L. Bruno, leader of the State Senate's Republican majority and a staunch ally, would stand by him, and that Republican legislators would stay in line. He misjudged the pressure on legislators to restore school aid and Medicaid cuts, the lawmakers said.
Once it became clear, however, that he would have to choose between being overridden and breaking his early promise not to raise taxes, he appeared to switch strategies and take steps to turn the situation to his political advantage, say legislators of both parties.
For one, they said, he disengaged from negotiations and accused the members of not producing any creative counterproposals. At one point, he said he did not even need a budget and could run the government on emergency bills, threatening lawmakers at every turn with vetoes. 
While that hurt him in the budget talks, many lawmakers said, it absolved him of responsibility for the final product.
Though he had privately said he might be willing to raise sales taxes and restore some spending cuts, according to lawmakers, Mr. Pataki publicly went on the warpath against the "tax and spend budget" of the Legislature. He labeled it a train wreck and predicted, like some latter-day Cassandra, enormous deficits in the coming years.
He made numerous public appearances to attack the Legislature's budget, projecting confidence, to the final moments of the battle. And even as he faced the cameras Thursday afternoon, less than an hour after the Legislature had rolled over him, he certainly did not appear like a beaten man.
Indeed, he did the political equivalent of spitting in the eyes of legislative leaders. He immediately vetoed a bill they had enacted to aid New York City, saying it would tax city dwellers too much, and again charged they had acted unconstitutionally. The move stole the Legislature's thunder in some New York City tabloid headlines.
In general, the governor departed from his usual low-key approach to behind-the-scenes negotiations and waged a public relations campaign. He tried to paint the Legislature as irresponsible.
The governor controls a large amount of patronage and money for special projects that he could use as leverage over the lawmakers. But aides to Mr. Pataki said he recognized early on that arm-twisting would not work with his Republican colleagues in the Senate, and instead he tried a more gentlemanly campaign of speeches and private conversations about the merits of keeping taxes low. (Some said his allies made a round of threatening calls to both Democratic and Republican Assembly members, however, in the final minutes of the veto-override showdown.)
Meanwhile, he was fighting an onslaught of advertising from various unions and advocates for social services, who spent millions on spots attacking the governor's budget and building support for a tax increase on people in upper income brackets.
In response, the governor went on television more times during this season's budget battle, clamoring for reporters' and the public's attention, than he had in his re-election campaign last fall. 
Still reaching for publicity, he held his vetoes until the final hour on Wednesday night. The next day, as the Legislature voted to reverse his vetoes, he was able to secure more headlines with his veto of the legislative package for city aid, worth $1.8 billion. (Lawmakers in Albany, in both parties, appeared poised to override that veto too, first thing Monday.)
With the battle over, Mr. Pataki seems to be gambling that the budget plan will fall apart and that he will be vindicated in the court of public opinion. Legislative leaders, meanwhile, are gambling that the public will understand that the spending plan Mr. Pataki first proposed was no better and would have created its own deficits.
From a political standpoint, the governor's recent anti-tax headlines might be all he needs. He has reaffirmed his fiscally conservative credentials and linked himself to the same economic philosophy emanating from the Bush White House. 
What may work for him on the national stage may not work in New York, however, his critics say.
"I think that if you're in Wyoming, you like that the governor was fighting what appeared to be an increase in taxes," said David A. Paterson, a Democratic state senator from Harlem. "But you know something, in New York, people used to believe that. Then they got to know him."

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: NEW GOVERNMENT; 
IN REVERSAL, PLAN FOR IRAQ SELF-RULE HAS BEEN PUT OFF

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 16 

 BODY:
In an abrupt reversal, the United States and Britain have indefinitely put off their plan to allow Iraqi opposition forces to form a national assembly and an interim government by the end of the month. 
 Instead, top American and British diplomats leading reconstruction efforts here told exile leaders in a meeting tonight that allied officials would remain in charge of Iraq for an indefinite period, said Iraqis who attended the meeting. It was conducted by L. Paul Bremer, the new civilian administrator here. 
 Mr. Bremer, who was accompanied by John Sawers, a British diplomat representing Prime Minister Tony Blair, told the Iraqi political figures that the allies preferred to revert to the concept of creating an "interim authority" -- not a provisional government -- so that Iraqis could assist them by creating a constitution for Iraq, revamping the educational system and devising a plan for future democratic elections. 
"It's quite clear that you cannot transfer all powers onto some interim body, because it will not have the strength or the resources to carry those responsibilities out," The Associated Press quoted Mr. Sawers as saying. "There was agreement that we should aim to have a national conference as soon as we reasonably could do so."
One Iraqi who attended the meeting said Iraqi opposition leaders expressed strong disappointment over the reversal. 
The decision comes at a time when Washington and London have been taking new steps to restore law and order in Iraq, cope with the devastation of civilian institutions and halt the looting and violent crime.
These conditions have emboldened former opposition figures to move rapidly into the political vacuum in Iraq, and former members of Saddam Hussein's government and the Baath Party to blame the allies for fomenting collapse, unemployment and suffering among the population. 
In a step calculated to combat any resurgence of Baath Party influence here, Mr. Bremer today issued an order banning up to 30,000 top-ranking members "from future employment in the public sector."
"By this means, the coalition provisional authority will ensure that representative government in Iraq is not threatened by Baathist elements returning to power and that those in positions of authority in the future are acceptable to the people of Iraq," Mr. Bremer said in a statement.
Today's decision to extend allied control indefinitely over the governing of Iraq was conveyed to Iraqi political figures as the United States and Britain worked assiduously at the United Nations to win broad international consensus for a resolution to lift economic sanctions on Iraq, in order to begin selling oil to finance reconstruction. 
In seeking support, the allies are facing demands for a greater United Nations role in shaping postwar Iraq, including a setting of the terms by which an "interim authority" would make the transition to democratically elected government. 
"They want broader support because they are desperate to get the oil pumping," said an Iraqi who attended the meeting. Mr. Sawers, who is Britain's outgoing ambassador to Egypt, spoke of the need to complete the "tactical" measures of re-establishing legal and social institutions before vesting a government with sovereign control.
The Iraqi who attended the meeting added that the decision also appeared to reflect apprehensions in the Bush administration, and more intensely in London, that the former Iraqi opposition forces are still a disparate group and that the Kurdish leaders as well have yet to coalesce into a ruling body. 
The fear is that a divided or weak interim government will not be able to withstand the intense and at times conflicting ethnic and religious pressures that have tended to divide Iraq instead of cementing it together.
"I don't think they trust this group to function as a political leadership," said the Iraqi political figure who attended. "And for us it is very difficult to participate in something that we have no control over. We don't want to be part of the blame committee when something goes wrong." 
Opposition leaders were "very respectful" to Mr. Bremer and Mr. Sawers, a participant said, "but I think everyone was also pretty forceful about the need to have full sovereignty for the Iraqis." A question they kept posing, he added, was, "Do you want to run this place, or should we?" 
No date was set for creating an interim authority, and no details about its powers and functions were discussed in the meeting, the Iraqis said. Mr. Bremer said he would meet with the opposition leaders for further discussions in two weeks. 
"They retracted what they said before," an Iraqi political figure said. The provisional government idea is gone, he said. As for the idea of convening a national assembly to select a government, he said, "there is no such thing anymore."
Today's decision was a disappointment for the former opposition forces and their supporters in the Pentagon and the Congress, where officials had been pressing for an early turnover of sovereign power to a government formed by the opposition groups. 
On April 28, the United States and Britain sponsored a political gathering of about 300 Iraqis and supported their call for a national conference to meet by the end of May to select a transitional government. Zalmay Khalilzad, who has served as President Bush's envoy to the Iraqi opposition, was a co-chairman of the April meeting, but did not return to Iraq for tonight's meeting. 
On May 5, Jay Garner, the civilian administrator who preceded Mr. Bremer, said the core of a new Iraqi government would emerge this month. "Next week, or by the second weekend in May, you'll see the beginning of a nucleus of a temporary Iraqi government, a government with an Iraqi face on it that is totally dealing with the coalition," General Garner said during a visit to Basra.
At that time, he said he expected such a government to include figures like Ahmad Chalabi of the Iraqi National Congress, Ayad Allawi of the Iraqi National Accord, the Kurdish leaders Massoud Barzani and Jalal Talabani, and Abdul Aziz al-Hakim of the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq. 
Since then, the group of former exiles and their Kurdish allies has expanded their leadership council to include another Sunni Muslim leader and another Shiite Muslim leader. 
The Iraqi figures were also surprised by the reversal since it appeared in recent weeks that Pentagon officials had persuaded the White House that the best course was to turn over power as quickly as possible to opposition forces.
But as the breadth of systemic breakdown in Iraq has become more visible, a counterargument has grown -- that the failure of the opposition to make the transition to a viable government would reflect poorly on the allied victory over Mr. Hussein and add to instability.
General Garner attended tonight's meeting but spoke very little, participants said. He was accompanied by Ryan Crocker, a deputy assistant secretary of state. 
Attending from the Pentagon was Walter Slocombe, who has been given the assignment to examine the growing problem of how to get under control the military forces that each of the main opposition leaders now controls in Iraq. He is said to be working on a plan to meld them into a national security force, a task that would require Kurdish leaders to give up control over their armies.
The opposition leaders were also asked to meet on Tuesday with Lt. Gen. John Abazaid, deputy to Gen. Tommy Franks, the overall American commander in the Middle East and South Asia, to discuss how the opposition groups can contribute to improving security. 
All of the Iraqi figures were pleased with Mr. Bremer's decision on dismantling the Baath Party. Nonetheless, Mr. Bremer reserved the right to himself to make exceptions to the ban in cases where the knowledge and expertise of a former Baath official might be essential to government functions, where the person's prior membership in the party was deemed nonthreatening and where a renunciation of Baath principles had been secured.

HEADLINE: 'Pomp and Circumstance.' Then What? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "College Graduates Lower Sights in Today's Stagnant Job Market" (front page, May 14): 
 As an '02 grad, I saw my classmates introduced to the disheartening dose of reality known as the American job market a year ago. 
This year is no better. Yet a majority of students still seems to harbor the comforting belief, as one put it, that "it's definitely temporary. Everybody has that feeling -- two or three years, and everything will be back to normal."
This is the kind of ignorant optimism that mires our country in economic (as well as social and political) woes. How bad do things have to get before Americans wake up and take notice? 
I implore the fresh faces in today's job(less) market to learn more about the sorry state of our union -- particularly the disastrous economic policies of the Bush administration -- and then either work to change it, even just through vocal disapproval and diligent voting, or leave for greener pastures, as I have. 

NICHOLAS KRUSE
Shanghai, May 14, 2003

HEADLINE: Wall St. Enthusiast for Oracle Takes a Job at the Company 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Oracle Corporation has hired one of its biggest fans on Wall Street as a top executive to work side-by-side with its chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison. 
 Charles E. Phillips, a leading analyst at Morgan Stanley, will become executive vice president of Oracle. 
 The move, which was announced Thursday, comes less than a month after Wall Street's top brokerage firms agreed to pay a total of $1.4 billion to settle allegations about conflicts of interest between analysts and the companies they follow. 
As an analyst, Mr. Phillips was host to Oracle executives for dinner at his Manhattan home. He has followed makers of so-called enterprise software, used by large businesses and organizations, since 1986. 
For a decade he was extremely bullish on Oracle's stock, even at times when the stock price was falling and Mr. Ellison was under attack from investors for cashing out options for Oracle stock. 
Among the 13 software companies Mr. Phillips covered, Oracle was one of only two that he rated overweight, or buy. The other one was J. D. Edwards & Company.
Mr. Phillips cooled on Oracle for one month, in March 2001, when he cut his rating to neutral after the technology bubble burst. A month later, he raised the rating back up to outperform, or buy. 
While Oracle's stock has fallen from its split-adjusted highs of around $45 in September 2000, it has done better than many of its peers. It is up 32 percent in the last year. 
At Oracle, Mr. Phillips will be responsible for corporate strategy and business development. He will be one of three executives, including Mr. Ellison, in Oracle's office of the chief executive. He will also be on the executive management committee. 
Mr. Phillips joined Morgan Stanley in 1994 and has been named the top enterprise software analyst every year since then by Institutional Investor magazine.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves AIDS Bill, Pleasing White House 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
The Senate voted early this morning to approve President Bush's $15 billion global AIDS initiative, handing the White House a legislative trophy that Mr. Bush can carry with him next month when he joins world leaders at an economic meeting of eight major industrial nations in Evian, France.
 At a time when nearly 10,000 people in Africa are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, every day, the bill authorizes the government to triple its spending on global AIDS, to $15 billion over five years. It makes good on a promise Mr. Bush made in January in his State of the Union address. 
 The White House had been pressing Senate leaders to adopt the bill, which is similar to one that passed overwhelmingly in the House. The measure gives Mr. Bush an opportunity to demonstrate to other nations, especially France -- where relations with the United States were seriously strained by the war in Iraq -- that America is committed to exercising moral as well as military might.
Mr. Bush told reporters today that he was "so pleased" the Senate had adopted the bill. "I'll be able to sign it and take it to Europe with me," he said, "as a symbol of the great depth of compassion that our country holds for those who suffer." 
The measure was approved by voice vote shortly after 2 a.m. after a marathon session ordered by Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader. Dr. Frist urged his colleagues to approve the House version intact.
Instead, the Senate made a slight change, a nonbinding provision encouraging the Bush administration to negotiate additional debt relief for AIDS-stricken African countries. House Republican leaders said they expected to adopt the Senate version early next week.
"We have given the president the leverage he needs to call upon the world's wealthiest nations to join our commitment to address this crisis," Dr. Frist said after the vote. 
The bill is intended to curb the AIDS epidemic in 12 African nations and two in the Caribbean. It will authorize enough money, proponents said, to prevent 7 million new infections, provide antiretroviral drugs for 2 million people infected with H.I.V. and care for 10 million patients as well as children orphaned by the disease.
Advocates for people with AIDS offered a mixed reaction to the vote. Some said the bill was not generous enough; others objected to its fine print, including a provision, inserted by House conservatives, that requires a third of the money for prevention to go to programs that promote abstinence until marriage.
"The president will get to pat himself on the back for this bill at the G-8 summit in two weeks in Evian," said Sharonann Lynch, an official of Health GAP, a nonprofit advocacy group. "But good P.R. won't win a war on global AIDS."
The Global AIDS Alliance, another nonprofit group, described the measure as "a cruel joke."
Still, Bono, the Irish rock star who has traveled the world to promote more spending on global AIDS, called it a "historic bill."
The measure does not actually provide money for the initiative; that will be left to House and Senate appropriators. Senate Democrats complained today that Mr. Bush's budget for 2004 includes only slightly more than half the $3 billion promised in the Senate bill. "The real test of America's resolve," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, "is whether we fund this promise."
In a series of votes, mostly along party lines, Republicans beat back efforts by Democrats to alter the bill. The exception was the provision on debt relief, which was adopted by voice vote.
The defeated amendments included one to strike the abstinence-only provision, and another, offered by Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, that would have authorized more money for a new global fund to fight AIDS. Mr. Durbin accused Dr. Frist of rushing into the vote without adequate debate.
"This is too important an issue, and it really should be bipartisan," Mr. Durbin said before the vote. "It shouldn't be an issue where they're trying to stare down anyone who wants to change the House bill."
The measure authorizes the United States to donate as much as $1 billion next year to the global fund, but caps American contributions at a third of what international donors provide. Mr. Bush has said he intends to use the bill to press other countries to donate more.
In recent weeks, Mr. Bush met with senators involved in the AIDS bill negotiations. Among them were Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the committee's senior Democrat. 
"He wants money from the G-8, he wants commitments, he wants somebody besides the United States in the ballgame," Mr. Lugar said, explaining why he took his name off the amendment for debt relief, which Mr. Biden favored. "I have told him that I will support him."
Despite the disagreement over the details, some senators, including Dr. Frist, said the vote was one they could feel good about.
During the debate late on Thursday night, Dr. Frist spoke of the destruction caused by AIDS, saying, "As history looks back at this day or this year on senators in this body, will we be able to say that we did everything possible to reverse the course of that destruction? I think at the end of this day, we will say yes."

HEADLINE: Candidate Bush Files Papers for '04 Race 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
President Bush declared himself a candidate for re-election today, filingpapers that allow him to begin raising money and put a campaign staff in place for a race that his advisers say will hinge on whether he can revive the economy and protect the nation from terrorism.
 After months in which it said Mr. Bush was ignoring electoral politics to focus on the war with Iraq and pushing his tax cut through Congress, the White House pulled back the curtain today on a campaign operation that plans to send out one million fund-raising letters in the next few days, has a Web site up and running and has assembled a group of top officials ready to start work. 
 Although the core of Mr. Bush's strategy is to remain an above-the-fray leader, his aides and political advisers said he planned to move quickly to collect millions of dollars to wage his campaign, beginning with a fund-raiser next month. Republican fund-raisers said the campaign was drawing up a heavy schedule of appearances this year for Vice President Dick Cheney, who confirmed last week that he would be on the ticket again. 
But in what could be a move to tamp down expectations, officials disputed widespread reports that they intended to raise $200 million or more to pay for advertising and other activities through the Republican convention in New York late next summer. They said their announced goal would be closer to the record $100 million the Bush campaign raised for the 2000 election.
Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's longtime strategist and the architect of the re-election plan, will remain on the White House payroll, administration officials said. Mr. Bush named Ken Mehlman, the White House political director, as his campaign manager. Mr. Mehlman will run the campaign from an office in Northern Virginia.
The campaign's finance chairman, overseeing fund-raising, will be Mercer Reynolds, a friend of Mr. Bush who is a former ambassador to Switzerland. Jack Oliver, the deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee, will run the campaign's fund-raising operation day to day as deputy chairman for finance. 
Republicans said Marc Racicot, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, would probably leave the committee to take the post of campaign chairman. The leading candidate to replace Mr. Racicot is Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist, though Mr. Gillespie may be named instead to run the convention in New York next year, people with ties to the White House said.
White House officials said Mr. Bush made the decision to set up the campaign, officially Bush-Cheney '04 Inc., in a meeting on May 8. He approved the personnel appointments over the weekend and this morning signed the forms required by the Federal Election Commission.
The White House said Mr. Bush would forgo federal matching funds during the primary campaign. By doing so, Republican strategists said, Mr. Bush will free himself from any spending limits and be able to bank a huge war chest that he can use in the months next spring and summer between the end of the primaries and the party conventions, when the Democratic nominee is likely to be broke. 
In comments to reporters this afternoon as he left the White House for a weekend at Camp David, Mr. Bush made it clear that he would resist being cast as a candidate, insisting that his mind was on creating jobs and keeping the American people safe.
"The American people will decide whether or not I deserve a second term," he said. 
His focus, he said, is "helping people find work" and "dealing with countries from around the world to make sure that they know that the war on terror continues."
Mr. Bush begins the race at a time when his standing in the polls is formidable and the Democratic field is fractured and little known by voters. But he must also deal with an economy that has lost more than two million jobs since he took office, a rapidly rising budget deficit, a depressed stock market, 41 million people without health insurance and an aging population that is increasingly concerned about the long-term viability of Social Security and Medicare.
"The Democrats are clinging to the one piece of flotation they have, and that's the economy and the associated issue of health care," said Ross K. Baker, a political scientist at Rutgers University.
Terry McAuliffe, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said he was surprised that Mr. Bush had gone through the formalities of setting up a re-election campaign "since all this man does is campaign every day" through a slick White House operation that juxtaposes his role as commander in chief with his domestic agenda.
"This election will be about jobs and who the American public thinks will do a better job of creating jobs," Mr. McAuliffe said. "The American public is sick and tired of him trying to use patriotism to push through an ultra-right-wing agenda."
Although Mr. Bush's re-election effort is primarily about keeping him in power, Republican strategists said Mr. Rove was hopeful that it could further a broader goal: tipping a nation that has been almost evenly balanced between the parties more clearly and lastingly to the Republican side.
They said the White House was intent not just on winning a convincing victory for Mr. Bush, but also on expanding the thin Republican majorities in the House and the Senate to reduce the need to compromise on nearly every issue. In pursuit of this goal, they said, the White House has been unusually involved in recruiting candidates for House and Senate races, reinvigorating state party organizations and encouraging interest groups to back the administration's agenda.
White House officials, they said, hope to keep up a strategy of dividing Democrats on critical issues like tax cuts, leaving the party prone to infighting and without a coherent message.
Mr. Bush and his political team have also worked hard to court elements of traditionally Democratic electoral blocs, including labor unions and Hispanic voters, without alienating their base of white conservatives in the South and West.
Republican strategists and administration officials said the White House's emphasis in the next few months would be on winning as many legislative victories as possible to establish a record of accomplishment they can carry into 2004. 
They said Mr. Bush would push hard to resolve differences between House and Senate Republicans over the tax bill as quickly as possible so he can claim credit for having given the economy a lift. They said he would also like to push a bill providing prescription drug coverage to retirees through Congress this summer to neutralize Democratic efforts to attack him on health care.

HEADLINE: Job Security a Thing of the Past for City Workers 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

 BODY:
For Winifred Gourdine, 2003 at least started out as a good year. 
 A promotion she had spent 12 years working toward as an addiction counselor for prisoners had recently come through, bringing with it the promise of $46,000 a year, money enough to help her care for a teenage nephew. 
 But Ms. Gourdine's good fortune ended yesterday as she and about 2,000 other municipal workers were ushered into the unemployment line, casualties of the city's fiscal crisis and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's effort to pare the city's largest expense, its payroll. 
Hundreds more city workers who have also received pink slips will work their last days over the next several weeks. The mayor signaled yesterday that still more employees could be laid off if the State Legislature does not override Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a $1.8 billion revenue package.
"If they were not to override the veto on Monday," Mr. Bloomberg said during his weekly radio show on WABC-AM, "we'd start the process to send out cuts, the next $1 billion contingency plan. We'd lay off 10,000 workers. It would devastate the city."
For Ms. Gourdine, one of 57 employees laid off from the Rikers Island drug intervention program, the devastation has already begun.
"I always thought when my time was right, I would get my promotion and my raise," said Ms. Gourdine, 47, of the Bronx. "But this is terrible. My father was a civil servant, a bus driver. I come from an era that believed when you get into city government you're secure. You don't have to ever worry when you work for the city."
Now, with no job, no college degree and limited savings, Ms. Gourdine says her worries are endless. There is the cost of maintaining the single-family home she shares with her mother and her 14-year-old nephew. 
"It's like everything came at one time," she said. "I'm already one of the homeowners with the 18.5 percent tax increase. Now the water is going up. There is no break. There is an increase for this, increase for that. There is no affordable anything in New York right now."
As she milled about the Manhattan offices of the Social Service Employees Union, which represents 385 of those who worked their last day yesterday, Ms. Gourdine said she was certain of only one thing: "The mayor is trying to push working people out of this city." 
With yesterday's layoffs, the prison drug intervention program is all but shut down, with just a skeletal staff remaining. 
Ronald B. Moore, a colleague of Ms. Gourdine's who was also laid off from the program, said he was as worried about the inmates who depended on it as he was about himself.
"We were making a difference," Mr. Moore, 44, said of the program, which provided 600 beds for drug treatment 24 hours a day, year-round. "These are things that correlate into savings for the taxpayer and the city when we can give some knowledge to young people that interaction with drugs is not a good thing." 
He said being angry at Mr. Bloomberg or the union would be a waste. "I can't fault them," he said. "My beef is with the people I worked with every day. They didn't do anything to present something to keep us around."
For now, Mr. Moore said, he continues to hope that a miracle will restore his job. 
The cost of living in New York City without a job, even with a college degree, is too discouraging to think about, he said. His monthly payments include $1,800 for a two-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights and $565 for his car loan. 
"I've got to move to a smaller place, leave my neighborhood and my people," he said. "I've got to do all of this because somebody didn't want my program. It's sad."

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: DIPLOMACY; 
Germany Pursues U.N. Accord to End Sanctions on Iraq

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 16 

 BODY:
Moving away from Germany's near-total opposition to American policy on Iraq, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said today that he wanted to reach an agreement on the Security Council resolution being pressed by Britain and the United States.
 The resolution would lift economic sanctions on Iraq and give the United States and Britain broad authority to administer the country in the aftermath of the war. 
 After meeting with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell here this morning, Mr. Schroder said in a statement, "Together we established that it makes sense to come together in New York at the United Nations headquarters and, if possible, to develop a unanimous position." 
Mr. Schroder explicitly agreed for the first time with the central American demand that the sanctions imposed by the United Nations in 1990 be lifted.
With relations between Germany and the United States virtually frozen since well before the beginning of the Iraq war, Mr. Schroder's conciliatory statements were in sharp contrast to the diplomatic jousting over the American-led campaign, which Germany adamantly opposed. Mr. Schroder's statements seemed clearly intended to repair ties between two important allies.
Relations between Mr. Schroder and President Bush have been particularly frosty for months, and the countries have exchanged insults that would long have been unthinkable. 
There are still tens of thousands of American troops based in Germany, a country that was pivotal to America's European alliances for decades.
Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, who met separately with Mr. Powell today, said afterward: "The U.S. draft resolution is a good basis for our discussions and the talks today also showed that we are well on the way to an agreement. I am very optimistic."
Mr. Powell said, "It should be possible to come to closure quickly over the next several days, a week, on a U.N. resolution."
The Germans, who hold a nonpermanent seat on the Security Council, stopped short of announcing outright support of the resolution, with Mr. Fischer indicating that there was still more negotiating to be done, not only with the United States but with other Security Council members.
"We are of the opinion that the sanctions that were imposed in the past no longer have any meaning and that they should be lifted as soon as possible," Mr. Schroder said.
"I was pleased at the chancellor's commitment to lift sanctions entirely," said Mr. Powell, standing on the lawn behind the gleaming, modern German presidential office, with Mr. Schroder at a lectern beside him.
The changed mood seemed to mark some success for Mr. Powell, whose one-day visit to Germany came at the end of a weeklong foreign tour that also included the Middle East and Russia, during which he sought to garner support for the British-American Security Council draft.
Europeanmembers of the Security Council, including Germany, France and Russia, want the United Nations to play a central role in Iraq, while France and Russia have called for United Nations weapons inspectors to return to Iraq before the sanctions are formally lifted, something that the United States opposes.
In an effort to win broader approval of the resolution, Britain and the United States have submitted a revised draft that gives a somewhat greater role to a United Nations envoy to Iraq, but the resolution still gives the members of the coalition that joined the war there decisive power to administer the country and control its resources while a new Iraqi government is created.
"We believe the United Nations must play a vital role," Mr. Powell said in a German television interview broadcast today. But, he continued, "There is probably still continuing discussion as to how large a role it should play." 
Mr. Powell arrived here from Russia, where he failed in talks with President Vladimir V. Putin and Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov to reach agreement either on ending sanctions or on the wording of a Security Council resolution. Today, Deputy Foreign Minister Yuri V. Fedotov said Russia and China, both permanent Security Council members, wanted further "serious amendments" to the British-American draft.
But while Mr. Powell acknowledged in Moscow that there were still "outstanding issues" between Russia and the United States, the mood following his talks in Germany seemed warm and friendly, particularly in contrast with the recent past.
Mr. Powell and Mr. Fischer seemed to go out of their way to announce their close personal friendship, with Mr. Powell referring to Mr. Fischer by his first name, saying, "Joschka and I are always able to speak our hearts and minds to one another."
Mr. Powell also notably reiterated a point that had been a refrain among German leaders during the months of nearly frozen relations but had rarely, if ever, uttered by Bush administration officials: that friends can disagree with each other, even sharply, and still remain friends.
"We also know what draws us together -- shared values, sacrifices together and working in many parts of the world together now, whether it's the Balkans, in Afghanistan or elsewhere," Mr. Powell said.
Despite the expressions of optimism, neither side was prepared to say they were in full agreement yet on the terms for the lifting of sanctions or on the resolution. Germany, while clearly eager to mend its ties with the United States, entered into an informal alliance with France and Russia in opposition to the Iraq war, and the government here seems eager for those countries to agree on a postwar formula for Iraq.
Mr. Schroder has apologized in recent weeks for what he called "exaggerated remarks" made during his successful election campaign last fall in which his opposition to military action in Iraq both won him a second term as chancellor and deeply angered the United States. 
At a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Berlin last week, Mr. Schroder spoke of the "truly vital friendship" between the United States and Germany, but he also said he rejected the idea that Germany would have to choose between the United States and its partners in the European Union.
Throughout the months of openly hostile relations, German officials said they wanted to find ways to heal the rift. 
"The last several months have been very, very difficult," Mr. Powell said in an interview with German television, but he added that the two countries needed to move on.

HEADLINE: The Art in Budget Cutting 

 BODY:
The depth of the city's fiscal crisis, with its $3.8 billion hole, means nothing is untouchable, no cuts unthinkable. Mayor Michael Bloomberg has tried to do the right thing by protecting the fundamentals: education, health, safety and sanitation. But even these are vulnerable. Among the thousands laid off over the next few months will be hundreds of teachers' aides and dozens of fire marshals. Nearly half of the city-supported children's health clinics will close. There will be fewer police officers enforcing quality-of-life laws. Trash collections in the outer boroughs will become less frequent, just in time for the hottest days of the year. 
 This is a three-hankie budget, with something to make almost everyone cry. In such a bleak picture, there is little justification for keeping firehouses open just because they have been community fixtures. And, sad to say, the city does not really need to keep open small zoos in Brooklyn and Queens, much as some residents love them. 
 But the mayor may want to take a second look at proposed cuts in some useful and cost-efficient social programs, like funds to help keep low-income families together instead of sending children into foster care, which costs a lot more. The proposed cuts in the budgets of the parks, libraries and cultural institutions that help make New York the place it is may also merit review. The cuts would eliminate many workers who keep up park grounds and restrooms, threatening a return to the bad old days when green spaces were dirty and dangerous. The 34 members of the Cultural Institutions Group, which includes some of the city's largest and most visited sites -- like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Botanical Garden and the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- will lose $25 million in operating funds. That translates into layoffs, canceled programs and lost revenue.
Mr. Bloomberg suggests that cultural institutions compensate by passing the hat. To his great credit, the mayor puts his own money where his mouth is -- he is a major private contributor to the arts. But fund-raisers say that finding well-heeled contributors and foundations to fill the void is becoming harder and harder. Even with an ambitious fund-raising drive, the New York Public Library, which is mostly privately financed, foresees reduced hours and book purchases if it loses a projected $7.3 million in city aid on top of the $16 million cut last year.
Because these institutions draw not only New Yorkers but also millions of tourists, the cuts could have enormous impact on neighborhoods where they are the chief employers. The amount of city support is a tiny slice of the municipal budget, and the size of the projected cuts for cultural institutions is proportionately much larger than the cuts for other programs. The mayor and the City Council, as they continue working on the final spending package, need to trim very carefully in this area and ask themselves when the money saved is outweighed by potential economic losses.

HEADLINE: Talks in Congress Dim Hopes for Speedy Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
President Bush is determined to get a tax bill enacted quickly that eliminates taxes on stock dividends, even if only briefly, administration officials said today.
 But the view in Congress is that negotiations between the House and Senate on tax legislation could take weeks, and there is little enthusiasm in many quarters for a temporary tax suspension. 
 Just before midnight on Thursday, the Senate voted, 51 to 49, to approve its version of the tax legislation. The central element, adopted when Vice President Dick Cheney cast the vote to break a 50-50 tie, would reduce taxes on dividends for one year, abolish them entirely for three years and reinstate them in 2007. 
Last week, the House approved a substantially different tax bill, which would reduce the tax rate on dividends and capital gains to 15 percent. The 10-year revenue loss from the House bill was calculated at $550 billion, compared with $350 billion for the Senate bill.
Administration officials said today that the president much preferred the Senate bill, was not concerned about charges that the off-again, on-again tax was a gimmick and was most interested in proclaiming victory and moving on.
Once the tax on dividends is off the books, these officials said, Democrats will not have the political stomach to restore it.
As he boarded his helicopter to spend the weekend at his retreat at Camp David, Md., President Bush told reporters: "I'm optimistic about our economy and its future. I'm even more optimistic now that the Senate has acted."
The administration's next goal, the officials said, is to move on to Medicare legislation, a step that cannot happen in earnest until the tax issue is resolved. 
Moreover, they said, delay in enacting a tax cut will limit its effect on an economy that is flagging now.
One aspect of the legislation passed by the House and the Senate that has received relatively little attention and that could help the economy at once, one official said, is a $400 per child tax rebate that will be paid to nearly all taxpaying families within weeks of the time the bill becomes law.
What the president does not want, the officials said, is a protracted fight over taxes among Republicans in Congress, but that is what may happen.
Republican officials on Capitol Hill said House leaders might wait a week or two before appointing members to the House-Senate conference committee on the legislation in the hope that the additional time -- and increased pressure from President Bush -- would persuade the Senate to increase the size of the tax cut.
Senators tend to advertise their independence and play down the influence the president has on their votes. But on the tax bill, three crucial votes came from senators -- George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, and Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Evan Bayh of Indiana, both Democrats -- whose states the president had visited to promote his tax plan while the Senate was considering it. 
The ability of senators to negotiate in the conference committee is restricted by the promise made by Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Finance Committee, that he would not bring a bill to the floor of the Senate that showed a revenue loss of more than $350 billion over 10 years. Mr. Grassley, who would be chairman of a conference committee, made the pledge in order to get a budget passed by the Senate last month.
House leaders were furious when Mr. Grassley did this without warning them. Now some are considering a strategy to avoid a conference and bypass Mr. Grassley. 
Under this plan, Senate and House leaders would determine next week the elements of a bill that would please the House and still get enough votes to pass the Senate. On Friday, the House would take up the bill passed by the Senate, rewrite it to meet House specifications and pass it, and then leave for a 10-day recess, challenging the Senate to pass it too or thwart the president's desire to have a bill through Congress by Memorial Day.
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority leader, has told Republicans to be prepared to work late on Friday.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, who is often less confrontational than Mr. DeLay, seemed uncomfortable with this approach. "A formal conference is how we usually do things," Mr. Hastert said. "It would have to be an extraordinary situation if we did not do that."
In addition, Mr. Grassley is proud of his reputation for being straight-forward and is unlikely to relent without a fight. "I keep my word," he said Thursday night.
House leaders are cool to the Senate's approach of suspending taxes on dividends and then reinstating them, a procedure known as a sunset. "The general view," one top staff member said, "is that it is gimmicky and not very good economic policy. You want a policy that changes people's long-term behavior, knowing this is the way the law is going to be."
In moving the tax bill through the Senate in two days of marathon sessions, Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, pleased the White House, and he annoyed Democrats by refusing to bring up a bill that would increase the nation's debt limit by nearly $1 trillion. Democrats had hoped that a debate over the debt limit this week would highlight the effect of tax cuts on the record budget deficits, but Dr. Frist decided to postpone the matter until next week, putting some distance between the issues.
The postponement, however, strained the Treasury Department's ability to manage the debt. A spokeswoman for the Treasury said the debt had come so close to the limit of $6.4 trillion that the department had to postpone next week's routine sale of short-term securities.
"Things are rather urgent now," said the spokeswoman, Betsy Holahan. But Ms. Holahan said that if the Senate raised the debt limit next week, there would be no danger of default. The House has already voted to raise the limit by $984 billion, the largest increase ever.

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: WAR CRIMES; 
Mass Grave in Iraq May Hold Kuwaitis Missing Since 1991

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: HABBANIYA, Iraq, May 16 

 BODY:
A map provided by a former driver for Iraqi military intelligence brought Abdulaziz al-Qubaisi Abu Musab to the abandoned Iraqi military camp here this morning in search of the answer to the question that most Kuwaitis have asked -- and dreaded -- since the end of the 1991 Persian Gulf war: where are the nearly 600 missing Kuwaitis?
 Mr. Abu Musab, a member of the Iraqi National Congress, the political movement headed by Ahmad Chalabi, said he had been given the map by a man who, in October 1991, was among the drivers who took the Kuwaiti prisoners to their execution in Baghdad and subsequent burial here, 50 miles west of the capital. 
 It was impossible to speak directly to this driver, who calls himself Samir and still fears for his life, or to say today how accurate his account of the execution is. But the map he gave Mr. Abu Musab proved very accurate. 
For the past 12 years, Kuwait has demanded to know the fate of nearly 600 prisoners taken by Saddam Hussein's security forces after the country was invaded by Iraq in 1990. It has offered $1 million for information. Mr. Abu Musab said attempts to mobilize Kuwaiti or United States military help to open the suspected mass grave here had drawn no response for days.
So, today, he put a tractor and backhoe on a trailer and drove west from Baghdad past American checkpoints and burned-out Iraqi tanks to this gentle slope of desert facing the crystalline Lake Habbaniya shimmering in the early summer heat.
He straddled the mechanical claw and began digging. He had to go deep, 10 feet down, past a viper that he disturbed and then killed, through gravel and sand, because that is where Samir said the bodies were heaped in three places marked on the carefully drawn map.
Then, just where Samir's map said they were, he found the first 40 decomposed bodies that, according to the driver's account, are the first installment of nearly 600 Kuwaiti corpses.
If forensic examinations confirm Samir's account, the mass grave here would answer one of the most painful and enduring mysteries for Kuwait, the tiny American ally that fought invasion and occupation in 1990-91 and, 12 years later, turned over much of its country to United States-led forces that drove Mr. Hussein from power last month.
The bodies lay in bundles, the same jumble of bones, decay and bits of fabric that the earth is yielding all over Iraq.
Some skulls betrayed execution wounds. Green plastic ties that can be used as handcuffs were scattered among the remains. A finger bone was all that lay within the coil of one. A random shoe separated from its owner still held a constellation of foot bones that had collapsed to one flat dimension without the flesh that once gave them shape. 
"They killed them in Baghdad and brought the bodies here," Mr. Abu Musab said. 
In pre-empting allied forces and the forensic specialists whose task it will be to document the mass graves that are being unearthed throughout Iraq, Mr. Chalabi's group appeared to be trying to elevate the priority that American officials have assigned to the investigation of the killings by Saddam Hussein's security forces. 
Mr. Chalabi, by taking matters into his own hands in a period of political transition here, appeared to be pushing himself forward on an issue that has the potential to galvanize the Iraqi people by calling attention to the mass killings.
The ambition of Mr. Chalabi to play a central role in the governance of postwar Iraq is well known, and he has strong allies in the Pentagon. But many Iraqis are hostile to him.
"This grim discovery, together with the mass grave sites being found across the country in cities like Hilla, reveal to the world the scope of the brutality of Saddam's regime and his crimes against humanity," Mr. Chalabi said. "The world must act now to assist the Iraqi people with proper forensic experts and documentation specialists, so that the full extent of Saddam's crimes can be uncovered."
In a pointed criticism of Arab leaders, one he has already made, he added, "Those who supported this regime are now witnessing the monster that they enabled."
Mr. Abu Musab gave this account of what Samir told him in a meeting in Baghdad three or four days ago:
The killing began one morning in October 1991 at 8:30. The frightened Kuwaitis -- blindfolded, with hands bound by lime-green plastic ties -- were ordered into horseshoe formations at the training school for the intelligence service in Baghdad. The prisoners had been brought there that morning in vans and buses.
A single intelligence man carrying a machine gun positioned himself inside the horseshoe. The prisoners wept and cried out the Muslim prayer before death: there is no god but God.
The gunfire began. The shooter pivoted, according to the account provided to Mr. Abu Musab, using the horseshoe formation to make the executions quicker. 
Formation after formation was brought forward until all were dead. All were men, save one.
In Samir's account, he and three other drivers then loaded the bodies onto Mercedes trucks and drove them to this base, where one 10-foot-deep pit already was cut into the sand. Two other pits were dug to hold the remaining bodies near a large sand berm, a water tower and a fence. 
When the work was done, Samir and theother drivers and 15 men who had helped with the burial were forced to live here for three months as the desert removed all traces of their grisly dig. 
Before they were allowed to leave, they were warned that if they ever talked, Iraqi intelligence would find them and kill them.
Today, Samir is just another unemployed Iraqi who does not want to advertise his old profession, but he has heard about Kuwait's offer of a $1 million reward for information leading to the recovery of its missing. 
"But he is still scared that someone in intelligence will take revenge because the people who participated in this act are still around," Mr. Abu Musab said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bodies being unearthed at a mass grave west of Baghdad may be those of Kuwaitis missing since 1991. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)(pg. A9) Map of Iraq highlighting the grave site located in Habbaniya: Forty bodies have so far been dug up at a mass grave at Habbaniya. (pg. A9)

HEADLINE: City Lays Off 2,000 as Talks Grow Bitter 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The Bloomberg administration appeared to toughen its stance toward the municipal unions yesterday, ratcheting up the harshness of its criticisms and carrying out layoffs that the unions said should have been delayed while negotiations continued. 
 The unions accused the city's chief labor negotiator of walking out of last-minute negotiations aimed at stopping the first major round of municipal layoffs since the Dinkins administration. 
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had suggested that he might suspend the layoffs if the unions agreed to $600 million in labor savings. But City Hall officials, using tough language, dismissed the unions' money-saving proposals as paltry. 
"The mayor has given them chance after chance to help save these jobs, and they are the ones who have so unfortunately refused to help, and so a few thousand workers will end their employment with New York City today," said William Cunningham, communications director for Mayor Bloomberg.
The standoff is one of the most bitter between City Hall and labor leaders in decades, and raises questions about whether the two groups can come together on productivity savings and other contract issues at a time of dire fiscal crisis.
After yesterday's bargaining session ended, the administration's top negotiator, the city labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, announced that the layoffs threatened by Mayor Bloomberg would take effect, making yesterday the last day of work for more than 2,000 city workers. They represented the first major layoffs by the city since 1992, when David N. Dinkins was mayor.
"They asked us to stop the clock on layoffs, and we said we weren't going to do it," Mr. Hanley said after leaving the bargaining session. "We said there was nothing further to talk about."
The failure of yesterday's negotiations represented the most definitive rupture between the unions and Mr. Bloomberg, who has looked to the unions to play a major role in helping the city close its $3.8 billion budget gap and ease future budget pressures. 
Among the money-saving proposals the unions made to City Hall this week was for union volunteers to use the unions' political phone banks to make calls to help collect more than $1 billion in uncollected taxes and fines. The unions also fleshed out their proposals on how to save the city $100 million annually through the workers' health plans, including, one city official said, increased employee co-payments. In addition, the unions said they would be willing to lend the city $200 million from their health-care funds at low interest rates.
Like other union leaders, Randi Weingarten, chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee and president of the teachers' union, voiced anger about the layoffs and the failure of the talks, held at the headquarters of District Council 37. 
"We did everything, despite the name calling," she said. "I was shocked that they would walk out."
But Mr. Hanley said the unions' proposals were hardly worth discussing. "It's been a year since we've been at this, and the unions have not proposed meaningful, quantifiable, recurring savings," he said, asserting that many of their proposals were one-shot revenue sources, which Mr. Bloomberg rejects.
The city sent out 3,000 pink slips two weeks ago, and Mr. Hanley said about 2,000 people would stop working effective yesterday, with several hundred more losing jobs over the next few weeks. The layoffs affect many groups, including sanitation workers and caseworkers in the Administration for Children's Services. 
"I'm angry at Bloomberg and the union for what they're doing to us," said James Wilson, who lost his $28,000-a-year job at a homeless shelter in Jamaica after working there for 12 years. "The union should have given back something. I don't know what they did. It's all confusing. I don't know how to accept this. I just pray something opens up and they call me back."
Mr. Hanley said that in June, 2,000 workers in the department of education would be laid off.
Ms. Weingarten, the chief negotiator for some 300,000 municipal workers, is caught between the city's demands for substantial sacrifices, like adopting a longer work week and reducing vacation and sick days, and the demands from the uniformed unions not to grant substantial concessions. Several union leaders have said that, if they had to choose, they would prefer seeing layoffs to agreeing to concessions that could take years for the unions to win back. 
Ms. Weingarten seems increasingly trapped between her roles as leader of the larger group of municipal employees and as head of the teachers' union, as teachers are largely immune from the threat of layoffs. Many people on both sides of the table note that teachers and perhaps members of the city's largest union, District Council 37, might be willing to entertain some of the mayor's ideas for savings, but that leaders of the uniformed service unions are completely intransigent. 
Peter Gorman, president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, said the unions should not give "one penny" to help the city. Several union officials said the presidents of several uniformed unions have taken Ms. Weingarten to task in private Municipal Labor Committee meetings when she suggested meeting Mr. Bloomberg halfway.
Ms. Weingarten said it was quite an accomplishment to persuade all the unions to propose $100 million in health savings, which would come to $330 per union member per year. She said the $600 million in savings sought by the mayor would cost union members $2,000 each.
"The mayor is asking unionized workers to pay twice," she said. "The unionized work force is paying the new taxes, new fare increase, the new tuition hikes. Why should they, as opposed to everybody else, pay twice?"
Ms. Weingarten said Mayor Bloomberg appeared determined to lay off workers because he rejected the unions' proposal to have City Comptroller William Thompson, State Comptroller Alan Hevesi and an official to be named by the mayor examine the validity and value of the union's proposals. 
The union leaders insist their proposals are worth $600 million, while the Bloomberg administration says they contain just $20 million in specific savings.
"The real issue today was whether we're on the right track to stop the clock on layoffs until we exhaust this process," Ms. Weingarten said.
Arthur Cheliotes, president of Communications Workers 1180, which represents 8,000 supervisors and middle managers, asserted that the mayor's strategy was to take back labor's hard-won gains. 
"I think long-term he's looking to use this fiscal crisis to really undermine our health benefits and pensions," he said. 
City officials insist that Mr. Hanley did not walk out of yesterday's session, and that he would like to continue a dialogue with the unions.
"The mayor remains interested in any proposals by labor to increase productivity and create real and recurring savings, none of which we have seen to date," said Ed Skyler, a City Hall spokesman. "Substantial fiscal challenges still lie ahead, and labor can still help shoulder the burden and protect our work force."

HEADLINE: Tax Cut Plan: A Boon for Whom? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Senate Adopts a Tax Cut Plan of $350 Billion" (front page, May 16): 
 While President Bush muscles his way to a big tax cut, our economy slogs along at a pathetic pace. 
 One wonders if the Bush administration likes to have a high percentage of the work force unemployed. Unemployment helps employers to hold wages down.
Meanwhile, the thrifty who depend on interest income have less spending power. That further depresses the economy.
Most people would be happier to have more income rather than lower tax rates. The unemployed don't pay taxes. The underemployed pay little. Spending creates jobs.

GENE W. DEVAUX
Greenwood, Mo., May 16, 2003

HEADLINE: Imperial Blues 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Margaret MacMillan's review of "Empire: The Rise and Demise of the British World Order and the Lessons for Global Power," by Niall Ferguson (April 20), is perhaps rather too lenient. Ferguson's lucid work certainly does justice to some of the more positive remnants of the imperial rule: exportation of parliamentary systems of democracy, economic infrastructures and a global economic system. The experience of India, however, which was the "Jewel in the Crown" of the empire, raises some serious concerns. The thrust of Ferguson's work stresses the positive, more "modern" legacy of the empire. But the very notion of "modern" in India's case is problematic. 
By the middle of the 18th century, India accounted for nearly 25 percent of the world's global trade. Whenthe British left, this figure had dwindled to around 4 to 5 percent. The world demand for fine Indian textiles was essentially satisfied by those from the "dark satanic" Manchester mills. Much scholarly research has demonstrated that during the period of British rule India's economy underwent a process of "peasantization," whereby agriculture was given primacy at the expense of domestic industry and which ensured that Britain would be able to exercise dominant economic muscle by guaranteeing itself a market for British textiles in a country from which the colonial power had learned so much (over 1,000 words of Indian origin have made their way into the English language, a majority commerce-related). Thus, to claim that the British Empire helped to spearhead a modern, global capitalist system would be somewhat misleading.
 MacMillan's review certainly addresses the more convincing arguments of the book, but it ignores the complication that the "Jewel" of the argument raises: that the British Empire bequeathed a "modern" legacy to the current world.

Hayden J. A. Bellenoit
Oxford, England
