HEADLINE: FOOD; 
Cat Fight

BYLINE:  By Julia Reed

 BODY:
I should declare my loyalty to catfish upfront. Or, more precisely, to American farm-raised catfish, more than 70 percent of which comes from the Mississippi Delta, where I grew up.
 During my brief career as a business reporter, I wrote about the fledgling catfish industry first for The Orlando Sentinel and then for U.S. News & World Report. The Catfish Farmers of America were so grateful that they sent me a plaque "in recognition for the contribution made . . . through the use of my craft." More thrillingly, they asked me to reign as a sort of ad hoc Catfish Queen and ride on their float in the 1987 Mobile, Ala., Mardi Gras parade. The fact that I didn't remains one of my greatest regrets. I assume I would have gotten to wear a crown, and I have always imagined it to have been in the shape of two catfish with their mouths meeting in the middle, their rhinestone whiskers shimmering above my forehead. 
 The fish I would have represented is, forgive me, a relatively new breed of cat, bearing almost no resemblance to the omnivorous, mud-loving bottom feeders my father and I fished for when I was little. 
That's because in the 1970's and 80's, when Mississippi farmers were facing the worst depression since the 1930's, many of those who could still get a bank loan decided to trade in their soybean and cotton seeds for fish fingerlings and started digging ponds. Since then, the farmers and their trade organizations, the Catfish Farmers of America and the Catfish Institute, have spent at least $70 million aggressively marketing their product. They printed endless cookbooks, published impressive stats (the fish is raised in environmentally controlled conditions; it is low in fat and cholesterol) and supported enormous events like the Catfish Festival in Belzoni, Miss., a community of 2,660 that is rightly billed as the "Catfish Capital of the World." Last year 630 million pounds of farm-raised catfish were processed in the United States, bringing an estimated $243 million to Mississippi alone, with an impact of more than $2 billion on the state's economy.
So when the Vietnamese started peddling catfish from the Mekong Delta in this country under brand names like Delta Select (a moniker mighty close to the popular Mississippi brand Delta Pride), the farmers got very upset. One of the first things the Americans challenged was the right of the Vietnamese farmers to use the word itself. They maintain that the Vietnamese fish is really basa fish, whatever that is, and that labeling it as catfish is, in the words of Hugh Warren, executive vice president of the C.F.A., the equivalent of "selling kangaroo meat as sirloin." Last year the C.F.A. persuaded Congress to bar the Vietnamese from calling their fish catfish and to require them to stamp their packages with the country of origin so there wouldn't be any more confusion about which delta had been the fish's birthplace.
Since there are more than 2,000 species of catfish in the world, it does seem a tad ridiculous to contend that our North American family, Ictaluridae, is the only one that can be correctly called catfish. But in this current war with Vietnam at least, I am firmly on our side. I can't help it. I have never been good at escaping my roots. And I honestly do believe it is a superior product.
Farm-raised catfish are pure little packages of protein, raised in ponds filled with aerated and circulated well water and fed pellets composed of soybeans and corn. They don't taste muddy; they taste sweet. John Edgerton, the Southern historian and food writer who laments what has happened to the taste of chickens since they've been mass-produced, admits that farm-raised catfish are "an anomaly: one of the few artificially produced foods that may be better than the original." Nothing, he says, "beats pond-raised catfish, not even the native cats of the South's lakes and rivers."
The latter is a point the American catfish farmers have seized on in their battle with the Vietnamese, who raise their fish in huge underwater pens in the polluted Mekong River. "They've grown up flapping around in third-world rivers and dining on whatever they can get their fins on," read one advertisement produced by the catfish lobby. Representative Marion Berry of Arkansas, whose state is also a top catfish producer, went so far as to accuse the Vietnamese fish of being contaminated with Agent Orange. "That stuff doesn't break down." That last crack is a bit much, especially since we're the ones who sprayed the stuff over there in the first place. Also, now the farmers are claiming that the Vietnamese are illegally "dumping" their catfish on the U.S. market at artificially low prices and asked the Commerce Department to impose import duties. The department responded with a preliminary ruling recommending import duties of as much as 64 percent. The Vietnamese contend that this violates the spirit of free trade and that the United States is protecting the interests of "a relatively small group of wealthy catfish industrialists." 
I have to confess that I agree with the free trade part, but until now "wealthy" and "industrialist" were not words I thought I would ever live to see bracketing "catfish." First of all, these days you don't get rich (much less become a personage as impressive as an industrialist) farming anything in the Mississippi Delta. Also, catfish has always been an inexpensive food for the masses. At catfish fries across the South, hundreds and sometimes thousands are fed -- the world's biggest, which serves 12,500 pounds of catfish, lasts about a week and is held every April in Paris, Tenn. A staple of old-fashioned Southern retail politicking, a catfish fry features fillets dredged in seasoned cornmeal and deep-fried in huge drumsof roiling oil, accompanied by tartar sauce, pickles, coleslaw and fries. I can think of no better way to enjoy catfish and frequently do at catfish joints like Middendorf's in Manchac, La., or at the Taylor Grocery in Taylor, Miss. 
But since the farm-raised industry has taken off, the locals have gotten more adventurous. I have become addicted to both the catfish and capers and the smoked catfish pate from the Crown Restaurant in Indianola, Miss. (They ship just about anywhere in the United States: 800-833-7731.) I also love catfish meuniere, and it is excellent in a classic bouillabaisse or bourride and in a Creole concoction called courtbouillon. This has almost nothing in common with a proper clear court-bouillon used to cook fish or shellfish and is usually pronounced COO-bi-yon. It is closer to a stew than a soup, and like most things that originated in New Orleans, it is an amalgamation of French, Spanish and African cooking. It is easy and delicious, and I hate to admit that it can also be made with redfish or red snapper. As much as I love it, recently -- and perhaps perversely -- I have been more inclined toward a dish that originated in Vietnam's neighbor Laos, where, by whatever name, they have been eating catfish for a long time. While I bow to their history, I am still mindful of my own. So I would never actually make it with anything other than farm-raised catfish from the (Mississippi) Delta.

Laotian Catfish Soup
1 1/2 pounds catfish fillets
12 garlic cloves, peeled and finely chopped
3 to 4 Thai chilies, seeded and finely chopped
3 (double) fresh kaffir lime leaves, stem and main vein removed, finely chopped
14-inch piece fresh lemongrass, thinly sliced
2 shallots, peeled and finely chopped
2 tablespoons peanut or vegetable oil
1 quart chicken broth or water
2 tablespoons fresh lime juice
2 1/4-inch-thick slices peeled galangal (fresh or frozen), optional
1/4 cup smooth peanut butter
1 can (about 14 ounces) unsweetened coconut milk
6 tablespoons Thai or Vietnamese fish sauce
2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh basil leaves
2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh cilantro
Cooked jasmine rice (optional).
1. Cut the catfish fillets into strips about 1 inch long by 1/2 inch wide, place on a plate, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate.
2. Saute the garlic, chilies, lime leaves, lemongrass and shallots in the oil in a deep skillet over medium heat until very fragrant, about 5 minutes. Add the chicken broth or water, the lime juice and the galangal if you're using it and heat the mixture to a slow simmer. 
3. Whisk the peanut butter and 2 tablespoons of the coconut milk in a small bowl until blended and then whisk it into the garlic mixture. Stir in the fish and remaining coconut milk and simmer gently until the fish layers separate when prodded with a fork, about 2 minutes. Stir in fish sauce, basil and cilantro and simmer 2 minutes. Serve immediately, with rice if desired.
Yield: 4 to 6 servings.
Note: Thai chilies, kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass, galangal and fish sauce are available at Bangkok Center Grocery, 104 Mosco Street (between Mott and Mulberry Streets), 212-349-1979.

Catfish Courtbouillon
1/2 cup vegetable oil
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 large yellow onion, peeled and finely chopped
1 green bell pepper, seeded and finely chopped
3 large garlic cloves, peeled and finely chopped
1/2 cup finely chopped celery
1 stick butter
6 cups fish stock or water
1 can (35 ounces) Italian tomatoes, roughly chopped
1 bunch Italian parsley, leaves chopped ( 1/2 cup lightly packed)
3 bay leaves
1 teaspoon dried thyme or 1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme
1 teaspoon dried or 1 tablespoon chopped fresh oregano, marjoram or basil
Juice of 1 lemon
1 cup dry white wine
4 pounds catfish fillets
1 bunch green onions, finely chopped
Cayenne pepper and salt to taste
Cooked rice for serving.
1. Heat the oil in a heavy 5-quart saucepan or enameled Dutch oven until smoking. Add the flour and stir until blended. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture is smooth and straw colored, about 3 minutes. Stir in the onion, pepper, garlic and celery. Reduce heat to medium and stir in the butter. Continue cooking until the vegetables begin to soften, about 5 minutes, stirring constantly. Meanwhile, bring the fish stock or water to a boil.
2. Stir in the tomatoes and their liquid, parsley, bay leaves, thyme and oregano, marjoram or basil to the flour mixture. Add the boiling fish stock, lemon juice and wine and stir gently. Simmer until thickened, 20 to 30 minutes. Add the fish, green onions and cayenne, stir gently and simmer just until the fish layers separate when prodded gently with a fork, about 2 minutes. Taste for seasoning. (It will need salt if water is used.) Serve over rice.
Yield: 10 to 12 servings.

HEADLINE: Commute to Nowhere 

 BODY:
 I was surprised by the decidedly unsympathetic letters (May 4) in response to Jonathan Mahler's article (April 13). As half of a couple that have experienced serial unemployment and the persistent threat of job loss, I understand the nonfinancial implications. For a family, it is not unlike chronic illness: uncertainty about the (near) future, depression, feeling that others (employed or healthy) are vaguely uncomfortable around you -- friends stop calling because they don't know what to say.

Terri Bernsohn
Evanston, Ill.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
Ken Loach: Still Driving On the Left

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
"IT'S funny how critics never seem to write about the content of films," said Ken Loach on a wet, snowy Manhattan afternoon in early March. Why was it, he wanted to know, that reviews in British and American newspapers will typically deal with every aspect of a movie except what it is centrally about?
 This was, I suspect, a rhetorical question. In any case, the content of Mr. Loach's films -- he has been making them since the mid-1960's, when he began working on weekly dramas for the BBC -- is hard to ignore. He has weathered the vicissitudes of British ideological and cinematic fashion and remains a staunch and unapologetic proponent of the stark, politically charged realism that flourished in those days, when, as he put it, "it was sexy to be on the left." Sexy or not, Mr. Loach, a stoop-shouldered, shy-seeming man of 66, has stayed there ever since, unbudged by the Thatcherism of the 1980's or Tony Blair's post-socialist "third way." 
 Mr. Loach's films are both the expression and the record of his political commitments; it would be a disservice to him and to them to pretend otherwise, though he does not make any grand claims about their political effectiveness. "We used to say back in the 60's that one good shop steward was worth six filmmakers -- or one good union organizer was worth six filmmakers," he said over lunch at a Midtown restaurant. "I think that's probably true." Since his first two features, "Poor Cow" in 1967 and "Kes" two years later, the grim lot of the British working class -- in particular the effects of work, poverty and the putatively benevolent intervention of the state on proletarian family life -- has been Mr. Loach's principal subject, though far from his only one. He has made movies about political violence in Northern Ireland ("Hidden Agenda"), Nicaragua ("Carla's Song") and Civil War-era Spain ("Land and Freedom") as well as about social misery in London and Glasgow; about Los Angeles janitors ("Bread and Roses") as well as Yorkshire railway workers ("The Navigators"). But to dwell too much on the overt political content of these films -- in solidarity, in disapproval, or in some wishy-washy liberal combination of the two -- is to risk missing their deeper theme, which is the terrible, almost always tragic collision between individual free will and the impersonal forces that mock, manipulate and thwart it.
Needless to say, Mr. Loach approaches this question less in the spirit of "The Matrix" than in the spirit of Marx, who observed that while people may make their own history, they do not do so in circumstances of their own choosing. When the title character in "My Name is Joe" (1998), who struggles with alcoholism and unemployment, cries out "I've got no choice," he could be speaking for any number of Mr. Loach's heroes and heroines, who seem driven, deceived or dragged kicking and screaming to their sad fates. They do, however, kick and scream -- they do, in spite of everything, make and act upon their choices -- which is what makes them heroes and heroines, rather than case studies.
Liam, the main character in "Sweet Sixteen," which opened in New York and Los Angeles on Friday (the day after "The Matrix Reloaded"), is a young teenager growing up in the drug- and unemployment-plagued housing projects of Glasgow. Like Maggie, the welfare mother in "Ladybird, Ladybird" (1993), or Maya, the illegal immigrant in "Bread and Roses" (2000), he meets the hard facts of his life with a fair amount of inventiveness and grit. "I think fighters are always attractive," Mr. Loach said. "I think people who see themselves as victims are not." But the attractive qualities his characters show -- the resilience and joie de vivre that make us root for them -- more often than not contribute to their defeat. Liam, whose mother is in jail on a drug charge, wants nothing more than to make a better life for her, his sister and his young nephew, and so, with admirable entrepreneurial pluck, he goes into the drug business himself, with consequences that are no less devastating for being foreseeable. "In a way I think that's what makes them tragic characters rather than just victims," Mr. Loach said. "Their strength is their undoing. I mean that's like classical tragedy in a way."
The tragic dimension that Mr. Loach allows his workaday characters, and that Paul Laverty, the screenwriter with whom he has frequently collaborated, teases out of their situations, is most fully realized in the performances of the lead actors, many of whom have been non-professionals. Martin Compston, who plays Liam, had never appeared in so much as a school play before he auditioned while still in high school for "Sweet Sixteen," but he inhabits Liam so completely that you sometimes have the impression of watching a documentary, and his air of innocence and determination -- of being a child growing up fast and wrong before your eyes -- gives the film's climactic scene an almost unbearable power.
This scene, in which Liam confronts his mother's bullying, criminal boyfriend, Stan, echoes the pivotal moments in many of Mr. Loach's other movies -- moments when the heroes' confident belief in their ability to control their own destinies is exposed as a fantasy, and their knowledge of themselves and their world shown to be crushingly incomplete. Ian Hart, playing an Englishman fighting with the Spanish Republicans in "Land and Freedom," learns, from his lover, of fratricide and betrayal within the ranks of the left. In "Bread and Roses," Maya lambastes her sister, Rosa, for selfishly opposing the union she is trying to organize, and is brought up short by Rosa's horrific story of sacrifice and abuse.
In these cases, and when Maggie is confronted by the social workers who have come to take away her newborn daughter in "Ladybird," the characters are taken by surprise. And one of the reasons these scenes, so full of tears and conflict, escape the distortions of melodrama is that the actors partake of their shock. "They should know everything about the character but not about the story," Mr. Loach said, explaining that he insists on withholding crucial details of the script from his cast members. "It's a test of the script, of the writing, that their instinct will follow the character." If he had told Mr. Compston the outcome of Liam's encounter with his mother's boyfriend, Mr. Loach said, "he would have artificially ratcheted it up. It would have been phony." Instead, the young man's panic and confusion -- the actor's instincts melding perfectly with the character's responses -- produce an excruciating realism, without the slightest tincture of sentiment or theatricality.
The way Mr. Loach works is strikingly resonant with the content of his movies: the actor is simultaneously free and subject to the invisible control of the story, poised like the hero on the knife-edge between choice and fate. There is a social and political dimension to this predicament -- since the agency of fate tends most often, in Mr. Loach's films, to be the cruel logic of capitalism or the bland, crushing power of the modern democratic state. It is also, in a larger sense, a painful and universal aspect of the human condition.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
So Sweet, So Sensitive, So Self-Absorbed, So 70's

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
IT doesn't require the Council of Economic Advisers to recognize that the United States is having economic troubles. All it takes is turning on a pop radio station or MTV to get the strange feeling that the mid-1970's have returned: the days of post-Vietnam and post-Watergate letdown, oil crisis, unemployment and soothing soft rock to provide consolation for it all. Three decades later, sensitive, guitar-slinging nice guys are once again swarming the airwaves, blanketing the concert circuit, accounting for innumerable Internet downloads and easing untold dorm-room seductions. 
 John Mayer, who had been plugging away since the late 1990's, has become a headliner, and alongside him have come strummer-songwriters like Jack Johnson, David Gray, Pete Yorn, Jason Mraz, Howie Day, Jesse Harris, Mason Jennings, Scooter Scuderi, Steven Delopoulos and more. To heighten the deja vu, James Taylor, the songwriter Mr. Mayer hailed as "the blueprint" on the Grammy Awards show, released a new album and a greatest-hits collection, while Fleetwood Mac has re-emerged with an album, "Say You Will," that deliberately echoes its mid-1970's heyday. Both 1970's stars returned to the Top 10; Ben Taylor, the son of Mr. Taylor and Carly Simon, also released a debut album, "Famous Among the Barns," with unmistakable paternal influences. 
 But what are younger songwriters, members of the punk and hip-hop generation, doing when they croon about the beauty of their girlfriends and the pain of getting kissed off? Shouldn't they be shouting rather than whispering, toughing things out instead of moaning, as Mr. Mayer does, "My stupid mouth has got me in trouble/ I said too much again." 
Mr. Mayer and his fellow songwriters often play the same comforting role as their forebears. Turning away from the bad news of the outside world, they focus on personal affairs: mostly romance, but also the endless processes of self-invention and finding a place in the world. They make a show of modesty, singing quietly and letting their music share a room instead of dominating it. They offer harmony instead of noise, conversation rather than confrontation, resignation instead of rebellion. 
They're not uniform by any means. Some, like Mr. Gray on "A New Day at Midnight," can make private ruminations riveting. Some, like Mr. Mayer on "Room for Squares" and Mr. Rice on "O," merge a deceptively low-key charm with supple grooves and telling details. Some, like Mr. Yorn on his album, "Day I Forgot," are hit-or-miss songwriters, and many more drown under cliches. Individually, the songwriters tend to come across as genial, good-natured, unpretentious characters who don't mind joking about themselves; Mr. Mayer cheerfully mocks the word "sensitive," even as his songs embody it. But collectively, as a movement, all those edgeless tenor voices and all that deference, self-consciousness, sublimated anger and self-pity might just get on your nerves. Singing about love, they project profound self-absorption. 
Every so often, the songwriters bemoan some larger problem. In songs like "Cookie Jar" and "The News," Jack Johnson worries about violence and callousness in the media. But for Mr. Johnson and the other songwriters, the general response is a shrug: "Times Like These," the opening song on his new album "On and On," philosophizes, "What will be will be, and so it goes." Instead of a rallying cry, it's a sop for complacency.
These guys also do a whole lot of apologizing. The mark of the new sensitive songwriter is that sooner or later, he finds himself lingering over the words, "I'm sorry." They're atoning not only for their own romantic mishaps but also, in a way, for the surge of machismo in 1990's rock. After a decade of gangsta-rap misogyny and metal and punk posturing, virtually the only nice guys left on the charts were the smiley automatons of the boy bands, who were packaged for teenage and preteen listeners. So there was a niche waiting to be filled by friendly young men who write their own songs, play their own instruments and come across as genuine and uncontrived, singing from the heart. They were perfectly placed when the pop pendulum swung away from artifice. 
There was a already a sincere streak in 1990's rock. It was soon classified under the indie-rock genre emo, which is full of small, nervous voices and lyrics that confess to endless insecurities, wounds and second thoughts -- the same things that preoccupy the acoustic pop songwriters. But emo's music, rooted in punk, often puts up obstacles to keep away nonbelievers: truncated melodies, shifting meters, sudden bursts of noise. The pop guitar-slingers (and a few emo figures like Chris Carraba of Dashboard Confessional) take away those musical barriers. They don't want their music to be as jagged as their emotions; they invite everyone to listen and sing along. 
While these songwriters have ended up in roughly the same position as their 1970's models, they got there circuitously. They don't have roots in ragtime, blues, old-time country or protest songs; their foundation is 1970's pop and what followed it. The 1970's provided both worthy prototypes -- Paul Simon, Joni Mitchell -- and tacky ones. Onstage, Jason Mraz unabashedly covers songs by unctuous 1970's groups like Bread, while the Thorns -- a songwriters' alliance of Pete Droge, Matthew Sweet and Shawn Mullins -- ape the sticky-sweet high harmonies of Crosby, Stills and Nash. 
But current male songwriters have two more recent models: the women who were gathered on mid-1990's Lilith Fair bills -- among them Sarah McLachlan and Jewel -- and the Dave Matthews Band. Though Mr. Matthews and his band revel in musical intricacies and unfolding jams, he himself is a brooding songwriter strumming an acousticguitar. As the Dave Matthews Band worked up to the arena circuit, it showed songwriters there was an audience for earnest, handmade music and a way to reach them: through the jam-band Internet grapevine. It also brought home the boundless utility of a groove, which can carry a song through uninspired patches and move audiences to dance as well as listen. 
The younger songwriters are far more rhythmically fluent than the folkies who grew up in the 1960's. Many of them are thoroughly at home with jazz chords and reggae syncopations, and every so often they'll allow themselves a few lines of something like rapping. Onstage, although not on their mild-mannered albums, they often show a pushier side. Pete Yorn's band pounds out his folk-rock songs while he sings with a slurred grunge yowl; Damien Rice, whose recorded songs are hushed and calmly intimate, plugs in his distortion pedal to make the live versions much stormier. 
Turbulence isn't hard to find elsewhere: in hip-hop, in hard rock, in overblown power ballads. Even current country music dispenses its verbal treacle with a brawny beat. Perhaps we should be grateful that at least one zone of pop still prizes light-fingered subtlety and tries to beguile listeners instead of buttonholing them, and still presents men who try to respect and understand women. There's nothing wrong with songwriters offering solace in unsettling times. But it would be much easier to love their sensitivity if they weren't so in love with it themselves.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jack Johnson, left, and Pete Yorn are two of a new crop of guitar-slinging songwriters who make a show of modesty, singing quietly and letting their music share a room instead of dominating it. (Photographs from Getty Images)

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Detroit

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD; MICHELINE MAYNARD reports on business for The Times from Detroit.

 BODY:
When Henry Ford founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, he was just one of dozens of American automobile entrepreneurs, but he endured to become the most recognizable of the industry pioneers.
 One hundred years later, the company that bears his name is dealing with a financial crisis that is forcing it to cut costs and close factories, but Ford is celebrating its heritage anyway. 
 In June, the company plans a five-day event on the grounds of its headquarters in suburban Dearborn, including concerts, test drives and an exhibition of Ford's most notable vehicles. The activities are just part of a busy summer for the Motor City, whose residents avidly take to the outdoors during the one season when it isn't likely to snow.

Events
Birthplace of the Motown sound and home to the rap star Marshall Mathers, better known as Eminem, Detroit is also a world center for pulsating techno music. Movement 2003: The Detroit Electronic Music Festival will be held May 24 to 26 on Hart Memorial Plaza downtown; www.movementfestival.com. Past festivals have attracted a million fans to various stages. The lineup will include Slum Village, Jeff Mills and Buzz Gorree.
The Ford centennial, www.celebrateford100.com, will be held June 12 to 16 at the Henry Ford II World Center, The American Road, Dearborn, known locally as the Glass House. Thousands of owners of Ford's classic vehicles are expected to put their cars on display, and there will be Model-T rides. You can also whip around the Ford test track nearby for a $50 charitable contribution. Concerts include the Detroit Symphony Orchestra June 13, Beyonce Knowles June 14, and the country singer Toby Keith June 15. Tickets good for all five days, including the concerts, are $24.94. 
At the Henry Ford Museum, 20900 Oakwood Boulevard, in Dearborn, (313) 982-6100, www.thehenryford.org, "Bond, James Bond," previously shown in London, will include gadgets, costumes and storyboards from 40 years of Bond films. Timed tickets for the exhibit, June 28 to Dec. 31, are $7 in addition to general admission for the museum, which is $13.50.
On May 29, 30 and 31 and June 1, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra www.detroitsymphony.com, (313) 576-5111, features Jian Wang playing the Dvorak Cello Concerto, with Neeme Jarvi, the music director, conducting at Orchestra Hall, 3711 Woodward Avenue, Detroit. Tickets are $15 to $80.
Summer wouldn't be complete without the Ann Arbor Art Fairs, www.artfair.org, July 16 to 19 this year. A combination of serious art, collectibles and kitsch, the free fairs are held at locations throughout Ann Arbor, 45 minutes west of Detroit and home to the University of Michigan. The oldest and most prestigious is the Ann Arbor Street Art Fair, a juried display, on the grounds of the Burton Memorial Tower, in the middle of the Michigan campus. 

Sightseeing
 Though downtown is compact, the city's outlying attractions are most easily reached by car, just as Henry Ford would have liked it. 
The Edsel and Eleanor Ford House, 1100 Lake Shore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, (313) 884-4222, www.fordhouse.org, was home to Henry Ford's only son, Edsel Ford, who lived at this 87-acre estate with his wife, Eleanor, on the shores of Lake St. Clair. The 60-room house and grounds lie in one of Detroit's prettiest and wealthiest areas. Entrance $6.
After being closed for renovations since September, Greenfield Village, www.hfmgv.org, a 90-acre outdoor museum of American history, with buildings, homes, amusements and shops spanning 300 years, reopens June 10. The village's entire underground infrastructure was replaced, with roads, curbs and sidewalks added. Tickets are $16. (Combination passes will be available with the Henry Ford Museum.)
The Charles A. Wright Museum of African-American History 315 East Warren Avenue, Detroit, (313) 494-5800, www.maah-detroit.org, houses the ongoing exhibition "Of the People: The African American Experience," which covers 400 years of history. Free outdoor concerts every Friday in June at 6 p.m. celebrate Black Music Month, and each features a different musical genre, including gospel, jazz, rhythm and blues, and techno. Closed Monday and Tuesday. Admission is $5.
Ford Field, 2000 Brush Street, Detroit, www.detroitlions.com, which opened last year, didn't bring the Detroit Lions football team any better luck in its debut season. But the $500 million stadium, which will play host to Super Bowl XL in 2006, is a popular downtown destination. Tours are conducted daily, while its shopping concourse and restaurants are open weekdays, 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. 
Ford Field sits next door to Comerica Park, home to the Detroit Tigers, www.detroittigers.com, whose baseball fortunes this year have mirrored the Lions' and whose stadium is another draw. The park, at 2100 Woodward Avenue, Detroit, boasts a Ferris wheel and a merry-go-round, with fireworks on Friday nights. The Yankees are in town May 30 to June 1; tickets are $5 to $60.
The Detroit Institute of Arts, 5200 Woodward Avenue, Detroit, (313) 833-7900, www.dia.org, is home to one of the city's most familiar images, Diego Rivera's Detroit Industry murals depicting the autoworkers at Ford's sprawling Rouge manufacturing complex in Dearborn. Henry Ford and Thomas Edison are shown conversing in one corner of the murals, which decorate the walls of the Garden Court. Closed Monday and Tuesday. Suggested admission is $4, $1 for children.

Where to Stay
Rooms may be hard to come by in Dearborn during the Ford centennial, since Ford reserved hotels well in advance for its dealers and other guests. But hotels encourage visitors to call for last-minute cancellations.
The Dearborn Inn, 20301 Oakwood Boulevard, Dearborn, (313) 271-2700, fax (313) 271-7464, a Marriott hotel, was built in 1931 on the orders of Heny Ford to serve passengers landing at the Dearborn airport across the street, where Ford's test track now stands. Designed by Albert Kahn, the inn has a traditional look, and its garden is a favorite place for weddings. The 220 rooms and 34 suites, renovated in 1996, tend to be on the small side, with a bed-and-breakfast feel. The inn also has five houses in back called the Colonial Village, each featuring suites. Rooms start at $169 for a double; Colonial Village suites are $209 a night. 
Budget: Detroit, being predominantly a business town, has few reliable choices under $100 a night. One less expensive option is the Courtyards by Marriott chain, with more than a dozen properties in prime spots throughout the area. A double room at the Courtyard Dearborn, Dearborn, 5200 Mercury Drive, (313) 271-1400, fax (313) 271-1184, behind Ford's headquarters, starts at $104 a night but discounts are widely available.
The copper-colored-glass Hyatt Regency Dearborn, at Fairlane Town Center, (313) 593-1234, fax (313) 982-6884, www.dearborn.hyatt.com, screams 1970's on the outside. But the 772-room hotel is gleaming inside from a much-needed $25 million renovation, completed last year. Rooms are tasteful, with blond-wood furniture, beige walls and red accents, and vary in size and shape, because of the curved walls. Rates start at $109 for a double room.
The Inn on Ferry Street, 84 East Ferry Street, Detroit, (313) 871-6000, fax (313) 871-1473, www.theinnon ferrystreet.com, a block from the Detroit Institute of Arts, is a rarity in a city dominated by chain hotels. Located in a regentrified neighborhood that was once home to Detroit's Jewish elite, the 42-room hotel, which opened in 2001, is actually four Victorian mansions and two carriage houses with rooms furnished with antiques. The hotel offers a free shuttle within a five-mile radius. Doubles start at $109 including breakfast, while a suite is $179.
Luxury: Detroit's slim luxury hotel pickings gained a welcome addition in December with the opening of the $85 million Westin Hotel at Detroit Metropolitan International Airport, 2501 WorldGateway Place, Detroit, (734) 942-6500, fax (734) 942-6600. The hotel, with 404 rooms and 10 suites, has a Pacific Rim air, with a live bamboo forest and streamlined furnishings. It is the only meeting and dining place at the airport that visitors can reach without clearing security. The rooms are decorated in dark brown, beige and cream. There is a state-of-the-art fitness center with a small pool and roomy whirlpool. Doubles start at $199; one-bedroom suites from $350 to $750. For weary travelers with long layovers, the Westin offers day rooms at $139 for eight hours.

Where to Eat
The Detroit Red Wings' late dominance of the N.H.L. has earned Detroit the nickname Hockeytown. That's also the name of a sprawling bar and restaurant at 2301 Woodward Avenue, Detroit, (313) 965-9500, across the street from Comerica Park. With an outdoor roof terrace, Hockeytown is noisy, especially after games, but child-friendly, and the menu encompasses both bar food and specialties that include broiled Canadian whitefish with a mushroom and sun-dried cherry sauce; and beef ravioli with homemade marinara sauce. Dinner for two, with a beer or glass of wine, will run about $40.
About a mile north, Agave, at 4265 Woodward Avenue, Detroit, (313) 833-1120, serves sophisticated dishes from the Mexico City region. Entrees include sauteed duck breast with an achiote seed-orange sauce and fresh beet-jicama salsa and mahi-mahi in a chipotle-cilantro cream sauce. Among the appetizers are a standout chile relleno, a whole poblano pepper stuffed with panela cheese, corn and summer squash; and ceviche made from scallops, rock shrimp and squid. For dessert, the warm chocolate-chipotle cake is worth the trip. The bar stocks 60 tequilas. Dinner for two, including drinks, will run $60.
Il Posto, 29110 Franklin Road, Southfield, (248) 827-8070, is run by Gianni Belsito, the chef and owner, who came to suburban Detroit from Italy by way of New Jersey and Florida. Service is attentive and decor understated. Fish, including sea bass, turbot and Dover sole, is flown in daily from Normandy, pastas are made in-house, and pastries, including a dense lemon cake, are shipped direct from Italy, except for the homemade tiramisu. Dinner for two with wine runs $150. Reservations recommended.
Dearborn is home to one of the nation's biggest Arab populations, and there is no better place to sample Middle Eastern food than at a La Shish restaurant. There are 10 in the suburban Detroit area, 4 in Dearborn alone. At the main restaurant, 22039 West Michigan Avenue, Dearborn, (313) 562-7200, portions are enormous, with one order of any appetizer, salad or entree easily feeding two. All the classic Arab specialties are available, but the restaurants have been expanding their menus lately with, for example, beef tenderloin or chicken sajji, marinated and seared. Big groups should spring for La Feast, appetizers, entrees and salads on a huge platter and serving at least six ($89.99). Dinner for two, with beverage, is $30. Alcoholic beverages are not served at all branches.

HEADLINE: Ashland, Ore. 

 BODY:
To the Editor: "What's Doing in Ashland, Ore." (May 4) offers a prime example of how the arts can transform a community. 
 When I presented myself as an actor to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in the summer of 1949, Ashland was a sleepy town with a large park, the Lithia Hotel, a movie theater, La Marre's drugstore, a coffee shop and the (then) Southern Oregon College of Education, overshadowed by Medford, its larger neighbor to the north. 
 The festival itself, in its third season after World War II, was a motley yet dedicated mixture of professionals, academics, and college students like myself. Yet supported by the Ashland community, Angus Bowmer (the founding director) put on good shows that attracted increasingly larger audiences, developing a vibrant arts community and a flourishing economy, enlivening the entire region. 
In these times of shrinking funds for the arts, Ashland can serve as an object lesson on why such support has implications that go far beyond the aesthetic and educational.

George Dorris
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
Costs of Prepaying Underlying Loans

 BODY:
 Q. I live in a co-op building on the Upper East Side. The interest rate on our underlying mortgage is close to 9 percent. When shareholders have asked about refinancing, we have been told that a punitive clause in the mortgage makes refinancing problematic. Do co-op mortgages typically have clauses that discourage refinancing, or were our board members unsophisticated when they negotiated the terms? . . . Jonathan R. Gross, Manhattan.

A. Andrew P. Brucker, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that the punitive clause, more typically called a prepayment penalty, is very common in underlying mortgages.
 "Prepayment penalties come in all shapes and sizes," Mr. Brucker said. In some cases, he said, the loan terms expressly prohibit prepayment within a certain number of years and then allow the borrower to pay off the entire mortgage before the end of the term only with a penalty. 
Other loans might allow prepayment at any time, with the penalty reduced over the years. For example, with a 10-year loan the prepayment penalty in the first two years might be 5 percent of the loan balance, dropping to 4 percent in the next two years, 3 percent in years five and six, 2 percent in years seven and eight and 1 percent in the last two years.
It is also possible for the underlying mortgage to be written with a penalty that guarantees that the lender receives the full interest income, even with prepayment. 
Mr. Brucker said that depending on when the loan was taken out, if banks were insisting on prepayment penalties the board might have had little choice but to accept the terms. But he said that the board might want to explore the possibility of refinancing or try to renegotiate the terms with the current lender, even with a prepayment penalty.
"We had a client two years ago that paid a penalty in excess of $1 million," he said. "When we did a financial analysis of the new loan the result was startling. Interest rates had dropped so precipitously that the co-op would recoup the penalty in less than a year and a half."

A Building In Disrepair

Q. I live in a rental building in Manhattan. The apartments are in total disrepair, with bursting pipes, falling plaster and faulty wiring. Our landlord owns a building up the street whose tenants have had the same trouble we have had in getting repairs. However, in that building, the landlord renovated the lobby and used the capital improvement to raise the rent. Although our lobby is in acceptable shape, we believe he plans to do the same thing here to raise our rents. Is there anything we can do to prevent this from occurring? . . . Liza Englander, Manhattan.

A. Jeffrey Ween, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said there is a provision in the Rent Stabilization Code that prohibits granting a capital improvement increase if essential services in the building have not been maintained or if inherently hazardous conditions are present.
"And I would say that bursting pipes, falling plaster and faulty wiring would qualify as inherently hazardous conditions," Mr. Ween said. 
As a result, he said, the building's residents should make sure that government officials are aware of the conditions. One way to do that, Mr. Ween said, is to file an action in the housing part of civil court. Once that action is filed, the court will schedule an inspection by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. 
Another way would be to object to the landlord's application for a capital improvement increase when the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal advises tenants that the application has been filed.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pennington; 
Small Town With a Sense of Community

BYLINE:  By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
THE pace of life is relaxed in Pennington, a one-square-mile borough in Mercer County, N.J., that was settled in the 17th century. Drivers traveling south on Route 31 must obey the sudden drop in the speed limit -- from 45 miles per hour in neighboring Hopewell Township to 25 at the borough's edge -- or risk speeding tickets. Elementary-school children walk to school along streets lined with pink-blossomed cherry trees. The mayor shows up at the Cup of Joe coffee shop in downtown Pennington every morning, ready to chat. 
 You do not have to live here long before just about everybody knows your name. "When people come into my store," said Jack Koeppel, a gallery owner on Main Street and lifelong Pennington resident, "I can greet them by their first names, ask them how their kids are doing. I know what's going on in their lives." 
 Pennington's small-town atmosphere and highly rated school system are big draws for young families. Because the borough is so small, children can easily walk to the two-block-long downtown and parents rarely have to drive their children to play dates or after-school activities. 
Many Pennington residents commute to Manhattan or Philadelphia. There is no train station in town, however, and the closest station with service to New York, in Hamilton, is a 15-minute drive away. From there, it is more than an hour to Penn Station. The commute is much easier for workers driving to state office buildings in Trenton, Princeton University and large corporate facilities in the area, including Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merrill Lynch. 
Pennington is just far enough off the beaten path that its tiny downtown has not yet been discovered by the national chains. There is no Starbucks, no Gap. Drive-through fast-food restaurants are banned. There are, however, a bank, a drugstore, a cobbler, a pizza parlor, a hardware store, several gift shops and restaurants.
The closest grocery shopping is the Pennington Supermarket, where, according to a former councilwoman, Susan Porcella, "the dairy section is in Pennington and the rest is in Hopewell Township." The nearest mall is the Quaker Bridge Mall, about a 10-minute drive away on Route 1. 
Laura Semler moved to Pennington in March with her husband, Michael, and their two boys, 5 and 6. They had been living in Madrid and decided they wanted a big yard and a slow-paced lifestyle when Mr. Semler took a job near Philadelphia. They found it in Pennington: "We really wanted a small town," said Ms. Semler. "We're two blocks from downtown. Once the kids are old enough to cross the street by themselves, I'd feel comfortable letting them walk."
Ms. Semler and her husband had first looked for houses in Princeton, just 12 minutes away. But they found that a comparable house in Pennington cost $200,000 less. They paid $730,000 for a four-bedroom, 15-year-old colonial in a small development.
Real estate agents say that home prices have risen steadily in recent years but that demand is currently not particularly intense. Beverly Willever, manager of Peyton Associates in Pennington, said prices range from $248,500 for a small two-bedroom house that needs work to $655,000 for newer construction. Houses are selling in about a month, she said, but some take longer. "The houses that need repair can sit for four to six months," Ms. Willever said.
Jimmy Maul, a broker associate for Keller Williams Realty in Princeton and a 13-year resident of Pennington, said prices had risen 12 percent a year since 1998 and jumped to 15 to 20 percent last year. But this year, he said, a harsh winter, the war with Iraq and the slowing economy combined to put a dent in sales. In the first week of May, there were 22 houses on the market. "We usually don't have as many houses on the market at one time," Mr. Maul said.
PENNINGTON also has a small number of condominiums, town houses and rental apartments, he said, an adult community for those 55 and over and an assisted living facility for seniors. 
Now that his children are grown, Mr. Maul is planning on leaving Pennington because of the high property taxes he pays -- $14,000 a year on a house with an asking price of $629,000. Because his house is newer, he pays more in taxes relative to his house's value than those with older homes. 
The high property tax level, most of which goes to finance the schools, is the biggest issue facing the town, said Mayor Jim Loper. "We want to keep a balance of senior citizens and young families," he said. "In the last few years, we've tried to have zero increase in taxes. But we can't do that forever." Rising housing prices also make it hard for middle-class families to buy. 
When Bob and Kathy Frederich and their two children moved to Pennington from Lexington, Ky., in December of 2001, they rented a house on Main Street. Once they realized how much they liked the schools, they decided to buy a 70-year-old fixer-upper in July 2002. The house needs extensive renovations, but it was the only one they could afford that had the space they needed. 
"The schools here are incredibly good," Ms. Frederich said. Her older daughter is in the second grade at Tollgate Grammar School, one of four elementary schools in the Hopewell Valley Regional School District and the only one in Pennington.
Ms. Frederich has been impressed not only with the quality of the teachers, but also with the wide variety of programs offered. There is a "Meet the Masters" program run by parent volunteers that introduces children to different styles of art; there are classes in violin, Spanish and computers; and the school just finished a "million minute challenge," with students recording the number of minutes they read outside of the classroom. 
After elementary school, students who live in Pennington attend Grades 6 through 8 at Timberlane Middle School and Grades 9 through 12 at Central High School, both located on the outskirts of Pennington. In 2002, 98 percent of fourth graders who took the Elementary School Proficiency Assessment test were found to be proficient in language arts and 92 percent were proficient in math. That compares with state averages of 86 percent in language arts and 74 percent in math. In the Grade 8 Proficiency Assessment tests, 96 percent were proficient in language arts, 89 percent in math and 96 percent in science. State averages for the eighth grade were 83 percent in language arts, 67 percent in math and 82 percent in science. 
At Central High School, the average scores on the SAT reasoning test for 2002 were 559 on the verbal test and 573 in math, compared with state averages of 498 in verbal and 513 in math. Last year, the school's average scores placed it 27th out of 307 high schools in the state, according to Dr. Robert J. Sopko, superintendent of schools. Seventy percent of last year's 280-member senior class attended four-year colleges, and 17 percent went to two-year colleges and nursing schools. 
"We are a highly academic high school," Dr. Sopko said. "We offer 55 extracurricular activities and a multitude of advanced placement courses." The high school also offers auto shop as an elective, has two woodworking programs, a robotics team that competes nationally and its own TV studio. A new TV studio, auditorium and gymnasium will be completed in July. 
Pennington is within a 20-minute drive of several private schools and is also the home of the Pennington School, a private day and boarding school founded by the Methodist Church in 1838. The school, which has 440 students in Grades 6 through 12, allows local residents the use of its tennis courts, indoor pool and playing fields. In 1980, after a fire destroyed a building at the school, the borough created Pennington Day, a street fair with proceeds going to rebuild facilities at the school. Since then, Pennington Day has been held in May each year, benefiting a variety of nonprofit groups. 
There are several popular summer programs for children in Pennington, run by the Hopewell Valley Recreation Department. One is a six-week teen travel camp for middle school students, featuring trips every day to the beach, an amusement park, New York City or a baseball game. The camp culminates in a three-day overnight trip; this year's trip is to Niagara Falls. 
For children 5 to 12, a weeklong Art in the Park program at Pennington's Kunkel Park is offered in the mornings for $140. Throughout the year, there are day and extended trips for adults and a senior program that includes a bridge club, walking club, exercise program and annual picnic. 
WHAT sets Pennington apart, many residents say, are its sense of community and tradition of volunteerism. The fire department and the rescue squad are made up of volunteers, and residents donate time to work on Pennington Day, the Memorial Day parade, the recreation commission and the streetscape committee. The mayor and council members are all unpaid.
Robbi Jones moved to Pennington after being divorced more than four years ago. She had lived on five acres in Hopewell Township, barely knew her neighbors and missed being part of a community. After moving to Pennington, "I went to the mayor and said, 'Put me on a committee,' " she recalled.
She moved into a house downtown, and started getting involved -- in the library, the Girl Scouts, the streetscape committee, Pennington Day and the Parks and Recreation Commission. "It's like Mayberry," Ms. Jones said. "My neighbor mows my lawn; I shovel his driveway."
Pennington's mix of Colonial, Federal, Greek Revival and Victorian-style architecture appeals to old-home lovers, and the Victorian stone Pennington Railroad Station, which now holds two condominiums, is on the National Register of Historic Places.
The borough's history dates to the late 1600's, when it was a crossroads called Queenstown, where travelers between Philadelphia and New York stopped overnight. In 1708, the Presbyterian Church was built, the village grew and two years later the name was changed to Penny Town -- a reference to the fact that a night's lodging could be had in a tavern there for pennies.
During the Revolutionary War, the Presbyterian Church became a barracks for British and Hessian soldiers, who were said to have usedthe pews for chopping meat. They also used a wall outside the church to practice jumping their horses, according to the legend. A crack in the communion table, which remains on view at the church, is said to have been caused by the blow of a Hessian soldier's sword.

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: DIGBY ANDERSON; 
A Cultural Critic Becomes Friendship's Best Friend

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
TO hear the angry pundits tell it, many business scandals of the last few years -- Enron, WorldCom, ImClone Systems, the list seems endless -- can be traced back to excess coziness among directors and chief executives, among management and favored investors, or, in other words, among friends. Friendships and the conflicts of interest they entail, some say, are increasingly interfering with ethics and good business judgment.
 Digby Anderson thinks that's hogwash. What's wrong with business today -- in fact, with society as a whole -- is a lack of friendship, not too much of it, he says. 
 "Friendship is a public virtue, not a threat," he said. 
Dr. Anderson, who holds a doctorate in sociology from Brunel University in London, is the director of the Social Affairs Unit, a London research center that he founded 23 years ago and has since earned a reputation in England of thoroughly relishing controversy. He and many of his colleagues have spent the last two decades publishing copious treatises and books about what has gone wrong in modern society -- for instance, why virtues like fortitude, courage and prudence are rarely talked of and no longer prized; why excessive sentimentality has taken over from true emotion and clearheaded thinking; why formal manners have all but disappeared; and why genuine ethics have taken a back seat to verbose moralizing.
Friendship is the latest addition to Dr. Anderson's list. "Society has simply pushed friendship out of politics and business," he said.
It is a belief he has gone to great pains to document. The death of friendship is a theme running through the introduction he wrote for "The War on Wisdom," a book scheduled to be published by the Social Affairs Unit next month. Two years earlier, he began sounding that theme in "Losing Friends," also published by the Social Affairs Unit. (In the United States, the books are distributed through the Manhattan Institute.)
In "Losing Friends," he wrote about the rise and fall of friendship, including its heyday in Greek and Roman society and its nadir today. He blames the usual suspects: geographic mobility, the shrinking nuclear family, the jealous demands spouses make on time. And he bemoans the disappearance of friendship from written fact and fiction: no friends listed in obituaries, few friendships extolled in modern literature.
Dr. Anderson gave voice to his laments at a recent informal lunch at a reporter's home -- a place chosen in part for convenience, in part for its seeming aptness as a friendly setting for discussing friendship, and in huge part because the hostess did not know that Dr. Anderson had once been a magazine's food columnist. As the meal continued, he expounded on why friendship's wane is bad for individuals, for society and, yes, for corporate America and the people who derive their livelihoods from it.
"All past civilizations have declined, and Western civilization is about due to go," he said, gamely piling his plate with assorted meats and salads. "The death of friendship is one symptom of that."
He says he believes political extremism has rendered friends powerless to help one another. Liberals' insistence on equal opportunity and impartiality, he said, has led to "egalitarian bureaucracy," a muddling of what had once been smooth-flowing business networks based on friendships. Years ago, he said, friends happily helped one another find jobs; today they shy away, lest they be accused of favoritism.
"Even though it makes sense to hire a friend, or even a friend's friend, there's this feeling that you have to give everyone an equal chance," he said.
The blow from the right, he said, has been a constant emphasis on the family as the "repository of all virtues" -- and, thus, the only institution worthy of trust and time.
"The ancient Greeks had a better idea: they considered their friends to actually be their family," Dr. Anderson said.
Both sides, he complains, have forgotten the benefits that placing friends above others can confer in business. To him, the company most likely to succeed is the one whose employee roster smacks of cronyism. 
A company whose board is run by the chief executive's best friend is probably better managed, Dr. Anderson said, "because only a friend will tell you that you're going down the wrong path."
Hiring someone on a friend's say-so also makes good sense, he said, "because a good friend's advice is worth a lot more than the bureaucratic knowledge you get from lists and questionnaires and applications." Hiring friends helps guarantee ethical behavior, he contended. "It takes ethical people to run an ethical business, so you are best off hiring friends, whose characters you know well," he added. 'After all, someone who cheats on his wife will cheat on the company."
(Dr. Anderson said he recently ended a friendship with someone who brought him a nasty piece of gossip "because I figured he would say similar things about me.")
The temptation to poke holes in Dr. Anderson's theories is irresistible. Indeed, that "friendly" lunch evolved into a four-hour freewheeling thrust-and-parry session in which Dr. Anderson deftly countered challenges to his beliefs. Among them:
* Have highly public friendships really disappeared in the last few decades? What about the Rat Pack, the Brat Pack or even the actors Matt Damon and Ben Affleck? "Those aren't true friendships; they are people indulging in activities together," he said.
* Doesn't business owe a chance to people who didn't grow up in the right neighborhood, go to the right schools or otherwise get a chance to make the right friends? "You can hire someone because you do not want to offend the rules of justice, or because you want a competent person who has been vouched for by someone who's known him for years," he said.
* What about all those conflict-of-interest stories that stem from cronyism and favoritism -- friends hiring one another's less-than-competent nieces and sons, approving one another's pay packages, feeding one another insider stock tips? He called it another case of faux friendship: "Friends do not ask friends to do dishonorable things," he said. In other words, those people are not friends, just mutual users masquerading as such.
It all sounds like a purely semantic argument, and maybe it is. But Dr. Anderson says semantics are not to be taken lightly.
Consider those ubiquitous corporate mission statements. "They're long and ethically nonsensical and full of inarticulateness," he said, temporarily veering from the subject of friendship to fire a salvo at his other pet peeve, faux ethicists.
"They keep using the word integrity, and they don't even know what it means." (Does he? "It means wholeness, not virtue," he said, sounding genuinely irate at the frequent misuse.)
BUT he is easily brought back to the topic of friendship, or lack thereof. After all, his thoughts on corporate ethics are academic; his thoughts on friendship are personal.
It is not that he feels friend-deprived. He says that he is still close to the man who was his best friend when they were 8 years old, that he has plenty of friends from a past life in academia, and that he and Judith, his wife of 37 years, have deliberately formed and maintained many friendships with other couples. 
But he is 59, and retirement is probably well under a decade away. He noted that people increasingly move away after they retire. "Nowadays, people seem to only worry about whether they can make good friends in the new place," he said. "I'm already thinking in terms of, when my retirement comes, will I be leaving any friend who needs me?"
And if he is? "I might still go," he acknowledged. "But at least I would let my obligations to friends weigh heavily in the decision. And sadly these days, too many people would not think of that."

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Warning Signs At the High-Risk Pool

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AFTER Amy Donnelly's husband lost his job last December as a toolmaker for a small manufacturing company, the couple decided not to continue their health insurance under the federal law, known as Cobra, that lets workers keep their policies for up to 18 months if they pay full premiums. The monthly cost, $850, seemed too steep, they said, and they thought they could get a better rate on their own. But Mrs. Donnelly, 40, said no one would sell a policy covering the couple and their 8-year-old son. The reason, she said she was told, was her diabetes.
 Mrs. Donnelly, who lives in Manchester, Conn., is one of a small but growing number of people who are considered uninsurablebecause they have pre-existing medical conditions like diabetes or heart disease. 
 For them, state-run high-risk insurance pools are supposed to be the answer. The pools, started more than 25 years ago, guarantee coverage for people considered high-risk for insurers. In many states, insurers must pay at least part of the cost to operate these programs.
The pools usually offer a couple of plans, with varying deductibles and co-payments. But for some people, the guaranteed coverage turns out to be an empty promise: the state pools are sometimes hard to join because of enrollment limits, and the premiums, though capped, may still be too expensive for some people. Worse yet, most of the pools themselves withhold coverage of pre-existing conditions for 90 days to a year.
Maybe that is why only about 153,000 people are enrolled in high-risk pools nationwide. But if, as expected, employers continue to cut back on coverage and states cut Medicaid programs, the number of potential members of these pools will continue to grow.
Thirty states have high-risk pools. But that number is deceptive. The plan in Florida has been closed to new enrollment since 1991. Louisiana and Illinois have waiting lists. And even though a state's pool may not be officially closed, "there are delays in getting enrolled," said Nancy Davenport-Ennis, the chief executive of the Patient Advocate Foundation in Newport News, Va. 
Many people never get to the application stage. That is because they can't afford the premiums, which are typically capped at 150 percent of the standard rate for an individual policy. When Mrs. Donnelly looked into the high-risk pool in Connecticut, she said, she was told that the monthly premium would be $650 to $700 -- just for her.
She and her husband, Hugh, 40, remain uninsured; their son received coverage under a state program for uninsured children. Mrs. Donnelly says she is looking for a part-time job to cover the health insurance premiums in the high-risk pool. "I don't want my husband and my son to lose everything if I end up in the hospital," she said.
Perhaps the most troubling feature of these so-called safety-net insurance plans is that they don't initially cover the very conditions for which private insurers rejected people in the first place. That was the problem faced by Sue Bolin, 48, of Gering, Neb., after her human resources consulting firm went bankrupt in December 2001. Ms. Bolin said she had an individual health insurance policy that was paid for by the company, but it ended when the company shut down.
Ms. Bolin, who has colon cancer, said she applied for Nebraska's high-risk insurance pool after being turned down by insurers. She said she was told that the state pool wouldn't cover pre-existing conditions for six months. Unable to afford the $15,000 monthly expense for chemotherapy, she stopped her treatments that December and turned to holistic alternatives. But they apparently didn't work: when she went back to her doctor in March, she said, more cancer was found. 
Ms. Bolin said she received a waiver of the pre-existing condition requirement, as allowed under certain circumstances by Nebraska law. But she said that by the time she qualified, after a grievance process, she had missed three months of chemotherapy and her six-month waiting period was almost up anyway. 
HEALTH policy experts argue that lumping sick people together into high-risk pools runs counter to traditional insurance principles of spreading the risk, in which people who are relatively healthy subsidize those with many health problems. Butsuch subsidizing would mean that healthy people would pay higher premiums, a prospect that insurers and many politicians find unpalatable. 
High-risk pools will play an important role in the Bush administration's strategy for expanding health insurance to the uninsured, said Thomas A. Scully, the administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. The Bush plan calls for a $1,000 tax credit to help individuals pay for health coverage. If that is going to work, "it's pretty critical to make sure there's an affordable product people can buy and a pooling mechanism for that to happen," he said.
In November, the federal government said $20 million would be available to help states without high-risk pools to establish them. Last month, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, announced that an additional $40 million in grants would be available in each of the next two years to help states offset losses from their high-risk pools. In 2001, states reported $401 million in such losses, according to Bruce Abbe, the vice president of public affairs for Communicating for Agriculture and the Self-Employed, which tracks high-risk insurance pools. 
Health experts say the federal grants, though helpful, are just a drop in the bucket. The same holds true, they say, for the proposed $1,000 tax credits. "It's like throwing a 10-foot rope to someone at the bottom of a 30-foot well," said Karen Pollitz, the project director at the Institute for Health Care Research and Policy at Georgetown University.
Unless high-risk pools improve their coverage and become more affordable, many people who are ill and uninsured will be left treading water on their own.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Deciding Who Hurts Most in a Slump

BYLINE:  By Steven Greenhouse 

 BODY:
THESE are some of the popular images of New York City's current economic slump. Goldman Sachs dismisses 2,900 workers in 2002 alone, while J.P. Morgan Chase lays off 2,000. Dozens of Silicon Alley start-ups go under while $300,000-a-year tech whizzes are laid off and become sales clerks at apparel shops to support their families.
 With images like these, some New Yorkers have gotten the sense that white collar workers like investment bankers and software developers have been hit hardest by the three-year downturn. But a new study disputes this notion, arguing that the slump has hurt low-level workers the most and that they account for the overwhelming majority of the city's unemployed. 
 The study by the Community Service Society, a nonprofit group that helps the poor, found that 78 percent of the city's unemployed are workers in manufacturing, construction, service, clerical and sales jobs, while 22 percent of the unemployed are white-collar workers, defined as executive, managerial, professional or technical.
"The data shows that blue-collar workers are pretty strongly over-represented among the unemployed and that white-collar workers are pretty much underrepresented," said Mark K. Levitan, a senior policy analyst at the Community Service Society and author of the study, "A Portrait of Inequality: Unemployment and Joblessness in New York City, 2002."
His study found that executives and managers make up 14.5 percent of the city's labor force but just 9 percent of the unemployed, while professional and technical workers comprise 20 percent of the work force, but just 13 percent of the unemployed. In contrast, blue-collar workers, defined as those in manufacturing, construction and repair work, represent 20 percent of the labor force but 30 percent of the unemployed. 
Some economists disagree with Mr. Levitan's argument that this should be viewed as a blue-collar recession. Irwin Kellner, who holds the Augustus B. Weller Distinguished Chair of Economics at Hofstra University, said one unusual aspect of New York's current downturn is that white-collar workers represent a far higher percentage of the unemployed than before. 
Using nationwide numbers based on employer payroll records, Dr. Kellner said managerial and professional specialty workers represent 17 percent of the unemployed. That is nearly double the 9.5 percent level during the 1990-91 recession and up from 13 percent three years ago, before the current slump started.
"I have the definite impression that this is more of a white-collar slump than a blue-collar slump," said Dr. Kellner, who is also chief economist for North Fork Bank. "It's true that manufacturers have cut their payroll 39 months in a row, but with the three-and-a-half-year bear market, there have been massive layoffs in New York of brokers, bankers, analysts and other people associated with Wall Street. And of course there's been the dot.com implosion, which has hit Silicon Alley."
Some advocates have seized on the notion of a blue-collar slump with the aim of persuading policymakers to give more aid to the lower strata of city workers. But other advocates have embraced the idea of a white-collar slump, believing that politicians will grow more concerned knowing that affluent workers have been hit hard.
James P. Brown, who analyzes the city's economy for the State Department of Labor, argued that the important issue was not whether the downturn was blue-collar or white-collar, but that the city was in a protracted slump. 
"We have unemployment rising," he said. "We have a lot of layoffs in the financial sector, white-collar and clerical support. That leads to less office buildings being built, which hits blue-collar workers because there is less construction going on."
He noted that New York City has lost 200,000 jobs over the past two years, with the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 fueling layoffs at hotels, restaurants. and airlines, with white-collar pilots and blue-collar mechanics and baggage handlers losing their jobs. Since the spring of 2001, the city's jobless rate has jumped to 8.5 percent from 5.3 percent. 
James Parrott, chief economist for the Fiscal Policy Institute, a union-backed research group, said Mr. Levitan and Dr. Kellner are both right.
"It's both a white-collar recession and a blue-collar recession," he said. "It's a severe recession that's touched virtually every occupational and industrial sector."

Kathryn Chen, Jason Bonanca

 BODY:
Kathryn Chen, a daughter of Mary and William Chen of Endicott, N.Y., was married yesterday in New Paltz, N.Y., to Jason Joseph Bonanca, the son of Madeline and Joseph Bonanca of Swansea, Mass. The Rev. 
Leland Gartrell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of New Paltz. 
 Ms. Chen, 33, is keeping her name. She is a foreign exchange trader and an analyst at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. She graduated from Johns Hopkins University and received an M.B.A. from New York University. Her father is a senior technical adviser, based in San Jose, Calif., to Advanced Semiconductor Engineering, a Taiwanese manufacturer and tester of semiconductors. Her mother retired as a librarian from the Jennie F. Snapp Middle School in Endicott. 
 Mr. Bonanca, 31, is a director and currency strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, the New York investment bank. He graduated summa cum laude from Tufts University and received a master's degree in international economics and European studies from Johns Hopkins. The bridegroom was a Fulbright scholar in Brussels from 1994 to 1996. His father is the chief executive of St. Michael's Federal Credit Union in Fall River, Mass.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Predicting the Path of a Submarine (or a Mutual Fund)

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT

 BODY:
RESEARCHERS at Yale appear to have solved a big problem for mutual fund rating systems. In doing so, the research team may have also found a better way to pick winning stock funds.
 The rating problem has to do with the classification and evaluation of funds that don't stick to a single investment style. The challenge is significant because most funds change styles at one time or another. Say a fund's primary investments, at some point in the past, shifted to small-capitalization from large-capitalization stocks. What is the best way to classify what its investment approach has been? 
 Virtually all major rating systems have simply placed funds into whatever peer group seems most similar, based on the most recent report of the fund's investment holdings. The systems then make statistical comparisons that assume that the funds have never deviated from that category. A fund in the small-cap category, for example, is assumed to have invested only in small-cap stocks even if, in the past, it has often held a big portion of large-cap shares. 
At least since the mid 1980's, researchers have known that these classification difficulties lead to skewed judgments about the performance of funds that change their investment styles.
The Yale researchers -- Matthew Spiegel, a finance professor, Harry Mamaysky, an assistant professor of finance, and Hong Zhang, a doctoral fellow in finance -- believe that they have solved this problem. Their work, which has circulated for several months in academic circles as a working paper, is at http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=389740.
The researchers relied on a statistical tool that has primarily been used in navigation and rarely in investing. It is known as the Kalman Filter, named for Rudolf E. Kalman, an emeritus professor of engineering at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich. Mr. Kalman introduced his technique in 1960 in research supported by a grant from the United States Air Force, and the technique has been used to track moving targets like submarines.
Imagine trying to predict the direction of a submarine, and how long it will go in that direction, based only on the location and time of past sightings. The Kalman Filter translates the information in those sightings into a single forecast and updates that forecast when the submarine is seen again.
In some ways, services that rate mutual funds face similar problems. They do not know where a mutual fund manager is taking his portfolio at any given moment. But they do know how the portfolio is performing. The Kalman Filter uses a fund's raw returns to continuously update a forecast of the fund's future performance.
The filter does that by constructing a unique benchmark for each fund, based on the returns of the fund and those of a series of conventional stock market style indexes. The filter adjusts the fund's individual benchmark based on a probability analysis of the shifts that the fund is making among various investing styles. The researchers rate a fund highly only if it has significantly outperformed its own benchmark.
TO test their application of the filter, the researchers calculated the return of a portfolio that invested each month in the five funds that outperformed their respective benchmarks by the greatest amount over the previous five years. (That means the portfolio does not necessarily own the five funds with the largest absolute returns.) From January 1993 through 2002, the portfolio beat the Wilshire 5000 by 5.9 percentage points a year, on average. The portfolio also outperformed all other rating systems studied by the researchers.
Professor Spiegel is confident enough in this system to have a Web site that updates his list of the highest-rated funds (http://som.yale.edu/spiegel/dynamic/FundsRankedbyKalmanAlphaR2Sort.html). The professor, by the way, earns nothing from the site. As of March 31, the five funds that had outperformed their benchmarks by the largest amounts over the previous five years were IMS Capital Value, T. Rowe Price Health Sciences, Needham Growth, Wasatch Ultra Growth, and Smith Barney Aggressive Growth.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Top of the Heap"A portfolio of the top mutual funds, as picked monthly by a new rating system, outperformed the stock market from 1993 through 2002. Graph tracks portfolio chosen by new rating system (before loads or redemption fees) and Wilshire 5000 index from 1993 to 2002. (Source: Matthew Siegel, Harry Mamaysky and Hong Zhang Yale University )

HEADLINE: India, Jobs and Peace 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "More 'Can I Help You?' Jobs Migrate From U.S. to India" and "American Official Praises India's Move to Defuse Tensions With Pakistan" (news articles, May 11): 
 You report that India is attracting American jobs, and that India is moving to ease tensions with Pakistan. Could these events be related? The more American jobs move to India, the more India has to lose from an escalation of tensions. Also, higher employment means that people can find fulfillment in work rather than in pursuit of nationalist ambitions.
The United States should seek to employ more people in troubled countries, as a way of stabilizing these countries and giving their governments a stake in stability. Perhaps we could offer free English classes to increase the number of employable people. Wouldn't it be great to read someday that North Korea is reducing tensions in order to attract American jobs?

ILYA SHLYAKHTER
West Roxbury, Mass., May 11, 2003
