HEADLINE: The Senate Energy Bill 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "An Empty Energy Bill" (editorial, May 12):
 Those in Congress who dare to propose the nuclear solution understand the benefits of nuclear power. 
When compared with other energy sources, nuclear offers low production costs, energy security and stable supplies. Unlike coal emissions, waste from nuclear can be safely consolidated and contained. New nuclear plant designs offer the best means to produce the large volumes of hydrogen necessary for hydrogen to become the fuel of the future. 
 The notion of government investment in the electricity infrastructure is not new. Rural electrification in the 1930's was made possible by a legislated 2 percent interest rate. What you regard as an unenlightened commitment of resources today could tomorrow prove to be a brilliant act of social foresight.

LARRY R. FOULKE
LaGrange, Ill., May 14, 2003

The writer is president-elect, American Nuclear Society.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
Madein Italy (Mostly), Driven in the U.S.A.

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PONTEDERA, Italy 

 BODY:
LINDA BOSTON cheers the hearts of executives in this dusty industrial town a short drive from Pisa.
 The day after Christmas last year, Ms. Boston, a magazine art director in Newtown, Conn., paid about $4,400 for a perky Vespa scooter in a shade she calls "toothpaste green." She didn't need it to buck trafficor to avoid the difficulty of finding a parking space, the motives for many Europeans who buy scooters. Most of her driving is in rural Litchfield County. 
 "A friend planted the idea, suggesting it might be fun to have a little scooter," Ms. Boston said in a phone conversation. "It's cool, but silly, too." 
Her purchase was welcome news here because the American market remains just about the only bright spot on a uniformly bleak scooter landscape for Europe's manufacturers. Not too long ago, they recall wistfully, they made the scooter once again the object of European desires, introducing a flurry of sexy new two-wheeled vehicles to outfox Japanese competitors who had almost driven them out of business.
By 2000, European manufacturers were churning out more than 1.6 million scooters, with clean-burning engines and catalytic converters, and Europeans unhappy with urban congestion and high gasoline prices scooped them up. So did many Asians. Piaggio, which makes Vespa, was assembling 250,000 scooters a year with a partner in India, and it had eyes on the Chinese market.
But by last year, European companies -- including Piaggio, the biggest scooter maker, with $1.1 billion in annual revenue -- were suffering anew as their home market collapsed. The economy turned down, and sales slumped 25 percent, to 1.2 million scooters. 
Moreover, the Asian offensive stalled, too. Piaggio stopped making scooters in India, concentrating instead on the light, three-wheeled commercial vehicles originally based on scooter technology.
Now, the industry appears set for a huge reorganization. The first step may have come last week, after the Italian investor Roberto Colaninno agreed with Piaggio's main shareholders and a gaggle of creditor banks to pump 250 million euros, or $285 million, in fresh cash into the ailing Piaggio.
The deal, if completed, would give Mr. Colaninno, who first made headlines in 1999 with a $30 billion hostile takeover of Telecom Italia, a 30 percent stake in Piaggio. A further 30 percent would be held by the current principal shareholder, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, a unit of Deutsche Bank, and 40 percent by the banks through a debt-for-equity swap.
In 2001 and 2002, Piaggio posted losses that its executives say were a result of service on its gross debt of 570 million euros. Deutsche Morgan Grenfell had borrowed about half of that sum to finance its leveraged buyout of the company in 1999. The capital increase would cut the debt.
"In Piaggio, I see a great opportunity to enter the market for the urban transport of people and goods," which is plagued by pollution and congestion, Mr. Colaninno said in an interview this month in La Repubblica, a daily newspaper.
News of his move prompted much speculation that Piaggio was his first step toward consolidating the Italian two-wheeled vehicle industry by combining scooter makers with motorcycle makers.
"The purer you are a scooter maker, the bigger your problems," said one industry executive who spoke on condition of anonymity. "We believe there will be consolidation."
Indeed, Piaggio had experienced the problem. In 2001, it acquired 20 percent of Agusta, a maker of expensive motorcycles like the Cagiva and Husqvarna, with an eye toward taking complete control. But disagreement over reorganization of Agusta's debt, estimated at 250 million euros -- about $213 million at the time -- thwarted a takeover.
Others had the idea of consolidation, too. When Deutsche Morgan Grenfell acquired control of Piaggio in 1999, it outbid the Texas Pacific Group. Earlier, Texas Pacific acquired Ducati, the company that is to motorcycles what Ferrari is to cars, with the idea of creating a range from the smallest scooters to the biggest superbikes. Deutsche Morgan's success in acquiring control of Piaggio scuttled the plan.
Both scooters and motorcycles have suffered from the general economic slump, experts say, though scooters have suffered most. Last year, European sales of two-wheeled vehicles with engines larger than 50 cubic centimeters fell 8 percent, to 457,000; sales of the smaller scooters plummeted 14 percent, to 762,000.
IN Italy, Europe's biggest market for scooters with roughly 40 percent of sales, a new law requiring riders of scooters and motorcycles to wear helmets hurt scooter sales by eliminating a reason to buy the smaller bikes. At the same time, insurance premiums for scooters rose more than 1,800 percent in the last decade, according to one estimate.
Sales of small scooters have also suffered because of the economics of the business: bigger bikes mean fatter margins. Piaggio has steadily introduced larger scooters with more powerful engines. The Granturismo, introduced in March, has a 500-cubic-centimeter engine, disc brakes and a catalytic converter. It can be equipped with a vapor recycling device that enables it to meet emissions standards even in California, where they are particularly strict. The Granturismo costs more than $4,000 even before options are added.
Some makers say they have benefited from a mix of scooters and motorcycles.
Aprilia of Italy, Europe's No. 2 maker, says it is pursuing a shift that it started last year toward higher-powered scooters and motorcycles. Monica Baretta, an Aprilia spokeswoman, said the higher price of more powerful models "translates into a more restrained drop in overall revenue."
In trying to re-establish itself in the United States, Piaggio is borrowing marketing strategies from others. When tightened emissions and safety laws led it to bail out of the United States in 1982, Piaggio first redesigned its Vespas to meet American standards. Then, three years ago, it copied Ducati's idea of establishing fancy showrooms and opened the first of a chain of Vespa Boutiques on Ventura Boulevard in Los Angeles. There are now 61 in the United States.
Last year, scooter sales in the United States climbed to 69,000, from 12,000 five years earlier, according to the Motorcycle Industry Council.
"We're just seeing the beginning, especially as people realize they can actually replace the use of the car for many things," said Douglas Day, the owner of Scooter Centrale in Plainville, Conn. Mr. Day, 45, sells scooters from Malaguti and Piaggio of Italy and Kymco of Taiwan. In December, he started a Vespa Boutique and has since sold about 22 Vespas.
His customers are "quite a range," he said. "Everything from college kids, for on-campus use, to retirees, who remember them from when they were young."
That connection with "la dolce vita" -- many Americans first saw a scooter when they watched Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn tool around on a Vespa in the 1953 movie "Roman Holiday" -- gives Italian scooters a marketing advantage over their Asian competitors.
Mr. Colaninno, however, is less romantic. Though he acknowledges having driven a Ciao, one of Piaggio's smallest scooters, as a youth, he recently told reporters that he avoids motorized vehicles for environmental reasons.
His vision for Piaggio, he added, is to meet the needs of modern city dwellers oppressed by pollution and congestion. Vespa's greatest recent success has been in big cities like Paris, London, Rome and Milan, he said.
"Our strategy will concentrate on answers to those needs," he said, "through the production of a scooter and very light commercial vehicle."
Still, Ms. Boston in Connecticut wasn't particularly thinking about the environment when she acquired her Vespa. "It's as cute as a bug," she said. "People notice it."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Charity in Cyberspace

BYLINE:  By RICK GLADSTONE

 BODY:
 Goodwill Industries International, the charitable organization, was founded 101 years ago by the Rev. 
Edgar J. Helms, a Methodist minister in Boston who wanted to provide business opportunities to the disadvantaged. He collected old clothes and discarded household goods from wealthy areas of the city, and trained and hired poor immigrants to repair and resell them. Over the decades, Goodwill has expanded into a nonprofit business with annual revenue of $1.8 billion, selling goods through 1,900 retail stores and providing other services. Its Internet auction site, shopgoodwill.com, started in 1999, was a pioneer among nonprofit groups. RICK GLADSTONE

HEADLINE: The President's Man 

BYLINE:  By Robert Dallek; Robert Dallek is the author, most recently, of "An Unfinished Life: John F. Kennedy, 1917-1963."

 BODY:
 THE CLINTON WARS
By Sidney Blumenthal.
Illustrated. 822 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.
 I ONCE asked John Connolly, the former Texas governor and aide to Lyndon Johnson, if he had deposited personal and public records at the L.B.J. Library. "Yeah," he replied of the papers, which number in the millions of pages, "but you ain't gonna find the whole story there." To paraphrase Churchill on wartime allies, the only thing worse than having incomplete or sanitized records is not having them.
Charting the Clinton administration's eight-year history is probably going to be more difficult than studying any recent presidency. Besieged by lawsuits that threatened to engulf almost everyone at the White House, Clinton assistants shunned paper or e-mail records of their daily deliberations. One told me that he would go down the hall to confer with his division chief face to face rather than discuss an issue on the telephone. Before joining the administration, Sidney Blumenthal recalls, he watched White House officials who "had to cope with stress and depression, and became exhausted" after being drawn into lawsuits. He himself "incurred about $300,000 in legal expenses," he estimates, and cites a survey that puts the costs to the White House staff from Kenneth Starr's inquiries -- in July 1998, before impeachment reached a head -+at $8 million. 
The constricted record makes Blumenthal's sprawling 800-page memoir of his four years as a presidential assistant, from 1997 to 2001, a welcome addition to the literature on Bill Clinton's tumultuous second term. A journalist with stints, most notably, at The New Republic, The Washington Post and The New Yorker, and the author of several books, Blumenthal brings a reporter's keen eye for telling detail and a columnist's talent for considered analysis and unmistakable opinion to his reconstruction of what he calls "the Clinton wars." (John Podesta, the president's chief of staff, gave senior staff members a Lucite paperweight, Blumenthal writes. "It depicted a roller coaster encircling the White House and was inscribed, 'I Survived the Clinton White House 1993-2001.' ")
Domestic and foreign policy issues form a part of Blumenthal's discussion, particularly Clinton's efforts during his second four years to keep the focus on the economic and social problems at home and international strife in Africa, the Balkans, Latin America and the Middle East. But public controversies erupting out of private actions -- above all the Monica Lewinsky scandal and Clinton's impeachment and Senate trial -- dwarfed the country's and the world's business and turn "The Clinton Wars" into a kind of lawyer's brief for the accused.
Blumenthal had found the chance to serve at the White House in general and with Clinton in particular irresistible. He describes working in the West Wing "like being in a turbocharged think tank that was also the ultimate political clubhouse that was also the office of the assignment editor for the nation's press." He compares it to "a 24-hour pickup basketball game," and says it brought past presidencies and even ancient kingships to life: the "West Wing was a vantage point from which one could see the widest expanse of American politics."
As for Clinton, he exuded the qualities of John F. Kennedy that had first drawn Blumenthal to politics. "My early perceptions of modernity," he writes, "about the relevance of intelligence, of the expanse of country and the world, about what politics means, about social mobility and social inclusion, all stem from Kennedy." Clinton had his own special attributes: he was a human dynamo, always in motion. A man of exceptional intelligence, "he rewrote every single speech, marked up every memo that crossed his desk and circulated daily to his aides and friends dozens of newspaper and magazine articles he had read, almost always underlining key parts and writing comments in the margins." His "thorough knowledge of government policy was prodigious. Rarely did anyone in the room know more than he about a given policy's details or implications when it was discussed." And in Blumenthal's view, the policies themselves were wise and constructive, expanding the economy, renovating the welfare state, improving educational institutions; it amounted to "a recasting of the national ideal."
Blumenthal paid a substantial price for his White House schooling and loyalty. Matt Drudge put out a story, soon retracted, that he was a wife beater. He was accused of participation in a cover-up of Clinton's dalliance with Lewinsky and of defaming her as a stalker, and was nicknamed "Sid Vicious" by the right-wing press. He drew Congressional, media and legal fire as an unbending partisan and co-conspirator in Clinton's transgressions, deserving of a prison term. 
Blumenthal remembers the experience as a daily test of discipline: "Anger, frustration, suspicion, doubt had to be suppressed. . . . Self-control didn't arrive on the doorstep like the daily newspaper. I had to put on a suit of armor every morning -- and keep it fastened all day long. While the blows rained down there was little to do but weather them. Inexpressiveness became the psychological order of each day, exhaustion the constant physical condition. . . . Self-denial was the price of public service that had to be paid."
At one level, Blumenthal's memoir may be seen as the counterattack, the release, he felt compelled to resist at the time. The book is partly an exercise in score settling: Kenneth Starr, Dick Morris, Christopher Hitchens are just a few of the tormentors who get the back of his hand. The book is also an exercise in something all too familiar to inside-the-White-House memoirs -- an exaggerated picture of the participant's importance. Comparing himself to the Antichrist in the eyes of the Christian right, Blumenthal "wondered which of my traits had invited this invective." Holding center stage, as his massive volume attests, might be one answer. 
The book offers a powerful and generally persuasive defense of Bill, Hillary and Blumenthal. But this will hardly be the last word on "the Clinton wars." The Clinton presidency will underscore the proposition that history is argument without end. It will also challenge historians to explain why the political combat of the 90's was so fierce. American politics, of course, has never been a vocation for the thin-skinned. Every president has been the object of scathing attacks, including the country's three greatest chiefs: Washington complained of " 'unmerited censures' of the vilest kind"; Lincoln was ridiculed as the "original gorilla"; and Franklin D. Roosevelt attacked as a demented "cripple."
Blumenthal sees the modern news media, with their affinity for scandal-mongering, as principally responsible for recent political bashing. But personal attacks on public officials are as old as the Republic. Newspapers, Alexis de Tocqueville observed in 1835, "disregard principles to seize on people, following them into their private lives and laying bare their weaknesses and their vices." 
Blumenthal may be closer to the sources of our current politics of hate when he says that Clinton's impeachment was "a monumental battle over very large political questions: about the Constitution, about cultural mores and the position of women in American society, and about the character of the American people. It was, ultimately, a struggle about the identity of the country." More specifically, we can see the 90's as a time of clashing cultural values: a battle for the soul of the country between 60's Clintonites -- pot-smoking, draft-dodging, womanizing practitioners of the counterculture, as the Christian right described them -- and bigoted, hypocritical evangelists, as the left would have it, preaching a return to God, country and family values while in pursuit of self-serving personal and political ends. 
Whatever the sources of the Clinton wars, they will be remembered as a low point in the country's history. Caricatures demonizing political enemies are an all too familiar and ugly side of the national experience, but they reached a level never before descended to in the Clinton impeachment. Clinton's egregious act of self-indulgence was outdone by an impeachment based not on constitutionally required high crimes and misdemeanors but on a vindictive determination to bring down a president who had offended self-righteous moralists eager to put a different political agenda in place.
As Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago said, "It is wrong to waste the precious gift of time on acrimony and division," and, he could have added, of energy on a personal matter that distracted the national government from attending to the many domestic and international problems crying out for action. 
Blumenthal's book may do more to stir old controversies than settle them. But participants in the Clinton wars would do well to understand that re-fighting 90's battles will be of less benefit to the country than detached analysis explaining how we can avoid future unproductive quarrels over the personal weaknesses of our presidents. Still, for anyone who wants to revisit the political acrimony of the Clinton years, Blumenthal's book is the place to begin.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 42

LENGTH: 4006 words

HEADLINE: How Architecture Rediscovered The Future 

BYLINE:  By Arthur Lubow; Arthur Lubow is a frequent contributor to the magazine and last wrote about the architects Diller + Scofidio.

 BODY:
In 1988, the Museum of Modern Art in New York showcased seven architects who had accomplished far more as thinkers than as builders. Of the group, Bernard Tschumi had obtained the grandest commission, for a large-scale Paris park, La Villette; but even though he had been working on it for five years, completion was still far off. Among the others, Tschumi regarded Frank Gehry of California, in practice for a quarter-century, as a senior colleague; yet, at that point, Gehry's best-known work was his own Santa Monica residence, notable for its use of plywood planks, corrugated steel and chain-link fencing. Rem Koolhaas was the author of a dazzling, much-read architectural manifesto, as well as the designer of a tiny house in Rotterdam and a dance theater in The Hague. Peter Eisenman was a longtime professor whose pugnaciously impractical Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, was just finished. Daniel Libeskind, Zaha Hadid and the Viennese team of Coop Himmelb(l)au were theorists and teachers, with a knack for winning competitions with exciting schemes that usually failed to find financing. 
 By the end of the 90's, however, these architects were directing large offices and erecting major buildings all over the world. In a turnabout as far-fetched as a didactic children's story, the ugly ducklings had gone from being unable to get any work to swanning about with a disproportionate share of it. Those prestigious projects they didn't nab went to other "advanced" practitioners, some of them relatively restrained formally (Renzo Piano, Arata Isozaki, Norman Foster, Jean Nouvel, Rafael Moneo, Alvaro Siza, Tadao Ando, Herzog & de Meuron, Toyo Ito), and some of them aggressively out there (Thom Mayne, Makoto Sei Watanabe, Santiago Calatrava, Diller + Scofidio, Mecanoo). Provocative, serious buildings cropped up in the unlikeliest places (Midwestern second-tier cities, the Australian wilderness) and not just as museums, airports and corporate headquarters, but also as public schools and multiplex cinemas. What was going on? Had a golden age of architecture arrived? If, like me, you thought so, a tougher question followed: Why? 
 It was tempting just to say "the Bilbao effect," wave your hand and move on. Gehry's Guggenheim Bilbao was the big arts story of the 90's. An overpoweringly beautiful building with a baroque extravagance of form and an exquisite sensitivity to its site, the Guggenheim Bilbao transformed an industrial Spanish backwater into a cultural mecca. Tourism quintupled. The fact that its opening in 1997 coincided with and ultimately eclipsed that of Richard Meier's orthodox Modernist complex at the Getty Center in Los Angeles (a hometown project Gehry dearly wanted) underscored the power of avant-garde architecture. Five years later, Gehry's museum is no longer attracting 100,000 visitors a month, but it has retained its allure: in 2002, not a bumper year for world tourism, the Guggenheim Bilbao drew 851,628 visitors and generated more than 162 million euros for northern Spain's economy. Although Gehry's building dominates attention, it is only one part of a municipally subsidized effort, which includes Norman Foster's subway system, an airport and bridge by Santiago Calatrava and an under-construction high-rise development by Arata Isozaki. The goal: to change the city's identity through architecture. 
Like any big-stakes, winning gamble, Bilbao's good fortune has inspired other cities and institutions to take the plunge. Nothing underlined that truth better than the award of the World Trade Center redevelopment project to Daniel Libeskind, after an aborted attempt had been made to give the job to a conventional corporate firm. Weirdly enough, cutting-edge architecture has become de rigueur. This development is encapsulated by a remark that the director for the National Center for Contemporary Arts in Rome made a few years ago to Koolhaas, who had entered the competition (which Hadid eventually won) to design its new museum. "We need a building that does for Rome what the Guggenheim did for Bilbao," Koolhaas was told. As the architect later remarked to me, "That is a staggering statement, because Rome doesn't need to be put on the map." 
Wherever it crops up, the new architecture manages to call attention to itself. Bucking the styles that predominated in the 80's, the best new buildings don't look backward historically or sideways contextually; they look optimistically forward. "Architecture is about exploring new territory," Tschumi says. Other than this refusal to blend in, however, the best contemporary architecture doesn't share a style. Even the seven architects lumped together in the 1988 Museum of Modern Art show under the confusing (and, as it turned out, nonsticking) label of "deconstructivist" varied wildly in their approach to form. They agreed completely on only one thing: most of what was then being built by the historical recyclers of postmodernism and the small-town nostalgists of New Urbanism depressed them.
Is there anything that unites a building like the Dominus Winery in the Napa Valley, designed by the Swiss firm of Herzog & de Meuron, with Koolhaas's Educatorium on the campus of the University of Utrecht in the Netherlands -- other than that both were completed in 1997 and both take your breath away? The Dominus headquarters is a private facility for the manufacture and storage of wine. Austerely rectilinear, with two huge cutouts that frame the mottled green landscape, it has one extraordinary feature: its exterior is clad in gabions, the rock-filled wire cages typically used to shore up embankments. Functionally, the stone insulates; it also, depending on the density of the fill, modulates light. To see the sun seeping through the multiple fissures of this building, which in its massive simplicity is otherwise so solid, is a mysteriously beautiful experience. By contrast, the feeling that you get walking through the Educatorium in Utrecht is one of swoopy euphoria. The concrete entrance ramp to this student center slopes up toward a wall that eventually curves over on itself to become the ceiling; the glass boundary of the cafeteria is sharply canted, with supporting columns spaced as irregularly as birches; and throughout the building, materials oscillate between rough and polished concrete, plywood and fine veneer and wire mesh and solid steel. The Dominus Winery and the Educatorium would seem to have nothing in common, other than their originality. However, in both cases, the architects were determined to find new methods and materials to satisfy the client's needs in unconventional ways. Both buildings, in addition to fulfilling their functions, make a powerful impression. Indeed, making an impression may be their most important function.
Before the Bilbao effect, there was the Beaubourg effect. Jean Baudrillard coined the term to describe the way in which another celebrated museum building, the Pompidou Center of 1977 by Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano, drew visitors to the rundown Beaubourg district of Paris. In the view of the dyspeptic Baudrillard, these museumgoers were being circulated as efficiently and impersonally as the air and water that passed through the building's prominent external ductwork. As Joan Ockman of Columbia University points out, both the Pompidou and the Guggenheim Bilbao are "alien objects dropped in from another world," but it makes a difference whether the object is dropped onto a world capital or a second-tier city.
Many of the museum directors in search of a Gehry-like crowd-pleaser preside over collections of contemporary art. The "difficulty" of modern art is such an old story that you can only imagine the gratification of a museum professional, inured to selling tickets to the sullen, the baffled and the dutiful, upon seeing jubilant throngs queued up at the door. Architecture at the moment boasts an enviable advantage: alone of the arts, it has an avant-garde that is genuinely popular. It appeals both to the critics and to the populace. If anyone doubted that the art exhibits at the Guggenheim Bilbao are at best secondary, Libeskind's Jewish Museum in Berlin might have been a laboratory-designed experiment. Opening without exhibits, it drew in the first two years 350,000 visitors, who usually had to wait patiently to enter a bare museum.
Cutting-edge architecture -- unlike literature, art or music -- delivers sensation without requiring decoding. Its widespread appeal evokes comparison to a pre-Modernist Eden, when Verdi was a popular hero and Dickens a best seller. Like Frank Lloyd Wright's Guggenheim Museum in New York and Jorn Utzon's Opera House in Sydney, Gehry's Guggenheim in Bilbao quickly became an icon. These are not ordinary buildings. Also in this category are the Eiffel Tower and the Seattle Space Needle -- spectacular edifices that didn't need to pretend to be "serious" buildings, since they were designed as symbols of World's Fairs. The gasps of delight elicited by the Guggenheim Bilbao remind me of the gee-whiz euphoria of the Futurama exhibit at the 1964 World's Fair in New York. (The gasps of horror at the Jewish Museum in Berlin are the dystopic variant of the same phenomenon.) And sharp intakes of breath are what the client wants: the gee-whiz response is perhaps the most important element of the program. Gehry told me that Bilbao's Basque government "asked for a Sydney Opera House. They needed that to happen. If it had been a quieter and less provocative work, it wouldn't have accomplished what they were seeking. The tightrope I walked was between doing what they wanted and having it work as a museum." To be sure, that imperative can produce meretricious results; but as programmatic demands go, "Dare!" is a godsend.
Looking for explanations for the flowering of advanced architecture, you must acknowledge the computer. Technological progress has done relatively little to produce masterpieces in the other arts (spectralist music, digital installation pieces, George Lucas special effects and Radiohead notwithstanding), but in architecture, the computer has opened many doors. Back in the early 60's, the structural engineers at the Ove Arup firm devised a system of more than a million repetitive ceramic roof tiles to compose the curved sails of Utzon's Opera House. Otherwise, it could not have been fabricated. A generation later, for the Guggenheim Bilbao, Gehry employed computer technology from the aerospace industry to dictate the various sizes of unique panels that his hand-drawn sketches and crumpled-paper models demanded. However, that was a transitional step, like the cast-iron Classical columns from the turn of the last century, which presaged the era of structural iron and steel. To the next generation, Gehry and his ilk, who use the computer merely for fabrication, seem sadly outmoded. The younger architects compose at the computer screen, with three-dimensional programming to render their unorthodox forms. "I used to study sculpture," says Winka Dubbeldam of Archi-Tectonics, a New York firm. "I can't think flat. I design everything 3-D from the beginning." 
For architects, computer-aided modeling is more than a new tool -- it creates a whole new way of thinking about design, in which structures grow with an organic responsiveness of form to function. Greg Lynn, a pioneer in the field, talks about the blob replacing the box. But Dubbeldam finds even that formal dichotomy outmoded. "It always seems to me that a box and a blob are the same thing," she says. "They are singular. With a sensitive volume, you get something more precise that reflects the surroundings." Going back and forth between the demands of the site and the client's program, she aims with three-dimensional modeling to design a structure that will fit properly, in the way a good helmet fits a head. She is using the sort of computer modeling that produced "Shrek." And the same public that consumed the movie is devouring new architecture.
If advanced architecture is popular, shouldn't it be marketable? The verdict is still out. A well-publicized plan to transform an unremarkable stretch of Hamptons property into the Houses at Sagaponac, designed on spec by interesting architects (Meier, Hadid and Steven Holl among them), has slowed in the two years since it was announced (only one house is under construction). A plan for Guadalajara that is more ambitious by several orders of magnitude, bankrolled by the Mexican herbal-supplements mogul Jorge Vergara Madrigal, is said to be fully financed. Enrique Norten of the firm Ten Arquitectos, who has been working with Vergara for six years, says that construction will begin at the end of the year. Along with a convention center by Ten Arquitectos, this megadevelopment on the edge of Guadalajara has recruited an all-star lineup of contemporary architects: a corporate headquarters by Jean Nouvel, an entertainment center by Coop Himmelb(l)au, a contemporary art museum by Toyo Ito, a sports arena by Thom Mayne, a hotel by Zaha Hadid and an educational and cultural institute by Daniel Libeskind. If completed, it will out-Bilbao Bilbao. "He wants to make it a competitive city in the network of cities," Norten says of his client. "He wants to build all this infrastructure and, by attracting conventions, culture and entertainment, make the city a world destination. It's about reinventing the city."
Vergara conceives of his development as a moneymaker. Most avant-garde architecture that gets built today is triggered by the profit motive. Even the nonprofit museums, which have taken the place of the Roman Catholic Church as the primary patrons of grand-scale architecture, are choosing ambitious designs in the hope of raising their profile and boosting attendance. (The church, of course, had a similar agenda.) It is perhaps instructive to contrast the Bilbao and Guadalajara schemes with the most celebrated conglomeration of cutting-edge architecture in the heroic age of Modernism: the Weissenhof Exhibition that Mies van der Rohe master-planned in Stuttgart in 1927. Apartment blocks and houses designed, among others, by Le Corbusier, Walter Gropius, Hans Scharoun, Bruno Taut and Mies himself -- the provocateurs of their day -- explored the capability of new technologies (steel frames, concrete slabs) to provide low-cost housing for working people. This was a distinctly other approach to reinventing the city, an approach that today seems even more dated and distant than the strip windows and flat roofs of the International Style. The goal then was to provide shelter and community; the aim now is to generate excitement or, maybe, to heighten awareness.
Although innovative architects still win commissions to create low-cost housing, the schemes are too often fatally compromised by budgetary or bureaucratic constraints. (Diller + Scofidio's Slither Building in Japan is a cautionary example; the final built product was stripped of many of their more interesting concepts.) High-cost housing faces other obstacles. "It's very expensive to build a curveball in New York," says Richard Born, who developed two 15-story residential towers designed by Richard Meier on the Greenwich Village waterfront. "When you build a courthouse or a museum, no one prices it per square foot. But when you build an office building or a condominium, you have to stay within the boundaries." Born says that in the West Village neighborhood of his project, condominiums were selling for an average of $700 a square foot -- which is about what it cost to construct the Meier-designed towers. Marketing the building as "a landmark property designed by one of the century's great architects," he says that he sold almost all the space within a couple of months, for an average of $1,500 to $1,600 a square foot. However, despite that triumph, when he investigated whether he could get bank financing to replicate the project on a neighboring lot, he found that the banks were still insisting on using market averages to determine loans. "Unfortunately, most bankers are not architecture aficionados," he says. 
Dubbeldam of Archi-Tectonics has designed another downtown New York condo, this one on the western fringe of SoHo, to be completed late this summer. Alongside and over a renovated warehouse, she has wrapped a glass-skinned tower that observes the zoning setback regulations -- not with the conventional steps, but with attention-grabbing bulges and undulations. "Codes and regulations don't have to be restrictions; they can be inspirations," she says. Like Meier's buildings, Dubbeldam's apartments are being marketed as architecture; without a Pritzker Prize-winning architect's name or the High Modernist correctness of the Greenwich Village project, they will be sold for less money to a more typically downtown clientele. (Among the buyers of the Meier-designed condos are Calvin Klein and Nicole Kidman.) "He's going to make more money than a normal developer would on a cheap building," Dubbeldam says of her client. That may be; but the larger point is that he is not a normal developer, he is an investment banker and architecture lover who is pursuing the project as an avocation. The typical developer will continue to build cheap, sell high and get out fast.
The progress of architecture depends as much on clients as on architects, and good clients are more plentiful in good economic times. The last decade was a boom period all around. "You're too late, it's dead in the water," Gehry said gloomily, when I called recently to sound him out on the Bilbao effect. "When people had money, they were adventuresome. When things tighten up, everybody pulls back." Gehry did manage to recently complete his performing-arts center for Bard College in the Hudson Valley (to great acclaim). But in the last few months, some of the more daring museum renovation plans have been scrapped. Koolhaas's brilliant, cantilevered concrete annex to the Whitney Museum of American Art has been abandoned, and his tear-down, start-over plan for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art is halted indefinitely. Libeskind's Jewish Museum in San Francisco is being scaled back. Gehry's Guggenheim in Lower Manhattan is off, and his Corcoran Gallery annex in Washington is stalled. 
A curmudgeonly critic might also observe that inspiration is as exhaustible as financing. Gehry's rippling, tilting volumes would have seemed shopworn had they popped up on the East River; even worse, the jagged forms and acute-angled window slashes that were so disturbing and apposite in the Jewish Museum in Berlin turn outto be stylistic tics that have recurred in every Libeskind project since. 
But whatever the temporary setbacks in cash or creativity, the goalposts of the architectural game have shifted. The public has developed an appetite for new architecture, and Gehry, Koolhaas, Libeskind and Hadid have become establishment figures, even while clinging to their avant-garde credentials. Intriguingly, a project by Diller + Scofidio is being discussed for the East River site on which Gehry's Guggenheim would have risen. When the names under discussion for a large-scale project in New York are Frank Gehry and Diller + Scofidio, you know that, despite the economic downturn, things are looking up.
The new architecture at its best forces the user to notice or rethink conventional behavior: even in its quietest renditions, it insists that you enter a contemplative state. Naturally enough, this architecture tends to find form as museums, airports, libraries, convention centers, concert halls, stadiums -- places that people visit for a limited time. Even those who adore roller coasters wouldn't choose to live on the Cyclone. Cutting-edge residences are invariably one-family houses commissioned by cutting-edge clients. People with less rarefied taste often will insist that they "like modern architecture" yet find a particular building that they use daily to be hostile and ugly in its avant-garde design. 
That complaint was voiced recently by many of the Strasbourg commuters waiting for the tram at the Hoenheim-Nord station designed by Hadid. "Maybe it is not done?" more than one asked hopefully. Placing another sort of confidence in the future, a more sympathetic user predicted, "I think people will appreciate it in 20 years." Time, of course, provides the critical test. With its oversize dovecotes and sundials, Palladio's Villa Barbaro at Maser, Italy, designed for enlightened clients, would have struck most visitors in the mid-16th century as exceedingly bizarre; now it is generally regarded to be one of the most beautiful buildings in the world. Time, too, will judge whether a structure like the Guggenheim Bilbao is a gorgeous artifact of its time (the Beatles' "Sgt. Pepper" in titanium) or a timeless classic (the Beach Boys' "Pet Sounds").
The appeal and the limitations of avant-garde architecture are illustrated by a remarkable structure that was erected in 2001 in Groningen, a small city in the Netherlands. Even in architecture-besotted Holland, Groningen is an unusual case. Under the influence of a design-conscious alderman, the city began in the early 90's to enlist the services of leading avant-garde practitioners. (Of the seven architects spotlighted in the 1988 Modern show, all but Gehry have built at least temporary structures in Groningen.) The intent was both to draw attention to a town that was isolated on the nation's northern periphery and to engage citizens in thinking about their urban environment. As part of the campaign, John Hejduk, the dean of the school of architecture at Cooper Union in New York, was invited to build a small tower in the city center. Well known for his explorations of architectural theory, Hejduk was the quintessential paper architect. Very little of what he designed was built, and the Groningen tower, which fell victim to local politics, was no exception. In a compensatory mood, the city donated land at the edge of a new housing development for the construction of one of Hejduk's early experimental investigations, the Wall House 2, from 1973. There was, however, a condition: that a buyer be found to shoulder the construction costs. For a decade, the developer sought unsuccessfully to find a patron for Wall House 2. Hejduk died in 2000. At that point, the city and the development company resolved to build the house on spec, as a tribute.
Once the house was finished, at a cost of about one million euros, it was obvious why a deal had been so elusive. A 45-foot-tall concrete wall cuts through the structure. "You could regard the house as being inverted, with the wall as a centerpiece," explains Olof van de Wal, the coordinator of the Center for Architecture in Groningen. "All volumes are attached to it. There is no way of passing from one volume to another without coming to the wall, which means climbing up or down a spiral stair." There are other challenges as well. "The entrance is at least 15 meters from the living space, because of the large hallway you have to walk through," van de Wal continues. "Also, there is the element of voyeurism. Each time you move from one part of the house to another, you are very visible to everyone on the outside. Even in private actions you take, there is this brief moment of visibility to the outside." As he sums it up: "The house doesn't make it easy to live in the house." A couple of elderly architecture devotees negotiated for eight or nine months, but in the end, probably discouraged by the cost and the spiral stairs, they backed out. Now the plan is to turn Wall House 2 into a cultural center. Each year, three or four artists, writers or architects will live there, then try to describe the experience. At certain times, the house will be open to the public. As a house, Wall House 2 is a nightmare; as a house-museum, it should succeed brilliantly. And as a guidepost to the route architecture has traveled over three decades, it is magnificent.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: F.H.A. Insurance Restriction; 
Limit Adopted On Fast Resales

 BODY:
The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has adopted a rule aimed at limiting the sometimes predatory practice called "house flipping."
 Under the regulation, mortgages on homes resold within 90 days of their acquisition will not be eligible for insurance issued by the Federal Housing Administration. 
The F.H.A. insures about one million mortgages a year, about 15 percent of the entire market. 
 "The Bush administration is committed to maintaining a strong housing market in which consumers can feel confident that they are protected from unscrupulous practices," Housing Secretary Mel Martinez said in a press release.
Sarah Ludwig, executive director of the Neighborhood Economic Development Project, an antipredatory lending advocacy group based in Manhattan, said: "We've had a lot of scams in which unsuspecting first-time buyers purchase woefully overappraised homes. An investor buys a property and cosmetically fixes it up. Then, working with an appraiser, the seller gets the appraiser to value the home at a significantly higher number than it's worth." When the new buyer defaults, the seller receives full payment through the F.H.A. insurance.
Calling the rule "a good first step," Ms. Ludwig said, "There is some concern that 90 days might not be long enough; the bad guys could sit on a property for 90 days and then sell it."

LENGTH: 769 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Name ThatTune About Tax Cuts

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ONE of the most enduring political images of the last generation is the one of Arthur Laffer, an obscure economist from the University of Southern California, scribbling a parabola on a cocktail napkin one night in the late 1970's to illustrate how tax cuts would lead to more government revenue, not less.
 The Laffer Curve became the basis of a whole political movement. Prominent politicians like Jack F. Kemp, then a Republican congressman from Buffalo, bought the theory. Then Ronald Reagan adopted it, and it became the justification for the main plank of his 1980 campaign for president (in the face of the elder George Bush's ridicule that it was "voodoo economics"). After Mr. Reagan was elected, he rammed through Congress in 1981 a tax cut that was then the biggest ever, and his staff produced forecasts showing that within a few years, the budget would be balanced. 
 Of course, the budget deficits mushroomed. In economics circles, the idea that tax cuts would pay for themselves was never widely held and was mostly abandoned by the late 1980's. Supply-side economists, as they call themselves, argued instead the much less provocative point that budget forecasters should take into account the view, accepted by nearly all economists, that the revenue lost from $1 in tax cuts would be somewhat less than $1 because of economic growth generated by lower taxes.
But that is far too sophisticated for a political sound bite. To this day, either directly or indirectly, conservative Republican politicians leave the impression that taxes can be lowered with no effect on the deficit.
At almost every stop as he tours the country to promote his tax-cut plan, George W. Bush makes the two-step argument that the way to deal with the budget deficit is to make the economy grow, and that the way to make the economy grow is to cut taxes.
His staff is more direct. In a television interview last weekend, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow was asked about studies showing that the Bush plan would lead to a rising deficit. "Well, it's actually going to be lower," Mr. Snow declared, "because none of those studies have factored in the feedback cycle -- that is, as the economy grows and gets stronger, more people are at work; there are more government receipts."
George Stephanopoulos, the ABC News moderator, said, "That sounds like supply side."
Mr. Snow replied, "The truth is, a growing economy leads to more government revenues, not the other way around."
Over the years, the accepted practice at the Office of Management and Budget and in Congress has been to assume that the government's revenue loss from a tax cut would be equal to the size of the tax cut. It was not that the revenue estimators believed that there would be no revenue effect from the economic stimulus of a tax reduction. It was that the disagreement was so vast over how much the effect would be.
This galled the many Republicans and conservative economists who believe that lower taxes are the solution, whatever the problem. So, this year, Representative Bill Thomas of California, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, ordered the Joint Committee on Taxation, Congress's expert tax staff, to project how much additional revenue would be produced by the stimulus from the tax bill the House approved this month.
THE tax staff is highly professional. But it answers to the Republican majority, and Democrats braced for an extravagant projection that would put them on the defensive as the plan moved through Congress. Instead, the report now circulating around Congress estimates that the "revenue feedback" from the House bill would range from 5.8 to 27.5 percent in the first five years and from 2.6 to 23.4 percent over the full 10 years covered by the bill.
"Eventually," the staff found, "the effects of increasing the deficit will outweigh the positive effects of the tax policy."
In other words, the economic return would be so small that even in the short term, the deficit would grow by at least three-quarters of the size of the tax cut and probably more.
Mr. Thomas's reaction was surprising. The study proves that the bill "stimulates the economy, creates jobs, brings more revenue back to the federal government," he declared during the House debate. "That's what this bill is all about," he added.
Democrats were amused at his attempt to paint a pretty picture on a spoiled canvas. Actually, declared Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, the report "should dissipate the pie-in-sky mirage that tax cuts will dramatically grow the economy and pay for themselves."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Fewer Receipts"Projected net increase in budget deficit from President Bush's tax proposal. Graph projects increase from 2003 to 2010. (Source: Congressional Budget Office/Joint Committee on Taxation)

LENGTH: 2039 words

HEADLINE: Argentina, Turning the Corner, Leans to Its Left 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES 

 BODY:
THE day after Nestor Kirchner qualified for a presidential runoff vote here late last month, the stock market plunged more than 8 percent. Investors who had been expecting a second round for a pair of more market-friendly candidates were disconcerted by the strength shown by Mr. Kirchner, the little-known Peronist governor from Patagonia with the populist image.
 Now, Mr. Kirchner, 53, is about to become president of this ravaged country, catapulted into power by the unexpected withdrawal on Wednesday of Carlos Saul Menem, Argentina's president during the 1990's. But on Thursday and Friday, the peso fell by a total of 5 percent against the dollar, reflecting the market's jitters about Mr. Kirchner's warning that "I will not be prey for corporations" and his attack on "groups and sectors of economic power that benefited from unacceptable privileges during the past decade." 
 When he takes office a week from today, Mr. Kirchner will inherit a situation that is alarming but nowhere near as desperate as it was a year ago. With the Argentine economy finally showing signs of bouncing back from the worst crisis in the country's history, the question on the minds of investors and economists is this: Will he make things better, or will he make them worse? 
American companies have a significant stake in any recovery here: in recent years they have consistently supplied a fifth of Argentina's imports, which fell to $8.9 billion in 2002 from $20.3 billion in 2001, as a result of the economic collapse last year. They also accounted for a fifth of all foreign investment. In addition, American banks, bondholders and pension funds are among the largest holders of the public debt on which Argentina defaulted in December 2001.
The challenges confronting Mr. Kirchner, whose administrative experience consists of 12 years as governor of a province of less than 200,000 people, are daunting. He must resolve disputes on compensating banks and utilities, force powerful provincial governors to reduce spending and begin negotiations on a standby agreement with the International Monetary Fund -- all at once and all within a short time, without the benefit of a resounding election triumph.
"The timetable is important," said Rafael Ber of Argentine Research, a market analysis firm here. "He needs to get the economy growing again, and he is going to have a short, short, short honeymoon -- three months at the most. Everyone wants results in the shortest possible time."
The most pressing concern, of course, is the country's debt burden, which has risen to more than $170 billion, the equivalent of nearly 140 percent of gross domestic product, since a default was announced late in December 2001. A rollover agreement reached with the I.M.F. in January this year expires barely two months after Mr. Kirchner takes office, and the new administration is scheduled to pay about $9 billion back to multilateral lenders by year-end.
STILL, Argentina has already confounded pessimists who predicted that the country would collapse unless it moved quickly to reach an agreement with the I.M.F. In fact, the economy is expected to expand 4 to 6 percent this year. Tax receipts are zooming, consumer confidence is up, and inflation has leveled off at less than 20 percent.
"The economy is remarkably stabilized," Anne O. Krueger, deputy director of the I.M.F. and one of Argentina's most implacable critics last year, said in an interview this month with La Tribune, a French financial newspaper. The interview has been widely cited by government officials here as proof that they were correct to resist the fund's demands for sharper spending cuts. "To the surprise of everyone, including myself," she said, "Argentina has returned to growth, without falling into hyperinflation."
But what does Mr. Kirchner plan to do? In the wake of his cruise to victory, market analysts here and abroad are trying to decipher his record and his campaign talk. They have found some of it frankly alarming: he has hinted, for instance, that he might nationalize the country's railways and has also talked of repudiating that part of the foreign debt he considers "illegitimate."
"We are not disposed to do everything to continue paying international creditors at the expense of the hunger of Argentines," Mr. Kirchner said in a meeting with the foreign news media here late last month. "We are going to insist on a considerable reduction in the debt and interest rates and a rescheduling" that will "allow Argentina to rearrange its external accounts."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Kirchner has defined his economic philosophy as "neo Keynesian" without providing much in the way of specifics. But he has talked, of a huge public works effort to lift the country out of nearly fiveyears of recession, led by a program to build three million new homes, which he says will create five million jobs in a country where the unemployment rate has been running at record rates of more than 20 percent.
But most economists say it would be a mistake for the new government to try to spend its way back to growth and jeopardize the budget surpluses that the markets and the I.M.F. expect. "You need to have saved during the boom to be able to spend in the troughs," said Juan Luis Bour, director of the Foundation for Latin American Economic Research, based here. "But what happens when you start from a point where you're broke?"
As a candidate, Mr. Kirchner also declined to meet with an I.M.F. delegation, leaders of the country's main industrial federation and the United States ambassador here. But now that he is about to take office, business leaders are predicting that the man who ran as a left-of-center populist will take a cue from Brazil's new president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.
"The difference from Menem is not going to be that great because the degree of freedom available to him as president is going to be limited," said Carlos Perez, executive director of Fundacion Capital, an economic consulting firm here. "He is going to turn out being someone like Lula, who frightens people during the campaign but, once victorious, begins to moderate his discourse and ends up being more Catholic than the pope."
One sign of continuity is Mr. Kirchner's indication that both the economy minister, Roberto Lavagna, and the Central Bank president, Alfonso Prat Gay, will be retained in their posts. Both men are already in touch with the I.M.F. and other multilateral agencies as well as private creditors and have won their grudging respect with fiscal and monetary policies that are considered to be prudent.
As governor of an oil-rich province, Mr. Kirchner has also shown himself to be a fairly canny money manager. When the state oil company was privatized in the 1990's, the provincehad a choice of becoming a shareholder in the new company or taking a cash payment. He chose stock and then watched as the shares the province had obtained for less than $20 each rose to nearly $50, at which point he ordered the province to cash in. It earned a windfall of more than $500 million.
Then, rather than deposit those proceeds in an Argentine bank, he moved them abroad, fearing that in the crisis that everyone saw looming, the federal government might try to seize the money. He was proved correct in December 2001, when bank accounts here were frozen and then converted from dollars into devalued pesos. After Argentina defaulted on most of its $141 billion in public debt, he moved the money from the United States to Switzerland and Luxembourg to avoid creditors in New York who were trying to get compensation.
BUT until Mr. Kirchner shows his cards and makes his peace with the I.M.F., foreign investors here prefer to keep a safe distance and remain silent. American companies ranging from Johnson & Johnson and Dow Chemical to MetLife and Kimberly-Clark declined or did not respond to requests for interviews to discuss prospects for the Argentine economy under his administration.
Since the default and subsequent currency devaluation late in 2001, foreign investment, which had been running as high as 4.5 percent of G.D.P. in the 1990's, has virtually dried up. The only outside capital flowing into the country has come from bargain hunters making purchases at fire-sale prices: Canadian and South African interests buying up gold mines, and Brazilian conglomerates acquiring the country's largest oil company and brewery.
In that meltdown, American companies may have been hurt less than their European competitors. French, Spanish and Italian companies in particular had invested heavily in electricity, water, gas and telecommunications -- all sectors that were hit especially hard by the devaluation of the peso and the government's refusal to allow tariff increases to compensate for that change.
The financial sector was perhaps clobbered even more, thanks to the government's decision to convert debts and credits from dollars into pesos at significantly different exchange rates. Big players like Citibank and Bank of Boston were affected. But a higher portion of American investment appears to have been channeled into businesses related to agriculture, which rebounded quickly and accounted for most of Argentina's exports last year.
"It was a bumper year for them out there" in the countryside, said Jorge H. Forteza, a regional vice president for Booz Allen & Hamilton here, referring to wheat, soy and meat producers. 
Some foreign companies that were already here have also moved to take advantage of idle capacity and the much lower labor costs brought on by the devaluation of the peso. I.B.M. has moved its Latin American telemarketing operations here from Miami and has also stepped up its software development locally.
THE recent growth, though, is mainly a result of domestic investment. Argentines are estimated to have sent more than $100 billion abroad before bank accounts were frozen in December 2001 and to have placed an additional $30 billion under their mattresses, and some of that money is starting to trickle back into promising economic areas like textiles, shoes, auto parts and the processing of dairy products.
"The beginning of the recovery was mainly driven by export-oriented sectors and import substitution activities," said Fernando Losada, an Argentina market analyst at ABN Amro Bank in New York. "But fortunately that initial spark has passed over to the rest of the economy, and you are now beginning to see a more generalized recovery."
Exporters want to keep their own momentum, however, and have been pressing the departing government to brake the strengthening of the peso, which before last week's declines was up nearly 20 percent against the dollar this year. The exchange rate here at the end of last week was about 2.87 pesos to the dollar.
Because Mr. Kirchner is from a province that exports not just oil but also products like mutton, wool, fish and gold, analysts see him as sympathetic to a slightly weaker peso.
Mr. Kirchner has also declared that his foreign policy will be one of "no automatic alignments." That means he is more enthusiastic about strengthening trade ties with fellow members of Mercosur, the South American common market, especially Brazil, than about seeking a bilateral agreement with the United States or joining Washington's Free Trade Area of the Americas.
Even before taking office, Mr. Kirchner and other Argentine officials have begun preliminary talks with the Brazilian government about coordinating exchange rate policies. The Argentine peso and the Brazilian real have been trading recently at roughly the same level in relation to the dollar, and officials hope to maintain them within a fixed band as the first step toward creating a common Mercosur currency.
The first signals of Mr. Kirchner's direction will come this week, beginning with the naming of his cabinet, scheduled for tomorrow. The uncertainty will not last much longer than that, becausethe political chaos of the last 18 months has left those now in power eager to hand off the entire mess as quickly as possible to the fresh, but unfamiliar, new face from Patagonia.
"Kirchner could turn the country either way," Mr. Forteza said. "Yes, he is a gigantic unknown. But he is a gigantic promise as well."

HEADLINE: Surprise! The Fed Isn't Just Greenspan 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FROM his leather chair with the brass nameplate reading "Mr. Greenspan," the chairman of the Federal Reserve commands an institution that often seems to speak in a monolithic voice.
 The meetings of the committee that sets the Fed's benchmark interest rate are closed to the public, and its decisions tend to be unanimous, an unusual pattern in this city. Even the minutes of the meetings do not mention the opinions of individuals, instead describing the combined wisdom of "members," "many members" or "some members," despite the Fed's moves toward greater openness since Alan Greenspan became chairman in 1987. 
 In recent months, however, disagreements that are often expressed only around the Fed's two-ton mahogany table have begun to seep out of the high-ceilinged boardroom overlooking Constitution Avenue. They have added to the uncertainty hanging over the American economy and appear to have contributed to the dollar's recent fall. 
The question at the center of those debates is easily the most important one facing the economy today: After three years of weak growth, is a post-bubble hangover raising risks not seen in 70 years -- like deflation -- or is the country finally on the verge of escaping its long slump?
"The committee is divided," said Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Fed in the mid-1990's and now an economics professor at Princeton. "And you can see why. It's a tough call right now."
Mr. Greenspan is the Fed's most important optimist, marveling at the economy's ability to avoid a deep recession despite a series of economic shocks that have included accounting scandals, the pricking of a stock market bubble, two wars and the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. He has told Congress that the war with Iraq was the main reason that businesses began making big job cuts again this year, and he has tried to assure investors that there are no deep flaws in the nation's system of corporate governance. 
Some of his colleagues are sounding less sanguine notes, however. William J. McDonough, the departing president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has said that problems with accounting standards and executive pay continue to harm the economy -- and need solving. Anthony M. Santomero, the president of the Philadelphia Fed, recently went out of his way to refute the idea that the Iraq war was the sole cause for slow growth, noting that the recovery began losing momentum last summer.
The differences have also put a few cracks in the Fed's usual unanimity, which Mr. Greenspan is known to cherish as an important sign of stability. Late last year, for the first time since 1995, one of the Fed's seven governors, Edward M. Gramlich, voted against Mr. Greenspan on an interest rate decision, preferring to encourage spending with a new rate reduction sooner than most members did.
Regional Fed presidents, who vote on a rotating basis, have dissented much more often. Robert D. McTeer Jr., the president of the Dallas Fed, voted with Mr. Gramlich at the meeting last year. That was the first time two dissenting votes had occurred at the same meeting since before the economy began to weaken in 2000. 
And after the most recent meeting of the Fed's rate-setting committee, on May 6, it released an unusually detailed statement that was widely viewed as a compromise. While the group voted unanimously to hold short-term rates constant, it specifically warned of a further and substantial decline in inflation.
Reasons to worry about deflation -- a broad decline in prices that can happen when economic demand is weak for an extended period -- have only increased since the meeting. The Labor Department reported on Thursday that wholesale prices fell in April at the steepest rate since 1947, and the government said Friday that consumer prices declined at the sharpest rate in 18 months. Some of the declines are a result of a decrease in oil prices that is unlikely to continue.
"We've had a lot of people running around saying, 'Deflation -- it can't happen here,' " Harvey Rosenblum, the research director of the Dallas Fed, said in a telephone interview last week. "I think it can."
Mr. Greenspan has not been one of those people. In recent months, he has publicly discussed the risks of deflation, and Fed staff members here have been studying ways they can lift growth, and prices, if they lower their benchmark rate to zero. The rate is now at 1.25 percent, the lowest since 1961.
Indeed, the differences on the Fed are not ones of night and day. Mr. Greenspan and other optimists do not discount the problems that deflation could create.
"The Federal Reserve has to guard against further declines from the already low prevailing level of inflation. And we shall," Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, said Friday during a graduation ceremony at Washington University in St. Louis, according to a transcript. But "the United States has too many good things going for it to make a forecast of deflation credible," he added, citing the Fed's previous rate cuts, a drop in oil prices, the end of the war and an increase in consumers' and companies' net assets.
In a telephone interview on Friday, Mr. Santomero, the Philadelphia Fed president, said the weak labor market and a low level of business spending remained troublesome. During a three-week tour of local companies that he had just finished, however, he said he had heard early rumblings of confidence.
"People are saying things are flat to slightly up. 'Meandering' is a word people use," said Mr. Santomero, a longtime finance professor at the University of Pennsylvania before joining the Fed in 2000. "But there is also some good news. Some businessmen say they have been on the sidelines long enough."
Some Fed watchers wonder whether part of the debate has been engineered by Mr. Greenspan so that the Fed can present a nuanced view of the economy without unnerving investors.
"People at the Fed don't want to be too clear if being too clear would be discouraging," said Wayne D. Angell, a former Fed governor under Mr. Greenspan in the late 1980's. "The chairman naturally has to be much more careful in what he says because it is watched so carefully."
Mr. Angell added, "There's no use having all these people ifeverybody's going to follow the same line."
But nobody seems to doubt that at least some of the disagreement is real, and investors have noticed the results. After the Fed warned of deflation this month, although without using the word, the dollar fell and has generally continued dropping; a euro is now worth $1.1578. The dollar is now near the level when it became Europe's currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
The internal debate is particularly important now because Mr. Greenspan has lost the air of omniscience that he possessed during the boom. He is still considered one of the most effective chairmen in the Fed's history, in part because of his prescient view that the economy had become more efficient in the 90's and therefore could grow quickly without accelerating inflation. Economists also credit him with keeping the 2001 recession mild through aggressive rate-cutting. 
But he has been as surprised as most economists at the persistence of the current economic slowdown. In May 2001, he said that there was "ample evidence that we are experiencing only a pause in the investment in a broad set of innovations." That pause continues today.
In March of last year, he said that "the forces restraining the economy over the past year are starting to diminish" and that the job market seemed to be improving. The economy has lost an additional 353,000 jobs since then, according to the Labor Department.
At its core, the debate inside the Fed involves whether the risk of more economic weakness is now great enough that it should act even more aggressively by cutting rates further.
"There certainly have been some differences on when to go the last mile on the federal funds rate," said Alice M. Rivlin, a former vice chairwoman, referring to the official name of the Fed's benchmark rate, the interest rate on overnight loans between banks that directly affects the rate on many credit-card, automobile, business and other loans. "It's a very dicey situation."
If the economy continues to weaken and job cuts continue, consumers could eventually pull back their spending more sharply, setting off a vicious cycle that could include deflation. Deflation can cause people to wait for future discounts on products and make their loans harder to pay off because each dollar of their debt is worth more. 
Robert T. Parry, president of the San Francisco Fed, said last month that "if this remains a jobless recovery, it can weigh on consumer confidence and lead people to pull back on spending."
"Frankly, the longer growth has to depend on the auto and housing sectors, the riskier the situation becomes," he added.
But if the Fed does cut the rate again, it would leave itself with less ammunition to fight an unexpected economic shock, like the overthrow of an important foreign government or the collapse of a big American company. Fed officials also want to avoid cutting rates excessively, and having to surprise the markets by raising rates later this year if the economy does strengthen quickly.
Disagreements within the Fed have been common, even during Mr. Greenspan's relatively tranquil tenure. Two things set recent months apart from the past few years: the number of officials who are more worried than Mr. Greenspan and the background of the skeptics.
William H. Poole, president of the St. Louis Fed, has long been considered an inflation hawk, dissenting to vote for a rate increase in 1998 and against a cut in 2001. In March, however, the board of the St. Louis Fed, along with the San Francisco board, requested that the Fed reduce one of its key rates, a symbol that it wanted a cut in the benchmark rate, according to minutes released Friday. 
"It's a hint that within the Federal Reserve system there was serious chitter-chatter going on" about cutting rates again, said Ethan S. Harris, a co-chief economist at Lehman Brothers. Regional Fed boards rarely ask for a cut if their president strongly disagrees, said Mr. Harris, who worked at the New York Fed for almost a decade.
The Fed last reduced its benchmark rate in November, for the 12th time since January 2001.
The dissent in September by Mr. Gramlich, a Fed governor and former economics professor at the University of Michigan, also turned heads. 
"I was astonished," said Tom Schlesinger, executive director of the Financial Markets Center, a liberal research group in Philomont, Va. "He's the very epitome of a mild-mannered guy personally. Like every Clinton appointee, he has taken great pains to keep the face of unanimity."
Looking at the risks facing the economy, though, some officials seem to have decided that aggressiveness has become more important than unity.

HEADLINE: Sleight of Hand on Capitol Hill 

 BODY:
The tax-cutting frenzy inspired by President Bush earlier this year has produced a predictable result: two misguided, poorly timed tax bills from the House and Senate that will not provide the short-term stimulus the country needs but will almost surely cause economic problems in the future. The two bills now head for a conference committee. There is little to root for in these deliberations, although one very useful provision in the Senate bill must survive. It would give $20 billion in emergency fiscal aid to deficit-ridden states whose budget problems will inevitably be compounded by the federal tax cuts. The conferees should also resist White House pressures to deepen the tax relief for dividends, which would make a bad bill worse. 
 Any list of the flaws in these bills should begin with one that has received less notice than it deserves, namely their fundamental dishonesty. You'll recall that President Bush originally asked for $726 billion in cuts over 10 years to go with his $1.3 trillion cut of two years ago. Everyone said that was too much, so the House passed a $550 billion bill, the Senate a $350 billion bill. Both numbers, as it turns out, are fictitious. 
 The Senate bill, for example, calls for substantial dividend tax relief that will "sunset" in five years so that the overall cost of the bill will not exceed the $350 billion limit. However, if one assumes (as one must) that the promised sunset will never occur, and that the dividend relief will instead become a permanent part of the tax code, then the true cost of the bill becomes $660 billion. Similar sleight of hand disguises the true cost of the House bill, which sunsets everything in sight -- child tax credits, marriage penalty relief -- and whose true cost, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, is $1.1 trillion.
The real numbers also mean that the economic impact of the eventual bill will be larger than advertised. Only two years after the original Bush tax cuts helped wipe out an expected $5 trillion surplus, the new cuts, combined with various spending increases, will add trillions more to a coming decade of red ink. This in turn will increase the need for federal borrowing, push interest rates upward and boost the cost of capital for private investment. For these reasons, a host of critics, including the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, believe that the measure's long-term negatives greatly outweigh its potential for short-term stimulus. 
Of course, as we have noted before, the bill's greatest flaw is its one-sidedness -- the fact that it will unfairly reward upper-income taxpayers while shortchanging lower-income groups and crippling the federal government's ability to meet vital needs in education, veterans' care, transportation and homeland security. Perhaps the conference committee will remedy some of these inequities, though we're not holding our breath. 
Meanwhile, a little over one million people have exhausted all their state and federal unemployment benefits, a number that will grow by another 700,000 this summer. In addition, 2.1 million workers will soon exhaust their state benefits. All these people need help from Congress. Such help would not only compensate in some small measure for these unfortunate tax bills but would give the economy a quicker, more certain shot in the arm.
