HEADLINE: THE DOLLAR'S DECLINE: THE EFFECT; 
A Falling Dollar: Some Lose, Some Win, Some Break Even

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN and SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The dollar's plunge in value against the euro and other currencies has captured the attention of the financial markets this week. But its effect on the economy may boil down to a murky mix of pluses and minuses for consumers, businesses and investors.
 Consumers may face higher prices, but at a time when deflation is the more dominant fear. Importers' margins may narrow, but exporters could reap the benefits of newfound competitiveness. A disorganized unraveling of the dollar might squeeze capital markets, but a controlled decline could help the economy to perform better in the long term. 
 "It's a very unusual confluence of events," concluded John K. Nelson, a managing director in charge of global foreign exchange at ABN Amro Bank in Chicago. 
If the dollar fails to reverse its slide, consumers can expect to face higher prices for a variety of imported goods and services. In some cases, the importers themselves may also suffer.
Louis Vuitton North America, a subsidiary of the French luxury giant, imports its high-end purses and bags from France and other parts of Europe and then sells them in the United States. The company last raised prices on its goods in February and will probably do so again if the euro continues to appreciate, said Claus-Dietrich Lahrs, the president of Louis Vuitton North America.
"We certainly have to buy them at more expensive rates than before," Mr. Lahrs said of the leather bags and accessories his company sells. "From time to time, the movement is too strong, and we adjust the prices here in the United States."
On the other side of the dollar coin, some companies that do most of their business abroad have not been above a little polite exulting in the changing exchange rate. Heinz Krogner, chief executive for Europe at Esprit Holdings (which is based in Hong Kong), said his company would save money on clothing bought in Asia, where several currencies' values are linked to the dollar.
The competition, Mr. Krogner said, might fare worse. "For companies that buy in the euro area -- say American clothiers who buy their suits in Italy -- they got problems."
Some exporters are looking forward to becoming more competitive.
Diamond of California, a leading supplier of nuts, exports about 30 percent of its production to Europe. "Most of that is a big produce business that we do in the fall," said Michael J. Mendes, the company's chief executive. "If the exchange rate remains at its current status, it's going to make us much, much more competitive against our French and Italian competitors."
The Dole Food Company also exports from the United States, but much of its produce originates in Latin America and elsewhere abroad -- the same areas where many European businesses buy. As a result, said Richard J. Dahl, the company's chief financial officer, the positive effect of the change in exchange rates was not huge. "You don't always see it come through in the way you might expect," he said.
For some of the biggest American businesses, like the Coca-Cola Company, though, the dollar's fluctuations may have little effect.
"It's important to note that you can't look at any one currency in isolation and draw conclusions," said Ben Deutsch, a Coca-Cola spokesman.
"Given that we operate in more than 200 countries, we take a portfolio approach to currency management and we must look at the overall basket of currencies as we manage our business," Mr. Deutsch said.
In a conference call last month, the company's executives said that they expected currency fluctuations to have a "slightly positive" effect on its annual results.
The muted reaction was echoed at the clothing seller Perry Ellis International, where executives are taking the long view.
"If this is an extended phenomenon for a couple of years it may have an impact, but we haven't seen anything yet," said Timothy B. Page, the chief financial officer. "The market's a difficult market right now for everybody. This is just another factor that we all have to pay attention to."
For companies whose products are relatively inexpensive to make but expensive to advertise and promote, the relative strength of various currencies can cause gnat-like annoyances, but rarely have major strategic impacts.
That is certainly true for the Alberto-Culver Company, a $2.65 billion company based in Melrose Park, Ill. It makes and sells its own line of shampoos, lotions and other personal-care products under brands including St. Ives and Alberto VO5, but also handles professional distribution for Procter & Gamble, Wella, L'Oreal and other manufacturers.
"Our kind of business is not capital intensive, and the cost of our goods is low," said Howard B. Bernick, the chief executive. "Our major investments are not in bricks and mortar, but in marketing and promotion to grow our brands. And those are things you do in local currencies."
In addition to making imports more expensive, a falling dollar can also cause jumps in the prices of domestic goods and services. Companies that buy raw materials from abroad may have to raise the prices on their final products, and American businesses may gain pricing power as imports become less competitive.
In the 1980's, the prospect of higher prices worried the capital markets when the dollar experienced a rapid depreciation, said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief economist of Salomon Smith Barney. Investors then feared that the Federal Reserve Board would have to raise interest rates while the economy was performing well.
But this time, Mr. Schoenholtz said, the circumstances are extremely different. With the threat of deflation receiving increasing attention, the possibility of tighter credit seems a long way off.
"Here you have this sizable correction of the dollar, and capital markets have behaved as if nothing has happened," Mr. Schoenholtz said.
That stock markets have remained fairly steady during the dollar's long decline, notwithstanding yesterday's activity, may also hint that investors see the depreciation as, on balance, a useful development.
Making American exports more attractive could provide a reasonable amount of economic stimulus, said Mr. Nelson of ABN Amro. "The current administration is under enormous pressure to reflate the U.S. economy, and doing that through exports is not necessarily a bad strategy right now."
From a longer perspective, though, the falling dollar has still given investors reason for pause. If the dollar's value stays low relative to other currencies, in terms of what it can actually buy, returns on investments in the United States will look less attractive. An unwillingness of overseas investors to buy up in dollar-denominated assets could lead to financing problems for American companies and the federal government. 
"Certainly, for portfolio investors who might be putting their money in the United States from abroad, it might be of some concern if they saw a substantial period ahead of a declining dollar," said Charles H. Dallara, managing director of the Institute of International Finance, a global association of financial firms.
Mr. Dallara did not see cause for alarm yet, but Mr. Nelson was somewhat less sanguine.
"The rate of decline and the political rhetoric we've been seeing will be unsettling to people who are examining alternatives amongst U.S. dollar assets," Mr. Nelson said. "The real issue isn't the exchange rate, it's the uncertainty around the decline."
With more uncertainty surrounding the dollar, Mr. Nelson predicted, foreign central banks would begin to consider diversifying their reserves away from dollar-denominated assets and toward euro- and yen-denominated assets. In that event, he said, "you're talking about billions and billions of dollars being sold."
Some economists already see foreign governments' bonds as more attractive than Treasury securities. Mr. Schoenholtz said he did not think Treasury yields would continue to undercut yields on the bonds of governments in the euro area. As a result, a bet on the prices of the German government's bonds, for example, might offer better value for institutional investors than a bet on Treasuries.
Mr. Dallara warned against taking the reversal in the dollar's fortunes as a more general verdict on the economy, though.
"There is a tendency that we all have to look at the dollar first vis-a-vis the headline exchange rates versus the euro and the yen," he said. "The fall is nowhere near as substantial as it might appear, because there are a number of major partners with which the U.S. trades -- Canada, Mexico, in Asia, around the world -- where the exchange rate moves are more moderated."

HEADLINE: Assaults on Teachers Are Increasing, Union Says 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Violent attacks on teachers in New York City's public schools have increased by more than 20 percent over the last year, the president of the teachers' union said yesterday. 
 The union president, Randi Weingarten, said that assaults of teachers by students climbed by 26 percent to 869 cases so far this school year, up from 690 cases in the same period last year, Ms. Weingarten said. Over all, violent acts against teachers rose nearly 23 percent, to 2,655 from 2,164, she said. 
 The union tallied the violence in an array of categories, including assaults, sexual assaults, robberies, reckless endangerment and others.
The union's numbers also showed that assaults on teachers by elementary school students increased nearly 53 percent, to 388 from 254.
As an example, Ms. Weingarten described an attack in December at Public School 18 in the Bronx. A 6-year-old first grader choked a classmate and then attacked two teachers and a school social worker with a chair, making a gash in the social worker's head.
"The bottom line is, we need to improve the tone in schools," Ms. Weingarten said. "We need to make it very clear that if a child or a teacher is assaulted, there will be a swift consequence to that action." 
The union study did not attempt to determine why violent acts were increasing, but Ms. Weingarten said that possible causes included a weak economy, tensions over world affairs and the failure of the schools to enforce the discipline code.
But the union's numbers also underscore the fact that there are many different ways to characterize and count the numbers of violent misbehavior in the schools. 
At a news conference last week after a graduation ceremony for 133 school safety agents, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that overall crime in schools had fallen by 6 percent and that major crimes in the schools had declined by 8 percent.
City officials said the mayor spoke specifically about cases in the schools that are designated as crimes, as defined in the penal code, and require a response by the police. Every student who pushes a teacher would not face an assault charge, they said. 
The city's Department of Education keeps records of violent acts that are not crimes, but officials would not release those statistics yesterday.
Ms. Weingarten acknowledged that many of the attacks reflected in her statistics would not result in the filing of criminal charges. The first grader at P.S. 18, for example, is too young to be charged with a criminal offense, she said. 
Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said that there was zero tolerance for violence in schools and that the increase in attacks on teachers was "unacceptable."
"I have made clear we will not tolerate any assaults on any teachers in our system," he said. "I have sent out the word that there has to be appropriate disciplinary actions taken."

HEADLINE: NYC; 
It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's a Horse?

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
GENUINE New York heroes have been in short supply lately, whether in government, politics, business, law enforcement, sports or -- need it be mentioned? -- journalism. So wouldn't you know that when a hero finally does come along, it's a horse.
 Well, why not? Humans, for the moment anyway, are not exactly providing great role models. 
 The animal in question is a 3-year-old gelding with the funny name of Funny Cide. Two and a half weeks ago, he became the first horse bred in New York to win the Kentucky Derby. On Saturday, in Baltimore, he won the Preakness Stakes by so many lengths that the rest of the field looked as if it were in a different time zone. 
Now Funny Cide is back at his home track, Belmont Park, on the border of Queens and Nassau Counties, getting ready for the Belmont Stakes on June 7. If he can win that grueling race, too, he will become the first horse from New York to win racing's coveted Triple Crown, and the first horse from anywhere to do so since Affirmed in 1978.
In racing, for those of you who think a furlong is a winter-coat size, the Triple Crown is the holy grail. It's the World Series, Super Bowl and Stanley Cup rolled into one. It's an O'Neill drama, it's Whistler's mama, it's Camembert. It's the top.
For many New Yorkers who follow the horses -- and whose horses may follow the horses, to steal from Joe E. Lewis -- the prospect of having a homeboy reach such heights is dizzying.
It may strike some as fatuous to invest so much emotional energy in a horse. But it has happened before.
A similar phenomenon occurred when the incomparable Secretariat captured the Triple Crown in 1973. As with Funny Cide's race with destiny, that feat had not been accomplished in 25 years. Secretariat simply blew away the competition, winning the Belmont Stakes by an unbelievable 31 lengths. If he'd gone any faster, they would have had to name a NASA rocket after him.
America in 1973 was a nation in trauma. The Watergate scandal had reached full bloom. The Vietnam War lurched toward an inglorious end. The economy stumbled. One national institution after another came under fire.
Then Secretariat showed up, a tonic on four legs. One woman told the sports commentator Heywood Hale Broun that after all the turmoil, this horse was what restored her faith in mankind.
New York could use a little restoring itself right now. These are not days of glory for the city.
The police, lionized with firefighters for their Sept. 11 valor and pain, have been tarnished by a disastrously flawed drug raid in Harlem a few days ago that appears to have scared an innocent woman, literally, to death.
The politicians in Albany spend more time fighting among themselves and posturing for the cameras than producing a budget that is genuinely balanced, not flimsily held together with more than $4 billion in borrowing that will leave their grandchildren to pay for the mess.
The civic nobility displayed after the attack on the World Trade Center has yielded to squabbling over government compensation for the victims' families, with everyone saying it isn't about money even as they demand more money.
SOME of the city's leading business executives are accused of criminal behavior or, at the least, sordid finagling.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is found by a judge to have misled New Yorkers about its finances, the result being an extraordinary court order to rescind new fare increases on subways and buses.
On New York sports teams, the two-legged athletes look far more ragged than heroic. Even the supposedly invincible Yankees seem suddenly, if perhaps temporarily, frail.
As for journalism, is there anyone in town unfamiliar with the crisis at this newspaper, brought on by the fabrications and plagiarism of a rogue reporter?
To the rescue, piercing the gloom, comes Funny Cide.
Winning the Belmont Stakes will not be easy. It is a long race, a mile and a half, and it has a history of making losers of sure winners. Indeed, Funny Cide is the fifth horse in the last seven years to approach the Belmont as a Triple Crown contender. None of the others made it all the way.
But many knowledgeable racing people believe Funny Cide has a good chance.
In the Preakness, by the way, he ran in a field that included an entry called New York Hero. That horse finished sixth.
The lesson, perhaps, is that it is not enough merely to be called hero. This is one label that you have to go out and earn.

HEADLINE: McGreevey's Miscues Feed Criticism of His Leadership 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 19 

 BODY:
As he travels incessantly around New Jersey, Gov. James E. McGreevey often talks like a man on a victory tour.
 He delights in telling audiences about his grand ambitions for New Jersey and the tough decisions he has made: revamping the Department of Motor Vehicles, reorganizing the state university system, enacting tough environmental regulations, fighting suburban sprawl, starting a literacy program. All of it, Mr. McGreevey invariably points out, accomplished while closing a mammoth budget deficit. 
 But back in the state capital, Mr. McGreevey frequently seems less a master of the machinery of state government than an earnest novice whose necktie keeps getting caught in the gears. Rarely does a week pass without his having to respond to headlines about a fresh political fiasco: taking junkets and personal helicopter trips at taxpayer expense, advocating pet projects and appointments for political patrons, or making a succession of high-profile nominations that turned into public relations disasters. 
Sixteen months into his term, even his supporters no longer write these off as a beginner's mistakes. Pollsters say the fits and starts have prevented the governor from clearly defining himself and raised questions about his judgment. That wobbly image, and the frustration caused by the state's fiscal problems, have led a surprising number of Mr. McGreevey's fellow Democrats to challenge him publicly, even though he led the party to power after a decade in exile.
Mr. McGreevey acknowledges that he has occasionally stumbled during his initiation to the job, but remains resolutely unfazed by the criticism and the recent polls that show his approval ratings in the 30's and low 40's. Incumbents generally get uneasy if those ratings dip below 50 percent.
The governor points out that many elected officials are suffering bad poll numbers because of the tough economic times, and insists his ratings will rebound with the economy.
"I've just got to keep getting my message out," he said during a recent interview in his office. "If you keep doing things that affect people's lives, with the D.M.V., with education, the environment, fighting sprawl, in the end, I think they realize that you made the hard decisions and did the right thing."
For now, the state's most powerful Democratic leaders say they fully expect that Mr. McGreevey will repair his image problem, but there is also a sense that they are eagerly awaiting the day when he will seem to have grown into the job.
"It's not likepeople hate McGreevey -- they want to see him more as a leader, defining himself more," said Richard J. Codey, the Democratic co-president of the State Senate. "We started to see that recently, and I think we'll see it more in the months to come."
While only ideologues and alarmists suggest that Mr. McGreevey's stature gap is approaching a crisis point, it has undeniably left him short of allies at a time when he must win approval of another austerity budget, negotiate a new contract with state workers and prepare for midterm elections that could weaken the Democrats' control of the Legislature.
Part of the problem is the timing: While Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York were incumbents who had built up good will before their poll numbers dipped as low as his, Mr. McGreevey has struggled while trying to establish himself.
Mr. McGreevey's blunders have also surprised many political analysts, because many of them involve the insider's game of New Jersey politics -- something he appeared to master while preparing himself for the job.
He was elected as a state senator in 1990, then as mayor of Woodbridge in 1991, and used his seat in the Legislature to establish himself in statewide politics. He ran against Gov. Christie Whitman in 1997, portraying her as too elite to understand how issues like high auto insurance rates were burdening New Jerseyans. When Mr. McGreevey narrowly lost, he kept right on running, winning the support of an unlikely assortment of groups: environmentalists and construction firms, labor unions and big business, civil rights leaders and members of the union that represents state troopers, who were accused of discriminating against blacks and Hispanics.
Because the state's Democratic Party is a kind of feudal system, he also courted the handful of Democratic bosses who control New Jersey fiefs, and who helped him fend off Senator Robert G. Torricelli's bid for the nomination for governor in 2000.
But by the time Mr. McGreevey defeated the Republican nominee, Bret D. Schundler, and was inaugurated in January 2002, the economy had soured, and the unwieldy coalition he had built during the boom became unmanageable during lean fiscal times.
Democratic lawmakers were frustrated that the governor said the state was too broke to finance their projects, and grew enraged when he used state money to pay for a hockey arena in Pennsauken, where George E. Norcross III, the Camden County Democratic power broker, owns a hockey team. Republicans howled when Mr. McGreevey signed a law that forced the state to use union contracting firms on construction projects, and increased the cost of building by tens of millions per year. 
The governor's handling of several key appointments has created dissension among Democrats, who say that he has repeatedly promised the same job to two candidates and infuriated different factions of the party in the process.
Although many of his high-level appointees have been solid, Mr. McGreevey has also floated a number of curious choices. He unsuccessfully pushed for a homeland security adviser who could not get a security clearance, and insisted on naming a poet laureate whose writings suggested that Jews had been forewarned about the 9/11 terrorist attacks.
The latest furor surrounded Zulima Farber, a candidate Mr. McGreevey had been considering for State Supreme Court justice. The governor withdrew his support after learning that she had a history of traffic violations and was the subject of a bench warrant for failing to appear in court on charges of unsafe driving. His about-face infuriated New Jersey's Hispanic political leaders.
Even the administration's most impressive achievement, winning approval of last year's budget without raising sales or income taxes, turned into a headache. Sharpe James, a state senator and the mayor of Newark, accused Mr. McGreevey of reneging on his financial support for a downtown sports arena and forced him to call a special session of the Legislature to pass the budget.
"Jim McGreevey has more personal relationships than any political figure I know, which provides a certain amount of support when you're going through a hard time, because these people think they're his friends," said Orin Kramer, a Democratic fund-raiser. "The flip side is that out of all those personal relationships come expectations that no governor can meet."
Republicans interpret the governor's weak poll numbers as a sign that voters resent having to pay for his mistakes and cozy relationships with political bosses and contributors. "Voters don't disapprove of the governor because of a bad economy," said State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the Republican chairman. "Voters are angry because Governor McGreevey's questionable judgment, missteps and misplaced priorities continue to exacerbate our state's problems."
But Mr. McGreevey says that his decisions regarding state projects and appointments have been based on merit rather than favoritism. His administration has also sought to portray him as moving away from party bosses -- a move that will be severely tested next month, when Mr. McGreevey faces a difficult battle to approve his budget.
Even in casual conversation, however, it is clear that Mr. McGreevey aspires to be more than just a New Jersey machine politician. His mind races -- discussing military history, quoting Shakespeare, analyzing various theories on management. He can discuss, in soporific detail, the most mundane nuances of tax law or health-care policy.
He also keeps an ambitious schedule. In his first year in office, he made 1,500 public appearances; because he and his wife, Dina Matos McGreevey, have an infant daughter, he also held occasional meetings in Drumthwacket, the governor's mansion, where he took breaks to rock the baby. "My wife says I don't change enough diapers," he admitted.
He has curtailed his public schedule this year, but during an interview last month, the cuff of a thermal undershirt could be seen beneath his business shirt, even though the temperature was in the mid-50's. "I get in and out of the car so many times every day, it's easier than taking my coat on and off," he explained. "A trooper taught me that. It's good."
His hyperkinetic energy level has at times served him well. Early this year, when a shocking case of child torture in Newark focused national attention on New Jersey's troubled child welfare system, Mr. McGreevey was swift and decisive in ordering an overhaul. After raising corporate taxes to close last year's budget gap, he made special efforts to reach out to the business community and prevent an exodus of jobs, and several other states have instituted similar tax increases this year.
But Mr. McGreevey's zeal has also had its downside. Lawmakers complain that he spends more time on the road than tending to legislative leaders. He has at times overextended himself -- becoming involved in local elections like this year's Newark school board race, which left Mr. McGreevey humbled when the candidates he backed were defeated.
On other occasions his administration has made hasty, ill-considered decisions like floating a proposal that would direct school boards in low-income areas to raise property taxes -- a politically incendiary issue with New Jersey voters. The plan was quickly withdrawn, but only after Mr. McGreevey was lambasted by Republicans as a tax-and-spend liberal and appeared wishy-washy for reversing course.
Some of the governor's advisers are urging him to restrict his public appearances, arguing that his eagerness to please makes it perilous to expose himself to so many people seeking favors. "He needs to know that at the end of the day, it's more important for him to be respected than liked," said former State Senator John Lynch, the Middlesex County power broker who has long been his mentor.
Still, anyone eager to write Mr. McGreevey's political obituary would do well to speak to one of his predecessors, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Mr. Kean, a Republican, was hobbled by a weak economy in his first term and when he imposed a broad tax increase, many political experts pronounced his career over. Once the economy rebounded, he found his footing, was re-elected and is now one of the state's most fondly regarded elected officials.
"A strong economy can cure an awful lot of problems," said Mr. Kean, whose son, State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., is frequently mentioned as a possible challenger to Mr. McGreevey in 2005.
Even if the economy continues to sputter, Mr. McGreevey can take comfort in the fact that New Jersey's Republican Party is dispirited, underfinanced and in disarray. Mr. Schundler, the conservative Republican whom McGreevey easily defeated in 2001, is believed to be gearing up for another race. Cliff Zukin, director of The Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers Poll, said that New Jersey's demographics lean heavily in favor of Democrats, and that despite the governor's sputtering approval ratings, many of his problems have not resonated beyond the limited segment of the population that follows politics closely.
For now, Mr. McGreevey intends to pray for an economic recovery, try to learn from his miscues (he repaid taxpayers for the helicopter rides and the junket to Ireland) and press ahead on his most sweeping plans.
To sell his ideas, and himself, Mr. McGreevey will also continue doing what he did in Woodbridge -- trying to shake as many hands as possible. While that strategy may seem far more feasible in a population of 60,000 than a state with 9 million residents, Mr. McGreevey is convinced that, over time, it can achieve the same results.
"In Woodbridge, I didn't care what people said or wrote, because everyone knew me, so they didn't have to guess my motives," he said. "You just have to let people know that you're trying. You're working hard and you're trying."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the leadership of Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey misstated the timing of the appointment of Amiri Baraka as poet laureate of the state and the governor's role in it. Mr. Baraka was appointed before, not after, he read a poem at a festival that suggested that Israelis had been forewarned about the 9/11 attacks. While Mr. McGreevey signed a proclamation in August 2002 appointing Mr. Baraka to the $10,000-a-year post, for which a state arts commmittee had recommended him, the governor did not insist on the appointment. He later called for Mr. Baraka to resign.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Germany: Thyssenkrupp To Sell Assets 

BYLINE:  By Petra Kappl (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The industrial conglomerate ThyssenKrupp plans to divest more noncore businesses, the company said after its supervisory board met. 
By focusing on its core divisions -- steel, capital goods and services -- ThyssenKrupp hopes to increase productivity 2 to 3 percent and sales to 40 billion euros ($46.35 billion) to 46 billion euros ($53.30 billion) in the midterm. In a step to avoid economic damage resulting from legislation in the United States, ThyssenKrupp repurchased 16.9 million shares for about 406 million euros from IFIC Holding, a state-owned Iranian company, thus decreasing IFIC's stake by 3.3 percent, to less than 5 percent. ThyssenKrupp said it would hold the shares for only a short period. Petra Kappl (NYT)

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Telecommunications:U.S. To Develop Rural Broadband Service 

BYLINE:  The New York Times 

 BODY:
 The Department of Agriculture said yesterday that it would spend $20 million on grants to develop broadband services in 40 rural communities in 17 states. About $8 million of the grants will go to more than a dozen Native American communities in Utah, Washington, Alaska, New Mexico, Arizona, Idaho and Oregon, officials said. 
"Through these grants," the department said, "the communities will be able to participate and take advantage of the high-speed telecommunications tools needed to be a part of the global digital community." While some of the money will go toward putting computers into homes, the grants were intended for small communities that do not have high-speed computer and Internet access for their police and fire departments, hospitals, libraries and schools. "Expanding the reach of information technology brings to the homes and businesses of America's most remote rural communities new opportunities for accessing education, health and economic resources," said Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman.

HEADLINE: Toys 'R' Us Reports Wider Loss in Period 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 19 

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us Inc. reported a wider fiscal first-quarter loss today as a small increase in revenue was more than offset by higher sales and administrative costs.
 The toy retailer reported a net loss of $7 million, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter, which ended May 3. 
 A year earlier, Toys "R" Us, which has 1,605 stores worldwide, had a net loss of $4 million, or 2 cents a share.
Excluding a $9 million after-tax adjustment for an accounting change, the company would have had net income of $2 million, or 1 cent a share. That beat by a nickel the estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.
Revenues rose 3.8 percent to $2.17 billion, from $2.09 billion a year earlier.
Stock in Toys "R" Us fell 78 cents, or nearly 7 percent, to $11.12 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.
John Eyler, the chief executive, said that excluding the special adjustments, the first-quarter would have brought a return to profitability in the early part of the year; the company last had a profitable first nine months in 1999. The fourth quarter is often regarded separately since the holiday season traditionally provides most of the company's sales and profits. 
"Although the early part of the quarter was negatively impacted by the soft retail economy and the war, the tone of business improved as the quarter progressed," Mr. Eyler said. 
Sales at the biggest unit, the United States toy business, were down 2.7 percent, to $1.17 billion, with comparable-store sales down 1.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Senator Clinton Addresses Students at Pace 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 19 

 BODY:
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told graduating seniors at Pace University's Westchester campus here today that America must continue to make sacrifices to ensure a better future. 
 A foundation of the nation, she said, was what philosophers call "future preference." 
 "It is what in large measure brings this class here today -- families who sacrifice so that their children can have better opportunities, people who do a good day's work in order to build something, to make their job mean something, people who start businesses in order to employ and create profit that can be recycled back into the society. People who understand that if we don't keep the future in mind, we impoverish the present and we dishonor our past." 
But, Mrs. Clinton said, "We are moving away from that understanding" of future preference, giving today's graduates substantial environmental, educational and economic concerns in a world where America must learn to balance military might with the ability to get along with others. 
After Mrs. Clinton spoke of the challenges facing the nation, an honors student, Nicholas M. Esposito, spoke of the personal challenge that he overcame.
When Mr. Esposito started college in 1997, his vision was so good that he did not need glasses. But in his third semester, Mr. Esposito, a City Island resident, was in a writing class, straining to see the print on his partner's paper when the professor asked where his glasses were. 
"I told him, 'I don't wear glasses,' " Mr. Esposito told his classmates in an address he delivered with the help of a tape and earphone, a guide dog by his side. "But if I didn't wear glasses," Mr. Esposito continued, "why couldn't I see the page?" 
Mr. Esposito said that his drive home that day was harrowing as he was forced to guess whether each traffic light was red or green. It would be the last time he drove, and he was also forced to leave college. 
Mr. Esposito learned that he had Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, a rare genetic disorder that causes blindness that settles in quickly. 
Mr. Esposito told the graduates that he missed both the visual world and the college he had left behind. "I thought of the students I had met and the classes I had taken," he said, "the professors who had taught me and the knowledge I had gained. All of this was gone, lost in the clouds that blocked my sight."
In those first months after learning the diagnosis, Mr. Esposito asked people to read to him, catching up on thebooks he had been studying when he left school. In 1999, using Braille, software that helped him in reading and typing, and independent travel skills he developed, Mr. Esposito returned to college. 
In addition to graduating from the honors program, Mr. Esposito, now 24, served as a student teacher of middle and high school students in Hartsdale. 
He plans to earn a master's degree at Lehman College in the Bronx, and he wants to be an English teacher who will use assistive technology -- similar to what he used as an undergraduate -- to read and grade his student's papers.
"Returning to school," Mr. Esposito said, his voice cracking, "was a rebirth for me."

HEADLINE: Legislature Overrides Veto of $1.79 Billion City Aid Package 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 19 

 BODY:
Acting with continued unity, the State Legislature handed Gov. George E. Pataki yet another resounding defeat today, voting overwhelmingly to override his veto of the Legislature's aid package for New York City.
 Without debate, lawmakers in the Assembly adopted the legislation, worth $1.79 billion, by a vote of 102 to 45, more than the two-thirds majority needed. Immediately afterward, the Senate passed the same package unanimously. 
 The aid for the city came about after negotiations among Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the state's two top legislative leaders and the City Council, which earlier this month officially asked the state to pass the bill. Legislation must now be enacted by the Council for parts of the bill to become law, said Chris Policano, a spokesman for the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller.
What the Legislature approved would let the city increase taxes on sales and income to help solve a $3.8 billion deficit and stave off the severe layoffs the mayor had threatened under a so-called doomsday budget. But the new city income-tax surcharge on those earning at least six figures contains a provision in its fine print that will cost many high-income taxpayers perhaps even more money than they first expected.
Under the city's current income tax structure, in which tax rates rise along with income levels, the higher rates are applied only to portions of earnings, those above a certain point. But under the new income tax structure, the higher tax rates would be applied to all earnings for some filers.
In a statement issued after the veto-override votes today, Mayor Bloomberg thanked Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader in the Senate, and Sheldon Silver, the Democratic speaker in the Assembly.
"The State Senate and Assembly have done a service for the people of New York City," Mayor Bloomberg said in the statement.
Mr. Miller said, "I am very disappointed that the governor vetoed this in the first place. And I'm glad that his attempt to divide the rest of the state from New York City didn't work."
The Legislature's override vote came after lawmakers in both parties last Thursday defiantly imposed their own state budget over Mr. Pataki's objections, handing the three-term Republican governor one of the most resounding defeats of his political career. Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver said it was now time to move on with other business of the state.
"I don't think this has to be seen as a defeat," said Mr. Bruno, when asked about future relations with the governor. "This is the legislative process working as it's supposed to, according to our Constitution and the laws of New York State, so I don't see any ramifications other than going forward."
But Mr. Pataki denounced the Legislature for raising taxes even further on New York City residents than it had on taxpayers in the rest of the state, saying it would drive jobs to neighboring states where the income taxes were lower. He said the lawmakers should have passed his aid package for the city, one that he proposed on May 13.
The governor's package did not include any tax increases, relying instead on gambling, selling city assets, leasing a water tunnel, raising a tax on absentee landlords and selling taxi medallions to radio-dispatched limousines.
"This is an unfortunate day for the residents of New York City and all the residents of New York State, because again the Legislature has made the wrong decision," the governor said. "What is doubly unfortunate is there was a better way."
The legislative budget restored billions of dollars in state spending on schools, hospitals, nursing homes and localities, including more than $1 billion for New York City.
The city aid package would allow the sales tax to rise three-eighths of a percentage point inside New York City. It also would allow for the refinancing of about $2.5 billion in debt from bonds that were used to help keep the city from going bankrupt in the 1970's, with the state picking up the debt-service payments.
Since the state fiscal year began on April 1, personal income-tax collections have declined, along with other prime tax revenues for New York, compared with the same period last year, according to Alan G. Hevesi, the state comptroller.
He said an analysis showed that personal income tax receipts had fallen by $99.7 million, or about 3 percent, compared with the same period last year, and that revenue from business and other taxes was also on the decline.
"Although one month in the new fiscal year has passed, this report shows that revenues continue to show weakness and that the economy has not fully recovered," Mr. Hevesi said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Mayor Spares 2 Threatened Firehouses After All 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
After the State Legislature passed a New York City aid package yesterday over the veto of Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reversed course and said that the city would be able to save two of the eight city firehouses that were scheduled to close. 
 The mayor's turnaround came after he and his aides insisted for months that the closing of the firehouses was politically difficult, but necessary, and that the firehouses would have to be closed even if Albany came up with the help they sought. 
 It came after he had already fought off entreaties from the City Council, which wanted to keep the firehouses open, and an ad campaign by the unions representing firefighters. 
But last night, the mayor reversed course, issuing a written statement saying that he would spare two firehouses "because of the assistance we have gotten today from Albany, and in the interests of exercising the maximum caution allowable."
The firehouses he spared were Engine 293 in Woodhaven, Queens, and Squad 252 in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Six more firehouses -- four of them in Brooklyn, one in Queens and one in Manhattan -- could still close by the end of the week.
The City Council, which has been trying for months to persuade the mayor to keep the firehouses open, was ecstatic at the mayor's change of heart. "I think it's a step in the right direction," Council Speaker Gifford Miller said. "I'm pleased that he's being responsive to the concerns that the Council and others have raised. Now we're going to keep talking to him about those other six firehouses." 
The reprieve came on the eve of the first scheduled court hearing of a lawsuit brought by city and state officials seeking to save the firehouses. Some city officials suggested it could be a strategic move on the mayor's part to strengthen his court case. 
But Councilman Bill de Blasio of Brooklyn, who is one of the plaintiffs in the case, said that he thought it would ultimately weaken the city's case.
"I think it's basically an admission by the administration that closing firehouses can compromise public safety," Mr. de Blasio said.
Until last night, the administration had maintained that all eight firehouses could be closed without jeopardizing public safety. In his statement, the mayor said, "the response times in the areas served by Engine 293 would have risen above the citywide average, something we would like to avoid."
But the mayor's statement held open the possibility that the firehouses still might have to close if the economy does not improve or the unions do not agree to concessions that could save the city money.
Pressure grew yesterday to gain those concessions.
A new report by the Citizens Budget Commission said the average cost of a city worker will top $82,000 next year, counting salary and benefits. The report said that represents a 30 percent increase in cost since 2000, nearly three times the inflation rate.
The budget commission, a business-backed group, found that the increased cost of the work force was driven by steep increases in the cost of pension benefits and health insurance. In the year 2000, the report said, the city paid an average pension contribution of $2,263 per worker. In 2004, the report said, the average pension contribution per worker will rise to $11,005. The rising pension costs are caused in part by the stumbling stock market, which has caused the city's pension fund investments to lose money, and by a state law that was passed over the objection of the city increasing benefits to retirees.
The report urged the city to require its workers to share in the cost of their health insurance premiums, which could save the city hundreds of millions of dollars a year, and to create a new, less expensive pension system for future workers. The Bloomberg administration has sought both measures as part of its efforts to win $600 million in concessions from the city's unions, but has met with no success so far.
Union officials criticized the budget commission report, saying that it was flawed in several respects, and arguing that the city's health insurance payments were still low compared with other plans in the region. 
Even with the state aid package, and the reprieve of one-quarter of the threatened firehouses, New York City is still planning the most layoffs and some of the most severe budget cuts seen in more than a decade to close a $3.8 billion shortfall in the budget, which takes effect July 1.
From foster care programs to zoos, the proposed cuts would reduce spending in almost every city department. And in a move that has sparked widespread outrage in many neighborhoods, the city wants to reduce garbage pickups outside Manhattan.
The administration said that the decision to spare Manhattan was made on the merits, arguing that it is so densely populated and produces so much garbage that fewer pickups would be impractical and save little money. But, the plan has revived interborough rivalry.
"It stinks," said Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum. "I smell a rat," added Councilman Lewis A. Fidler of Brooklyn. Councilman David Yassky, also of Brooklyn, complained that the proposal would "create a mountain of trash for a molehill of savings." And Councilman David I. Weprin of Queens said that it was the single biggest issue in his district.

HEADLINE: THE MIDEAST TURMOIL: WHITE HOUSE; 
Bush Insists Mideast Peace Plan Will Move Forward, Despite Bombings

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19 

 BODY:
President Bush defended the administration's peace plan for the Middle East today as his aides scrambled to revive Israeli-Palestinian discussions in the face of five bomb attacks on Israelis in three days.
 "I've got confidence we can move the peace process forward," Mr. Bush's said at a meeting with President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo of the Philippines, adding that the administration's plan, known as the road map, "still stands." 
 "We're still on the road to peace," he said. "It's just going to be a bumpy road." 
Despite the president's hopeful words, some administration officials conceded that little could be done to sustain the delicate momentum of the peace effort if the suicide bombings of the last few days continue.
Administration officials said that as a first priority, they would keep pressing the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, to take action against Hamas, the Aksa Martyrs Brigades and other groups that have taken responsibility for the bombing attacks against Israel.
But the officials also said there was room for Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, whose visit to Washington this week was deferred because of the latest violence, to improve conditions for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza, perhaps by easing some closures and checkpoints, without jeopardizing Israeli security.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell talked by telephone over the weekend with both Mr. Sharon and Mr. Abbas, the State Department said. 
On Saturday night, while the attacks were going on, Mr. Sharon and Mr. Abbas, who is also known as Abu Mazen, held the first high-level Israeli-Palestinian meeting since the current conflict began 31 months ago.
In Israel, Mr. Sharon was coming under pressure from conservatives in his cabinet to act against Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. But administration officials said it was still American policy to discourage Israel from expelling Mr. Arafat from the West Bank.
State Department officials conceded that a carefully orchestrated timetable for Israeli and Palestinian concessions, proceeding according to a schedule Mr. Powell negotiated when he visited Israel a week ago, was thrown into chaos by the bombing attacks.
Some in the administration say that the attacks were indeed intended to accomplish that objective, perhaps by Mr. Arafat, who has been sidelined as the United States maneuvers to replace him with Mr. Abbas.
Mr. Sharon was to have traveled to Washington by now for a meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House. Administration officials have hinted that Israel had been prepared to ease up on closures, checkpoints, work permits and other onerous restrictions that have badly damaged the Palestinian economy in the West Bank and Gaza.
In addition, Israel had talked of releasing large numbers of Palestinian prisoners and detainees, held since the beginning of the recent wave of suicide bomb attacks.
The administration had hoped that these steps would make it easier for Mr. Abbas, in turn, to start arresting members of militant groups -- a step that he and other Palestinians have said they could not carry out without an improvement in living conditions for ordinary Palestinians.
Meanwhile, the administration's strategy of following the step-by-step "road map" -- a seven-page document that lays out a timetable for creation of a Palestinian state in three years -- has begun to draw increasing fire in the United States and Israel.
Some Israelis are openly disdainful of the timetable, arguing that it requires too many unilateral concessions by Israel in return for amorphous Palestinian promises to end the violence.
Today, two dozen Christian conservatives led by Gary Bauer, a former Republican presidential candidate, urged the Bush administration to "go back to the drawing board" in the Middle East and abandon the current peace plan, saying that it "could lead to a disaster" for Israel and the United States.
On the other side, two former Middle East negotiators said in interviews that the administration's approach could be salvaged only by a more direct intervention in the negotiating process by Mr. Bush himself.
"We've been extremely sensitive about Israel's security needs," said Aaron David Miller, president of Seeds of Peace and a former Middle East specialist under Mr. Bush. "What we need is a full-time Middle East negotiator who is a political figure, who has some Middle East experience and is clearly empowered by the White House."
Martin Indyk, a negotiator under President Bill Clinton, said that because peace efforts were nearly derailed by a spasm of violence, an investment of time and energy by Mr. Bush was needed to restore momentum.
"If the president doesn't intervene now, the road map will be lost," Mr. Indyk said. "We went through these situations time and time and time again. If the president's efforts are focused on getting Abu Mazen to act, and getting Sharon to exercise continued restraint, he can create some momentum here."

HEADLINE: $25 AND UNDER; 
In Chelsea, Mexican Is in the Details

BYLINE:  By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
MOST restaurants have their ups and downs. Chefs leave, the economy escalates and dives, inspiration wavers. I'm sad when a restaurant I like loses its vitality, but I'm excited if it rebounds.
 Case in point is Rocking Horse Cafe in Chelsea. In the mid-1990's, Rocking Horse was one of the most exciting Mexican restaurants in New York, offering contemporary dishes that remained true to the Mexican spirit. But Sue Torres, the chef, who was instrumental in Rocking Horse's ascension, left and the restaurant seemed to lose its way. Dishes that were once unmistakably Mexican became muddied, the source of their inspiration no longer clear. 
 Happily, in the last year, Rocking Horse has regained its footing. The chef, Jan Mendelson, has sharpened the flavors and restored the clear tie to Mexican regional cooking while slowly integrating his own dishes. 
The small, bright bar and dining room exude energy and liveliness without descending to the tequila-fueled rowdiness typical of many Mexican restaurants. Yes, Rocking Horse offers an excellent list of tequilas and makes a particularly good margarita (I recommend the Chinaco blanco, straight up, no salt), but it does not make a sport of drinking. It also has an appealing wine list.
Beginning with the basket of salty house-made chips and chipotle-cilantro salsa, starters are a high point. Little tamales imbued with subtly earthy huitlacoche ($6.95), a funky corn fungus, are a wonderful counterpoint to a spicy poblano chili sauce. Skewers of pork, a special, were served with a fruity salsa of grilled jalapenos and charred tomatoes ($8.95) that was so complex I wanted to deconstruct it right away. 
Little, rich lobster turnovers ($9.95) go beautifully with a sweet corn sauce, while duck confit with epazote, wrapped in blue corn tortillas ($8.95), is deep and earthy. I was not so fond of shrimp, marinated in chili-spiked citrus juices like a ceviche and served in a cocktail glass with mango and sweet corn ($9.95). The sum total of the diverse ingredients still added up to bland. But a salad of crisp cornmeal-swathed calamari, with frisee, tart orange sections and cubes of chorizo ($8.95) is a superb combination of flavors.
Mr. Mendelson's main courses are more mellow than striking. He builds layers of flavors that sneak up without overwhelming, offering quiet pleasures. Mixiote ($17.95), a slow-roasted pork stew, practically falls apart with the touch of a fork. Despite its chili rub, it is more soothing than spicy, served with a sweet plantain mash and collard greens. Birria de pollo ($15.95), another traditional stew, is made with flavorful chicken thighs, which stay moist through prolonged marinating and braising, stand up to the mild spice and go well with the tangentially related ball of creamy polenta. Chicken breasts served as a good vehicle for a coarse pipian sauce ($15.95), which, with pumpkin seeds, tomatillos and chipotle chilies, had a nutty, smoky flavor.
A special of salmon flavored with avocado leaves ($18.95) was unpleasantly metallic. Much better are shrimp with papaya and poblano chilies ($18.95) in a light chipotle sauce, served with spelt tortillas, an odd option with a pleasing nutlike flavor. Chicken enchiladas ($14.95), wrapped in the more traditional corn tortillas, are the most familiar dish on the menu, yet, with their balance of fruit and spice flavors, are far better than the usual messy, cheese-dripping version. 
Not all the desserts ($6.95) work, but I give Rocking Horse points for creativity. Bunuelos, airy little doughnuts, come alongside a coffee cup of chocolate pot au creme, just right for dunking, while flan has a pronounced coconut flavor that is delicious with thick caramel sauce and candied pistachios.
Like some other restaurants in Chelsea, the Rocking Horse doubles as an art gallery. Currently the walls are hung with the abstract works of Steven Miller, which look like nothing so much as a series of Rorschach blots. Given the ascendant state of the kitchen, they lend themselves to bright interpretations.

Rocking Horse Cafe
182 Eighth Avenue near 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 463-9511.

BEST DISHES -- Tamalitos de huitlacoche, pork skewers with tomato-jalapeno salsa, lobster turnovers, duck confit crepes, calamari-citrus salad, mixiote, birria de pollo, chicken with pipian sauce, shrimp with papaya and poblano chilies, chicken enchiladas, bunuelos, coconut flan.
CREDIT CARDS -- All major cards.
PRICE RANGE -- Dinner: appetizers, $6.95 to $9.95; main courses, $14.95 to $22.95.
HOURS -- Sunday through Thursday, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 11 a.m. to midnight.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Restrooms are downstairs.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
Where Coming Attractions Are the Show

BYLINE:  By William Grimes 

 BODY:
GENERALLY, it's not a good sign when a restaurant starts fiddling and fussing with its format, and few restaurants have done more fiddling and fussing in recent years than the Tonic, now reborn as Amuse. Every few months, it seemed, a press release would announce a new chef, a new concept and a new dawn. The place seemed to be caught in a rolling identity crisis. Was it a glorified saloon? A hip lounge? A music club? A fine-dining destination? All of the above, and so much more, according to its publicists.
 Improbably, the Tonic maintained high culinary standards through it all, earning two stars in its last incarnation. Inevitably, good reviews led to yet another makeover. Gerry Hayden, formerly the chef at Aureole, took over the restaurant, renamed it Amuse, installed some insipid abstract art in the vast dining room and rolled the dice with yet another change in format. No rational person would bet on a favorable outcome. But Amuse somehow beats the odds. 
 Amuse is short for amuse-bouche, the French term for the bite-size preappetizers intended to titillate the palate. They serve multiple functions. They help keep hunger at bay, but they also inspire the chef to create an eye-catching bit of whimsy that can serve as a preview of coming attractions. Mr. Hayden has elevated the status of the amuse-bouche and designed an entire menu around small tastes, doing away with the appetizer-entree dichotomy.
His menu offers a half dozen choices in four price categories, $5, $10, $15, and $20. With each increase in price, the preparations become more complex and the ingredients more expensive. The portion size increases, too, so the more expensive dishes look like abbreviated entrees. Five dollars buys a silver julep cup filled with herbed French fries. Twenty dollars earns an upgrade to peppered duck breast with endive marmalade and a sweet, syrupy reduction of black mission figs. 
Cheap can be good, like the golden puff-pastry gougeres, filled with melted Gruyere and tiny nuggets of smoked ham. This is finger food at its finest. Marinated calamari and good Ligurian olives, an unbeatable combination, get a fresh green note from a few sparingly arranged celery leaves. At the low end of the scale, Mr. Hayden deploys his effects economically. He knows that the last thing an appetizer can afford to do is bore. Hence the peanut sabayon with his veloute of roasted shiitake mushrooms, a thrilling flavor matchup. The Amuse fries, alas, are thuddingly average, with an eggless Bearnaise dip undermined by far too much tarragon.
Given the tight constraints of the lower price categories, Mr. Hayden puts on quite a show. At the $10 level, marinated fluke could get along quite nicely with nothing more than red grapefruit segments and crunchy grains of salt. Slivers of piquillo pepper and spicy ginger cracklings give this appetizer-size dish the complexity and interest of an entree. Plump cod cakes, crisp and golden, rest on a fresh celery-root slaw, creamy and not harshly vinegared, with a lavish truffled tartar sauce. The random international influences on the menu tend to be Asian and Mediterranean, but Mr. Hayden throws a nifty curve with a pulled-pork tortilla. The meat, slow-cooked to the melting point, throws off a heady, cumin-tinged incense, and black-eyed peas add a down-home touch. Asparagus risotto, topped with a shaving of Parmesan and sweet-pea leaves, makes an appealing springtime dish, but the risotto could be creamier. 
Mr. Hayden manages to conceal the class differences between his categories ingeniously. The $5 dishes do not feel like economy class, and the $20 dishes do not upstage their humbler colleagues. Lacquered squab, a $15 dish, seems more like a superappetizer than an entree, with one succulent, brick-red squab surrounded by curried couscous and a lush salad of sweet peppers and spiced almonds. Butter-poached lobster, at $20, seems in its own way rather modest, despite the deluxe main ingredient, perfectly complemented by a rich coconut curry broth, hot and sweet. As a small crisp indulgence, Mr. Hayden adds a tempura onion to the broth. He plays ingeniously with fruit and salt flavors in his sauteed salmon, served with poached baby leeks, which he surrounds with warm citrus fruit and caviar nage. 
Even the big-gun dish, a surf-and-turf combination of braised short ribs and caramelized scallops, maintains decorum. The scallops are large, but there are only two of them. Braised beef is a neat block of manageable size. As sleight of hand, the presentation is brilliant. The flavors are intense and all-American, with a juicy, puck-size disk of honey-glazed turnip, and a heap of truly fiery spiced mustard greens.
The desserts, all $5, come through with distinction. Rosemary sabayon brings a spicy, musky note that intensifies the flavor of grapefruit, expressed two ways, in a cold, clean granita and in grapefruit segments bathed in honey.
Instead of the regulation molten chocolate cake, Mr. Hayden presents an elegant napoleon of bitter-chocolate pastry leaves and bitter-chocolate filling. The Granny Smith apple beignet should be regarded primarily as a way of getting to the maple-walnut ice cream in the side. Even the creme brulee manages not to bore. It's a deep-dish brulee, nearly three inches tall, with a layer of orange and lavender cream on top. Like much on the menu, it is clever, pleasing and bargain-priced. Let's hope it survives the next makeover.

Amuse
** Rating: Two Stars
108 West 18th Street; (212) 929-9755.

ATMOSPHERE -- A lively bar on one side, and a vast dining room on the other, with New American cuisine in portions priced by preparation and ingredients.
SOUND LEVEL -- Loud near bar; medium-loud in main dining room.
RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Gougeres with Gruyere and smoked ham; mushroom veloute with peanut sabayon; citrus-marinated fluke; cod cakes; squab with couscous; lobster with coconut curry broth; vanilla creme brulee; chocolate napoleon.
SERVICE -- Attentive.
WINE LIST -- A fairly conservative international list of about 80 wines.
HOURS -- Noon to midnight Monday through Saturday. Closed Sundays.
PRICE RANGE -- Dishes in four categories: $5, $10, $15 and $20; desserts, $5. Three tasting menus, $35, $45 and $55.
CREDIT CARDS -- All major cards.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Restrooms are on dining level.

HEADLINE: A Yak Attack On Beef And Bison 

BYLINE:  By MELISSA CLARK 

DATELINE: QUESTA, N.M. 

 BODY:
AS the sun sets on the Sangre de Cristo Mountains here in north central New Mexico, the dun-colored topsoil turns as red as blood itself. Long black shadows creep down the slopes in varying shapes: low and gnarly from thorny sagebrush, tall and majestic from oak and pinyon trees, and squat, shaggy and handlebar-horned from roaming yaks.
 Yes, yaks. These woolly animals, originally from the Himalayas, have been turning up on ranches in the western United States and Canada. And although their numbers are still minuscule compared with those of bison and cattle (North America counts about 2,000 yaks, 350,000 bison and over 100 million head of cattle), ranchers are increasingly betting that, like such low-fat red meats as venison and bison, yak burgers, stews and sirloins will soon be on menus all over the continent. 
 That may be a long shot, but the quality of the meat makes it a possibility. Yak is as lean as venison or bison (about 5 percent fat, compared to about 15 percent for beef), and, to some, tastes juicier, sweeter and more delicate. Certainly the people of Tibet and Nepal think so. There, yaks have been an integral part of the culture for 5,000 years, used not only as pack animals and for milk but also as a source of meat. Originally brought to the Western Hemisphere for zoos a century ago, yaks have been bred commercially here for only about 15 years. North America now has more than 30 yak ranches.
Tom Worrell, who grazes 125 yaks on his 3,300-acre Latir Ranch here, estimates that he is the third-largest yak rancher in North America. Mr. Worrell, an entrepreneur who also owns Dharma Properties, which builds environmentally friendly resorts, is a solidly built man with blue eyes, a leathery tan and eyebrows as dark and bushy as a yak hide. He delights in the merits of his hairy, humpbacked beasts.
"They only eat about a third of what a cow eats and can forage for food without damaging the environment," he said. "They have small hooves and are nimble, so they can move over rough mountainous terrain. They don't need much attention. Unlike cows, you don't have to get up in the middle of the night and calve them. They are pretty disease-resistant, so they don't need any hormones or antibiotics. And unlike bison, they are docile and easy to maintain."
Since yaks thrive in forbidding, rocky landscapes at elevations up to 14,000 feet, they can easily forage in places that most cattle could never even reach. Ranchers generally leave them alone to search out grasses, weeds and wildflowers. In winter, the yaks are in their element, cavorting in the snow without the need for shelter and eating ice instead of drinking water.
"Yaks are what you'd call free-range animals," Mr. Worrell said. While they are never put on feedlots, some ranchers -- though not Mr. Worrell -- add grain to their diet a few weeks before slaughter to whiten their fat. Meat from exclusively grass-fed animals has a yellow tint from the carotene in the grasses.
"It's just for looks -- American consumers aren't used to yellowish fat," said Bob Hasse, president of the International Yak Association and the owner of Desert End Yaks in Montrose, Colo.
The grain fed to yaks has no hormones or antibiotics, because it's not necessary. Much of the meat, Mr. Hasse pointed out, would satisfy the Agriculture Department's definition of organic, though no rancher but Mr. Worrell has filed the paperwork required to label it organic. All yak meat sold today is inspected by the department.
Mr. Worrell's yaks are raised by the ranch manager, Chuck Kuchta. With his worn Levi's, 10-gallon hat and bowlegged gait, Mr. Kuchta is the very picture of the cowboy he once was. But don't call him a cowboy. And definitely not "yakboy."
"We like to say Chuck's a recovering cowboy," Mr. Worrell said. "You've got to be careful about what you call him. For a while we were saying yakeroo, but I think Chuck prefers yakalero."
Mr. Kuchta is among a small group who have made the switch from cattle to yak, some going by way of bison, or American buffalo. But why should yak succeed where other exotic meats like ostrich and emu have failed? And the bison market is suffering from a huge oversupply after a decade of speculation (despite Ted Turner's best intentions). At the height of the bison bubble, the animals were selling for as much as $3,000. Now the price is less than a tenth of that. Yaks, which are about two-thirds the size of bison, are selling for an average of $2,500.
"The bottom fell out of the bison market because ranching bison doesn't make sense economically," Mr. Hasse said. "You need more capital to start out with. You have to put in a lot of sturdy fencing, and bison are much harder and more expensive to handle and feed than yaks. People wanted to raise bison because they have good eye appeal. They look good on the plains, and there's a romance to having this native animal on your land. But they just aren't feasible."
That is because at their core, bison are wild, ornery creatures that don't take to fences or, for that matter, to people who try to lock them up. As a result, a ranch needs more hands to manage the same number of bison as yaks or cattle. "You can never turn your back on bison," Mr. Hasse warned. "They're too aggressive."
Mr. Kuchta, who also raised bison in his post-cattle days, agreed that yaks require much lower maintenance. Domesticated yaks, he said, are so tame they are often considered family pets in Tibet. "You even hear stories about them sleeping inside the huts of their owners," he said. "I wouldn't try this with a buffalo."
Yaks are efficient eaters, needing less food pound for pound than either bison or cattle. To gain one pound, yaks need only 6 pounds of forage, as against 8 pounds for cattle and 12 for bison.
But even if yaks are more environmentally friendly than cattle and easier to handle than bison, finding a market for their meat has been is a challenge.
"Most people don't know what a yak is -- that it's a Himalayan bovine related to a cow," said Jerry McRoberts, who has been raising yaks for 15 years at the McRoberts Game Farm in the Nebraska panhandle near Sidney. "But if you get them to try it, they love it."
There is indeed a lot to love about yak meat. Although it is low in fat, it is very succulent, with a deep crimson color and a mild, rather than gamy, flavor.
"It's sweeter than even farmed venison and more tender than buffalo," said Joseph Wrede, the chef and owner of Joseph's Table, a restaurant in Taos, N.M., that is in the process of moving elsewhere in town. He serves cubed yak meat in a savory stew with aromatic vegetables, and "yakballs" in a heady red-wine sauce, atop pappardelle pasta or simmered in a chili. "We sell a lot of it," he said. "The people who are brave enough to try it really get into yak."
About a dozen restaurants in the United States regularly offer yak. They include De la Tierra at the Sundy House in Delray Beach, Fla., where Johnny Vinczencz coats yak tenderloin in a mustard crust, and the Cosmopolitan in Telluride, Colo., where Chad Scothorn serves yak steaks as a special, using the same kinds of sauces he would with beef.
De La Tierra, which is owed by Dharma Properties, gets its yak from Mr. Worrell's ranch. Mr. Scothorn buys his from Mr. Hasse, who also sells the meat retail, as does Mr. McRoberts. In the western United States, yak meat occasionally shows up in supermarkets and health food stores, where, at about two and a half times the price of beef and one and a half times that of bison, it remains a tough sell.
"A lot of people are turned off by the word," Mr. McRoberts said. "They think yak? Yuck."
"We wanted to change the name to woolly Himalayan beef," he added, "but I don't think the U.S.D.A. will ever approve it. Someone suggested we send it to David Letterman and have them come up with 10 alternate names for a yak. Who knows, it just might help."

HERB- AND DIJON-CRUSTED YAK TENDERLOIN
Adapted from De la Tierra at the Sundy House in Delray Beach, Fla.
Time: About 45 minutes
1 yak tenderloin, trimmed (about 20 ounces)
 1/4 cup vegetable oil
2 tablespoons chopped mixed fresh herbs (including thyme, basil and rosemary)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
 3/4 cup dried bread crumbs
2 tablespoons Dijon mustard.
1. Heat oven to 375 degrees. Brush tenderloin with 1 tablespoon oil, sprinkle with 1 tablespoon herbs and season with salt and pepper.
2. Heat a large saute pan over high heat, and sear tenderloin on all sides until golden brown, about 10 minutes. Transfer to a large roasting pan, and roast to desired doneness (10 to 12 minutes for medium rare). Remove from oven, and let rest 3 minutes.
3. In a bowl, combine remaining herbs with bread crumbs, and season with a little salt and pepper. Spread mustard over top of tenderloin, and press seasoned bread crumbs onto mustard to form a crust.
4. Heat remaining oil in a saute pan over high heat. Place tenderloin crust side down in pan, and cook until crust is golden brown. Transfer to a board, and let rest until ready to carve.
Yield: 3 to 4 servings.

CHIPOTLE YAK CHILI
Time: 2 hours
 1/4 cup olive oil
1 large Spanish onion, chopped
6 cloves garlic, finely chopped
3 pounds yak meat, ground
1 28-ounce can peeled plum tomatoes
2 chipotle chilies in adobo sauce, chopped
1 tablespoon kosher or coarse sea salt, or to taste
2 teaspoons dried crumbled oregano
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1 bay leaf
 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, or to taste
3 tablespoons chopped fresh cilantro
Saltines or corn chips (optional)
1. In a heavy 6-quart pot over high heat, warm olive oil and add onion. Cook over medium heat until onion is pale golden, about 10 minutes. Add garlic, and cook, stirring, 1 minute longer. Add meat, and sear it, stirring constantly, until it turns brown, 10 to 15 minutes.
2. Add tomatoes, chilies, salt, oregano, cumin, bay leaf and black pepper. Simmer, partly covered, until tomatoes break down and chili thickens slightly, about 45 minutes. Stir chili occasionally.
3. Stir in cilantro, and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes. Taste, and season with more salt and pepper if necessary. Serve with crackers or corn chips, if desired.
Yield: 6 servings.

YAK STEW WITH GREEN OLIVES AND LEMON
Time: 3 1/2 hours, plus 24 hours' marinating
4 1/2 pounds yak stew meat, cut in 2-inch cubes
5 garlic cloves, minced
2 large onions, sliced thin
1 bottle (750 milliliters) dry white wine
2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
2 sprigs fresh thyme, or 1/2 teaspoon dried
2 bay leaves
1 cup green olives like picholine, pitted and chopped
Grated zest of 1 lemon
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 tablespoon freshly squeezed lemon juice, or to taste.
1. Combine meat, garlic, onions and wine in a large nonreactive bowl. Cover, and refrigerate 24 hours, stirring once or twice.
2. Three hours before cooking, remove meat from refrigerator, and let it come to room temperature. Remove meat from marinade, and drain well, reserving marinade.
3. Heat oven to 325 degrees. In a large heavy-bottom nonreactive casserole, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add meat, and brown well on all sides, about 20 minutes. Work in several batches, to avoid crowding.
4. Add thyme, bay leaves, olives and lemon zest to pan, and season with salt and pepper. Pour reserved marinade over meat. Cover, and bring to a simmer. Transfer pan to oven, and bake until meat is very tender, 2 to 2 1/2 hours.
5. Add lemon juice to stew, and season with more salt and pepper, if desired. Discard bay leaves and thyme sprigs, and serve.
Yield: 6 servings.
