HEADLINE: Prime Beef Is in Short Supply 

BYLINE:  By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
JUST when restaurants are doing everything to attract customers, Peter Luger Steak House in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is purposely turning them away.
 The owners are serving only people with advance reservations, not drop-ins; they are taking nobody after 9:45 p.m.; and, for the first time, the restaurant, which is open 364 days a year, may close on Memorial Day and the Fourth of July. 
 The problem is that the supply of prime beef has plummeted over the past month or so. Restaurants and butchers are scrambling to stock up, or are making do with lesser cuts, and, some say, are not always telling the truth about what they are serving. It is a nationwide problem, felt most keenly in New York, which gobbles a huge proportion of this country's prime beef. 
"We could easily turn more tables," said Marilyn Spiera, the president of Peter Luger. "But we are not getting enough of the kind of prime beef we serve. The real crunch in top-quality beef started a few weeks ago. We refuse to dilute our quality. The only solution is to ration what we have and cut business."
Dealers say a rough winter out West meant that fewer cattle went to pasture, reducing the supply. And with the economy bad and money tight, ranchers are sending the animals to the slaughterhouse sooner so that they can get their money faster and spend less on grain. Fewer animals that might yield a big, thick, juicy, well-marbled, sublimely tender porterhouse are going to market. 
"They're brought forward as much as 40 days now," said Bobby Hatoff, president of Allen Brothers, a Chicago wholesaler. "They're lighter." Usually, a steer is slaughtered at 18 months, after six months in the feedlot for corn-fed beef, the kind most steakhouses serve. 
The shortage comes as demand has been steadily rising. Richard Abeles, an owner of Milton Abeles, a Mineola, N.Y., wholesaler that handles only prime beef, says his business has grown 30 percent a year over the past five years as more steakhouses have opened and attracted more than hungry men with cigars, and as more people have been trying the Atkins diet. But his supplies are tight, too. "I've never seen it like this," he said. "It's the scarcest it's been in more than 30 years."
Even when conditions are good, only about 3 percent of the graded beef sold in the United States qualifies as prime. Today, most experts say, less than 1 percent is prime. Since within the grade there are different quality levels, depending on marbling and the size of the steer when it becomes steaks and roasts, only a fraction of the prime grade will satisfy places like Peter Luger. 
Though steakhouse owners and meat buyers complain that prime beef has been much harder to obtain and that the price has gone up, most are not sacrificing business. Unlike Peter Luger, which serves only dry-aged porterhouse and bone-in short loin cuts -- and buys 10 tons a week -- other places also offer filet mignon, rib-eye and T-bone steaks. 
Instead of reducing the number of servings, some may be compromising. Or cheating. It's easy to substitute choice for prime, especially with naturally tender cuts like filet mignon.
Chris Gachot, co-owner of Gachot & Gachot, a New York wholesaler whose customers include Peter Luger, said his company was allocating prime beef to its best accounts. "Some high-end restaurants have switched to dry-aged top choice from prime," he said.
Wholesale prices are up 15 to 25 percent in the past week, depending on the cut. The major steakhouses have not yet raised their prices, though some are considering it. They hope the situation will ease soon. 
Bryan Dierlam, director of legislative affairs for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, a trade group, said the situation was not extreme. He said there were usually fewer cattle available for slaughter in the spring before they have fattened up in the feedlots. "In the next few weeks, the numbers should be up," he said. "There should be recovery as we get into summer."
At Fairway Market, Ray Venezia, the meat buyer, said the producers had not anticipated a crunch. "The shortage of prime has affected choice, and you'll see more and more of the big chains advertising select now," he said, referring to the grade below choice. Fairway has raised prices for prime beef by about 20 cents a pound, and Mr. Venezia said that it was now letting the cost cut into profits.
Stephen Jones, owner of the Knickerbocker Bar and Grill, said the price he paid for choice had gone up about 25 percent, to more than $5 a pound wholesale, and would probably force him to consider increasing the menu price for a T-bone from $29.95 to around $32. "This is a bad time to raise prices," he added. 
Grain-fed beef from heavier animals, which is usually the best, is scarcest of all. Ken Aretsky, the owner of Patroon, said his friends in the industry were all complaining that quality had been off lately.
"The situation is complicated because there's no meat coming in from Argentina because of hoof-and-mouth, and none from Australia because they've had a drought," said Charles Gagliardo, the buyer for Citarella stores, "so all the pressure is on American beef." 
The discovery of mad cow disease in Canada is a further complication.
Like a number of buyers, Mr. Gagliardo said he had been well taken care of by suppliers because of longstanding relationships, but he's not sure how long the situation will last. "I don't know how the little guys are managing, unless they're cutting standards," he said.
Some of the larger steakhouse chains have been cushioned. The Morton's of Chicago chain, with 65 restaurants around the world, contracted for all its 2003 beef last December. "Our cutters gave us the heads-up," said John Bettin, the president. The Smith & Wollensky chain also pre-ordered its beef, as did the Palm restaurants.
Stanley Lobel, an owner of Lobel's, the fancy butcher on the Upper East Side, said his clientele would not cut their standards as grilling season began. "My customers will only accept prime, and they don't ask the price," he said. If he cannot obtain enough prime beef, Mr. Lobel said, he will sell wagyu, or Kobe-style beef from American cattle, for the same price as prime, $32.98 a pound, trimmed, for porterhouse steak.
Mrs. Spiera of Peter Luger said she was first told the situation might improve in a few weeks. That may be optimistic. It's anyone's guess how soon supplies will rebound.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
San Francisco Emporium to Get New Life as Mall

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
Designed by the first San Francisco architect to be trained in Paris, the century-old Emporium store near Union Square once stood as a proud symbol of this city's sophistication, with its colonnade of 18 columns and its oval rotunda topped by a 102-foot-wide green glass-and-steel dome. 
But after years of decline, the Emporium, the first department store here, closed in 1996. The building itself was shuttered in 1999, leaving an unwelcoming dead zone in the midst of the Market Street retail district.
 This fall, however, two publicly traded real estate companies, Forest City Enterprises and Westfield America, hope to break ground on an unusual $380 million project to connect the Emporium building on five floors to its much younger neighbor, the San Francisco Shopping Center. The plans call for creating one of the largest indoor malls in the country, with 1.5 million square feet of space and the largest Bloomingdale's store outside New York. 
 The project is also expected to serve as a link between Union Square, a few blocks to the north -- whose park has recently been refurbished as part of an effort to spruce up the neighborhood -- and Yerba Buena, a developing cultural and residential neighborhood to the south that is now home to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.
Completed in 1898, the Emporium was designed by Albert Pissis, San Francisco's pre-eminent architect at the time. Mr. Pissis modeled the building after the Parisian stores he saw while studying at the L'Ecole des Beaux-Arts, said Norman M. Garden, a partner at RTKL Associates and one of the architects on the current project. The store had to be rebuilt after it was destroyed in a fire that resulted from the 1906 earthquake, but the elegant facade remained intact and will be restored. The dome will be raised 54 feet so that it will form part of the city's skyline.
The building's interior does not meet current seismic or merchandising standards, however, and will be gutted to make way for the five-level Bloomingdale's that will face Mission Street. It will be the chain's first store here.
The store is being designed as a brightly illuminated glass box so that passers-by will be able to view the activity within, bringing new life to a blighted street that many residents now avoid, said the store's architect, A. Eugene Kohn, the chairman of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates.
Opened in 1988, the eight-story (including a below-grade level) vertical mall next door to the Emporium is anchored by a five-level Nordstrom department store on its highest levels and currently has 68 shops. The expanded San Francisco Shopping Center will have room for 200 stores, said Richard E. Green, Westfield's vice chairman for operations. A nine-screen movie theater operated by a Western chain, Century Theaters, will sit on top of the Bloomingdale's store, and three floors of offices will be above the retail concourse. No parking is included in the project, but it is near a little-used municipal parking building with more than 2,600 spaces.
It has been more than five years since the owners of the Emporium, Federated Department Stores, selected Forest City to develop a Bloomingdale's in the old store. James A. Ratner, the chief executive of Forest City Commercial Group, said the company discussed a joint venture with the shopping center's previous owner, Rodamco, a Dutch company, in order to make the project economically feasible.
But the talks went nowhere until Westfield acquired the mall last year and quickly agreed to a joint venture. "The properties together make sense," Mr. Green said. The project was delayed because of a lawsuit that sought to block it on environmental and other grounds. The litigation was resolved in the developers' favor in December.
Under their agreement, the two companies will share ownership in the mall but it will be managed, leased and marketed by Westfield, the largest retail owner in California.
For Forest City, bringing a Bloomingdale's to Market Street is not quite the gamble it might have been had the San Francisco Shopping Center not gotten there first, Mr. Ratner said.
Building a mall on a street that borders the city's industrial area seemed like an outlandish idea when it was proposed in the 1980's, said Jim Chappell, the president of the San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association, a nonprofit research organization. "Even the week it opened," he said, "people said it will never work on the south side of Market, that they would never get anyone to cross that line." Then, too, San Francisco had never had a vertical mall, a format that is not always popular with shoppers, who often tend to avoid the upper floors.
But from the outset, the San Francisco Shopping Center, which is housed in a neo-Classical-style building that seems to echo the Emporium, has done well. Sales last year (not counting the Nordstrom store) averaged $529 a square foot, according to Westfield, far above the national average for major malls of $330, as calculated by the International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group. 
Brokers cite several reasons for the mall's success -- among them its location on top of the Bay Area Rapid Transit's Powell Street station, one of the busiest in the system, and the fact that Nordstrom occupies the top five levels rather than the lower floors, making it more likely that customers will explore the entire store.
But that configuration has made it harder to drum up business for the third floor, the one below the Nordstrom floors, said Mr. Garden, the architect who is in charge of restoring the Emporium facade and linking the two buildings. "If your destination was Nordstrom, you went quickly past it," Mr. Garden said, referring to the third floor.
In 1998, Mr. Garden and other members of Forest City's development team toured Asia, where vertical retailing is commonplace, in search of inspiration for improving circulation on the upper floors. "Vertical retail still scares everybody," Mr. Garden said. "We're all confident about the ground level, the BART level and the second floor. But what spells success for Levels 3 and 4?" Annual rents reflect the preference for the lower floors, with ground-floor space commanding about $150 to $175 a square foot and rent dropping to $75 to $125 on the second floor, local brokers said.
Rents in Union Square vary widely, from $60 a square foot per year on the side streets to as much as $450 a square foot for small spaces directly on Union Square, said Rhonda Diaz, a vice president of Terranomics Retail Services, a division of BT Commercial Real Estate, a company based in Northern California.
Once known as a shopping district for the carriage trade, Union Square still has its share of fancy stores, including a glassy Nieman-Marcus, where the City of Paris department store used to be. But these days, Union Square also has stores with more mass appeal like Armani Exchange and Benetton. The retail vacancy rate is about 13 percent, Ms. Diaz said.
Kazuko Y. Morgan, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, said Union Square draws heavily from visitors to San Francisco, who are evenly divided among business travelers, tourists and conventioneers. Only this last category has remained strong, she said, but "conventioneers don't spend as much money." 
Naturally, the developers hope that the downturn will be long over in 2006, when the expansion of the San Francisco Shopping Center is expected to be completed. The shopping center will remain open during the construction, they said.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; 
Some Best-Priced Space Isn't Even on the Market

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The space was not officially on the market, but executives at Julien J. Studley, a tenants' broker, learned that whole floors in the Bertelsmann Building at Broadway and 45th Street might be available. In short order they negotiated a 15-year lease for 180,000 square feet for the law firm of Pillsbury Winthrop, which will move from 1 Battery Park Plaza downtown to six floors in Times Square after July 1.
 Space that could be available for rent but has not been officially offered to the market is known as "shadow space." There are always companies that have vacant space to lease if the right potential tenant asks. But in the current economy, with the number of jobs shrinking, this unofficial space is becoming a major factor in the market, brokers say. 
 In a recent report, Cresa Partners, another brokerage firm that specializes in representing tenants, reported that if shadow space were counted, vacancies in some submarkets in Manhattan would be 20 percent to 37 percent higher than the reported rates. Since most of the shadow space is available for sublease, it is having a depressing effect on rents for spaces being offered for direct lease by landlords.
The gap between asking rents for direct and sublet space is as much as 40 percentage points in some areas, according to the Cresa report.
This excess space and downward pressure on rents could be a drag on a recovery in the real estate market, even if the overall economy begins to rebound, the report said.
Brokers say many corporations are reluctant to put unused space on the market because they fear it will send a signal that their business is ailing. But they say that tougher accounting rules are forcing corporations to take write-downs for empty space, making them more receptive to sublease deals, even at rents below what they are paying their landlords.
Gregg Lorberbaum, a managing principal at the Staubach Company, a tenants' broker, said his company estimated that most financial services companies in New York had at least 10 percent of their space potentially available for rent to third parties. "The space is not on the market, but it is there," he said.
Brokers who are doing their jobs properly know where empty space is, even if it is not reported on CoStar, the computerized real estate data service, said Peter G. Riguardi, the New York area president of Jones Lang LaSalle, the brokerage and services company. "Most sophisticated transactions people know where all the space is, including the shadow space," he said.
But because this information is not published, it is hard to know just how big a factor it is. "Some people say it is 10 percent," Mr. Riguardi said. "Some say it is 5 percent. But what is clear is that it tends to balloon in times like these." 
The good side of the situation, he added, is that if a client is interested in a certain part of Manhattan, it is likely that brokers will be able to find office space to meet the prospective renter's needs.
"Companies do not want to give the wrong impression to their employees or to external observers by putting space on the market," said Robert B. Emden, vice chairman of USI Real Estate Advisors, a brokerage firm. "But if you call the right person in a company, you will often find they are willing to give up space."
The space in the Times Square building owned by Bertelsmann that was leased to Pillsbury Winthrop was not on the market when negotiations on behalf of the law firm began last November, said Mitchell S. Steir, the chairman of the Studley company. The deal was not announced until March.
Although the law firm had been close to signing a lease for space at Times Square Tower, which is on 42nd Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, "as a tenant's broker, we have a responsibility to monitor the market for better opportunities," Mr. Steir said. Because Bertelsmann, the German media company, owns the building at 1540 Broadway, the law firm has a direct lease, eliminating the complications that can come with subleases.
Shadow space makes the real estate market less efficient because other landlords have trouble getting information on the terms of leases for space that was never offered to the market, Mr. Steir said.
When companies decide to sublease space, they typically want to move it off their books quickly and do not always hold out for the highest rent, he added. Because the deals are private, they often have a psychological impact on the market greater than the amount of square feet involved would ordinarily have. "The myth of excess corporate space then becomes a reality," Mr. Steir said.

HEADLINE: Fear of SARS, Fear of Strangers 

BYLINE:  By Iris Chang; Iris Chang is author of "The Rape of Nanking" and, most recently, of "The Chinese in America: A Narrative History."

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. 

 BODY:
Earlier this month, the University of California at Berkeley banned from its summer programs all students from mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore, out of fear that some might be infected by the SARS virus. The university's response to the epidemic illustrates how easily the fear of SARS can degenerate into a generalized antipathy toward Asians, even on college campuses.
 After facing sharp criticism for its decision, Berkeley modified its policy, announcing that it would permit some students from the banned countries to enroll, though not nearly as many as it had originally expected. It also said it would reserve special rooms on campus to isolate or quarantine people if any should fall ill, and that the Asian students would be closely monitored by campus health authorities. 
 There is no question that precautions should be taken to protect people from SARS: after all, scientists have not yet found a cure for the disease or a vaccination to prevent it. But without the mitigating influence of sound thinking, excessive fear of this new disease can lead to discrimination against Asians, something that is not without precedent in this country. 
In the late 19th century, anti-Chinese sentiment arose, fueled by a bad economy and workers threatened by an influx of cheap Chinese labor. Anti-Chinese propaganda tended to focus on issues of health and disease. In 1875, the American Medical Association sponsored a study to investigate assertions that Chinese women were spreading a unique, "Chinese" strain of syphilis. Though the study found no evidence to support the claim, one medical publication, The Medico-Literary Journal, nevertheless accused the Chinese of "infusing a poison in the Anglo-Saxon blood."
Elements of the American press helped fan the flames, portraying the Chinese as an unsanitary and dangerous race. An editorial in The Santa Cruz Sentinel in 1879, for example, described the Chinese as "half-human, half-devil, rat-eating, rag-wearing, law-ignoring, Christian-civilization-hating, opium-smoking, labor-degrading, entrail-sucking Celestials."
Another California newspaper, The Dutch Flat Forum, struck a similar chord at the time. "Women of California," it asked, "why do you persist in having your dirty linen fouled by unclean hands, under the pretense of having it cleansed? Do you not know that (in these exciting times when the Chinese are losing employment, and naturally mad at the white race) you are taking desperate chances of having disease introduced among us that will render desolate our firesides? And in fact we don't know but that the diseases among our children during the past year, which have baffled the skill of our most eminent physicians, and depopulated many households, have emanated from the Chinese."
Sensational news accounts of Chinese men luring innocent young white women into opium dens were complemented by advertising. For instance, ads for "Rough on Rats," a pest control product, featured a picture of a pigtailed Chinese man with his head tilted back, devouring a live rodent. The image was accompanied, not so subtly, by the anti-Chinese slogan of the era: "They must go."
Some Chinese-Americans found profit in perpetuating these stereotypes. Up through the 1930's, white and Chinese tour guides alike invented stories about a mysterious, labyrinthine world under Chinatown streets, filled with narcotics and brothels. In San Francisco, they ushered white tourists into fake leper colonies and fake opium dens and staged elaborate fights in which residents posing as opium-crazed gangsters dueled with knives in the streets.
Anti-Chinese sentiment was met with sympathy in Washington, where Democrats and Republicans adopted discriminatory platforms in order to win votes in California. Under pressure from the Workingmen's Party in California, Congress in 1882 passed the Chinese Exclusion Act, which specifically barred laborers and permitted only certain classes of Chinese, like scholars, diplomats and merchants, to enter. 
Consequently, Chinese immigrants endured much greater scrutiny than their European counterparts. To make sure no Chinese were using false identification papers to gain entrance under one of the permitted categories, immigration officers detained all new arrivals from China and interrogated them intensely about their identity, sometimes for months.
In 1910, the government set up a new immigration center at Angel Island in San Francisco Bay, formerly the site of a quarantine station that fumigated foreign ships and inspected passengers for signs of contagious diseases. Officials claimed that the physical isolation would stop the epidemics that they had been led to believe were "prevalent among aliens from Oriental countries." 
Although Angel Island was meant to contain disease, it produced the opposite effect by cramming healthy and sick Chinese immigrants together into close quarters. Hospitals in San Francisco refused to admit patients from Angel Island -- even though there were no medical facilities on the island to treat the critically ill. When one detainee came down with cerebral spinal meningitis, immigration officials moved him into a tent, where he was kept until he died.
Perhaps the most severe example of medical panic transforming itself into racial prejudice took place in 1899, when bubonic plague broke out in Hawaii. Though the disease hit whites as well as Chinese, the local board of health focused its efforts on the Chinese alone, placing them under quarantine, preventing them from sailing to the continental United States and burning down parts of Honolulu's Chinatown.
In 1900, officials in San Francisco followed Hawaii's example, closing Chinatown businesses, forcing Chinese residents to submit to inoculation and cordoning off the neighborhood with a nine-foot-tall fence -- a quarantine that a federal court later ruled unconstitutional. San Francisco authorities also tried to raze and burn down Chinese neighborhoods; it took the combined efforts of the ethnic San Francisco Chinese community, their lawyers and China's ambassador to the United States to save the community from complete destruction.
Suspicion of Chinese-Americans has waxed and waned over the 20th century, but it has never completely gone away. It is no wonder, then, that given this not-so-distant history Chinese-Americans are uneasy about the way in which people have responded to the threat of SARS. While we are right to expect the government to take all necessary steps to slow the spread of the disease, we are also right to demand more careful reasoning from American institutions. 
Though Berkeley's desire to protect its campus from SARS is understandable, its willingness tobar Asian students admitted to summer school was unfortunate. (According to the school's Web site, hundreds of other students from Asian countries -- those who had hoped to take English as a Second Language classes -- will not be able to come this summer.) 
The university's actions have had particular force for many Asians, in large measure because California has historically been home to the oldest and most virulent strains of anti-Chinese sentiment. As long as the university maintains criteria for exclusion based on nationality, not sound medical diagnosis, it will continue to face charges of anti-Asian prejudice. After all, SARS is a global disease. A blanket ban on Asians isn't protection against the virus -- it is simply discrimination under a different name.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles County Weighs Cost of Illegal Immigration 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 20 

 BODY:
In these wobbling economic times, it was only a question of when public officials would turn toward illegal immigrants and ask how much of a burden they pose to taxpayers.
 Nowhere is the question more sensitive than in Los Angeles County, where an estimated 1.1 million illegal immigrants reside. Even so, with the state's budget shortfall calculated at as much as $38 billion in the next 13 months and the county's at more than $400 million, it had to come. 
 Today, a Los Angeles County supervisor, Michael D. Antonovich, a Republican, introduced a symbolic proposal that would require illegal immigrants to obtain work permits and their employers to post bonds to pay for their health care costs. 
The proposal, which would require the county to work with federal authorities to draft such legislation, was defeated without comment in a 3-to-2 vote along party lines.
His proposal was not an attack on immigrants, Mr. Antonovich said, but an effort to address two serious problems for the county: unfettered immigration and financing the $350 million the county pays to provide health care to indigent workers, who are mostly Mexican.
"We're running an H.M.O. for illegal immigrants," Mr. Antonovich said, "and if we keep it up, we're going to bankrupt the county." 
"This is not a backlash against immigrants," he added. "This is also a way to give those people some legitimacy, to take them out of the dark, give them legal protections and tax them for the services they use."
Immigration lawyers said Mr. Antonovich's proposal was flawed, because only Congress has the ability to make immigration law. They cited Proposition 187, the statewide referendum that voters approved in 1994 barring illegal immigrants and their children from receiving public money. A federal court ruled the proposition unconstitutional because it conflicted with Congressional authority in immigration law.
These lawyers also said Mr. Antonovich's proposal would do nothing to address the situation of millions of immigrants without valid working papers who have settled and made new lives in the United States.
"The problem with proposals like Antonovich's are that they are effectively guest worker programs," said Thomas A. Saenz, vice president of litigation for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. "You're here for a short period of time and you're required to leave. At a certain point, people have earned the right to stay here with their families."
The county's health system is the largest safety net for the uninsured in the nation, and more than 2.5 million people receive treatment from it every year. It is estimated by county health officials that about 800,000 of those are illegal immigrants.
State law requires that counties provide medical care for uninsured people, but the financial obligation has proved so burdensome that the county shut 16 clinics last year. 
Earlier this month, a federal judge barred the county from closing a rehabilitation hospital and from cutting 100 beds at the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center, which would have saved an estimated $75 million in the first year alone. The judge ruled that such cutbacks would create dangerous delays in medical treatment and contribute to the spread of communicable diseases.
Things have gotten so dire, county officials are threatening to stop accepting the transfer of uninsured or indigent patients from private hospitals, a practice that lets the private hospitals avoid paying for the patients' care.
Illegal immigrants cost in other areas, officials and economists say, including education and law enforcement. The state requires that every child age 6 to 18 attend school, regardless of residency status. The number of undocumented children in the public school system is impossible to determine, though, since it is illegal for officials to collect information on immigration status.
And the Los Angeles County sheriff, Lee Baca, has had to close facilities and release nonviolent offenders from jail early to close a two-year, $170 million budget gap. A large part of that deficit, the sheriff said, comes from housing illegal immigrants who make up a quarter of the county's inmate population.
"The feds keep dreaming about controlling the borders," Sheriff Baca said. "But is it a reality or a myth? It doesn't look like a reality and the local taxpayer suffers."
Whether immigrants cost citizens money remains a point of debate. A 1997 study by the National Academy of Sciences -- regarded by economists as the most comprehensive, if flawed, review of the subject -- concluded that immigrants, over their lifetimes, provide an economic benefit to the country in terms of taxes versus expenditures.
But it also found that the fiscal impact of an immigrant with less than a high school education drains the economy of $13,000 over his lifetime, and most illegal immigrants tend to fall into this category. 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the cost of health care for illegal immigrants in Los Angeles misstated the number of people who receive treatment each year from the county's health system and the number who are illegal immigrants. The county treats about 800,000 people each year, not 2.5 million. It estimates that 200,000, not 800,000, are illegal immigrants.

HEADLINE: Lifeguard Recruits Are Tested; 'Baywatch' It Isn't 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
They travel in packs, following an endless summer sun. Primarily of South American extraction, they are professionals versed in nautical operations, emergency trauma medicine, endurance and hand-to-hand combat. They are already prepared for life-or-death situations, a responsibility that comes with the job.
 That was the profile that city officials pieced together last year when they first started looking far afield for recruits to patrol the city's beaches and swimming pools. Instead, the 37 foreign guards came from Eastern Europe, mostly Poland, Russia and Ukraine. 
 "It's the vestiges of communist sporting culture," Adrian Benepe, the city parks commissioner, said yesterday in a telephone interview. Mr. Benepe said he had a lead on a group of 15 or so lifeguards from the Netherlands. Still, he said, "we'd rather be giving these jobs to New York City kids."
That has not been easy in recent years. The city started advertising overseas last year, and in immigrant neighborhoods in Queens the year before that, but it has consistently fallen short of finding the 1,100 lifeguards it needs to patrol its 53 outdoor pools and 14 miles of beach.
So far this year, 115 new recruits, an uncounted mix of New Yorkers and others, have passed a test to qualify for the training course required to become a lifeguard, an improvement on the 100 new recruits mustered by this time last year.
"Each year," Mr. Benepe said, "we're doing slightly better locally."
The job pays $10.08 an hour in the first year. "A $10 job might seem better in this economy," Mr. Benepe said. "It beats not having a job."
That logic drew in Juliana Mercurio, 19, of Staten Island, who took the initial battery of tests at the West 59th Street Recreation Center yesterday afternoon. Though she has experience keeping an eye on swimmers upstate at Harriman State Park, she expected the city job to be more taxing. "I have to go through actual training," Ms. Mercurio said.
She took a vision test, demonstrated that she had been on earth for more than 16 years and swam three laps in 34 seconds.
Now she will train to accomplish feats like swimming a full lap underwater, swimming 440 yards, rescuing people who are pretending to be drowning, treading water and performing something called breaks.
Breaks, said Richard Sher, a lifeguard coordinator for the Parks and Recreation Department, can be defined thus: "Somebody grabs you; how do you defend yourself?"
After the initial training, she must pass another, even harder swimming test. Mr. Sher spent yesterday afternoon overseeing that harder test, given annually to the old standbys, the veteran lifeguards who grew up near the city's beaches and who come back every year. The standards are higher for the beach lifeguards, and the need for them is more urgent. Beaches open on Saturday; pools not until June 28.
In the humid indoor pool at the West 59th Street center yesterday, veteran guards lined up to do laps.
T. J. Mahoney, 19, from Rockaway Beach, Queens, was snapping his fingers violently, getting the blood flowing. Next to him, Meghan Proscio was putting on her goggles and cap. She has been a city lifeguard for the past four summers, but she had not been in the water for nine months.
They dived in, swimming hard toward spotters holding plastic signs counting their laps. They did not pace themselves. They splashed as they turned, their spotters recoiling as if the 80-degree water were lava.
Out of the pool, Mr. Mahoney said the job had been good for one New York City kid.
"Responsibility is the main thing," Mr. Mahoney said. "You kind of need it, and it teaches you a little more."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Meghan Proscio, foreground, was "rescued" by Ivan Aguilar in lifeguard testing yesterday in Manhattan. New York City uses 1,100 lifeguards. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: ASIAN ARENA; 
North Korea Is Said to Export Drugs to Get Foreign Currency

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20 

 BODY:
The North Korean government has been overseeing the production and export of thousands of pounds of heroin and methamphetamine each month to bolster the country's foreign currency reserves, a North Korean defector told a Senate subcommittee today.
 The defector, who was led into the hearing room wearing a black hood and who testified from behind a screen to shield his identity, told lawmakers that in 1997 the cash-short central government ordered all collective farms to dedicate 25 acres each to poppy cultivation. He also said that the government hired experts from Thailand to supervise the refining of those poppies into heroin. 
 "The only way to bring in large sums of foreign currency was to sell drugs to other countries," the defector told members of the subcommittee on financial management, budget and international security. 
The testimony comes at a time when the Bush administration is weighing tougher measures to isolate North Korea and press it to abandon its nuclear weapons program.
Among the ideas favored by administration hard-liners is a naval "quarantine" to seize shipments of missiles, drugs and counterfeit money bound from North Korea to foreign markets. 
American intelligence officials have believed for many years that the North Korean government has sanctioned and perhaps supervised the production and export of illegal drugs. 
But today's hearing represented the first time a defector claiming first-hand knowledge of the drug enterprise testified before Congress, Senate officials said. 
The defector's testimony could not be independently corroborated today. But Senate officials said he had been interviewed by South Korean intelligence officials who have vouched for his identity as a former high-ranking official in the North Korean government who defected to South Korea in late 1998. 
Republican lawmakers said today's testimony raised two national security concerns that went well beyond North Korea's drug smuggling. First, they say the North may be using profits from drug trafficking to finance the production of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. 
Second, the Republicans assert that North Korea could use its drug trafficking network -- which may include global crime syndicates like Chinese triads and Japanese yakuza -- to sell nuclear and other prohibited weapons to terrorists. 
"I think the proceeds of the drug ventures are in part funding their weapons programs," said Senator Peter Fitzgerald, a Republican from Illinois who was chairman of today's hearing. "Therefore, their drug trafficking needs to be stopped in order to protect our own national security."
Some Democrats, however, have argued that the United States should pursue a strategy of trying to negotiate with North Korea to get it to abandon its nuclear program before using military force to seize weapons or drug shipments, which the North has said it would consider an act of war.
"If we do not engage North Korea seriously, we will never know if such an agreement could be reached," said Senator Daniel K. Akaka, a Democrat from Hawaii. 
The State Department has also raised concerns that North Korea may start selling nuclear bomb-building material to emerging nuclear powers or terrorist groups. In February, Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage predicted that North Korea could soon have sufficient bomb-grade plutonium to sell or trade to "a nonstate actor or a rogue state." 
In April, after Australian authorities arrested the crew of a North Korean freighter on charges of smuggling $80 million in heroin, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell accused the North Korean government of being "a regime that thrives on criminality."
North Korea has denied any involvement in drug smuggling. 
During today's hearing, a State Department official asserted that because of the tight central government control over all enterprises in North Korea, there was "probable state involvement" in drug manufacturing and trafficking. 
"One wonders how any entity other than the state itself could be responsible for this high-volume drug trafficking," said the State Department official, William Bach, the director of African, Asian and European affairs in the bureau for international narcotics and law enforcement affairs. 
However, Mr. Bach said efforts by American intelligence officials to photograph North Korean poppy fields had not provided conclusive evidence about the extent of the poppy cultivation.
The subcommittee also heard testimony today from a second North Korean defector who supervised the production of mobile missile guidance systems. The defector, who also testified from behind the screen, said he witnessed the apparent sale of one of those systems to a Middle Eastern country in 1989, though he did not say which nation. 
American intelligence officials say they believe North Korea has been selling missile technology to Syria, Iran and Yemen for years. 
Nicholas Eberstadt, a Korea expert at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative policy group in Washington, told the lawmakers that North Korea's trade deficit had risen sharply in recent years. He said he considered it likely that the North was financing its imports in part through the export of drugs, counterfeit money and missile technology. 
"Drugs and counterfeiting are part and parcel of North Korean diplomacy," he said, "not an aberration."

HEADLINE: LETTER FROM AFRICA; 
Liberia Seen as Icon of World's Neglect of Africa

BYLINE:  By Somini Sengupta 

DATELINE: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, May 16 

 BODY:
At a popular restaurant here on the water's edge, the dinner menu offers a rare item: a vegetarian version of the traditional West African groundnut stew. Vegetarianism is anathema in this part of the world. But adjustments have had to be made in Sierra Leone because the world is here.
 Tens of thousands of foreigners have come to help restore peace in this tiny West African country. Pakistani peacekeepers patrol the streets. Norwegians are putting up houses for amputees (the most compelling casualties of Sierra Leone's decade-long war). The Bangladeshis have built a "friendship school." 
 War criminals are to be tried in a new courthouse, under construction now, courtesy of foreign donors. Already, 17,000 United Nations peacekeepers, the largest such force in the world, have disarmed the warlords and drug-addled child soldiers who carried on this country's decade-long war. Some people call this the United Nations of Sierra Leone. 
Today, Sierra Leone makes a strong case for international intervention. What makes it all the more remarkable -- and fragile -- is what stands next door: a portrait of neglect, an American invention called Liberia. 
The contrast is striking. The World Food Program can no longer deliver food aid to much of Liberia because its workers keep coming under attack by armed thugs. Liberian refugees have rushed by the hundreds of thousands into neighboring countries. Liberian mercenaries have ranged across West Africa, in search of new conflicts and attendant looting opportunities.
Liberian enemy factions -- the government of President Charles Taylor in one corner and rebels in another -- have made deadly alliances with rebel leaders and heads of state in next-door Guinea and Ivory Coast.
These are foul wars of revenge and greed. The misery they produce cannot be healed without ending the carnage in Liberia, analysts of the region agree.
But Liberia gets scant international attention. That negligence is a product of Liberia's peculiar history. The British took the lead in corralling international intervention for Sierra Leone, its former colony on this patch. The French have had 4,000 soldiers planted in Ivory Coast, its former colony. Liberia does not have a conventional colonial history. It was founded by freed American slaves in 1847; "the love of liberty brought us here," the Liberian coat of arms reads. 
For nearly 150 years, Liberia remained a virtual American colony, and during the cold war it ranked among Washington's most useful allies. The memory of that strategic alliance sits on the outskirts of the capital. It is called the V.O.A. refugee camp, named after the Voice of America radio transmitter that once stood there.
The United States has never recognized itself as an imperial power, let alone a colonial one. Even the title of "occupying power" is worn uncomfortably today in Iraq, where the now frayed term "liberator" has been the label of choice.
So America's former virtual colony seems to be nowhere near the top of Washington's priority list; in fact, not even on the Africa list.
"The end of the cold war produced a strategic disengagement, and Liberia is Exhibit A in terms of the consequences," said Chester A. Crocker, the Reagan administration's point man on African affairs. "There isn't a sense of strategic interest or a sense of historic responsibility that makes us take a more forceful stand."
The International Crisis Group, a research and advocacy organization, calls Liberia "the eye of the regional storm." The United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Ruud Lubbers, on a swing through the region last week, called it the "epicenter" of the human crisis in West Africa. Mr. Lubbers described Liberia's predicament as an emblem of the world's inattention to the continent. "It is an icon of the problem," Mr. Lubbers said of Liberia, "the violence, the gross negligence of the international community."
The United States has been reluctant to endorse peacekeeping missions in Africa. But it has quietly supported the Sierra Leone war crimes court, which is investigating the role of the Liberian president in the conflict and suggests that it may indict him.
The United States also gives military aid to Guinea, an ally of the rebel group now gunning for control of the Liberian capital. Rebels are said to control some 60 percent of Liberian territory. Fighting continues unabated.
The Liberian war's backdrop is international neglect. The relationship between Africa and the outside world has almost always been an unhappy one. A little more than 100 years ago, in the scramble for Africa, as it was called, the European powers sat down together to bargain and parcel out the continent's riches.
Today, a mixture of self-interest and historic ties compels the British and French to re-engage in their former colonies. Perhaps they and the other traditional power in West Africa, the United States, should follow the lead of the 19th-century imperialists and sit down to bargain again. Only this time the object should not be to divide the spoils but to bring a measure of peace to this ravaged place.
The Security Council was scheduled to send a mission to the region last week, but other matters, namely the debate over sanctions on Iraq, detained them. The mission has been postponed for next month, or the month after.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Liberians by the hundreds of thousands fled to neighboring countries from a land racked by foul wars of revenge and greed. A camp near Kenema, Sierra Leone, serves these refugees from the epicenter of West African misery and neglect. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: W.H.O. Expresses Optimism China Can Control SARS 

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Although China has reported the overwhelming majority of the world's SARS cases, the number of cases is dropping rapidly in many areas of the country, the World Health Organization said yesterday as it expressed wary optimism that China could contain the respiratory disease, although it might take as long as a year.
 Dr. Henk Bekedam said he was encouraged by the trend in China, where he is the W.H.O.'s representative in Beijing, and by that government's political commitment and mobilization of health workers to fight the new respiratory disease. 
 China has reported 5,248 of the world's 7,919 probable SARS cases. Of those, 3,273 are current cases. 
Beijing has reported the largest cumulative number of probable cases in the country, 2,444. But Beijing is now reporting fewer than 20 new cases a day, down from 100 cases earlier in the epidemic. Guangdong Province, where SARS first appeared last November, has reported the second-largest cumulative total, 1,514 probable cases. For last seven days, Guangdong has reported fewer than five new cases each day.
Four other provinces (Hebei, Inner Mongolia, Shanxi and Tianjin) have each reported more than 100 cases.
The experience of carrying out measures to detect SARS and control the infection in areas with large numbers of cases shows that "you can contain" SARS, Dr. Bekedam told reporters by telephone from Geneva where the W.H.O. is holding its annual meeting.
Dr. Bekedam said that after listening to scientists brief delegates from the W.H.O.'s 192 member countries he "did not believe that SARS should become endemic" in China.
"We are going for elimination and China will be the battleground," Dr. Bekedam said.
But Tommy G. Thompson, the United States secretary of health and human services, seemed to take the view that SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, was endemic when he told reporters in Brussels earlier in the day that he believed that SARS would probably reappear and cause deaths in the United States and Europe in the fall.
Despite the best efforts of health workers to contain the disease, Mr. Thompson said that he "did not think SARS is going to go away," according to The Associated Press.
Mr. Thompson's statement implied that he believed that SARS is becoming one more on the long list of endemic diseases that are permanent fixtures in many regions of the world, although a spokesman for Mr. Thompson said he did not use the word in talking to reporters.
Dr. Bekedam said he expected new SARS cases to appear in China for six months, maybe even a year. He also cautioned that experience had shown that if vigilance slipped, one case could lead to scores of others.
The most urgent need is improved infection control, Dr. Bekedam said. "If your hospital infection control is not in order, then instead of controlling it, you are spreading the disease," he said.
But to prevent spread, China needs donations of medical equipment like masks and other protective gear for health workers as well as mechanical ventilators, Dr. Bekedam said.
Other urgent needs include improving the infrastructure of the Chinese health system, which has been weakened over the last 10 to 20 years as the Chinese government has focused on economic development and invested less in public health.
Dr. Bekedam said that a poor system for detecting and monitoring diseases was one reason health workers had not found the contacts for more than 50 percent of recent SARS cases in Beijing. Also, health workers may not be asking enough questions to trace a new case to an older one.
Yet another possibility is that the definition of a case of SARS may be too broad and is detecting different respiratory ailments that happen to be occurring by coincidence at the same time.
Lastly, Dr. Bekedam said, epidemiologists need to investigate a possibility that the SARS virus is being spread in a different way in Beijing than elsewhere.
Ma Xiaowei, the Chinese vice minister of health, told the meeting delegates that there was a distinct age pattern to SARS cases in China. For unknown reasons, SARS has generally spared children; 2.8 percent of the country's cases were in children younger than 14. The percentages for other ages were: 29 percent for ages 20 to 29; 23 percent for 30 to 39; 18 percent for 40 to 49; 11 percent for 50 to 59; and 10 percent in those 60 and older. 
Seventy percent of the deaths occurred among people with heart disease or diabetes, he said.
Dr. Bekedam said the W.H.O. and Chinese officials were making a major effort to determine the original source of the SARS virus in nature. If SARS jumped species, health officials need to find the source so they can develop strategies to deal with such animal reservoirs to prevent similar introductions in the future, he said.
Dr. Bekedam did not speak about the spread of SARS in Taiwan, which has reported 383 cases, because Taiwan does not come under his jurisdiction. The W.H.O., a United Nations agency, rejected Taiwan's request to be an observer at the meeting because the United Nations considers Taiwan a province of China.
The Philippine secretary of health, Manuel M. Dayril, criticized the W.H.O. for confusing the public by using terms like probable case. Many people believed that if the case was probable, it was confirmed, he said.
Mr. Dayril also said that the W.H.O. had created unnecessary public anxiety and economic chaos by issuing travel advisories before the agency had consulted affected countries, an action that made his government fight both SARS and hysteria. 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the declining number of SARS cases in China referred incorrectly to Tianjin, which still had more than 100. It is a city, not a province.

HEADLINE: Shareholders Ask Hollinger to InvestigateExecutive Pay 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Shareholders frustrated by the way Hollinger International, the newspaper publisher, is managed and governed are turning to Hollinger's high-powered outside directors for help.
 Tweedy, Browne, a money management firm that owns 17.7 percent of the outstanding shares of Hollinger, asked the company's board to investigate $73.7 million in payments to Conrad M. Black, the chairman and chief executive, and other senior executives. The demand came in a letter to the board that was dated Monday and filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 Tweedy, Browne officials are trying to get the attention of the company's outside directors, who include Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, and Richard N. Perle, former chairman of the Defense Policy Board. A representative of Tweedy, Browne is expected to try to raise the issue at Hollinger's annual meeting in Manhattan tomorrow, though the compensation of the executives is not on the agenda. 
The complaints of shareholders center on the management fees and other payments that Lord Black, who is an English lord, and his management team have received from Hollinger. Tweedy, Browne said those payments had exceeded $200 million since 1995.
In its letter to the board, Tweedy, Browne concentrated on $73.7 million paid to the executives since Jan. 1, 2000, under agreements not to compete with the buyers of assets sold by Hollinger, which publishes The Chicago Sun-Times, The Daily Telegraph of London and The Jerusalem Post. Those payments should have gone to Hollinger and the executives breached their fiduciary duty and their duty of loyalty in accepting them, the letter said.
Paul B. Healy, vice president for corporate development and investor relations at Hollinger's offices in New York, did not return calls seeking comment. Bloomberg News reported yesterday that Lord Black said in a phone interview that he would discuss the fees at the annual meeting and might change the way they are paid.
But that response did not appease Tweedy, Browne. Robert E. Curry Jr., a partner in Kirby, McInerney & Squire, a New York law firm that represents the investors, said they wanted the fees returned.
"What we're asking for is disgorgement," Mr. Curry said. "We're asking the board to claw back what's already been paid to them."
Mr. Curry cited corporate law in Delaware, where Hollinger is incorporated, in his demand letter. He argued that the board had a duty to investigate what he said amounted to "misappropriation of corporate opportunity."
The investors would need help from the directors or the courts in a dispute with Hollinger's management because Lord Black has effective control of the company. More than 70 percent of the voting control of Hollinger is held, either directly or indirectly, by the Ravelston Corporation, a company owned by Lord Black and several other men.
But Hollinger International, whose shares trade on the New York Stock Exchange, is subject to the same corporate governance rules as other public American companies. A majority of its directors must be independent.
At its annual meeting, 12 people are standing for election to the board, including Lord Black and his wife, Barbara Amiel Black, who is a vice president of the company. Along with Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Perle, the independent nominees include Richard R. Burt, the former ambassador to Germany; James R. Thompson, former governor of Illinois; and Marie-Josee Kravis, an economist married to the financier Henry Kravis. A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's Holdings who was released from federal prison last week, is not up for re-election.
Hollinger has sold newspapers in Canada and the United States over the last three years. In each deal, Hollinger, Lord Black and other executives signed agreements not to compete with the newspapers sold, according to Tweedy, Browne.
In November 2000, Hollinger sold Canadian newspapers to CanWest for $2.1 billion. As part of the deal, Ravelston received $25 million in noncompetition payments and another $27 million went to Lord Black and three other executives, according to Tweedy, Browne.

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: THE CONTRACTORS; 
Feeding Frenzy Under Way, as Companies From All Over Seek a Piece of the Action

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20 

 BODY:
The pitch from Egyptian and Jordanian companies is that since their workers speak Arabic, they are best suited for jobs rebuilding Iraq.
 The Filipino companies emphasize that they have a well-educated, English-speaking labor force that has worked around the world with American construction companies. 
 And the British, though their appeals are understated, offer what some Bush administration officials argue is the most convincing case: that they shed blood in Iraq as the United States' military ally and remain the most important partner in the occupation of Iraq. 
Governments around the world -- and the companies whose causes they support -- have besieged Washington in a campaign to win a piece of the reconstruction action in Iraq, according to administration officials and lobbyists and companies vying for work. 
Like prospectors rushing to California, thousands of companies have rushed here to compete for roles in what could become the biggest reconstruction effort since the Marshall Plan rebuilt Europe after World War II.
The pleas are being lavished mainly on the Bechtel Corporation, which as the lead contractor in the United States-financed rebuilding effort will be dispensing subcontracts for everything from bridge building to port repairs to restoring water supplies.
In less than three weeks, Bechtel, based in San Francisco and the largest construction company in the country, has been flooded with more than 20,000 e-mail messages, resumes and applications from people and companies around the globe hoping for a chance to win a subcontract, according to Howard Menaker, Bechtel's Washington spokesman. The Web site explaining the subcontracting process says it has had 71,000 hits. 
"This response is huge," Mr. Menaker said. "Is this normal? Not at all. This is a project that has garnered world attention, and this is extraordinary for us."
The would-be subcontractors are not deterred by the fact that Bechtel will only begin setting up makeshift offices in Iraq this week, that security in the country is tenuous and that electricity and running water may be nonexistent.
Moreover, the available money is far short of what reconstruction officials say will be needed. Bechtel's original contract is for no more than $680 million. But independent estimates are that the final cost for an effort of the extent outlined in Bechtel's contract with the United States Agency for International Development will be $20 billion.
Bechtel's Washington office has been visited by official delegations from Bulgaria, Romania, the United Arab Emirates, Lithuania, Australia, the United Kingdom, Singapore, the Philippines, Poland, Hungary, South Korea, the Czech Republic, Thailand, Portugal, Denmark, Turkey, Spain and Germany.
Among other pitches, these countries are variously promoting their companies' low labor costs, Arabic speakers and sophisticated technology.
"An elaborate courting scene is going on all over Washington with official delegations and corporate officers walking around advertising themselves at public events," said a lobbyist representing some of the companies. "In private they're pulling out their hair because they can't get the right information, and they're afraid they'll miss out on the biggest deal in decades."
Bechtel, which expects to subcontract 75 percent of the reconstruction work, is holding meetings in Washington, London and Kuwait City to help would-be partners apply for the work. The first session is planned for Wednesday at the headquarters here of the United States Agency for International Development.
Of all the competitors, British politicians have publicly complained that their companies deserve special treatment because of Britain's involvement in the war. 
During a visit to Washington in search of subcontracts late last week, Baroness Symons, the British minister of state for trade and investment, said there were no hard feelings about the United States' dispensing the prime contracts only to American companies. The Bush administration cited security considerations and a desire to give out the contracts quickly.
Lady Symons said that she had no objection to the requirement that the British compete on an equal basis with other foreign companies for the subcontracts being given out by Bechtel and others that have won contracts from the Pentagon.
"We're not looking for specialized treatment, because we don't feel we need to ask for special treatment," she said. "We're the natural partners."
Still, Lady Symons, who is the deputy leader of the House of Lords, said she wanted to make sure the Bush administration's top officials heard the message that the British are excellent partners in peace as well as war, as good at rebuilding nations as they are at fighting terrorists. She met not just with important officials at Bechtel but also with officials close to the company at the State Department, the White House and the Pentagon. 
"We believed in the war and gave our expertise," she said. "We believe in the reconstruction and offer our expertise." 
At all the stops, she and the four leaders of British industry who accompanied her made the case that British companies had a long and close relationship with Iraq and Iraqi businesses, from the imperial days in the early 20th century until international sanctions were imposed in the 1990's.
"Our companies built many of the plants in Iraq and know how they operate," said Anthony K. Allum, chairman of the Halcrow Group, a British contractor specializing in transportation and water infrastructures. Mr. Allum is also the head of a new Iraq working group to promote British subcontractors.
At the British group's meeting with Bechtel, Mr. Allum slipped officials what he called a select list of some 18 British companies that he considered the top candidates for work in Iraq.
Among those listed were Black & Veatch, a firm of consulting engineers that worked on the Karkh water project for western Baghdad and the Basra water supply; Hyder Consulting, which worked on Iraq's port, roads, sewerage and bridges in the 1970s and 1980s, and Vector, consultants and project managers who worked on airports in Baghdad, Basra and Mosul.
Something clicked. In its first announcement of subcontracts, Bechtel gave Mr. Allum's company a subcontract to provide civil engineering support in Iraq.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Bans Canadian Beef Because of Case of Mad Cow
Mad cow disease was diagnosed in a cow in Canada, and American health authorities immediately placed a ban on imports of beef, cattle and animal feed from Canada.
 The report stunned ranchers through much of western Canada, where trading in livestock was halted because of plummeting cattle prices. Shock waves spread through the financial markets in Canada and the United States. Page A1. 

Shareholders punished McDonald's, Wendy's, Tyson and other companies with significant beef interests or operations in Canada. The United States imports about three-fourths of Canada's beef exports. A6.

Despite the news, the Dow, Nasdaq and Standard & Poor's 500 fell only fractionally. C7.

Hewlett-Packard Beats Forecasts
A year after its merger with Compaq, Hewlett-Packard posted fiscal second-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street's estimates despite continued weakness in technology spending. The company reported net income of $659 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with $252 million, or 13 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, which excluded Compaq's results. Market Place. C3.

Judge to Certify Allstate Suit
A federal judge tentatively agreed to certify an age-discrimination lawsuit filed by Allstate agents as a class action, sharply raising the stakes in the case and the pressure on Allstate to begin negotiations toward a settlement, legal experts said. C4.

McGraw-Hill Fights U.S. Subpoena
McGraw-Hill is refusing to disclose information about natural gas trades that it used to compute price indexes, federal regulators said as they asked a federal judge to order the company to comply with a subpoena. The company said the request sought too much information and violated its First Amendment rights. C4.

FedEx Delivery Trucks Go Green
FedEx plans to replace 30,000 of its delivery trucks with energy-saving, environmentally friendly hybrid vehicles. C4.

Regulators to Meet on Settlement
Securities regulators plan to meet with investment bank officials tomorrow to discuss whether proposed regulations governing the interaction between bankers and research analysts might need to be clarified. C12.

Elan Settles With King on 2 Drugs
Elan has settled its legal battle with King Pharmaceuticals over the sale of rights to two of Elan's drugs in the United States to King. World Business, Section W.

Stars of 'The Practice' to Depart
David E. Kelley Productions confirmed that Dylan McDermott, left, the lead actor of the struggling ABC drama "The Practice," as well as five other prominent cast members, including Lara Flynn Boyle and Kelli Williams, have been dropped. In a statement, David Kelley expressed regret that the cast members had to be let go, blaming what he called"economic and creative realities." C2.

Opera Loses Its Key Supporter
ChevronTexaco announced that it would withdraw its support from the Metropolitan Opera's Saturday afternoon live radio broadcasts after the 2003-4 season, ending the longest continuous commercial sponsorship in broadcast history. E1.

Plans for Mall in San Francisco
There are plans to connect the century-old Emporium store near Union Square in San Francisco with an adjacent shopping center to create a huge indoor mall that will include the largest Bloomingdale's store outside New York. Commercial Real Estate. C6.

A federal judge in Michigan suspended her ruling that would have stripped A. Alfred Taubman's family of its right to vote any of its shares to block a takeover bid for its shopping mall empire, Taubman Centers. C6.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By Joyce Wadler 

 BODY:
Yonda Lies da Castle Of My Foddah-in-Law
We don't know why it is, but we are fascinated by the DUKE OF LUGO'S fan. He was using the fan -- which is neither large nor small and is black and white -- when we saw him a few weeks ago, at a benefit at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and then again last week at the New York City Ballet spring gala. And it wasn't hot on either occasion, so you figure it out. 
 The Duke, who is very tall, is married to the INFANTA ELENA, daughter of KING JUAN CARLOS of Spain. We asked the Infanta, who was wearing a diamond necklace and matching earring, who designed her gown. She did not know and walked with us to her husband. 
 He gave us a look that suggested he likes his reporters poached.
"You are asking about her clothes," the Duke asked, disdainfully. "It comes from her closet."
Yes, we can believe that.
"You should know who it is," he said.
Well, perhaps, but we don't.
"I could tell you who is -- every single dress the woman is wearing. It is from her closet. Is that true or not?"
You know the freshen-the-drink moment we speak of from time to time? 
It is right now.
Also attending were ROB MARSHALL, the director and choreographer of the film "Chicago," and CANDACE BUSHNELL, who is married to the New York City ballet dancer CHARLES ASKEGARD. They met last year, at this very event, and married eight weeks later, which might be why they were drinking Champagne and flirting with each other like two kids at a prom. 
We also spoke with JOHN LITHGOW, the actor and children's book writer who wrote the narration for one of the evening's ballets, "Carnival of the Animals," and danced in the ballet as a lady elephant. 
Mr. Lithgow had become involved in the project through CHRISTOPHER WHEELDON, the company's resident choreographer. Mr. Lithgow and Mr. Wheeldon became friends when Mr. Lithgow starred in the Broadway show "Sweet Smell of Success." Mr. Wheeldon was the choreographer for the musical. 
"Once it was all written, he asked me to play the elephant," said Mr. Lithgow, who is more than six feet tall and solidly built. "I said yes instantly. Who would say no to that?" 
The role Mr. Lithgow dances is that of Nurse Mabel Buntz, who performs a dainty waltz at the Elephant Ball. He wears a chiffon dress with a hem of marabou feathers over a fat suit, which gives him an enormous bust and hips.
"I started taking ballet classes in February," Mr. Lithgow said. "Just put me in my dress and back me up by four dancing boys." 
Did he adapt a ballet dancer's diet? 
"No," Mr. Lithgow said. "I was supposed to be an elephant."

We're Sorry Already
Y'know our little headline higher up? The one that is a line often attributed to the Bronx-born TONY CURTIS? 
We're having second thoughts. 
The Duke of Lugo, JAIME DE MARICHALAR, comes from a titled family himself and was trained as an economist. 
So the following headline might have been better: Yonder Lies the Castle of My Father-in-Law, the King.

Yonda Lies My House in Umbria
Once we start mingling with titled people, we become so giddy we just cannot stop, so on to DAME MAGGIE SMITH. She will be starring this Sunday evening in the HBO movie "My House in Umbria," adapted from the WILLIAM TREVOR novella about a writer who experiences a terrorist attack on a train and her relationship with her fellow travelers. 
Among those attending the party for the film at the Four Seasons restaurant last week were MARISA BERENSON, whose sister, BERRY BERENSON, had been a passenger on one of the planes in the Sept. 11 attack; ARNOLD SCAASI and his partner PARKER LADD, the host of "Open Book" on the A & E network; PRINCESS BENEDETTA PIGNATELLI, a freelance writer who tells us she rarely uses her title; and Dame Smith. Or Ms. Smith. She has grande dame posture, but smiled warmly.
Any perks with the title, we asked? 
"It's just an honor," she said, "but it makes you feel old."
A gender issue: 
"When someone becomes a sir, or knight, his wife becomes a lady," Ms. Smith said. "But when you become a dame, your husband does not receive a title."
Ms. Pignatelli, a New York University graduate, writes for Italian magazines and newspapers.
Does she like New York?
"Yes, I like strange places," she said.
Which would be?
"Places like Harlem, the Bronx. It was not easy to sell a story to my editors in Italy about the Bronx. By then they agreed. Because of the J. LO mystique." 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Boldface Names column on Wednesday about a party for the film "My House in Umbria" misstated the background of Princess Benedetta Pignatelli, a freelance writer who was a guest. She did not attend New York University.

HEADLINE: Case of Mad Cow in Canada Prompts U.S. to Ban Its Beef 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS with SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 20 

 BODY:
Mad cow disease was diagnosed in a cow in Canada today, and United States health authorities immediately placed a ban on imports of beef, cattle and animal feed from Canada.
 The report shocked ranchers through much of western Canada, where trading in livestock was immediately halted because of plummeting cattle prices. The shock waves spread through the financial markets, where prices in many Canadian and American meat and restaurant companies fell sharply. 
 Canadian authorities stressed that only one cow out of Canada's total cattle population of 3.6 million was found to be sick and there was no immediate evidence that the disease had spread among livestock or humans. 
But authorities had trouble explaining the source of the disease, or reassuring the public that there was no possibility of other cases.
Officials said they were not sure whether the sick 8-year-old cow was imported and whether -- if so -- it had the disease already, or contracted it here. Should the cow have contracted the disease in Canada, from locally produced feed, today's news would be considered far more threatening.
Canada is the world's 10th largest beef producer, representing 2.5 percent of total world output. The United States accounts for 78 percent of Canada's beef exports, but last year's total -- 1.1 billion pounds of beef -- represented only 4 percent of American beef production, according to Cattle Buyers Weekly, an American industry newsletter.
The cow, from an unidentified ranch in Alberta, was to be slaughtered in January when a provincial veterinarian noticed that the animal was unusually thin. Suspecting pneumonia, he took its head for routine testing and sent its remains to a rendering plant. The rendering process yields beef protein that is sometimes used in pet food, but the destination of the material from this cow is unknown.
Veterinary personnel did not suspect mad cow disease, so the head was tested only Friday in a provincial laboratory. When the test came up positive, tissues went to a federal laboratory and samples were sent to Britain over the weekend.
"I want to stress the cow did not go into the food chain," said Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief. "I want to stress from the beginning this is one cow."
It was the first case of mad cow disease in Canada since a single cow was reported infected in 1993.
The uncertainties surrounding the cow amplified the threat to the Canadian economy, which had already stumbled in recent weeks from the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Toronto in March and April.
The interruption of Canadian beef exports, although still temporary, will almost certainly increase beef prices for American consumers and restaurants. Since Canadian cattle pass south every day -- last year more than a half a million live head of cattle came across the border from Alberta alone -- any significant spread in Canada would almost certainly threaten American herds.
The United States imported $1.1 billion of cattle from Canada last year, amounting to one third of all American cattle imports, according to the Agriculture Department. 
Mad cow disease wreaked great hardship on Britain after it was first diagnosed in 1986, spreading through 180,000 livestock and causing more than 100 human deaths around Europe. It has changed diets and culinary practices in much of Europe, and raised new questions about the health benefits of eating beef for many consumers around the world.
The affected animal came from a herd put together from different dealers in northern Alberta three years ago by a breeder who has not been identified. 
The Alberta herd has been impounded. The animals will be held in quarantine, tested and killed. The rancher recently sold 211 calves in Alberta. "We know where they are," said Dr. Francine Lord, national manager of import and export for animal health at the food inspection agency in Ottawa.
"We're very concerned about it," said Gary Little, a veterinarian with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency. Referring to the acronym of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, the technical name of the disease, he added, "Canada has had a reputation for being B.S.E.-free. We'll take whatever measures are required."
The disease first appeared in England in the mid-1980's when hundreds of cattle began staggering and losing weight before dying. Autopsies showed that their brains were riddled with holes and contained clumps of a sticky plaquelike substance.
The disorder was soon found to be related to a class of diseases known as transmissible spongiform encephalopathies caused when brain proteins deform and become highly toxic. While the disease can occur sporadically -- in humans it is called Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease -- most of the time it is transmitted when an animal eats tissues from an infected animal. Human victims, who can suffer a variant of the disease from eating tainted beef, incur memory loss, dementia and eventually paralysis.
News of the ban on imports of Canadian beef prompted sharp falls in the stock prices of companies like McDonald's, the world's largest buyer of beef, and Tyson Foods, the world's largest beef processor. McDonald's shares fell 6.7 percent to $16.95 a share, Tyson Foods Class A shares fell 4.9 percent to $9.01, and Wendy's International shares fell 6.6 percent to $28.55 a share.
A report by Merrill Lynch today suggested most of the economic impact in Canada would be psychological, noting that total annual exports of beef products are equivalent to two weeks of Canadian auto exports. "We cannot rule out a 'fear-induced' setback in the Canadian dollar," it said, "especially in light of the massive recent runup."
Ben Thorlakson, chairman of the Canada Beef Export Federation in Calgary, told the Canadian Press news service that "we will leave no stone unturned until we have returned Canada to B.S.E.-free status."
Canadian officials immediately faced questions about why it took so long to test the infected cow. Mr. Vanclief said cattle that enter the food chain are given priority in testing. "Don't try to leave the impression that this animal went into the feed chain," he told reporters.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief and his counterpart from Alberta, Shirley McClellan, confirmed yesterday that mad cow disease, which is potentially fatal to humans, had been diagnosed in a cow on a ranch in Alberta.; Cattle grazed yesterday in a pasture in Alberta. Officials stressed that the cow with mad cow disease had not entered the food chain. (Photographs by Associated Press)(pg. A6)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Indonesia: Economy Slows A Bit 

BYLINE:  By Wayne Arnold (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Indonesian economic growth slowed less than economists had expected in the first quarter, as strong agricultural output offset weaker growth in consumer spending. 
The economy expanded 3.43 percent compared with the same quarter of 2002 after growing 3.82 percent in the three months before. While the government has said its new campaign against rebels in Aceh province will have little effect on its budget, some investors believe it will further discourage foreign investment. Currency traders appeared to believe otherwise yesterday, and drove the Indonesian rupiah to its highest level against the United States dollar in 21 months on expectations that government asset sales would lure funds from overseas. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

HEADLINE: Man Charged With Stalking 

 BODY:
A 27-year-old Queens man who was arrested Monday at Shea Stadium was arraigned yesterday on charges that he has been stalking Mets General Manager Steve Phillips since January.
 The man, Matthew Barnes, "repeatedly acted with intent to harass, annoy or alarm" Phillips and "acted in a manner that caused him to be fearful and concerned for his safety," District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said in a statement. 
 Barnes "yelled, cursed and demanded to see Mr. Phillips," and refused to leave stadium property, the statement said.
 Barnes, according to the police, is unemployed and homeless and last resided on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. He was arrested outside the team's offices at the stadium.
 Barnes is facing charges of stalking, harassment, menacing and criminal trespassing.
 If convicted he could be sentenced to up to a year in jail. He is being held without bail until a psychiatric test can be administered.
 Ana Ferrin, a Legal Aid lawyer representing Barnes, said the charges were ridiculous. She said last night that Barnes was "homeless and down on his luck" and was at the stadium seeking employment as a vendor.
 Phillips has been under siege from fans and the media for his handling of a team with a large payroll that has won only 19 of 45 games this season.
 Before the Mets' home game last night, Phillips declined to answer questions about the arrest.

HEADLINE: PLUS: AUTO RACING; 
A Broken Foot Won't Stop Elliott

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
Bill Elliott will race in Sunday night's Coca-Cola 600 in Concord, N.C., with a broken left foot. It is up to his crew to figure out how to keep him comfortable through the longest race of the season. 
 Elliott broke his foot last Saturday in a six-car accident during Nascar's all-star race. He went to Indianapolis yesterday to meet with Dr. Terry Trammell. He was fitted for a carbon fiber foot protector and a brace to use when he races. Elliott, 47, broke three bones on the top of his left foot.

NO END TO FEUD: CART and the Indy Racing League have found something new to fight about. Three of five CART panelists withdrew from a two-day open-wheel racing summit yesterday after questioning the forum's objectivity. CART officials were also put off by the location, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, which is owned by Tony George's family. George was the founder of the Indy Racing League and the key player in the CART-I.R.L. split in 1996.
 The two-day discussion was focused on improving the image of open-wheel racing amid a poor economy and the rapid growth in popularity of Nascar.
